title: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes        (The Hunger Games #0)
author: Collins, Suzanne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I walk up to the podium. The audience hushes in anticipation. They must wonder: what will I say? How did I feel about this prequel to my beloved book I walk up to the podium. The audience hushes in anticipation. They must wonder: what will I say? How did I feel about this prequel to my beloved book series? I lean into the microphone, my thumb hovering in front of me. With a jerk I plunge my thumb down to the floor with a loud PPPTTTTTTHHHHHHHHWe didn't need this. Let me count the ways.Of all the characters to get a bookIn the original trilogy, Suzanne Collins introduced a menagerie of interesting characters. Characters for whom we had sympathy, characters whose histories we wondered after. President Snow was never one of those characters. Sometimes the bad guy is just the bad guy. To give him a backstory? Why? I mean, the book doesn't do a lot to garner sympathy for the monster he becomes, so I guess there's that, but even still, I entered this book thinking what is the why of this story and it wrapped with that question unanswered. A Haymitch or Mags or Joanna or Coin or Finnick book would have been lightyears more interesting. Hell, the book could have even delved into the 25th games or gone somewhere entirely new. To give us the 10th Hunger Games through the eyes of a villain that is neither entertaining nor likeable? What a waste. We didn't even get a richer view of the world or the war, so the book doesn't even serve as world building lore. It's just... ugh. I hate what this does to the timeline & charactersWhen we met President Snow in The Hunger Games, it's the 74th games and he's been President for quite some time. We don't know his age, though we do know that Caesar Flickerman has been an announcer for a long time, and never seems to look older. Sure, there's ways to keep folks looking young and keep their clocks ticking, but sending us to the 10th hunger games for this prequel? It means that, for the 74th games, President Snow is 82yrs old. Blech. Worse, it makes Tigris a whooping 85, still alive, still running a shop. What?? This book ruined what Tigris could have been. Make it the 16th hunger games, JFC. Also, the mechanisms that have/haven't been built around the games in 10yrs is nonsensical. Also also, Snow being the one to introduce betting on and assistance in the arena? I get the message that the adults are even using the Capitol children, to do their jobs for them, but it honestly felt lazy. Like the introduction of the katniss roots to the story. Like dropping the phrase "catching fire." Collins was raising her eyebrows so hard at her readers, I think she might have pulled a muscle. It's boringThis book is from the perspective of Coriolanus Snow. Like the trilogy that came before it, Ballad... is trapped within the confines of the main character's head. The narrative is influenced by his interpretations of the world moving around him. Unlike the original trilogy, this method fails with Snow as a vehicle. We hardly see the games; we're mostly sitting in a chair listening to Snow think about the games philosophically, and judging his fellow students around him. Even though we were trapped in Katniss' head, we still understood who Peeta and Haymitch and Plutarch were. We don't get any richness to the characters flitting around Snow, we just get his put-out brush-offs. I didn't care about the games, I didn't care about the Snow family, I didn't care about the other students, the Peacekeepers, Lucy Gray Baird... I cared a little bit about Sejanus Plinth. A lot of good that did me. It lacks the character building of its predecessorsKatniss Everdeen was a firey character who was curious and angry about the world. Coriolanus Snow doesn't really care what's going on around him, as long as he lands on top. It could have been interesting if Collins had leaned into her character's sociopathy, but she didn't. She seemed torn between humanizing him and allowing him to be a pure, black-hat villain. That indecision sent us spiraling even deeper into a poorly constructed main character, a poorly constructed story, and flat secondary/tertiary cast members.The songs. My god, the songsThere were so many, and the audiobook version has the narrator speaking them plainly. FUCKING SING, BRO! This was pretty awful. That last one is a petty complaint, but it leads me to my final thought on the book and hey this is the only spoiler don't look if you don't want to be spoiled I said don't look okay you've been warned: I despise that Lucy wrote The Hanging Tree. Why do we harm stories that were complete?...more

title: The Woman in Me
author: Spears, Britney
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So many celebrities get fat, juicy book deals. They promise tell-alls, they insist they have unique and interesting stories to tell. Then, check deposSo many celebrities get fat, juicy book deals. They promise tell-alls, they insist they have unique and interesting stories to tell. Then, check deposited, they sit down and write a bunch of fluffy nonsense that wastes my time and makes me angry (see Conan O'Brien's assistant's unreadable garbage and Amy Poehler writing a whole chapter about how she doesn't want to write the book so she's going to have friends write essays about nothing within her book).Britney Spears didn't do that.Britney Spears said "you paid me money because you wanted to hear the full story. Well here it is. All of it."It's brave, it's unflinching, it's heartbreaking. Yet it's simultaneously somehow patient and hopeful and kind. Britney Spears' parents turned her into a cash cow in the most awful sense of the idiom, then used and abused her and ultimately took over her life and institutionalized her so that they could take her money. As Spears recalls her father saying: "I'm Britney Spears now."And how awful were we? That is, society and the public? Judging her, following her escapades on the front of tabloids and Perez Hilton. I was only 18yrs old in 2007, but it still sucks that I was caught up in the nonsense; how Britney Spears was recast as a villain simply because she couldn't be perfect, something not one of us is capable of being.Honestly this book really only got 4 stars instead of 5 because of the god stuff at the end. I know that her faith is something that is helping her move past her trauma, but I could do without it, sorry. #atheist4lyfe.PS. Michelle Williams did a bang up job reading this book. She truly sounded like Britney Spears....more

title: Wavewalker: Breaking Free
author: Heywood, Suzanne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a perfect example of how marketing makes the book. This book didn't have a strong marketing team. I'd never heard of it. My husband stumbThis book is a perfect example of how marketing makes the book. This book didn't have a strong marketing team. I'd never heard of it. My husband stumbled on an article mentioning the book. I asked after it when he brought it home from the library, and it sounded fascinating. Wavewalker is what it appears to be: absolutely fascinating.At 7yrs old, Suzanne Heywood's parents made an announcement: the 3 of them and Suzanne's 6yr old brother would hop into a giant sailboat and follow Captain James Cook's 3rd voyage, which would take ~3.5yrs. 10yrs after they set sail from England, Suzanne escaped her abusive and neglectful family to find a life on solid ground. I really don't want to say much more. Heywood's life was lonely and cruel. She survived a life threatening injury and abandonment. She survived a childhood and adolescence of solitude and sadness. And all of this was navigating aboard a sailboat, full of her narcissistic, alcoholic parents, her ambivalent brother, and a constantly rotating menagerie of amateur adventurers, sailors, and youths looking for cheap transportation. Heywood deserved the type of marketing that Tara Westover received when she wrote Educated. She was robbed. This book is better than Educated. Everyone should read this book. ...more

title: House of Leaves
author: Danielewski, Mark Z.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I rarely find myself at a loss for words. How did I find this book? Did I enjoy it? Was it scary? Is the hype justified?I... I don't know.Here's what I rarely find myself at a loss for words. How did I find this book? Did I enjoy it? Was it scary? Is the hype justified?I... I don't know.Here's what I do know.House of Leaves is a wild concept. A found fiction work of massive proportions, which came out on the heels of "The Blair Witch Project" and years before the likes of "Paranormal Activity." The premise, roughly, goes as follows:Johnny is a grubby guy in his early 20s working at a tattoo parlor and bumbling around in the 90s world of LA clubs and drugs. He walks into the apartment of a dead guy, and is drawn to a chest full of papers. Turns out the dead guy (who was found dead in a puddle of blood with claw marks on the wood floor) had been laboring to create a comprehensive & academic analysis of a movie. This movie may or may not actually exist in Johnny's world. It has a cult following, but some folks disclaim its existence. "The Navidson Record" is a documentary (is it?) created by Will Navidson chronicling his family (him, a wife, a son, a daughter, a dog, a cat) as they embark on next chapter of their lives into a home in Virginia. Thing is, the house is bigger on the inside. And that extra space might be malevolent. House of Leaves is wildly fractured. It's partly the dead guy's academic musings, partly a collection of prior academic texts on the film and its subjects, partly a retelling of what one actually views when watching the film, partly Johnny's scribblings as he works through all this writing, and partly inserts by the person who receives the final product from Johnny. Confused yet?I like fractured narratives, but this was something else. Author Mark Danielewski has given us hundreds of footnotes. Some of them refer to fake articles that were purportedly written about this fake movie. Others are very real philosophical texts / news articles / etc. Some of the interviews and academic texts that refer to the movie in this book treat it like a documentary. Others treat it like a work of fiction. Johnny is unsure whether this movie ever existed at all. Also, Johnny is slowly losing his mind. The retelling of the film is fascinating. Will, his family, and his friends' attempt to explore the yawning hallway that has appeared in his house is fun and fraught. Johnny, on the other hand, is awful. He's a sexist piece of shit, and, quite frankly, I feel like Danielewski is also quite sexist. The way the few women in this 550+ book are portrayed is repugnant. This book has hardly any women, and those that appear are characterized as sex objects, nags, or insane. Not a good look, and a big factor in my 3-star rating. It's very, very telling that the glowing s of House of Leaves come from men, and the skeptical, eye-rolling s come from women. I especially love Emily Barton, coming to us from The Village Voice in 2000: "Danielewski’s bloated and bollixed first novel certainly attempts to pass itself off as an ambitious work; the question for each reader is if the payoff makes the effort of slogging through its endless posturing worthwhile."Ha!In an attempt to create real academic discourse in House of Leaves, Danielewski goes down wild philosophical rabbit holes. I enjoyed his discussion of The Minotaur, of the nature of echoes, of labyrinths. I also liked that, in pulling fake quotes from real people such as Stanley Kubrick and Stephen King, he believably captured their unique voices. That said, parts of this book are very bloated and feel embarrassingly earnest. Danielewski wants so badly for us to think he's clever, and it's laid bare in some very awkward passages (the biblical sections, woof). The book delves into the spatial tools usually used by poets. When characters are walking down The Hallway, the text becomes squished into the middle. When the ceiling presses down, the text only appears on the bottom of the page. Some of it was clever, but a lot of it was exhausting (why do I have to flip the book upside down and all around and read backwards? This is just stupid). There was a part of the book where Johnny is like "some of these pages were set on fire. I kept in what was left and didn't try to fill in the holes on the page made by the fire." And then, like, a single letter is missing. That's not how fire on paper works?! I know that's petty but it was exhausting to read this section with all the "[ ]" indicating burned away letters and words. For it to not even make sense made me throw up my hands. I'm going back to Emily Barton for the TL;DR: "It is frustrating that House of Leaves is such a mess, because when Navidson’s story glints through the murky waters of Danielewski’s prose, it grabs hold and won’t let go... The horrors that ensue keep the pages turning even when one’s patience for the writing wears thin."I couldn't agree more. I really enjoyed the parts of the book that were focused on Navidson’s story. I also enjoyed the dead dude's philosophies. That said, Johnny detracted from enjoyment of the book, and much of the physical elements of the book fell flat. Would I recommend this book to you? I mean, maybe. If you like open-ended, unanswered academic horror, sure, try it on. But this book always has been and always will be quite polarizing. ...more

title: Radicalized
author: Doctorow, Cory*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I found this book only accidentally. I was listening to Cory Doctorow speak on Vox's Today, Explained podcast. As he railed against the enshittificatiI found this book only accidentally. I was listening to Cory Doctorow speak on Vox's Today, Explained podcast. As he railed against the enshittification of social media, he also mentioned that he's written some books. His 2024 The Bezzle wasn't yet published, so I settled for the top result on my library's interface. A short story collection boasting "dystopia is now" on the back cover. I loved it.Honestly, the 4 stars is really just because Doctorow isn't amazing at writing dialogue. People don't really talk the way his characters talk. Nevertheless, the messages in these pages were so poignant I couldn't ding him anymore. Go and read Radicalized.Oh, you need more convincing? Well, fine, then.Here's what you'll get when you listen to me:Story #1 follows a woman who has fled to the United States as a refugee. After getting kicked around for a while she finally finds herself in a subsidized apartment where the landlord has made deals with companies. That is, they've installed specific toasters and fridges and ovens in exchange for a cut of the profits. What profits? Well, these appliances only work with "authorized" products. The toaster has its own line of bread, etc. When the toaster company goes out of business and can no longer tell the difference between authorized and unauthorized bread, our protagonist tries to break free of the change of late stage capitalism.Story #2 opens on a superhero who sees white cops beating the hell out of an innocent black man. The superhero decides to intervene. What this means for how he's viewed and treated by society, and what it means for the black man involved, is something he could never anticipate. Story #3 is a critical look at our healthcare system. Why are certain treatments for deadly illnesses not covered? And what happens if we move to even the score, eye-for-an-eye style?Story #4 is the crumbling of society, told from the point of view of an incredibly wealthy financial advisor who has been doomsday prepping for just such an occasion. Each story is brutal in its own way. Comments on climate crisis, on moral obligation, on the importance of free choice, on the commodification of people, on our distance from the natural world. And this was written in 2019, before all the madness of 2020 and beyond. It rocked me. And, if it weren't for clunky dialogue, this would get 5 stars simply because of how timely and earnest it is. ...more

author: Doctorow, Cory*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Bezzle is a lecture on a bunch of broken systems within our society that are loosely tethered together by a flimsy plot about a forensic account wThe Bezzle is a lecture on a bunch of broken systems within our society that are loosely tethered together by a flimsy plot about a forensic account who meets people interacting with / working through said broken systems. It was exhausting and boring and plodding. The characters were the barest of sketches, because they were merely vehicles for the broader social commentary author Cory Doctorow wanted to make. This should have been a NYTimes Opinion piece or something; it shouldn't have been marketed to us as narrative fiction. What's more: if you're educated about these systems, this book was a feeble echo chamber. I'm not sure anyone picking up this book needs an education on the history of psychedelics or pyramid schemes or how the rich hide their money. Also, the idea that a rich, white man in California would be thrown in prison for having some cocaine on him is ridiculous. C'mon, Doctorow, that would never happen. Two stars rather than one mainly because Doctorow is a clever person who has important things to say. He just chose the absolute wrong medium for this particular message. ...more

review: Because I am a researcher by trade, I can't help but do my research when gearing up for a new personal challenge. After years of half marathons and loBecause I am a researcher by trade, I can't help but do my research when gearing up for a new personal challenge. After years of half marathons and longer distance triathlons, I'm finally running my first 26.2. Reddit informed me this is THE book for training. Who am I to question the anonymous masses ?This is Hal Higdon's third edition of his "how to run a marathon" handbook. Updates include "women run now too!" And "you should drink and eat while running, who knew!" It's pretty funny, and also a little sexist. I got a couple of good nuggets out of the text, such as in-depth breakdowns of speed workouts I could incorporate, as well as an alternative training schedule to the one I'd pulled off Runners World. But if you've been an endurance athlete for a while, there really isn't much groundbreaking in these pages, and some of it was quite dated....more

title: Holly
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I... I might be done with new Stephen King. I enjoyed The Institute and Fairytale was decent. But this...The character of Holly is one of his strongerI... I might be done with new Stephen King. I enjoyed The Institute and Fairytale was decent. But this...The character of Holly is one of his stronger inventions. Awkward, independent Holly who worked through the timidity impressed upon her by her mother to become one hell of a private investigator.This book did her a disservice.The biggest issue with this book is there's no intrigue or mystery. King immediately tells us what's going on, who did it, and what became of what they did. The reader is forced to watch Holly trudge along and figure out what we've known the whole time. There's dramatic irony, and then there's boring storytelling. This falls into the latter. King needed to hold something back - either let the WHO dangle till the end, or save the WHAT BECAME OF IT for the climax of the plot. Without that, this book should have just been a short story. It's also a rather repetitive book. King goes on and on about COVID: getting it, wearing masks, elbow bumps. Like, I appreciate his encouraging the elderly readers to get vaccinated, but the 85th time he awkwardly dragged masking up into the narrative I groaned out loud.Lastly, the racism in this book served 0 purpose. It was just gross. The bad guys were so bad without using words I wouldn't print here. Stephen King needs to stop it already with his commentary on race. He's in no position to comment at all....more

title: Wizard and Glass        (The Dark Tower, #4)
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's book 4 in quest to The Dark Tower, and we're inching along The Path of the Beam. We'll measure the journey in inches because Roland has a story tIt's book 4 in quest to The Dark Tower, and we're inching along The Path of the Beam. We'll measure the journey in inches because Roland has a story to tell, and it's going to take a while.Wizard and Glass takes a break from Old Roland and his rag-tag group of New Yorkers, and flings us into Roland's youth. He's 14 and has been sent out with his two best friends to look into something going on in the outer reaches of his world. There's corrupt cowboys and a perverted witch and a sexy orphan and The Thinny. The best part of this book is Sheemie. Prove me wrong. King falls into the same old pitfalls: his characterizations of women/POC leaves much to be desired. That said, this was another fun installment of his epic. Pivoting to Roland's past through a story of boys going to a town where things aren't quite right was clever. It had echoes of Harvest Home and many a spaghetti western. We also finally met Susan so, that's one mystery solved. I appreciated the "previously on..." at the start of the book. King knows he was taking his time penning these books, so helps his readers out. All series writers take note. Even if you're churning books out relatively near one another it's still nice to reorient your readers before plunging them into the middle of a story....more

title: He Who Drowned the World        (The Radiant Emperor, #2)
author: Parker-Chan, Shelley*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A tragedy: The second & final book of this duology was dull, uninspired, I read the first 50 pages, skimmed another 150, flipped to the end, and slammA tragedy: The second & final book of this duology was dull, uninspired, I read the first 50 pages, skimmed another 150, flipped to the end, and slammed it shut.For me, the chief flaws of this book were:1. Too many characters too fast. In Parker-Chan's first book, She Who Became the Sun, the reader spends much of their time following Zhu Chongba. We watch their growing up and struggling to survive. We're invested in the character. Chongba's counterpart, Ouyang, isn't fleshed out until later. Parker-Chan makes the correct move here: introduce the world, get us deep in one character, then flesh out another. There were a few tertiary characters as well, most notably Wang Baoxiang, the sad son. Well, in He Who Drowned the World we're jumping from character to character with whiplash speed. We have no time to get resettled in Parker-Chan's world, or to become reacquainted with characters. Nope. Straight into the fire. It's near impossible to care about the various players in this book when we're just quickly scratching the surface of one, then jetting off across the lands to another. Parker-Chan may have been living in this world for the past year, but the rest of us haven't been. You need to sllloowww dooowwwnnn. 2. This is a battle book, which gets a big yawn from me. She Who Became the Sun had so much character building and interesting, dynamic scenes between characters. Everything I read in He Who Drowned the World was just "let's talk about strategy. FIGHT! Here's a plan to infiltrate- FIGHT." Blech, ugh, blarg. Not my taste, and a huge departure from the first installment. Yes, we all knew the second book would involve war, but there's a way to do it without a plodding "we walked, we talked, we fought" plot. This might not be fair; war books aren't my jam. But it's my  so here we are. 3. The 3 main characters feel so much flatter to me in this second book. Ouyang and Wang Baoxiang are just trembling little balls of rage. Every other paragraph reminds us how they're shaking with fury or biting back screams of anger or whatever. We get it. Can we have, oh, I don't know, DEPTH?! Speaking of, the artist formerly known as Zhu Chongba (their name is changed at the end of the first book) is on some Dune fate shit. Walking toward their terrible purpose, knowing nothing will get in their way. Flattened. Disappointing. I simply could not with these characters. So I discarded it. Life too short and all that. PS. The next book in my pile is the 4th installment of Stephen King's Dark Tower series. He spent several pages up front both recapping his epic, as well as giving us the last few pages of the prior book. Other serialists take note: that is how you do it. I was flailing for pages and pages in He Who Drowned the World trying to remember what in holy hell was going on....more

title: Abroad in Japan: Ten Years In The Land Of The Rising Sun
author: Broad, Chris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In anticipation for our trip to Japan next year, I decided to stick Abroad in Japan into my ears over the past week. This memoir tells the story of ChIn anticipation for our trip to Japan next year, I decided to stick Abroad in Japan into my ears over the past week. This memoir tells the story of Chris Broad, who, fresh out of college, joined the JET program to teach English in Japan in 2012. Despite having little knowledge of the country or its language, Broad is accepted into the program. He's lived in Japan ever since.I loved 2/3 of this book. Broad's first 3 years in Japan were vivid and entertaining. Broad retells his attempts to navigate conventions, culture, food, and public transportation. This is why I came to this book. I wanted to hear what it's like to navigate a country so different from the one in which I live. I wanted to hear about the cities I plan to visit: Osaka, Tokyo, Kyoto. I wanted detailed recountings of random bars and restaurants he'd slipped into, how he found the weather, everything. And the first two thirds of the book really did deliver that. After year 3 in the JET program, Broad decided to move on from teaching and become a full-time YouTuber. Great! That means we'll see even more of the country through his eyes! Wrong! Now we get lengthy chapters about cats and about some random pop star I've never heard of and about the time Broad went viral after an air raid alarm went off at 6am. And, look, maybe it's unfair to swipe a star off of my  because the book went full memoir at a certain point. But the book became so myopically focused on Broad's career... it got real dull. At one point he mentions this incredible cycling journey he completed, but all we hear about it are the negative comments on the YouTube videos. Seriously? He tried to pull it back talking about earthquakes, but then he complained about Kyoto having tourists and I was sort of put off by the dude by the close of the book.TL;DR - entertaining and well-written for two thirds of the book; falls off once he starts talking about cats. ...more

title: Frankenstein: The 1818 Text
author: Shelley, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Richly written without being dull or long-winded, Frankenstein is a classic for a reason. Victor Frankenstein goes away to medical school. He lost hisRichly written without being dull or long-winded, Frankenstein is a classic for a reason. Victor Frankenstein goes away to medical school. He lost his mother and is obsessed with the ideas of life and death. This obsession leads him to create life in the form of his unnamed creation. Horrified by what he achieves, Victor Frankenstein abandons his abomination. He suffers the consequences. There are so many ways to read Frankenstein; I'm not going to tackle those. I'm just going to tackle random thoughts I had about a book that really doesn't need another :- Victor Frankenstein is a bad man who is clearly incapable of thinking ahead. He's the definition of book smart not street smart. He deserved everything he got.- Poor, poor, Elizabeth.- Frankenstein Sr. should have shook off his son. Like, bruh, you have another son?! Why are you going loopy over what you've lost! Look at what you have! Speaking of, what even happens to Ernest?!- You don't become that eloquent spending a year spying on an impoverished family. - I like that the story is a dude telling some other dude's story. That removal adds some serious, unreliable narrator / game of telephone elements. Dig it. - Women really don't exist in this book. Because Frankenstein is about the hubris of Man. If Woman had been represented in this book in any significant way none of these shenanigans would have happened. - True moral of the story: think before you act.The book was great, the person behind the book is fascinating. If you avoid "scary" books, Frankenstein isn't scary. Check 'er out.kthxbye...more

title: The Waste Lands        (The Dark Tower #3)
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another King novel, another 3 star .Fun, spooky, and a little gross, The Waste Lands begins at the #1 question I had at the close of The DrawingAnother King novel, another 3 star .Fun, spooky, and a little gross, The Waste Lands begins at the #1 question I had at the close of The Drawing of the Three: what does all this mean for Jake?! I appreciate that King knew his readers were clamoring for that answer, and I enjoy Jake, even though King has never been particularly good at writing children as children. The Waste Lands is the first book where the Dark Tower story is really rolling. The Gunslinger really just introduced Roland, that slinger of guns addressed in the title, while The Drawing of the Three pulled together the rest of our main characters. Now everyone is together and moving toward The Tower. What I liked:- The whole scene with our band of walkers meeting the old timers in their dusty town- Oy & Jake- The House & The Key & Jake- The bearWhat I didn't like:- How King writes Susannah- That whole scene with Susannah and the Evil Entity. Yyeeeccchhhh- The incredibly long descriptions of gore and pestilenceAnd that's why, yet again, we have a 3 star . Some of his characters are lovely, some of his scenes are compulsively readable, but he trips on himself time and time again when writing women and people of color. I also think the agreement with Blaine came a little easy and felt a little weak, but I guess they had to get out of there somehow. All-in-all, I don't dislike my time in search of The Dark Tower, but so far I don't really get the hype....more

title: Divine Rivals        (Letters of Enchantment, #1)
author: Ross, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Naw.I picked up this book because it appeared on a "if you liked Babel read me" list.Bull-fucking-shit.I read the first 70 pages, skimmed another ~50,Naw.I picked up this book because it appeared on a "if you liked Babel read me" list.Bull-fucking-shit.I read the first 70 pages, skimmed another ~50, and noped out.Divine Rivals takes place in a fictional world where there are trams and typewriters and ancient gods who were defeated by humans (what! How even ?!) but sometimes wake up or influence the world such as making houses magical in weird/random ways and if all of this is sounding off the wall it reads that way too. There isn't enough world building for any of that to make sense. We get the barest sketches of the what and the why of the preternatural elements of the world and are promptly left to flounder on our own. Maybe there's more of an explanation down the line but honestly it should have came up front so I don't feel bad about dinging the book for that.Our main character is Iris who is 18 and dropped out of school but won a competition so now she's a writer for one of the better newspapers in her city... What ?? And the other up-and-coming journalist on staff is a 19yr old rich boy. Again : what ?????Then there's some weird You've Got Mail stuff but if Tom Hanks had known from the get-go that Meg Ryan was the penpal and also chose to deceive her for longer and in less endearing ways. Yuck. This was supposed to be a love story ? Pass....more

title: Fourth Wing        (The Empyrean, #1)
author: Yarros, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Badass, dragon-riding warriors where the main character is female + some hot&heavy romance? Sounds good to me. This book had been recommended to me byBadass, dragon-riding warriors where the main character is female + some hot&heavy romance? Sounds good to me. This book had been recommended to me by several people before it was finally my turn to pick it up from the library. I put the book I was already reading on pause to dig in... and came out feel very meh about the whole thing.Fourth Wing focuses on its main character, Violet Sorrengail, 20yrs old. She was training to be a scribe for the military until her sensitive father died and her warlord mother commanded her to put down the books and pick up some daggers.Why would a mother do this? Especially when her older daughter is already embroiled in the (nebulous, murky) war she's leading? Her eldest, a son, is 5yrs dead fighting in the same war. What's more, Violet is made of tissue paper. She has a joint disease that makes her super susceptible to injury. Dragon School (that's what I'm calling it) kills a hefty percentage of soldier-hopefuls. What sort of mother would shove their delicate daughter into this? Especially when that daughter doesn't want to go and is also already studying to be a scribe. Unclear. Author Rebecca Yarros didn't flesh that out. I wonder if it's because Yarros hails from a military family herself (father is career; husband is career), so going into the military maybe seems... natural to her? I don't know, but her refusal to flesh out Violet's mother leaves a gaping hole for me. Even Violet's sister and best friend try to convince Violet to ignore her mother and ditch Dragon School. Violet demurs, with vague statements like "she'll just haul me back here." What?? Run away! To attend Dragon School, the very first thing you have to do is walk across this slippery, narrow parapet. Violet anticipates ~16% of those who attempt it will FALL AND DIE. AND NO ONE WILL STOP THEM. Don't they have a war to win?! Why in the ever loving fuck are they killing off dragon riding soldier potentials?!The senseless violence only gets more unhinged. Students murder each other just for funsies. Then, on Dragon Prom, when the dragons come check out the humans and pick their dates, the upper years can't interfere even if students go out and murder fellow students and/or murder dragons. Again: there's a war afoot. What is even going on?!?! These rules are nonsensical. I mentioned Violet's best friend. Let's talk about him again. Violet wants to bone him, and he likely feels the same. He breaks the rules right at the beginning of the book in an effort to get her to run away from Dragon School. When she resists, he resigns himself to try and protect her. Then, Yarros decides that it's better for her protagonist to be attracted to the tortured, dark, angry character, rather than the level-headed one, so she writes in something about how the level-headed one would never, ever break the rules, even if it meant Violet died. So, she scrubs away his personality and all we have left is someone so obsessed with The Law that he'd straight up watch the woman he loves dies. This is contradictory and insanity. I have more.I don't know how she manages it, but Yarros manages regularly pen both fragmented and run-on sentences. She lops off the first word or two of a sentence, assuming we'll get it from context clues. In the very next sentence? She'll go on for a paragraph. I ask you: WHERE THE EDITORS AT?!Yarros probably wrote Violet as "lifting her chin" approximately 5000 times. People can do other things with their bodies. Again: Editors? Anyone?There's so much explanation of the way the different platoons are split up and the military hierarchy of this world. That would be fine, if Yarros took equal care to flesh out her characters. She didn't. So we have these two dimensional characters surrounded by intricately defined badges and chains-of-command. EDITORS?! BUELLER?!Lastly, and this feels petty, but there's too much cursing in this book. It's not that I'm so stuffy and uptight that I can't handle some *ahem* adult language. No, there's so much cursing in this book that it just felt lazy. Why bother with inventive language and description when you can just pepper in some "shits" and "fucks." Oh, you edgy. The hype around this is so confusing. What, exactly, did people like? Does everyone just love dragons so much they don't care about the story around them? Yarros does some good things with her narrative: we have offhanded LGBTQ+ representation (offhanded as in they're mentioned casually, which I appreciate), and we have a female protagonist who rides dragons. But... so what? Inclusion and a female main character doesn't inherently make a book good. That same female protagonist is constantly guarded and saved by those (men) around her. Even as Violet is going on about how she can take care of herself, and even as her broody love interest tells her how strong she is, her arms are falling out of their sockets and men and dragons are picking her up and whisking her away from danger. She does not read as strong to me. She reads like a weak, whiny liability. Her transformation into an agile fighter adept with daggers comes out of nowhere and makes no sense. Then again, nothing really makes sense in this book so... **shrugs**. PS sex scenes that read: "he slammed me against furniture and shoved himself inside of me with super duper force so angry" aren't sexy. Yuck. Get a grip, and get a proper lay....more

title: The Making of Another Major Motion Picture Masterpiece
author: Hanks, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not good.Meandering, tangent-y, and... kind of racist?The Making of Another... started off cute enough. Following little Robbie in his slightly overlyNot good.Meandering, tangent-y, and... kind of racist?The Making of Another... started off cute enough. Following little Robbie in his slightly overly ideal childhood. Why are we starting with him? Because his uncle takes him to get comic books, and one of those comic books is going to become a movie in 2020. We fast-forward ahead to Robbie as an adult, working for a comic book company. Then we're following his uncle as an older man. Then a director. Then that director's assistant. Then we got an entire chapter about typewriters.I listen to audibooks when I run. This puppy, despite the whiplash of character and time, still managed to put me to sleep even through speed workouts. It was all over the place and I found myself preferring silence over running to this book.The audiobook is billed as "full cast," but Tom Hanks does the bulk of the narration. This would be fine, save for the fact that he voices a Chinese woman with accent and all and it was all so incredibly cringe. The concept was interesting: start with a comic in the 1940s, see how that comic influenced the life courses of some people, follow that comic to being rediscovered by a director and turned into a movie. But the meat hanging off of the concept was blechy. NEXT....more

title: Slewfoot: A Tale of Bewitchery
author: Brom*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's too much moaning in this book. "He moaned in pain," "A moan of fear," "she let out a moan as images flooded her mind." There are so many otherThere's too much moaning in this book. "He moaned in pain," "A moan of fear," "she let out a moan as images flooded her mind." There are so many other ways to describe these scenarios. Why is everyone moaning all the time??? Also, when someone is sentenced to death by hanging, they are HANGED, not HUNG. The word is used incorrectly dozens of times in the book. A quick Google would have cleared that up. HOW DID NO ONE GOOGLE THAT??!?! IT READS SO WRONG!!Ahem.Ok, now that I've gotten that out of my system, I have to tell you something:I really, really loved this book. The year is 1666, and Abitha Williams doesn't fit in. She came to the New World to be married off, and was not raised in the Puritan ways of life. She doesn't understand the obsession with God and the Devil; doesn't understand the terrible way women are treated in this society. She lives and works on a farm outside of town, peddling charms and remedies as a trusted cunning woman/folk healer when she can. It's not very Christian, but it certainly isn't devilish either. Meanwhile, in the woods beyond her farm, something ancient begins to stir...Beyond the immersive world of well-developed characters and conflicts, I loved this book because of author Brom's ability to weave Christianity and religions of old. What is stirring in the woods has nothing to do with the Christian God or Satan. He is something Other, sure, but the Christians twist everything Other into evil. They lack the curiosity to understand the world around them. They lack the wisdom to listen when they come up against something unknown. To me, this is still true of organized religion, and it's what makes organized religion such a mar on our civilization and the Earth. Brom's exploration of the natural world before Man, and how Man ruins with his fictions and fears was perfect. Funneling that through a Puritan village when the witchcraze was still raging in Europe was genius. Yes, there are some historical inaccuracies and yes some of the characterizations were unbelievable. But, to be fair, I think I belong to a cast of maybe 2 dozen people who know enough about the witchcraze to stop and go "uuhh... that's not how that happened." Brom is forgiven for not spending 4 years researching the history of witchcraft.So, yes, this book was lovely. It just needed a better editor. Merged :There's too much moaning in this book. "He moaned in pain," "A moan of fear," "she let out a moan as images flooded her mind." There are so many other ways to describe these scenarios. Why is everyone moaning all the time??? title: The Price of Salt, or Carol
author: Highsmith, Patricia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is such a delicate book. It brought tears to my eyes.The Price of Salt takes place in the late 40s/early 1950s. Our protagonist, Therese, is a 21This is such a delicate book. It brought tears to my eyes.The Price of Salt takes place in the late 40s/early 1950s. Our protagonist, Therese, is a 21yr old woman working at a department store in NYC right before Christmas. She wants to be a set designer for plays, but hasn't yet been able to break into that world. She has a boyfriend toward whom she feels indifferent. He doesn't excite her. He's a mediocre artist who will eventually fall into his father's business. Therese doesn't know what she wants, but it's not this.Then Carol walks into the store.What happens next is masterful juxtaposition. Carol is in her early 30s, has a young daughter, is going through a divorce. She and Therese meet at her lowest point. She is terrified of what comes next. She tries to scare Therese off, but Therese is absolutely smitten. Almost begrudgingly, Carol enters into a love affair in which she has all the control, while the rest of her life spins out. And how beautiful is that? Patricia Highsmith takes two women: a young optimist who had been searching for someone or something to spark excitement and love meets a tired, angry, scared older woman on the cusp of the unknown as a divorced woman at a time when women do not get divorced and rarely work... never mind entangle themselves romantically with another woman.Therese is frustrating in her naivety and obsession. Carol is frustrating in her guarded nature and coldness. The pair are exceedingly selfish, attempting to fight through the fog toward what their futures may look like, and trying to discern if those futures involve the other. The book is framed around a jarring dichotomy: desperate overtures and the mundane. It's masterful. It's wrenching. It's literature at its finest.(Why 4 stars, then? Because, in the end, I honestly hate them both, and I don't think that was the book's intent. Oh well.)....more

title: This Is How You Lose the Time War
author: El-Mohtar, Amal*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There seem to be two camps with this book: folks who loved it, and folks who didn't get it.I'm afraid I fall into the latter half.This is How You LoseThere seem to be two camps with this book: folks who loved it, and folks who didn't get it.I'm afraid I fall into the latter half.This is How You Lose the Time War is a sci-fi romance that borrows from the likes of Romeo and Juliet and the film "The Fountain." The broad strokes of the plot seem to be: there is a person, named Red, working for The Commandant, and a person, named Blue, working for The Garden. They become curious about one another. They become obsessed with one another.The Commandant and The Garden are at war, I guess. Why and for what? We don't know. What exactly are The Commandant and The Garden? No idea. Red and Blue travel through time and parallel timelines, dipping into major world events to partake or simply watch. How do they infiltrate these pieces of history and how do they get there and why is this necessary for the war? Your guess is as good as mine. Red and Blue write "letters" to one another. But the letters are unhinged. In smoke, in venom, in the rings of trees. It's poetic, I guess. It's also ludicrous.Now, look, I don't need a book to spell everything out for me. I do, however, need a book to provide a bit of context, to provide time and place, so that I can get lost in the story. This is How You Lose the Time War doesn't do that. We're dropped in the middle of a conversation, with no idea how we got there or where we're going. It's never cleared up. I found myself floundering reading this book. Saying things like "huh?" and "wait, what?" and "how the fuck does that make any goddamn sense."I will say one thing: there are some beautiful lines in this book. There is lyricism and powerful one liners. The staccato rhythm of the narrative lends itself to quick, punch-in-the-gut turns of phrase. But the beauty of those words are rather lost when they're not attached to any fleshed out character or conflict. I wish this had been a collection of poetry rather than a novel. We didn't need the nebulous war that's waged across time and space for shrug emoji reasons. We could have just had a few feverish love poems requiring no plot or character to make them effective. ...more

title: The Witches Are Coming
author: West, Lindy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: DNF, could not take it.I sought out this book because of an excerpt I had stumbled upon online, but that excerpt misled me.The Witches Are Coming fallDNF, could not take it.I sought out this book because of an excerpt I had stumbled upon online, but that excerpt misled me.The Witches Are Coming falls into this genre of book that has become quite popular, and is not up my alley. I call it: "random person with no expertise rants about stuff they don't like." Because Lindy West is a completely random person. She calls watching Adam Sandler movies and having opinions about them "research." She calls reading a couple of blogs online a good representation of public opinion about a certain celebrity/piece of media/cultural moment. I just can't abide someone who has no business telling me what I should and should not like screaming at me from a book of mediocre craftmanship.Also, the Trump shit probably resonated when this book was published in '19, but I just don't want to fucking hear it anymore.I feel mildly bad giving this book a 1-star . For some people, this book is likely a nice little rage outlet. For me, though, it was just exhausting reading about someone getting so frothed up about South Park. You don't have to like it, but don't tell me I can't because Matt Stone and Trey Parker have identified as Republicans. I also still listen to Michael Jackson. I also still watch Buffy the Vampire Slayer. We're allowed to separate art from the artist. We're allowed to consume media that we enjoy. To have some random angry person try and make me feel bad for liking things is not worth my time. ...more

title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi        (Amina al-Sirafi, #1)
author: Chakraborty, Shannon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: About halfway through The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi, I had a sinking feeling. Ah, crap, I thought to myself. This is a series, isn't it?. It seemsAbout halfway through The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi, I had a sinking feeling. Ah, crap, I thought to myself. This is a series, isn't it?. It seems as though all books belong to larger series these days. Can't anyone write a one-off? Can't anyone resist the publisher's push to churn out more books? I honestly think that was the problem with She Who Became the Sun. It was such a wonderful story. The only way I can reconcile the total shit show of its sequel is that the author was monetarily coerced to drag it out. Whether Shannon Chakraborty always intended for Amina's adventures to span multiple novels, or whether the publishers waggled a check in front of her face, it makes no difference. The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi stands alone. The primary objectives of the book are resolved, and we're left with a nice little bow at the end, with the door cracked open for continuations. Is that a spoiler? If it is, well, you're welcome. I feel like you should know before going into this book that you can read it and then move on, if you so choose. You won't have to kick rocks waiting for #2 to come out. You can enjoy Amina on the sea, and then continue living your life.How wonderful, because The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi is a success. It's a playful pirate tale about Amina al-Sirafi, a retired pirate captain. She's in her 40s, living a quiet, remote life with her mother and daughter... until she's called back to the waters. It's a unique lens. Amina is older, she has ailments and she isn't as quick as she used to be. She's torn between the love and duty she feels toward her daughter, and the call of the ocean. She's also utterly normal. While people whisper tales about the fearsome pirate Amina, Amina describes herself more as a reformed thief and scavenger. She scoffs at the fictions weaved about her, though doesn't correct them. Better to have folks think twice before challenging her. Amina's crew includes longtime friends, each of whom have unique voices, worries, and desires. Dalia is an elderly potions wizard; Majed a genius navigator; and Tinbu a loyal and loving first mate. Their setting contains some real world details, as well as a heaping helping of magic. Their language is frothy, light, and contemporary. Honestly, I could see the language getting dull over multiple books. As a single novel? It was delightful. Fantasy can be anything. Why not a middle aged lady pirate who struggles with the warring calls to ambition and to familial responsibility? I'm relieved to see more representation in fiction, and to see authors having so much fun with the task....more

title: Drama Free: A Guide to Managing Unhealthy Family Relationships
author: Tawwab, Nedra Glover
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's a testament to my therapist that there wasn't much revolutionary for me in Drama Free. I picked it up on recommendation, and because the holidaysIt's a testament to my therapist that there wasn't much revolutionary for me in Drama Free. I picked it up on recommendation, and because the holidays are coming, you know, the most land-mine-filled time of the year for folks with difficult family. I got the most out of the "Healing" section of the book. We could all use a reminder to give ourselves the love and support we want/need but don't receive elsewhere. Tell yourself you're proud of yourself. Take the time to celebrate your accomplishments. Reflect on the loving relationships and the life you've built in spite of the environment in which you grew up. All of this was wonderful.Because this book spans all family relationships, only certain sections will apply to any given reader. There's pieces for parents, siblings, children, extended family, and in-laws.I give this book 4 stars, because it provides tools and validation for folks who do not have the luxury of effective therapy. This book is important. That said, for me it wasn't really a 4 star book. I am privileged enough that I already had a lot of these tools in my box. The anecdotes/"case studies" didn't add anything for me, personally. I skipped those. That said, I could see them being helpful for others to feel less alone. The big problem I had with this book was when Nedra Glover Tawwab tackled the concept of a person who grew up in a dysfunctional household not wanting to have children. She says things like (and I am paraphrasing) "instead of thinking about what you went through, think about the world you could build for a child." She doesn't say "but it's totally cool and understandable if you don't want to have kids. For those of us who had to parent our parents and/or our siblings, it is enough to want to spend your adulthood parenting yourself." This was a damaging oversight, in my opinion. I wish she had had the lens to recognize that some of us have to defend not wanting to have children. If our upbringing influenced that, we don't have to push past that. We can finally just focus on taking care of ourselves....more

title: The Stranger in the Woods: The Extraordinary Story of the Last True Hermit
author: Finkel, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While this book gets 4 stars for me, that rating comes with a warning: it's doubtful you'll come out of this book liking either the hermit in questionWhile this book gets 4 stars for me, that rating comes with a warning: it's doubtful you'll come out of this book liking either the hermit in question, or the journalist who made it his mission to tell his story.The Stranger in the Woods tells an almost unbelievable story: Maine native Christopher Knight walked into the Maine wilderness in 1986 and stayed there until he was caught in 2013. Journalist Michael Finkel read about it from his Montana home and decided he needed to meet Knight and write a piece on him. The book weaves Knight's story with the philosophy and study of loneliness vs. aloneness, stoicism, humanity's social urges, the healing powers of nature, and mental illness. The book is slight, owing in large part, I think, to the lack of information Finkel actually has on Knight. Knight's family declined to speak to Finkel (despite his aggressive attempts to persuade them), and Knight himself seemed torn between telling his story and turning Finkel away. He landed in an odd middle ground, sharing pieces of himself, but only enough for us to get a bare sketch of who he is and what brought him into the woods.And that's the big issue here, and why I waffled on a 3 star vs a 4 star rating. We don't actually know why Knight first went into the woods, why he stayed, and why he arguably terrorized the community he repeatedly burglarized for 27 years. Finkel doesn't explicitly say it, but hints that Knight may have been so disenfranchised with the world, and was on the brink of killing himself when he plunged into the forest. But that's an educated guess on Finkel's part; Knight never says why he did it. He simply says he got in his car, drove down to Florida, then back up to Maine, then parked his (brand new, co-signed by his brother) car, left the keys, and pushed into the woods. He found a decent spot to hunker down, and so he did. Note that he did this with no plan and with basically no gear. So next up on the list was to go and steal everything he needed from those around him. Who was around him? Mostly seasonal cabins. Oh, and a camp for adults with special needs which is run exclusively on donations. Knight stole from the camp and from the cabins consistently for 27 years. He also stole cash, though he never ventured to a store. He just broke into places and took their food and clothes and propane tanks and books alcohol and bedding over and over again. Victims told stories of children being terrified, of adults staying up all night with their gun in their lap, people being scared of going outside at night. And this is where the narrative really suffers. Finkel clearly likes Knight. Finkel is also a man. Can you imagine being a woman and knowing there's someone out in the woods who has been breaking into homes for decades. He never hurt anyone and he comes across as harmless, if a little odd, but how in the actual fuck could anyone have known that? People were leaving stuff out for him with notes begging Knight not to break into their homes. He did it anyway. He terrorized a community for almost 30 years for no reason.So, spoiler alert: I think Knight is a bad person. If you want to escape into the woods for all time, fine. But to make that decision with no gear and no planning and just steal from people? And then posture like you've cracked the code of life by doing this? You're a parasite, dude. Get a grip. Is he severely mentally ill? Finkel suggests not. He states that the legal system tried to label him with various diagnoses: Aspergers, Autism, Schizoid Disorder, but that none of them fit. Finkel is skeptical that Knight suffers from any mental illness at all, and that he might just prefer the company of the self and of nature. If that's the case, then let me diagnose him as a selfish prick. His family thought he was DEAD. His mother AGONIZED over him disappearing for the better part of THIRTY YEARS. And Finkel's story demonstrates zero remorse on Knight's part, other than he's a bit ashamed of all the stealing now that he's been caught. Bish please.Then we've got Finkel himself. Dude lives in Montana with a wife and kids, but keeps going to Maine to talk to this guy who doesn't want to talk to him. He's basically stalking a family that has begged him to leave them alone. His persistence could be chocked up to his profession, but I think that Finkel's just a dick. That might be why his book is so sympathetic toward Knight: he sees himself in the guy. I feel sorry for Finkel's wife. Also at one point he goes on a tangent about prison isolation and Knight's isolation in the woods. Apples to oranges, bro. Prison isolation usually means no light and no stimulation at all. You should have read another book before you grasped at that straw. That pissed me off. So why, then, did this book get 4 stars? Because despite how trash Knight and Finkel are, this book is absolutely fascinating. That a person could tuck into the woods for 27 years before he was found. That he was able to survive solely on things he stole and his scrappiness (because he went into the woods when he was 20. Most 20yr olds would die immediately during their first Maine winter exposure). I also appreciated the long list of further reading in the back of the book, and the descriptions of the Maine woods, a place I have been exploring since I could toddle around on two legs. The moral of this : read it, but brace yourself. ...more

title: Chasing Cassandra        (The Ravenels, #6)
author: Kleypas, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Each year my buddy Sam and I do a book exchange over the summer. This year I read this, her favorite romance novel. Romance isn't exactly my genre, soEach year my buddy Sam and I do a book exchange over the summer. This year I read this, her favorite romance novel. Romance isn't exactly my genre, so I'm not sure I'd ever give more than 3 stars to one. Here's what I can say.Sam called it before I even took the book out of the library: these personalities are not my flavor of love story. I like a hard girl and a soft boy (#peetaforever), so a strong, "my heart is frozen" kind of guy didn't exactly blow my skirts up. Cassandra herself just wants to have a quiet life with a man and a family. Which is fine, but not exactly my kind of gal.That said, the story was a fun, breezy affair of trying to convince yourself you shouldn't take what you want. I enjoyed the many literary and mythology references peppered throughout, and appreciated the modern take on women (eg. having the male protagonist, Tom, tell Cassandra her body is hers alone to do with what she will. Hell to the yes. Also the body positivity. Yes! Women have curves!).The best part of this book, though, isn't even our characters-in-love. It's Bazzle, the lil street urchin Tom takes in for reasons not made clear until the end. He's so cute and his introduction adds depth and common ground for both Cassandra and Tom. I could read a whole book about Bazzle....more

title: One Life

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Megan Rapinoe tells us out of the gate: this was a money grab and who was I to not grab money ? Given this preface, I'm not surprised about my lukewarMegan Rapinoe tells us out of the gate: this was a money grab and who was I to not grab money ? Given this preface, I'm not surprised about my lukewarm feelings toward One Life. Sections of the book are just Rapinoe giving us blow-by-blow recaps of games : "so-and-so ran the ball down the field and passed it to blah-blah who moved toward the goal and we watched the ball sink to the back of the net." Yawn. I could just rewatch a highlight reel, thanks. Rapinoe doesn't get deep about herself, though I do commend her for the section about her brother and his struggle with addiction.That's one thing I'll say : Rapinoe knew this was a money grab and went "oh, you want a book? I'll write a book," and then filled much of her pages with frank commentary on racism, sexism, and homophobia. Which, like, kudos. You were given another medium for your platform and made good use of it. That said, folks picking up this book likely already agree with her views, so who is this for, exactly ? I already agree with her views; her talking at me about them didn't change anything. Though I did take to heart when she said "when I say something 'rude,' I think about who I'm speaking for, not who I'm speaking to. " I like that. Her ghost writer should have guided her more. The book is rife with the passive voice. It also makes a lot of bizarre generalizations about cultures ? All Australians are blah, the French are all yadda yadda. That was jarring. Why are you making sweeping statements about whole populations to which you have not been deeply exposed ? It felt ignorant, which was a bummer for someone railing against the ignorance when it comes to color of skin or sexual identity.Never has a book been so solidly 3 stars : interesting and entertaining enough, with boring and bizarre passages that totally rip you out of the book.Caveat : I listened to the audiobook exclusively on runs....more

title: The Longest Race: Inside the Secret World of Abuse, Doping, and Deception on Nike's Elite Running Team
author: Goucher, Kara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kara Goucher is an incredibly brave woman and an incredibly talented athlete. I've seen some criticism that she "perpetuated" female athlete abuse witKara Goucher is an incredibly brave woman and an incredibly talented athlete. I've seen some criticism that she "perpetuated" female athlete abuse with her early silence. I have to say that I find this criticism bullshit. Imagine you're young, you've landed a dream job, you're eager to please your boss and reach your goals. Are you really going to question your superiors or speak up for others or stand up for yourself? So few people are capable of that. Ever. It only took Goucher until her 30s, and what silence she broke was way scarier for her than it would be for someone to speak up, say, in an office environment. To roll your eyes and say a 23yr old woman should have known better is asinine. The people who lob this criticism have likely never spoken up in their pathetic, navel-gaze-y lives.Ahem.If you couldn't tell from that defense, The Longest Race is not just a book about Kara Goucher's relationship with running. It's about Nike, their Oregon Project, and the monster Alberto Salazar who was protected by Nike even after he was found guilty of doping violations and of sexually assaulting women under his tutelage. In short: it's a lot.Goucher and her ghost writer Mary Pilon take all of this head on. They speak frankly about Salazar's abusive behavior. They're honest about the toxic body expectations that are placed on female athletes. They point out how women's bodies are constantly sexualized and commented on, from sports attire ads to Runners World articles to sideline banter. Being a runner and a woman can be complicated labels to wear. Many women come to running as a way to make their bodies smaller, rather than as a way to love themselves. Goucher explores all of these relationships, and how her orientation to the sport changed and evolved through each chapter of her life. I'm not sure I've ever read a better memoir/piece of running nonfiction. Like Goucher, I love running still, but you better believe I'm relieved I never owned much Nike gear. I'll never buy it again.One final note: having Mary Pilon's name on the cover and having her write the first pages of the book was a classy act. That honestly tells you everything you need to know about Goucher. I believe her. We should all believe women more. ...more

title: The Mountain in the Sea
author: Nayler, Ray*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading Ray Nayler's bio at the back of the book you find out his day job is the international advisor to the Office of National Marine Sanctuaries atReading Ray Nayler's bio at the back of the book you find out his day job is the international advisor to the Office of National Marine Sanctuaries at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This begs the question:What the fuck does Ray Nayler know that we don't?The Mountain in the Sea is so many stories wrapped into one. It's a battle cry for conservation. It's an acknowledgment that humans aren't the only intelligent, or even the most intelligent being on the planet. It's a question about what makes a soul, what makes consciousness. It's a morality debate when it comes to AI. It's a warning about how we destroy the planet to harvest as many resources as we can as quickly as we can.In short: it attempts way too much, and fails on nearly ever front. For starters, there are way too many points of view in this book. We've got Ha, the scientist who is obsessed with the intelligence of octopuses living on an island trying to make contact. We've got Rustem, a hacker who gives us a lens into tech and AI companionship in this near-future. There's Eiko, a gentleman who was forced into slavery on an AI-controlled fishing boat. And then we get a few other vignettes into the peripheries of this world. Because Nayler is spanning the globe with his scope, we never really get to know any of the characters in the book. We're staring at them from 30,000 feet, trying to piece out their motivations, fears... the humanizing qualities of them. Which is ironic, because one of the main themes of this book is that humanity does not just exist within homo sapiens. Why, then, are we denied getting close to a single character?I feel like Nayler had a really fantastic idea here. He was mulling over some big, philosophical questions about who makes humans, whether homo sapiens embody those qualities, and the responsibility we have to protect the world we've raped and pillaged since we began walking upright. But these are GIANT ideas, and can't really be tackled in a single, fictional book. Plus, Nayler isn't a writer and it shows. The first 30 pages are gruellingly bad. Poor metaphor, clunky scene setting. Just a horror. Once he pivots toward dialogue and plot it's not bad anymore, persay, but the writing isn't what I would consider "good."Also, not enough octopuses.TL;DR - excellent ideas poorly executed by someone who isn't a writer and who also probably knows something we don't namely that octopuses are going to take over the world....more

title: The Great Alone
author: Hannah, Kristin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was billed as a porthole into off-the-grid living in Alaska in the 1970s.Nope.This book is just another sad sack book about an abusive man aThis book was billed as a porthole into off-the-grid living in Alaska in the 1970s.Nope.This book is just another sad sack book about an abusive man and his wife/daughter dealing with his abuse.I hate abuse books.I hate tragedy porn.That's what this is.It gets 2 stars because the fleeting descriptions of Alaska, of frontier living, of progress vs. tradition, were interesting & sometimes quite beautiful. The acknowledgments state that Kristin Hannah spoke to actual folks who have lived in backwoods Alaska for generations. It's very cool to know that those snippets were pulled from real-life experiences. But that's all they were. Snippets. Most of the book consisted of horrible descriptions of abuse, fear, and tragedy. Ugh. No thanks. And also why? Why did we have to go so hard??I also hated the internal monologue of our protagonist, little Leni. She's constantly admonishing herself for wanting to leave her home and leave her so-called helpless mother. Girl, eff your mother. She chose this partner and she keeps choosing to stay. Children-as-parents are an absolute reality in this world, but a work of fiction that doesn't take a step back to at least provide a little narrative explanation of "no matter how untrue it was, Leni felt guilty about wanting to leave" is irresponsible. If a child living in that reality picks up this book, they aren't given an alternative viewpoint. This book is confirmation bias that children should suffer an abusive parent for the safety of parent #2. No. Children, get out. Get out now. Further proof that The Nightingale was a fluke. I'm done with Kristin Hannah. #motherinlawrecommendation...more

title: Pageboy
author: Page, Elliot
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Dark, deep, and honest, Elliot Page bravely wrote his memoir Pageboy with the conviction to leave nothing out. Not the sexual assault, not the crueltyDark, deep, and honest, Elliot Page bravely wrote his memoir Pageboy with the conviction to leave nothing out. Not the sexual assault, not the cruelty of his father, not the fear and abuse that came with being different. The narrative is not quite linear. We start in his youth, go through becoming famous, struggling with sexuality and identity, and last to acceptance of the self. But at times we dive backward or speed forward, the better to illustrate a scene or to provide context to Page's life. I read somewhere that Elliot Page wrote this book himself, and was also the one to incorporate the notes/changes suggested by editors and agents. In a world where celebrities are churning out memoirs at an alarming pace, and with most of them being ghostwritten, it was refreshing to hear Page wanted the book to be his. It helps, too, that Page actually has an important story to tell. That said, the book is a little clunky. Page seems to loathe contractions. Page sometimes seems hellbent on being poetic, and some earnest attempts to weave a beautiful sentence ring hollow, either because a word was used incorrectly or because the obvious effort takes the reader out of the narrative. Page mentions Maggie Nelson's Bluets collection multiple times, so I have to wonder if he just desperately wanted his book to have similar elegance, leaning more toward poetry than prose. Other times, Page is (deliberately?) crass. The way he describes sex is so clinical, stark, and littered with slang. That was jarring. Writing about a cabin gets the care of a Shakespearean sonnet, but all sex scenes (and consensual, fulfilling sex scenes, mind. Not just the bad/coerced sex scenes) are devoid of the flowery language found in the rest of the book. For me, this was wildly awkward.And awkward language is really the only reason this book gets 4 stars. Outside of that, this book is a triumph. Elliot Page lends his voice (literally. I listened to the audiobook read by Page himself) to the collection of writings on being trans, which is a very small collection indeed. This comes with its own unique set of expectations, sensitivities, and care, and I think Page navigated all of that masterfully while also tackling both the injustice and the privilege he has experienced. What a difficult thing to do, and yet, somehow, Page knocked it out of the park....more

title: Spare
author: Prince Harry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not really fair to rate this since I left it incomplete, but the reason I left it incomplete is because I just didn't feel the desire to listen to it.Not really fair to rate this since I left it incomplete, but the reason I left it incomplete is because I just didn't feel the desire to listen to it. Every time I went for a run I moved toward podcasts or music rather than this book. It was morbid curiosity that caused me to reserve the audibook at the library. When it arrived on my phone, I put it in at 1.5x speed, hoping that would help me get through it. The book arrived in my ears right around the time The New Yorker ran its piece by the ghostwriter J. R. Moehringer, which was perfect timing.I'm sure Moehringer tried his best, but this book was a fluffy, surface piece on a man who grew up royal, and wasn't given the tools to grapple with what that meant. I'm not downplaying the bullshit Prince Harry had to endure secondary to the public privilege he was born into, but the book was so myopic in scope. There was no contextualization to his life and entitlements. Prince Harry, for all his grandstanding and fleeing to the United States, seems incapable of balancing his trauma and his inherent advantages as he reflects on his life. This was predominantly why I chose to listen to other things during the time I had this book at my disposal. When time came up on this book and I was only 50% finished, I shrugged it off and let the library have it back. I sincerely doubt I was going to learn much more anyway. ...more
