title: Yellowface
author: Kuang, R.F.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My lukewarm feelings are not R.F. Kuang's fault. This isn't my kind of book. I picked it up because I loved Babel so much, but there were no allusionsMy lukewarm feelings are not R.F. Kuang's fault. This isn't my kind of book. I picked it up because I loved Babel so much, but there were no allusions that this book was anything like Babel. I just felt like I wanted to read everything by Kuang... even genres I dislike.And I disliked this book. I dislike unlikable narrators. I dislike books where everyone sucks. I dislike books that are so satirical that they gaze up their own orifices to oblivion. If I had read interviews with Kuang before I had picked this book up I might have been warned. She talked about Girl on a Train. You know, one of the worst books ever written. And that's fine. Kuang didn't write this book for me. She wrote it for herself. I read as much when I went down a context rabbit hole to try and situate myself with my interpretations of the text vs R.F. Kuangs intentions. Yellowface starts with our main character, June Hayward, feeling sorry for herself. She and her frenemy Athena Liu are both writers who met while in college at Yale. Difference is, Athena skyrocketed into the upper echelons of the publishing world shortly after graduation. June has been languishing in the shadows. June starts as a sympathetic character who harbors what seems to be legitimate anger with the publishing world (though she does displace that anger on Athena). As the book goes on, June becomes cartoonishly racist and vile, and I honestly can't tell if that's just us getting more introduced to the character, of it that was Kuang's/her editor's decision to make her less and less sympathetic. It just became a toxic wasteland of resentment and jealously and racism and finger pointing and fictional Twitter threads and it wasn't for me. It was muddled, it weirdly veered into a psychosomatic thriller for a bit, and... I don't know, man. I honestly feel unequipped to talk about this book anymore. Instead, here are some of the rabbit holes I went down:NPR interview from MayFavorite quote from this interview:"I think fiction should be about imagining outside our own perspectives, stepping into other people's shoes and empathizing with the other. So I really don't love arguments that reduce people to their identities or set strict permissions of what you can and can't write about. And I'm playing with that argument by doing the exact thing that June is accused of - writing about an experience that isn't hers."Bustle article from MayFavorite soundbytes:"“June’s voice came too easily,” Kuang says. “All those horrible feelings of worthlessness and depression and jealousy that June feels, I’ve felt them all.”"--"I spent the first few years of my career having a really hard time dealing with jealousy of other writers who I thought were having better careers than I did, and I tried to articulate this in Yellowface. It’s not the kind of envy that’s represented in Hollywood… it’s more like terror at the idea that somebody else succeeding means that things are over for you."The Bookseller article from FebruaryI don't have any pull quotes for this one, but I appreciated the conversation about the publishing world....more

title: Lessons in Chemistry
author: Garmus, Bonnie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Suspend your disbelief for this fluffy-yet-feminist chick lit sensation.Elizabeth Zott is living in the late 1950s / early 1960s, but that's not goingSuspend your disbelief for this fluffy-yet-feminist chick lit sensation.Elizabeth Zott is living in the late 1950s / early 1960s, but that's not going to stop her from being a scientist. No formal education? No problem! She's naturally brilliant and naturally beautiful. This seems to be a thing with chick lit books these days: women who are gorgeous but unaware of it, and are the smartest person in the world despite being raised by seagulls (see Where The Crawdads Sing). I hate this new trend. Who cares how beautiful/uggo our protagonist is? And no, I'm sorry, if you were raised by carnies, you aren't the smartest person in the world. That's just wildly improbable.These gripes aside, this book really is a fun read. Mostly because our main character just can't wrap her mind around the misogynistic bullshit around her. It's wonderful to see very real sexism and then have a female main character slice through it with simple a simple "why" or "that isn't rational" or a No. 2 pencil (see book for more on that). The book makes a neat little circle of its plot, with entwined characters and the growth of everyone around Elizabeth Zott. Zott could've used some growth too, but she doesn't seem to get there. That's okay, though. I was here for the bubbles, not a Bildingsroman. Zott's dog and daughter are outrageously fictional, but they were lovely complements to her larger-than-reality personality. Lessons in Chemistry is a perfect plane/beach read. You can leave in the middle of a sentence and drop right back in. I don't know how it'd stand up if read in the dead of winter by the fire; I do think I read it under ideal circumstances. And, look, it's not breaking any glass ceilings, but it was fun, and it was a relief to see sexism in a book that was addressed head-on, instead of a shrugged "that's the way things were." This is FICTION. We can do ANYTHING. And Bonnie Garmus did. ...more

author: Sims, Stacy T.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was skeptical of this book, but after it was mentioned in an athletic/exercise subreddit for the 80th time, I caved.What lured me in: the promise ofI was skeptical of this book, but after it was mentioned in an athletic/exercise subreddit for the 80th time, I caved.What lured me in: the promise of a discussion about adapting around the natural hormonal waves my body experiences month-to-month. That was a big part of what the Reddit chatter had been about. There is one chapter on this (pgs 16-34). I don't know that I want to take Zinc, Magnesium, Omega 3 Fatty Acids, and Aspirin every day for the 7 days leading up to my period. That's a lot of supplements to counteract a bit of a performance slump. But I'm not a professional athlete so **shrug**. All this to say: this chapter didn't do much for me save for validating the dip I see in my physical capabilities each month. This book was written in 2016; a lot of what was written felt commonsense to me. Things like: don't avoid carbs (never have, never will), get enough sleep (I have walked out of gatherings announcing I HAVE TO SLEEP. You don't have to tell me twice), don't fast (duh! but also thank you for saying it out loud), and drink water, or water with extra stuff in it when you're sweating a lot (yes, though I do have to get better about fueling during a long workout). The big issue is that a lot of the nutrition advice is suspect. When someone tells me I should be regularly fueling with things like brown rice syrup, quinoa flour, and sprouted whole grain toast, my eyebrows go wwaaayy up. Also, when someone tells me to choose egg whites over eggs, or low/no fat dairy over full fat dairy? No. This is diet advice, not endurance athlete fueling advice. My hackles stood on end reading this shit. The sample meal plans in here felt deprive-y and smacked of Disordered Eating Lite.PS. was this book sponsored by Kashi? It was pushed several times. That stuff is nasty IMO. So, where does all of this leave us? I gave the book 2-stars mostly because it feels more harmful than helpful. My own disordered eating was triggered; I had to sit down with a journal and write out why I'm allowed to eat pasta and cookies. There were some good nuggets: the hormone stuff, the recommended strength training exercises. That said, in trying to flesh out an entire book, Stacy Sims veered into diet culture. This is a diet book with a strong woman on the cover....more

title: The Rise of the Ultra Runners: A Journey to the Edge of Human Endurance
author: Finn, Adharanand
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Adharanand Finn was approached to write a piece on ultra running. "No way," he said. "Participate in an ultra run for an article? I'm a marathon runneAdharanand Finn was approached to write a piece on ultra running. "No way," he said. "Participate in an ultra run for an article? I'm a marathon runner, bish. That sounds dumb."But then he couldn't stop thinking about it. He called the magazine back, strapped on some shoes, and fell in love with the ultra running world. So he hatched a book plan: immerse himself in ultra running, all while striving to gain entry into the coveted UTMB race. A race so prized, you have to compete in several other sanctioned races to accrue enough points to even qualify to enter. If this sounds weirdly gate-keepy and money-grabby, I mean, it is. And Finn talks about it. Finn spends 2 years training and racing and meeting all sorts of people in the ultra running world. He doesn't shy away from speaking on the dangers of the sport: injury, heart scarring (?!?!), exposure, etc., while also describing the special nature of running in the woods and over mountains and along cliffs, pushing your body and mind to its limits. I do feel this book is billed incorrectly. More than anything, this book is a memoir. It's Finn's personal journey into the world of ultra running, with some special guests. Also there was one thing I really, really didn't like about this book. Finn has a section where he's talking about the starting line of ultra runs: everyone is white. Meanwhile you look at road marathons and there are way more POC/African competitors. Why is that, he asks? Having already written a book about Kenyan runners, Finn went to Africa to try and recruit some folks to run a 50mi race. Thing is, a big driver for competing in road marathons is the prize money. Ultra running doesn't really have that. The sponsorship gigs aren't as robust, and the prize money is basically nonexistant. Finn convinces a runner to come out and run a 50mi race in England. If he wins, Finn says, he'll get entry into a race in CA. That race will have a $10K prize for the winner.Sheesh.So the runner agrees and shows up in England. The race is a 10mi loop done 5 times. The first loop, the runner is in the middle of the pack. The second loop, he's in third place. As he comes around at mile 30, he's in 1st. He stops at the tent, sits down, and says he's going to stop. Finn pushes. The runner replies: "my toe hurts. I'm stopping." Finn keeps pushing, but, and good for the runner, he stands firm. A few pages later Finn is like "Ultra running is pain so I didn't get it. But I guess he didn't want to risk injury because his body is his livelihood."NO SHIT, FINN! This whole bit just felt gross. Finn wanted this story in his book: grab a marathon runner from Africa and plop him in an ultra race and see what he does. The marathon runner dropping out didn't fit into his narrative, and so he got bossy and obnoxious. But, like, dude. Fucking seriously? This guy and his entire family rely on his body and its ability to perform in road races. There is literally 0 reason for him to push himself to injury for this worthless trail run. Check your privilege. Get fucked. Also the irony considering Finn's own, initial reaction to participating in the sport. Like, what?!?! JFC!Whew. Ok. Got riled up there.So that vignette left a really bad taste in my mouth and left a stain on the entire book for me. Was it a fun, personal insight into ultra running? Yes. But the author can be completely tone deaf, and that was a huge bummer. ...more

title: Madhouse at the End of the Earth
author: Sancton, Julian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Explorers in the age when there were actual lands to discover were unhinged. Pile onto a boat captained by a man obsessed with glory who doesn't have Explorers in the age when there were actual lands to discover were unhinged. Pile onto a boat captained by a man obsessed with glory who doesn't have the resume or the follow through to inspire trust that you'll be safe or, you know, come out alive? Sign me up! At least, that's what young men were saying over and over again as they climbed onto boats and sailed into oblivion. The Belgica's journey to Antarctica sounded questionable before it had even crossed the equator. Nevertheless, Adrien de Gerlache found a gaggle of adventurers willing to risk their lives and sanity for the glimmer of a chance to be the first to reach the south pole.I don't want to spoil much about what the crew endures. I will say that there is a vibrant cast of characters, some of whom seem larger-than-life but who were very much real, who will shock, anger, and surprise you. Also: poor penguins. Also also: never underestimate the power of the sun.I also need to say: I love that author Julian Sancton has an author's note at the close of the book where he goes "So a New Yorker article briefly mentioned this ship. It sounded insane. No book was written on it, so I wrote it myself." Badass. Brava. Like many nonfiction books, Madhouse... borders on tedious ever-so-slightly. But the madness and mayhem surrounding this journey carries the narrative forward even when we're simply cataloging supplies....more

title: Good for a Girl: A Woman Running in a Man's World
author: Fleshman, Lauren
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Lauren Fleshman is a decorated professional runner. She began running as a teen, and her ability, grit, and dedication led her to Stanford, and then uLauren Fleshman is a decorated professional runner. She began running as a teen, and her ability, grit, and dedication led her to Stanford, and then under Nike's payroll. However, because she's a woman she was often undervalued, ignored, and expected to professionally present like a man (that is: not get pregnant, not have curves/soft bits to her body, not bring up menstruation despite the fact that a woman's period affects performance). This book is her examination of all that time, what it meant to be a female athlete then, and what it could mean in the future.I ate this book up. Anyone who enjoys running, or struggles with body image, or struggles with disordered eating, or struggles with expectation, will see themselves in Fleshman's narrative.We don't talk about the unique pressures that are put on female athletes. Our bodies hold more fat because of our biological ability to carry children. To demand we shed all fat is asinine. There is an expectation that women need to accept that they must be thin and that they will be sexualized and objectified regardless if they're walking along the beach or if they're a professional athlete. I never put too much thought into the fact that female running kits are glorified bathing suits themselves. Why? And why did Fleshman have to fight so hard to run in what felt best to her: loose shorts. Because leering men. Folks should be focused on female performance, not female bodies. We still have a long way to go.My one gripe is the section toward the end of the book that just felt like a list of accomplishments / low key advertisements for her endeavors outside of racing: the nut bars she made and marketed, the blog she created that took off, her partnership with Oiselle. I think it was her way of being like "ah, I want to end this book but I have all this other stuff to say. Shit. Ah, well, here's a quick rundown!" But it felt rushed and had a different tone than the rest of the book. A tone that, if taken out of context, sounded a bit like "look at me I'm amazing I'm so smart and successful wheeee." I'd hate to say it was off-putting, but, like, it wasn't not, you know? I honestly don't think she meant it, but I wish her editor had tweaked that section. My petty grumblings aside, I really loved this memoir. Fleshman bares her soul to us: how disordered eating alters how you view yourself and food, how we can get so focused on an outcome or goal that we lose our "why." These are incredibly difficult things to discuss with a therapist, nevermind in a book that's going out into the world for everyone to read. But she did. She should be so proud. Her father would be, too. ...more

title: Yearbook
author: Rogen, Seth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of the best audiobooks I've encountered. Before we go further I have a confession to make: I'm not an audiobook person. I find most of them droninOne of the best audiobooks I've encountered. Before we go further I have a confession to make: I'm not an audiobook person. I find most of them droning and dull. I need a really animated voice to keep me "in" it, as it were. Well, Seth Rogen delivered in Yearbook. Not only did he do a fantastic job reading himself, but he employed several other people to lend their voices to various characters in his book, and also included many sound effects: music, rain, background chatter, etc. This is what I want from an audiobook.Outside of the listening-as-an-experience piece of the puzzle, the content itself was funny, earnest, and entertaining. There are so many celebrity memoirs out there that are just asinine. The anecdotes are squeaky clean and are more "look at me ain't I the cutest/coolest/most-down-to-earth-est ever?" Seth Rogen doesn't appear to be trying to paint himself in a certain light. The book is basically a series of vignettes about the most hilarious and/or outrageous things that have happened in his life. I laughed out loud on multiple occasions which was a feat: I listened to this whole thing on my runs. This isn't going to blow your mind, but if you want something mild that will make you giggle, I really can't recommend this book enough. Unless you hate drug use. Then, seriously, pass this book by. ...more

title: Bag of Bones
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you've read Stephen King before you're not going to be surprised by my issues with this book: King is a lil bit sexist and a lil bit racist. The olIf you've read Stephen King before you're not going to be surprised by my issues with this book: King is a lil bit sexist and a lil bit racist. The older white male gaze is particularly strong in this book. It grates.Despite that, I still liked Bag of Bones. In fact, I'd say this is one of the scariest King books I've read. The book opens with Mike Noonan, age 36, becoming a widow. From there, he spends 4 years in a sort of suspended animation, just surviving, unsure what even to do with this life. I get this. I'm 34. If I lost my partner suddenly, my entire world would be shattered. Mike is only pulled back to reality because his lakehouse is calling to him. Because it needs him to play his part in a larger, longer, more terrifying story. Hauntings, murder, how broken our law systems are, rich people who think they are the law... this book has a lot. And that haunting... whhhooooooo boy that haunting. I also appreciated the Easter eggs from other King books. Insomnia, I'm looking at you. The book doesn't fall on its face like a lot of King books, but there is a very uncomfortable scene that leans deeply into the aforementioned sexism and racism that almost dipped this book into 2-star territory. I ultimately decided the sum was worth more than that part, but, if you choose to try this book, read with care....more

title: The Covenant of Water
author: Verghese, Abraham*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's weird that I'd describe a ~715 page book as "tight," but that's what I had to say when I turned the final page of The Covenant of Water. Abraham It's weird that I'd describe a ~715 page book as "tight," but that's what I had to say when I turned the final page of The Covenant of Water. Abraham Verghese's book is long, yes, but it covers 77 years and richly fleshes out a dozen characters as its reader follows a family through generational trauma and perseverance. I feel rather lacking trying to describe this book, but I'll try. We begin with a child bride, agonizing about leaving her mother and being essentially sold off to a much older man. She must learn to be wife to him and mother to his small child, while being a child herself. From there, we track her family as the tree branches out across time and territory, the central focus of the book shifting as each generation comes of age. There's a lot of history in this book, and a lot of medicine. Some of the medicine bits were kinda sorta super gross, but Verghese is a doctor by training, so I guess he isn't shy when it comes to chatting about flaying tendons or whatever the fuck. That said, The Covenant of Water still achieves beauty. It is about survival, about finding oneself in the darkness, about faith in oneself when all other faith has run out. It's about the complicated web of family and tradition and expectation, and, above all, it's about love. Despite the sheer number of characters we meet, Verghese keeps a steady hand as he walks us between settings and points of view. I never felt lost, even when we left Parambil for so many pages to meet a man who, at least at first, felt apart from the central narrative. And that's where the beauty of this book really sings: the cohesion. Every piece of this book is thoughtfully planned, so that in the end we step back to see the mosaic that was forming before us all along. If the book weren't as long as it is, and if I weren't itching to dive into a new world, I might have been tempted to flip to the beginning and start the book anew, with all its secrets revealed. Is this  meandering and unhelpful? I'm not sorry. To explain too much about the book is to give it away. Suffice to say The Covenant of Water tells 3 separate coming-of-age stories about a tiny family in Parambil, complete with their intricacies, secrets, and "the Condition" which plagues them. If you like dramatic fiction, just go out and read it. There is pain in this book, yes, but the pain, like the rest of the book, is thoughtful. No tragedy porn here, for which I am deeply relieved. ...more

title: Women Without Kids: The Revolutionary Rise of an Unsung Sisterhood
author: Warrington, Ruby
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, I have to be honest: I'm not finished with this book. I'm just over halfway. But I am so devastatingly disappointed that I'm putting it down forOkay, I have to be honest: I'm not finished with this book. I'm just over halfway. But I am so devastatingly disappointed that I'm putting it down for a while. I can't read it at night, it gets under my skin too much. When I have the mental fortitude, I might try to finish it... we'll see. I went out and bought this book from my local bookstore after hearing author Ruby Warrington on Jameela Jamil's fantastic podcast "I Weigh." Warrington and Jamil's conversation was electric for a woman like me: mid-30s and in a marriage where we decided not to have children. In the podcast, they discussed the family you choose vs. the family you are born into, the state of the climate and the world, how individualistic priorities can be. I am so sick of people asking me "why" when I say I don't have kids. It doesn't make any sense to me why folks think they have the right to ask me to defend my life choices. I hear it almost as much as I hear "but do you get enough protein" when folks find out I'm a pesca-mostly-vege-tarian. So I ran to the bookstore to read a book where I would see myself reflected. Despite how deeply seen I felt listening to the aforementioned podcast, I felt abandoned reading this book. Warrington makes grand, sweeping claims that are backed up by nothing. Most women who don't have children bonded more with their fathers?! What?! No, bish. Women who don't have children are introverts? Ha! As if. Women who don't have children are...Stop trying to define us! There is no "look" to women without children. I thought that was the point???It felt like she was trying to answer that "why" that women without children are often met with. Which is so besides the point in my opinion. We don't owe anyone the "why." Let's talk about the "how" and celebrate different families. That's another thing, she treats the word "family" as one that pertains to units with children. No. I have a family. It's me and my husband. Full stop.A large part of this book is basically a memoir. False advertising. I'm really tired and really frustrated. I just wanted a book that celebrated all the things a woman without kids is, rather than focus on what she isn't. Warrington says she interviewed many people, but I haven't heard from hardly any of them more than halfway through the book. I guess we have to start somewhere with this conversation, but I don't want anyone in my life to read this book. It honestly feels like it would give those people a free pass to pathologize me, which is exactly what I'm trying to avoid. This book could have been a triumph. It was a let down. ...more

review: Wow.I had been told that this book took a critical look at the true crime murder genre that is so popular these days. I was hoping for something scathWow.I had been told that this book took a critical look at the true crime murder genre that is so popular these days. I was hoping for something scathing and introspective.Well, guess what? This book is NONE OF THAT. It's just a run-of-a-mill who-dunnit that plays a little bit with the idea of memory, that is, how expecting people to remember details from 20+ years ago is a bit much. This book also makes a bunch of flippant, eye-rolly comments about how woke culture has gone too far and we need to take a step back which could have been a hot take if it has been executed competently.This book is not competent. It's a hot mess. It's yet another asinine book about a drunk, fumbly, bored and sad woman inserting herself into a murder when she has no reason to be involved. I fucking hate these types of books. I had been promised this was a satire of them, not one of the same ranks. Ugh. I read the first almost 200 pages trying to decide if it was a poorly written satire or if I had been pranked. Then I skimmed the rest of the book looking for any hint of cleverness or intrigue. I found none. I am bereft, adrift, annoyed, depressed. Oh well. Thanks for nothing....more

title: Babel
author: Kuang, R.F.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow.How long did it take R.F. Kuang to write this book? I'm not only impressed by how tight the story is, but also the amount of research that went inWow.How long did it take R.F. Kuang to write this book? I'm not only impressed by how tight the story is, but also the amount of research that went into penning all 542 pages. 5 stars. Read this book.Oh, you want more? Oh. Shit. Okay. Hmm...Babel tells the story of Robin Swift (that's not his true name. It's a name he was forced to give himself to fit into the British world). Robin is a young boy spirited away from his motherland of Canton, China to be trained up to attend Babel. What is Babel? A language & translation school housed within Oxford. His education and lifestyle is paid for; he's guaranteed a life of comfort so long as he sticks to Babel's script. Turns out that's not so easy.The world Kuang builds in Babel is uncanny valley territory. It's fashioned after the real world as it was in the 1830s, but massive changes have been made. The most glaring is the Babel school itself. Sitting in the middle of Oxford, Babel is a giant tower, bigger on the inside than it appears on the outside, that houses all of the translation students and the wealth of silver they horde like dragons. You see, Kuang's world is magical. The world runs on silver bars that, when inscribed with "match pairs" of words in different languages, can do anything from power the lights of London to make you invisible like you're Harry Potter darting around Hogwarts. It's a clever device, not just because it allows us to feel closer with the main characters (they are, after all, living in a parallel of our world), but because magic is a smart teaspoon of sugar to make the medicine go down. The medicine, in this case, is the following message: fuck the rich. Fuck imperialism. Fuck racism. Fuck your capitalistic society. Burn it all down. So much rage in such a beautiful package. It's genius. Speaking of genius, Kuang has that in spades in the etymology department. I loved every single time she stepped back and explained the history and meaning behind certain words. You'd think it would get exhausting. It never does. I thought about knocking a star off because there are two "planning" sections of this book that drag. In order to move the timeline along and get us from one plot point to the next, Kuang spends several pages giving us internal monologues and breakdowns of daily tasks/chores. It wasn't necessary and was a bit repetitive. Those sections could have been cut in my opinion. That said, I finished the book and immediately wanted to read it again, so, I'm wrong. Sometimes you need some dull exposition to get to the good stuff. I accept this. Brava....more

title: A Swim in a Pond in the Rain: In Which Four Russians Give a Master Class on Writing, Reading, and Life
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4 stars for the Russians ; 2 stars for George Saunders.I went into this book thinking it was going to be an English-class-in-a-jar sort of situation. 4 stars for the Russians ; 2 stars for George Saunders.I went into this book thinking it was going to be an English-class-in-a-jar sort of situation. That I'd get a couple of short stories I would not have otherwise read, and then get a fabulous deep dive into those stories and the authors and environments behind them.What I got were fantastic stories written by Russian behemoths that were book-ended by the inane ramblings of a person ill-equipped to discuss these stories. Saunders' interpretation of "analysis" seems to equate to "I'm going to re-hash the story we just read, talk about myself for a while, and then maybe give you the tiniest morsel of information about the author and the world surrounding the story when it was written." Saunders' sections were a letdown, but Chekov, Turgenev, and Tolstoy delivered (I wasn't keen on Gogol's The Nose, and, judging by Saunders' lack of real discussion of the story, other than saying "why?" a lot, he isn't either). If you haven't yet read The Singers or Master and Man you're missing out. Also ending on Alyosha the Pot was a great idea; the story brought tears to my eyes. I'm crediting Saunders' editor with that choice.Am I coming down too hard on Saunders? I honestly don't think so. I'm not sure Saunders deserves much at the end of the day. These passages made me groan out loud: Any story that suffers from what seems like a moral failing (that seems sexist, racist, homophobic, transphobic, pedantic, appropriative, derivative or another writer's work, and so on) will be seen, with sufficient analytical snooping, to be suffering from a technical failing, and if that failing is address, it will (always) become a better story. AndIf you're a pro-immigration person, are there anti-immigration feelings down there inside you? Of course: that's why you get so emotional when arguing for immigrants' rights. You're arguing against that latent part of yourself. When you get mad at a political opponent, it's because he's reminding you of a part of yourself with which you're uncomfortable.Some stories just suck, and there is no homophobic person inside of me. I do not hate myself, thanks. TL;DR - read the stuff on Saunders' syllabus, but don't bother with the man himself. I should have known; I didn't like Lincoln in the Bardo...more

review: This book is exactly what it claims to be: a story about Scott Jurek and his wife Jenny Jurek finding their next steps in life while Scott races alongThis book is exactly what it claims to be: a story about Scott Jurek and his wife Jenny Jurek finding their next steps in life while Scott races along the AT. So... 3 stars because I wasn't misled.But that doesn't mean I particularly enjoyed this book.My main issue is that Scott Jurek seems to be an incredibly selfish partner. The first indication of this is that the cover of the book say "by Scott Jurek" with a tiny "with Jenny Jurek" beneath it. Well, Jenny opens the book up and closes every single chapter. Why the fuck aren't they sharing equal billing? Because, when it came to this journey, Jenny certainly shouldered more than she should have. Fresh off another miscarriage, her husband drags her into the woods to oftentimes just be alone, cold, and dirty, in a shitty black van that's serving as his dumping/sleeping grounds during an ill-planned attempt to re-discover the glory of his youth. They were both hurting, they were both listless, and so Scott ran into the woods with the excuse of wanting to break a record on a trail he hardly knew at all. In doing so, he abandoned his wife. He expected Jenny to just be there for him. Forget her pain. Forget her needs. She literally misses medical follow ups for her D&C surgery for Scott. Like, what? What the actual fuck? Who is this guy? He also casually mentions so many promises he made her that he ultimate broke. Examples include making her miss a dear friend's wedding and making her spend her birthday taking care of him and his stupid "goals."I actually had to Google pretty early on to see if they're still together (they are) because I was just so angry with how Jenny is treated. And that's how she and Scott were willing to have their relationship portrayed in a book. How much worse is it when it's not presented to the public??I agree with Scott's detractors during his record attempt: people should take their time with the AT. Racing it takes the heart out of it. You can see it in the book: it sounds like he hardly even registered some of the most spectacular parts of the trail (such as the Whites in NH) because he was so physically and mentally fucked up from moving at such a grueling pace. They talk about how he smelled like vinegar because his body was breaking down amino acids/muscle and was actively cannibalizing itself. Like, bro, what? Why? Why are you doing this? What is this goal really about? Or are you just running away from your life?The more I write, the more I want to knock a star off, but I'm not going to. I could see this book resonating for some people, and, again, this book was what it claimed to be. I just felt that Scott Jurek came off like, as his name suggests, a real jerk. ...more

title: Ninth House        (Alex Stern, #1)
author: Bardugo, Leigh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A quick, fun read, Ninth House takes our world, and adds a little black magic. Alex Stern has found herself matriculating at Yale University. She doesA quick, fun read, Ninth House takes our world, and adds a little black magic. Alex Stern has found herself matriculating at Yale University. She doesn't belong, and she knows it. But a free, Ivy League education is hard to pass up, even if you were only given the spot because you can see dead people. What?? Well, Alex was recruited by Lethe, a secret society that serves as a sort of watchdog for the other secret societies on campus. The purpose of a watchdog house, however, isn't to police wild keg parties. Naw, Lethe attends all of the dark magic rituals that secret societies dabble in.This is brilliant. If magic was real, of course the ultrawealthy would have harnessed and horded it to protect and multiply their wealth, power, and chokehold on society. In the very first chapter, Alex watches as undergrads read the intestines of a Poor to provide NASDAQ projections. Tea leaves, but make it guts. The flippant attitude of the wealthy toward the middle/lower classes was so biting, it's clear author Leigh Bardugo has some opinions about the folks who attended Yale with her. Get it, girl. Trust fund babies don't care about killing houseless people so they can do things like teleportation. I don't want to say much more, lest I give the twists and turns away. Suffice to say this is an original story of ghosts, magic, and murder, told through the lens of a wrong-side-of-the-tracks young woman as she navigates youths with popped collars and yacht access. ...more

title: Chain-Gang All-Stars
author: Adjei-Brenyah, Nana Kwame*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm honestly unsure how to sum up such a masterful work of fiction. Is it even really fiction? Or is it a premonition? Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah has buI'm honestly unsure how to sum up such a masterful work of fiction. Is it even really fiction? Or is it a premonition? Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah has built a believable dystopian future. In it, incarcerated individuals are given a choice: rot in prison, where new torture devices are liberally used, or sign up for CAPE, a new reality television series where prisoners are forced to fight to the death, gladiator style. "Choice" is a generous word here, for reasons best left to the book to unpack.While Chain-Gang All-Stars primarily follows two incarcerated women participating in the games, Thurwar and Hurricane Staxxx, Adjei-Brenyah gives us several other perspectives. The book is a veritable viewpoint kaleidoscope, the better to paint his world. We see through the eyes of several other incarcerated people as they decide to join CAPE and perish in its stadiums, board meetings by investors/owners of the Games, protestors, and spectators. Adjei-Brenyah also uses footnotes to give both context to his characters and provide several real-life examples of the law's violent abuse of people. In doing this, he breaks that fiction wall, reminding us that this book isn't mere entertainment, it's telling a story that we may very well be building toward in our real world. Chain-Gang All-Stars overflows with humanity and heart. It grapples with fear, feelings of self-worth, suicidal ideation, regret, and love. Somehow, though, this book is primarily a piece of cultural criticism. Readers are encouraged to think critically about how we as a society value human life; how racism, classism, and sexism are oppression; how our cultural obsession with reality TV and disregard for incarcerated people could allow for this exact reality in the not-too-distant future. It was a brave and incredibly difficult book to write. It turned out a triumph. ...more

title: The Year of Lear: Shakespeare in 1606
author: Shapiro, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: James Shapiro is an English professor at Columbia and is NYC's Shakespeare Scholar in Residence at the Public Theater. He is a true expert in all thinJames Shapiro is an English professor at Columbia and is NYC's Shakespeare Scholar in Residence at the Public Theater. He is a true expert in all things William Shakespeare.I was drawn to this book for a couple of reasons: 1. Shakespeare, obviously. I received my Masters in English, sure, but we didn't talk much about Shakespeare the person in class. Who was he? How did he come up with these plays? What was going on around him?2. The year 1606. I've spent a lot of time researching and reading about the 1400s - 1600s, but the early 1600s in particular are fascinating. I'm perversely drawn to King James for all his women hating narcissistic bullshit. To have him framed around Shakespeare's plays, the plague, and other goings on in the year 1606 was too good to pass up.And that's just what this book tackles. Of course, Shapiro has to expand his lens to provide a holistic picture of time, place, and person, but we really are following the year 1606: how The Gunpowder Plot affected politics, what the religious climate looked like, what plague was doing to the people, what theater looked like, how the monarchy was changing under this new Scottish king, and how the plays Shakespeare wrote during that time captured the moment. Shapiro argues that Shakespeare likely penned 3 plays during 1606: King Lear, Macbeth, and Antony and Cleopatra (I say "argues" because there is some difference in expert opinion regarding when the latter two were conceived). What I loved most about Shapiro's discussion of these plays is the acknowledgment that Shakespeare was rebooting shit. I. Fucking. Knew it. YOU HERE THAT, PEOPLE WHO ATTENDED GRAD SCHOOL WITH ME?! I FUCKING TOLD YOU. Ahem. Bragging rights aside, this is invaluable insight into Shakespeare's process. Did you know there was a play called King Leir from which Shakespeare pulled heavily? Or that a book about the relationship of Antony and Cleopatra had recently come out and that full lines were lifted from that book and incorporated into Shakespeare's play on the same topic?? Next time I get all bent out of shape that they're making yet another Halloween movie, I'll have to remember that.I thoroughly recommend this book, with the caveat that the subject matter might not be fascinating for everyone. For me, though, The Year of Lear was an informative, thorough, and engaging look at a year that still has relevance in our 2023 lives....more

title: The Dark Queens: The Bloody Rivalry That Forged the Medieval World
author: Puhak, Shelley*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Dark Queens suffers from a lacking historical record. The people and events within its pages existed/occurred in the 500s (yes. The 500s), so muchThe Dark Queens suffers from a lacking historical record. The people and events within its pages existed/occurred in the 500s (yes. The 500s), so much of what we know is cobbled from poetry, lore, and letters, not just contemporaneously, but also from relics hundreds of years later, as chroniclers and fanboys furnished their own re-tellings. Shelley Puhak researched as much as she could to flesh out the lives of Brunhild and Fredegund, two Queens who fought to retain their rule while the men around them were cut down with frightening speed and regularity. However, Puhak was reluctant to take much license in her writing, leaving us, her readers, with a text that is rather dry and plodding. A "this happened, then this happened, then this guy died, then this bishop was sneaky," sort of birds-eye view. Personally, I'd have preferred more liberal extrapolations for better narrative flow and a more compelling story, but I respect Puhak's dedication to accuracy. It just didn't make this a page turner.Gripes about sterile recounting aside, credit where credit is due. Puhak saw a gaping hole in the historical record and strove to fill it with an accessible book. And Puhak can write. The prologue and epilogue are fantastic commentaries on the sexism of academics, on the lack of insight into what it must be to be a woman in power, protecting your babies and trying to hold onto your rule, and on the lack of care we as a culture have paid to women in history. It's clear Puhak could have really given oomph to the flesh and blood of Brunhild and Fredegund if she had wanted, but she resolved to stay true to the facts. And we're skint on facts....more

title: Powers and Thrones: A New History of the Middle Ages
author: Jones, Dan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I took my time with this book. 578 pages isn't that long of a book, not when stacked against the likes of Dickens or Dumas, but this book is dense witI took my time with this book. 578 pages isn't that long of a book, not when stacked against the likes of Dickens or Dumas, but this book is dense with information. If you read too fast, you might miss some fantastic nuggets, such as the fact that this guy Duke Philip signed all his letters "farewell, turds."The task Dan Jones set for himself was hefty: write a succinct overview of the entirety of the Middle Ages. He chose to tackle the assignment by breaking the book up into parts centered around themes.Part I introduces populations at the beginning of the Middle Ages, which he defines as "Romans," "Barbarians," "Byzantines," and "Arabs." It's a very high level view of who was alive at that time, and what their societies looked like. Jones is setting the stage.Part II introduced classes of people: Franks (which discusses king, emperors, popes, and vikings), Monks (focusing on religious professionals), Knights (aka those who fought for hire, and those who evolved into noblemen), and Crusaders (the fighters and the holy men who waged a global war in the purported name of their God). Part III gives us another cohort of people: Mongols, Merchants, Scholars, and Builders... they're pretty self-explanatory, I think.We wrap with Part IV, which is organized by major events: Survivors (plague, revolution, the Little Ice Age), Renewers (significant men in The Arts), Navigators (all those explorers of the time: Marco Polo, Christopher Columbus, Magellan), and Protestants (that little Christian revolution).The war bits / throne successions got a little dull for me (this guy ruled then got sick and died so then it was this guy but he was swiftly dispatched so his baby became king...). Dull though I may have found those bits, they were pivotal to moving the story long. As society shifted and evolved, the people in power were the primary hands shaping that world. This book is one of many on the Middle Ages, but it excels at giving its audience an engaging, broad strokes narrative of the year 400 AD - 1527. Jones' writing is at its strongest when he focuses on a singular person and takes poetic license to get into their head and their environment. He can really bring history to life, which is a feat for any history book. His bibliography serves as a "see more" section. If there were stories/events/people you wanted to delve into more deeply, Jones has you covered.At the top of the book, Jones wrote: "I am going to ask - and I hope to answer - some big questions: What happened in the Middle Ages? Who ruled? What did power look like? What were the big forces that shaped people's lives? And how (if at all) did the Middle Ages shape the world we know today? There will be times when that may feel a bit overwhelming.But I promise you, it is going to be fun."He kept his promise....more

title: Children of Ash and Elm: A History of the Vikings
author: Price, Neil
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow ! What a yawn fest !Yet another book that was marketed as being for the layman, but was a dull, dry, academic text. I know there's a lot of questiWow ! What a yawn fest !Yet another book that was marketed as being for the layman, but was a dull, dry, academic text. I know there's a lot of question marks when it comes to the Vikings. Much of their history has eroded with the sands of time. But Neil Price could have done more here. At points it's like he's listing off items on a grocery list: "the Vikings had blades shaped like rectangles and triangles. They had bows. They had sheaths. They had..." can't we have a bit of narration, buddy? Perhaps a character or two to hang our hat on? He'll edge into something interesting, say, this wild burial site of a female warrior, but then he'll just shrug and be like "well, that's a thing. MOVING ON." What??? Despite his inability to make assumptions for the sake of a compelling narrative, he still manages to jump to insane possible conclusions that bewilder and offend his readers. Price is all "we know so little of the Vikings, you never know, women could have been very powerful and equals in their society." Then goes on to say "we do know that women were enslaved and raped and forced to stay at home." Ok, bro, which is it? Why are you trying to make Vikings a woke culture? No one expects that! I knuckled down and really read the first 300 pages, but I got so bored I had to skim the latter 200. If you're a Viking obsessive you might overlook the sterile, long-winded writing which lists items found in burial sites and settlements for pages on end. I could not. ...more

title: Demon Copperhead
author: Kingsolver, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I mean, yeah, Demon Copperhead gets 4 stars. It's written so vividly I felt as though I could reach out and touch the characters: Damon, June, Emmy, MI mean, yeah, Demon Copperhead gets 4 stars. It's written so vividly I felt as though I could reach out and touch the characters: Damon, June, Emmy, Maggot... they were all so uniquely them. Their personalities and their environment were so richly crafted by Barbara Kingsolver I was completely engrossed. People would talk to me and I legitimately wouldn't hear them. I was in Lee County, watching these people live their lives.Why the 4 star rating, then? Because of the tragedy porn, guys. When things got too dark in this book, I had to gloss over sentences, paragraphs. I don't need a book putting me on mood stabilizers. One must protect the self. Moving away from point systems, let's talk about the book itself. Demon Copperhead is a modern re-telling of Dickens' David Copperfield. I was relieved to see the inside jacket blurb declare David Copperfield isn't a prerequisite for reading the book. I really enjoy Dickens, but David Copperfield is one of the only stories of his I haven't read. I knew, Dickens inspired that it is, Demon Copperhead would be dark. But I wasn't prepared for how dark.Things that really get the sadness roaring in my ears is neglected children and neglected old people. Demon Copperhead has neglected children galore. Poor Tommy made me cry. Little Damon searching for love and getting kicked in the teeth again and again? Heart wrenching. Because that's what this story is about: the impoverished and forgotten children of America. How we treat and mistreat them, what they need and what they get. It's all too real. The fact that Kingsolver takes the story of a sad little boy and weaves into it classism, racism, corporate-sponsored poverty, and the opioid epidemic? Astonishing. The moral: TAX THE FUCKING RICH SO WE CAN HAVE SOCIAL SERVICES THAT ACTUALLY SERVE THE PEOPLE GODDAMNIT WHERE'S MY GUILLOTINE....more

title: The History of the Medieval World: From the Conversion of Constantine to the First Crusade
author: Bauer, Susan Wise
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have to give this book 4 stars. There is no choice. Susan Wise Bauer tackles Europe, Asia, North Africa, and even a bit of the Americas as she spansI have to give this book 4 stars. There is no choice. Susan Wise Bauer tackles Europe, Asia, North Africa, and even a bit of the Americas as she spans the years 312 - 1129. Yep, you read that right. Wise Butler tackled almost a millennia in her 666 paged book (and yes, I did chuckle at that number, especially since Christianity has a starring role within these pages).Unfortunately, because she is spanning such an insane time frame, and because record keeping wasn't exactly a priority when folks were getting pillaged and burned down all the time, there isn't much depth to these pages. I kind of felt like an alien, circling Earth, watching as the decades melt by, with kingdoms rising and falling in a blink of an eye. Not many of the names in this text stick, because they're only on the scene for a few pages, if that. I did appreciate Wise Butler's lens into the women who tried to seize power, but would have loved her to have actually cracked that open and looked deeply. I loved the vignette about Leif Erikson, but that's all we could really call it, because it only lasted ~4 pages. Yes, I'll admit, I skimmed at times, especially sections that were particularly "King Man ruled but then got murdered, his murderer took the throne but then his wife's lover pushed him off it. Loverboy ruled but was poisoned..." and on and on. It did get a bit tedious to read. That said, it's an incredible feat to have written this book and at the slim page count relative to the time frame it tackles. I'm not quite sure what I wanted from this book now that I'm out of it. I think I had hoped for an in-depth view of the social and political landscape of civilization, but I can't say that the source material exists for a book like that to even get published. So, yes, this book gets 4 stars, but it can get dry as hell. You've been warned....more

title: Fairy Tale
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Of all the Stephen King books I've read, most end up with a 3 star rating. Why? Why do I continue to read him when it seems I find his books just okayOf all the Stephen King books I've read, most end up with a 3 star rating. Why? Why do I continue to read him when it seems I find his books just okay?This is where the starring system sort of breaks down. The reason Stephen King gets 3 stars is not because his books are just okay. King is great at writing dialogue. He excels at writing stressful, fast-paced scenes. He masterfully weaves tension into complicated and interesting conflicts. The reason Stephen King gets 3 stars is because these excellent storylines with interesting characters always have a giant flaw that I can't get around. A flaw that threatens to unravel the entire story if you look at it too closely. Fairy Tale is no different. This story is different than many of Kings other books. It's a dark fantasy more than anything else. An adventure story dappled with all old fairy tales that many of us will find familiar. Our main character, Charlie, is a 17yr old who is in over his head. His youthful naivety and optimism is just what this book needs. Who else could be a hero? The beginning is great. A boy who grew up in a difficult household, a household that made him special, finds himself helping the crotchety old man down the road. This old man reveals a secret that forever changes Charlie's trajectory.And then Charlie makes a choice.A choice that makes no sense.And the rest of the narrative I was stuck thinking "I'm enjoying this... but what brought Charlie here makes no sense. Who would make this choice?" And King seems to know that his readers will struggle with this choice. The book is written in the first person, with Charlie writing all of this down for us. Thanks to this, Charlie breaks the fourth wall with the reader a few times. "I know what you're thinking," he says, addressing the camera like he's Zack Morris, "but remember I'm just a 17yr old kid, and this made sense to me." DID IT, THOUGH ?! DID IT REALLY ?!Sigh.I'm not going to spoil anything. Suffice to say Fairy Tale is yet another book that is a really interesting story but makes no sense. Like the buildings in the kingdom of Empis, it looks fine on the surface, but look away and its gets all melty and distorted. Ah well....more

title: Backlash: The Undeclared War Against American Women
author: Faludi, Susan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you want to learn a lot and also be infuriated then this is the book for you.Lovingly researched and earnestly written, Backlash tells the story ofIf you want to learn a lot and also be infuriated then this is the book for you.Lovingly researched and earnestly written, Backlash tells the story of how the 1980s set women's rights back; a backlash (get it?) to the 1960s and 70s. Faludi breaks down movies, politics, abortion rights, employment rights... the gamut. Did she talk about Fatal Attraction too much? Yes. Did some of the statistics get a little long-winded? Yes. But this book, as a whole, stands as a tremendous feminist tome for the second half of the 20th century. You'll laugh, you'll groan, you'll feel your face heat up in rage. I recommend reading it in spurts, so that you can really digest the content without getting emotionally exhausted. A book like this should be required reading. That said, I wish she would have updated the ending when they published the 2020 edition. It ends on a hopeful note which was incredibly depressing what with our rights being ACTIVELY TAKEN AWAY AND ALL.Sigh.Thank you, Susan Faludi, and believe me when I say we're still just as mad (pun intended).----I'm waiting on 3! That's right: 3! whole books from the library, slated to all come in next week. So this will be a piecemeal book. Sorry Faludi, but it's probably for the best that I take this in sips. Also Goodreads... doesn't have the 2020 paperback listed as an option? But I've got a 2020 paperback in my hands. Weird. I am READING this not listening to it, but I want the credit for the updated content, so here we are, with me using the audiobook entry on the site. C'est la vie....more

title: In Defense of Witches: The Legacy of the Witch Hunts and Why Women Are Still on Trial
author: Chollet, Mona
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The name of this book is a bit misleading. This book is maybe 15% about witches. The rest is modern feminist theory.The beginning of In Defense of WitThe name of this book is a bit misleading. This book is maybe 15% about witches. The rest is modern feminist theory.The beginning of In Defense of Witches speaks about the medieval witch and reasons why she was persecuted (for her work in midwifery; for being old/ugly; for having agency when Woman should have none). It was great, but it lasted for a few pages. The rest of this book spoke to the expectations that Woman:1. Get married (to a man, of course)2. Have children3. Stay young and beautiful by any means necessary4. Quit lying about having pain and illnessIt was an interesting read; I'm always here for some feminist theory, but it was not what I thought I was getting into when I read the synopsis. Indeed, I actually just re-read the synopsis and feel as though I read a different book than what is pitched here. The three types of women referenced in the synopsis are: unmarried, without children, and old/ugly. But this book speaks more to how women grapple with these expectations in the 20th/21st centuries, rather than discussing how these categories were treated during the witch-craze in the 1400s - 1600s. Again, that's totally fine! But the witch thing felt like a click-baity way to get folks who wouldn't have otherwise picked up the book to check it out. Like many theory books, it got a bit repetitive. And some of it actually felt a bit dated. Mona Chollet lives in France, so perhaps the expectations for women are different between our cultures, but certains passages felt like Chollet was hearkening back to the 80s and 90s, rather than focusing in on present-day issues. PS. Any publishers wanting a book that actually tackles the 1400 - 1700 witch, like, hit me up. For real tho. ...more

title: The Very Secret Society of Irregular Witches
author: Mandanna, Sangu*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was the book I needed during COVID. It's the coziest book I have ever read. Is there conflict? I mean, some, but this book is mostly about being This was the book I needed during COVID. It's the coziest book I have ever read. Is there conflict? I mean, some, but this book is mostly about being comfortable with yourself and finding your people and your home. This is what a wholesome, hug-of-a-book looks like. Everyone yammering about Under the Whispering Door is an idiot.The Very Secret Society... tells of the story of Mika Moon. She is a witch and she is an orphan. In fact, all witches are orphans due to a protection spell run amok generations ago. In a further effort to protect themselves, witches do not spend much time together. To be alone is to be safe. When Mika, lonely-but-managing, receives a curious message inviting her to teach 3 young witches, she can't help but be enticed. 3 witches? Together? And how did the sender of this message know she's a witch?? A heartwarming romp ensues. I won't say much more. This book is part coming-of-age (okay, so Mike is 31yrs old in the book. But she was never given the opportunity to explore herself before now, so let's roll with it), part romance, and part hot-cup-of-tea-by-the-fire-with-a-blanket. You'll read most of it with a small smile on your lips... and isn't that refreshing?Not everything is tied up at the end of the book, but that's OK. That's life. As author Sangu Mandanna gently reminds us again and again: we do not have to be extraordinary or change the world in order to make an impact on the tiny universe surrounding us. And what a new and wonderful perspective that is. ...more

title: Under the Whispering Door
author: Klune, T.J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What to say about a book that tries so hard to be earnest, yet fell so short for me? How to sum up how this book simultaneously annoyed me but also geWhat to say about a book that tries so hard to be earnest, yet fell so short for me? How to sum up how this book simultaneously annoyed me but also gently reminded me to slow down and enjoy the time I have?Here goes nothing.Under the Whispering Door tells the story of Wallace Price. Wallace Price is a high-powered lawyer who is cruel, selfish, and completely oblivious to the concept of humanity. He's despicable. Then he dies. But his journey has only just begun.I liked the things TJ Klune had to say about death and grief and what it all means. Reading this book affords you moments of introspection: what really matters to you in your life? Are you tending to those things? Do you approach the world with kindness? Do you stop and feel, with each of your senses, the world and the wonder around you? That alone would have made this book a 4-star-er for me, if Klune hadn't made the choice to explore this idea 26 different times in under 400 pages with similar conversations that petered out in the exact same way. Reading the acknowledgments made me understand: Klune wrote this book as a sort of catharsis to grief he was processing at the time. So these conversations are like him talking to himself about life and death. It was repetitive within him, so it became repetitive in the book. It didn't serve the book.The characters of Norman and Mei were fun and interesting and lovable, but Norman is an old man and Mei is a young woman who grew up with completely different experiences. Yet Norman, Mei, the aforementioned Wallace, and the not-yet-mentioned Hugo all speak exactly the same. The same colloquialisms. The same quips and one liners. These people would never ever have the same voice in real life. I think they're all speaking like Klune, which was distracting and an odd choice. Now we're going to circle to the thing that I really had a problem with, which is Wallace Price himself. Like I said, he's despicable in the beginning. After death, however, we are expected to consider him a likeable protagonist. Bitch, please. After, like, 3 days of death, he's cracking jokes and cuddling dogs and forging bonds with the people around him. His ex-wife basically spit on his grave at his funeral. He ruined the life of a coworker over a tiny mistake. This vile person would not all of a sudden be fun and helpful and loving in mere DAYS after a DECADE+ of being a piece of shit. It just doesn't track. I was supposed to root for him, but I couldn't. All I could do was stare at the book in confusion. If Klune wanted this journey for Wallace, he should have made Wallace cold and distant because of past hurts. You know, shelling himself off so he isn't hurt more by the world. Making him a sociopath and then undoing it in UNDER A WEEK was lunacy and I'm angry about it.Okay. We can move on.So, where does this leave us? Under the Whispering Door was a lovely idea: give the world a story about death that is hopeful and reverent of life. That said, it fell very short in its characterizations, most glaringly how horrible the lead was, and, if you ask me, still is at the close of the novel....more

title: Harvest Home: A Novel
author: Tryon, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How to describe a very well-written, very good book that was ruined by one graphic, unnecessary scene?I'm going to try. Harvest Home is one of those bHow to describe a very well-written, very good book that was ruined by one graphic, unnecessary scene?I'm going to try. Harvest Home is one of those books that should have already been adapted into a film (ok, I know, there was a made-for-TV movie in 1978, but I mean, like, a real film). The elements are classic: outsiders come to an insular community; weirdness ensues.The book is first-person narration. Our story teller is Ned, a city man who got sick of the grind and so he and his family (his wife Beth, and his teenage daughter Kate) decide to move to the country to get away from it all. Minor plot hole about how they had enough money for Ned to straight up quit his job and then just... paint all day? We'll forgive it.The village of Cornwall Coombe is stuck in the past (the "present," in this case, is 1973). The townspeople follow ancient traditions and their lives, it seems, revolve around corn growing and harvesting. Everyone here grows corn, and the survival of the town hinges upon the crop. Ned and Beth are super into it. "Look how simple and wonderful this is!" they say. When they find out the town also listens to little Missy, a 14yr old "touched" girl who does things like plunge her hands into the entrails of a chicken to read the future, Ned sees it as a red flag. Beth is like "oh, that's just country folk!" ...c'mon Beth.Sufficiently freaked out by Missy, Ned decides to dig into the history of Cornwall Coombe, and uncovers more mysteries than he solves. It's here that the book really starts to pick up. I say that because Harvest Home is a slow-burn book. This can be tiresome in other books, but author Thomas Tryon is such an adept writer you don't mind the smolder here. The town is described in full technicolor, complete with all the main players and their histories and eccentricities. I have never read a horror/thriller book where the author actually bothers to build in rich scenery. I was harassing anyone who would listen about this book. It's creepy AND it's beautifully written? Slam dunk!Because Ned is our first-person narrator, we're never quite sure what's real and what's not. Are there supernatural elements to this town? Or perhaps there are logical explanations to what Ned is experiencing? Or perhaps he's going crazy? You don't know, and you waffle between the choices, eager to see how it's going to turn out.But then.Usually I'd put a spoiler tag on at this juncture, but the next part is so egregious I feel compelled to spell it all out as a warning. If you want to decide for yourself, skip this next paragraph.But then Ned decides to do something that makes absolutely no sense and absolutely ruined the book for me. He suspects a woman of doing something, and so he attacks her. It seems like he's going to murder her, which falls in line with the "madness" choice. To be clear: I accepted that the narrator might commit murder. But then he stops. He decides he doesn't want to just murder her. So he... has sex with her. And, because it's written in the first person, we know that Ned isn't just having sex with her, he is trying to fuck her to death. I'm not kidding. That's what he thinks. It's graphic and horrible and upsetting and... just... why? It didn't move the plot along. If Tryon wanted to make sure Ned was no longer a sympathetic character, there were better mechanisms than this. You see I said "sex" and not "rape." This is because the scene suggests the woman is consenting, despite how violent and disgusting the scene is (remember how descriptive I said this book is? Yeah, well, so is this scene). Later, though, the woman does accuse Ned of rape and the town... doesn't arrest him/do anything/react that much? I know it's the 1970s but what the actual hell. I... I just don't understand the purpose of this scene other than Tryon wanting to write a traumatic sex scene. It was all so needlessly graphic. I'm still giving the book 3 stars because the book was wonderful, that's right, WONDERFUL, except for this one scene. But no mental gymnastics can get me to the place where I see the point. A solid 4 star book loses an entire star for this single, repugnant vignette. Okay, I'm done.The resolution to Ned's digging is tight, the ending is good, and the revelations of the town are satisfying. Harvest Home is a horror/thriller book with flourish. It's a tale about a town with secrets, and it could have been great if the author wasn't sick in the head. ...more

title: I’m Glad My Mom Died
author: McCurdy, Jennette
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book might be triggering for some folks who have had a difficult relationship with their mother and/or with their body and/or with food.I have stThis book might be triggering for some folks who have had a difficult relationship with their mother and/or with their body and/or with food.I have struggled with all of the above. And, yeah, there were times where Jennette McCurdy's writing was so blunt and honest that I had to take a break. But her approach (leaning into the voice of the moment (childish when she was a child, etc.), simplistic sentence structure and language) resulted in a powerful narrative about a very difficult life. Jennette McCurdy grew up kind of poor in a hoarder household. When I say "kind of" I mean she always had a roof over her head, but she also learned to worry about money very early because it was a constant topic of discussion underneath said roof. At age 6 her mother pushed her into acting. By age 11 her mother was teaching her how to be an anorexic. Her mother was that special brand of manipulative and loving that is so confusing and heart wrenching to live through. The fact that McCurdy is able to write about it so clearly and truthfully is a testament to how therapy and reflection, when done right, can help with childhood trauma. Look, I'm not gonna talk much more about this. Suffice to say I saw myself in much of this memoir, and I thank her for the courage it took to pen this book....more

title: Scrappy Little Nobody
author: Kendrick, Anna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another audiobook for runs.--------------Look, celebrity memoirs are very rarely good. I said it. Their primary job is acting, not writing. They're doAnother audiobook for runs.--------------Look, celebrity memoirs are very rarely good. I said it. Their primary job is acting, not writing. They're doing the former really well; should we expect them to excel at the latter? If they were offered money to write up some anecdotes about themselves, why shouldn't they? That's why I wasn't too annoyed back when I read Amy Poehler's seemingly random, slap-dash attempt. She had better things to do, and it was just a paycheck. That's fine. I won't say that Scrappy Little Nobody is a very good memoir ,but it's real, it has some good nuggets, and it is what it is: a reflection written by someone whose job is decidedly NOT writing books. When I started listening to Anna Kendrick's Scrappy Little Nobody I was reading Jennette McCurdy's I'm Glad My Mom Died. I'm not sure I could have found celebrity memoirs that are more polar opposite. McCurdy was forced into show biz by her abusive mother, striving for the love and acceptance she never actually got. Kendrick came up with acting as a career all on her own, and her family regularly ferried her from Maine to NYC to make that dream come true. Her father even moved to New York for a spell while Kendrick was on Broadway, just to support his kid. Kendrick's narrative waffles between her trying-to-make-it era and her I'm-very-famous era. She tells some interesting anecdotes and is endearingly self-deprecating throughout. She missteps, because she's human and, again, writing isn't her job. The one that made me wince was when she was talking about wanting hair like Amanda Bynes: "in What A Girl Wants, not mugshot." Woof, Kendrick. Way to punch down on a woman struggling with abusive parents and a mental health crisis. But, again, I honestly don't think Kendrick meant anything by it. In her attempts to come across cool and likeable, she fell into the high-school-reminiscent trap of being mean about other girls because you're, like, so totally not one of them. None of us are perfect. We've all said things we regret. Unfortunately, Kendrick had a few published in a memoir.There were two thoughts she left us with that I really, really loved, and I think Kendrick deserves credit for penning them. The first was Kendrick saying she doesn't care if people consider her a "nice" person (the following was scraped off the internet because I'm not rewinding that audiobook to get you a perfect quote. What I'm saying is: I can't say these are 100%, or even in order, but I tried my best):As Sondheim said, Nice is different than good. Do you need to do whatever you’re told to be a nice person? Maybe. Do you need to do whatever you’re told to be a good person? Of course not! Man, woman, personal, professional—some people have a skill for persuading you the best thing you can be is obedient.AndI gave up on being Nice. I started putting more value on other qualities instead: passion, bravery, intelligence, practicality, humor, patience, fairness, sensitivity. Those last three might seem like they are covered by “nice,” but make no mistake, they are not. A person who smiles a lot and remembers everyone’s birthday can turn out to be undercover crazy, a compulsive thief, and boring to boot. I don’t put a lot of stock in nice. I’d prefer to be around people who have any of the above qualities over “niceness,” and I’d prefer it if that applied to me, too. I’m also okay if the most accurate description of me is nervous, and a little salty. But at least I know what I want to strive for.The second thought, which I can't seem to find on the internet (the internet failed me?!?!), was Kendrick reflecting on people talk about wanting to go back to their youth/20s, and how she has no interest in that. She has no interest in being the anxious, insecure, sheep-y person many of us become for a few, feverish years when we're younger. But what really struck me was when she said (paraphrasing, thanks a lot, internet!): "I'm not confused about what that word [friendship] means anymore." It hit me like a lightning bolt. So many of us put up with so much shit from people because we think they are our friends. It takes a long time to realize that someone who tears you down; who makes you feel bad for being yourself when yourself is totally normal and not a horrible, sadistic monster; who takes pleasure in your missteps and failures; is no friend at all. Some of us never come to that realization. I think we could all be better served if we took a step back and looked at how we treat our friends, and how our friends treat us. So, thanks Anna Kendrick....more

title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
author: Zevin, Gabrielle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, more than anything else, tells us there isn't an appropriate category for those friendships so deep that they feTomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, more than anything else, tells us there isn't an appropriate category for those friendships so deep that they feel like family or, even more, an extension of ourselves. Without that categorization, lines blur. We step over the friendship/partner line, trying to decide how much of ourselves to share, whether the relationship has conditions, and partitioning off the parts of ourselves which we dislike/feel shameful about/etc. Gabrielle Zevin's Sadie and Sam can be exasperatingly obtuse in their inability to appropriately communicate... but that's human, isn't it? To jump to conclusions, to fill in gaps, to turtle in on ourselves rather than leave ourselves out there open and vulnerable.Zevin creates a rich world with deep characters. We follow Sadie and Sam for 30 years, from their meeting as children through their late 30s. The pair meet in California, and both attend schools on the east coast (MIT and Harvard, respectively). Though they haven't seen one another in years, they are drawn to one another, to the ease of their partnership, and to how one pushes the other. Thus blooms both a professional and personal entanglement that is complicated and wonderful at the same time. This book is a bit about video games, but it's really just a story about how we grow and change, and whether we take people along with us. And, while the book is primarily focused on Sadie and Sam, Marx is the best character in this book... perhaps one of the better characters I've come across. The section titled "The NPC" is heart-wrenching and perfect. If the entirety of this book had been written like that section, this would be a 5-star book. Holy shit.A favorite passage:The way to turn an ex-lover into a friend is to never stop loving them, to know that when one phase of a relationship ends it can transform into something else. It is to acknowledge that love is both a constant and a variable at the same time....more
