title: Small Game
author: Braverman, Blair*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Blair Braverman writes really good articles and nonfiction. Unfortunately, that talent doesn't translate to her first foray into fiction.Small Game teBlair Braverman writes really good articles and nonfiction. Unfortunately, that talent doesn't translate to her first foray into fiction.Small Game tells the story of Mara, who is roped into auditioning for a new survival reality television show. When she is picked, she decides what the hell. There's prize money, and that money could maybe get her out of the life she hates.Why does she hate her life ? We don't know. Braverman doesn't give us much insight into her characters. The book is written in 3rd person limited, focused on Mara, but just barely. We don't get much of her inner thoughts at all. I'm not sure why this choice was made. It really should have been 1st person. Holding every single character at arms length in a narrative that was supposed to be harrowing and intimate was a mistake.Mara arrives at the show with 4 other contestants: Jake, the normie; Kyle, the boyscout; Bullfrog, the old man survivalist; and Ashley, the fame seeker. Want more insight into these characters ? Too bad, you won't get it.My biggest complaints are as follows :- the dialogue is clunky and often doesn't read like people talk.- all of the characters of unlikeable despite being the barest sketch of themselves.- Mara herself.What we know of Mara is an insufferable contradiction. She is meek and pliable externally ; internally she's all "I'm smarter than everyone here and they may think they have my number but I have THEIR number."You don't, though, Mara. The book opens with her trapped with a boyfriend she tells us she doesn't like, but we don't see that he's a bad guy. She says she can't leave him because of finances, but she has a job and lives off the land. She doesn't have enough money for a bus ticket? Then, in the survivor show, she allows herself to become the pet of one person, and accepts another person to be a pet of her own. She seems to hate humans in general, but then she becomes obsessed with one of them. None of these interpersonal relationships are unpacked, so it just reads as garbled nonsense. Who is Mara? I don't know.The book was a good idea: survivalist TV show gone amok. But Braverman wasn't able to create a sense of place and person that was believable or interesting or developed. To be clear: I really, really love Braverman's nonfiction, but this book was, unfortunately, a flop....more

title: Double Bind: Women on Ambition
author: Romm, Robin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I normally don't give stars to books I didn't finish, but this one is an exception.This book is false advertising. It is not women on ambition. It's tI normally don't give stars to books I didn't finish, but this one is an exception.This book is false advertising. It is not women on ambition. It's the author's writer friends talking about their successes. I tried to read this book chronologically, but the first essay was a person shitting on her friends for having different ambitions than climbing to the top of their profession. What? Why are we shaming people for making their lives full in different ways? Disgusting. The second essay was a long, drawn out complaint about the television industry. Also apparently every single person in the world wants to run their own TV show? Guess I'm not a person of the world. The third essay was mostly someone gushing about talking to Oprah.At this point I flipped to the essayist who drew me to this collection in the first place: Blair Braverman. Her contribution was great. She spoke about dog sledding and how it's a male dominated sport but is also one of the more even playing grounds . It was balanced and interesting and well-written.So I flipped to the back of the book, where the contributor bios lived, to see if there were any other non-writers in this collection. There were 3: a psychiatrist, a psychologist, and someone "from the tech world." I skimmed the psychiatrist's entry. It rambled on about estrogen for several pages. It was then I decided I'd had enough and put this book on the pile to go back to the library.I'm so, so sorry, Blair Braverman. You didn't deserve this. ...more

title: The Most of Nora Ephron
author: Ephron, Nora
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My Oma gave me this book. Her best friend (since they were in high school in the 1940s) saw it and remembered that I had always wanted to be a writer My Oma gave me this book. Her best friend (since they were in high school in the 1940s) saw it and remembered that I had always wanted to be a writer in my youth. So she bought it for me. Is that going to color how I feel about this book? Absolutely.---------------------------------------------------With about 80 pages left, and all of it in the "Personal" section of the book, I gotta start talking about this anthology of Nora Ephron.First of all: I wish the person who put this collection together had inserted themselves a few times. I think broader context for some of the more dated and outdated entries would have been helpful. But alas, he stayed silent. So here are my thoughts:Section 1: The JournalistVery interesting - because Ephron was a journalist in the 70s dealing with sexism and the social upheaval of the time, this section provided really great and unapologetic context for that world.Section 2: The AdvocateI cried. It was great. Also, I didn't know that Betty Freidan became such a fractious and narrow-minded figure in her later years.PS. The person who put this collection together put a piece on Ephron's 10th college reunion (1972) right next to her address to the Wellesley Class of 1996. Brilliant and hilarious choice. Section 3: The ProfilerThis was rough to read at times. Look, I get that writing unkindly about women was a "thing" for a while, but it's just cringey to read now, especially from someone who, in the previous section, was such a staunch feminist. She writes well here, but I was sort of gobsmacked that she took so many cheap shots at women: how they looked, how their personal lives shaped up. Oh, and her piece on Jan Morris was flat out offensive. This is where I really wish the person who compiled this collection had stepped in. And this is one of the primary reasons I gave this collection 3 stars. The "profile" on Lisbeth Salander, however, was hilarious. A good bit of satire. Section 4: The NovelistI'd never read Heartburn before and I really loved it. It's nothing groundbreaking, just a lightly fictionalized retelling of Ephron's own divorce, but the way she wrote it was just so vivid. It underscores how talented of a writer Ephron was. Section 5: The PlaywrightI'd never even heard of the play Lucky Guy but it was a well-written piece about the importance of journalism... and also the egos that exist within that field.Section 6: The ScreenwriterWhen Harry Met Sally is one of my favorite movies, so obviously reading the screenplay was a delight. After the screenplay concludes we get a brief reflective from Ephron, penned in 1990. She breaks down the politics of writing a movie (how many edits you go through, how much the characters of your voices change), and also lifts the curtain a bit on the goings ons with When Harry Met Sally. I did not know that it was Meg Ryan's idea to fake an orgasm in Katz's ; nor did I realize Billy Crystal came up with the famous "I'll have what she's having line." Good on Ephron for being honest that these bits don't belong to her. Section 7: The FoodieA lot of dated feelings about food. It was interesting, but definitely weaker than all that preceded it. Section 8: The BloggerMeh. Most of this was written around 2005 - 2007, and it's mostly just rantings about Bush and Watergate. My least favorite section by far; I skimmed it because of that, and also because it was repetitive. Another cornerstone for the 3-star rating. Section 9: PersonalI've still got most of this section left, but I don't think it's going to change my feelings on this collection. These last 80 pages appear to be reflections, almost all of them written towards the end of her life. They're a summation of sorts, of where's she's been and how she defines herself. I pulled a page out of Harry's book, and read the last 2 pages first. They're a list of what she won't miss when she's gone, and what she will. I cried then, too.So, it was good, but there were some problematic things in it that deserved addressing, yet no one did, and that really brought the whole thing down in my opinion. Oh, I almost forgot. At one point she said that men are inherently more funny than women. Interesting how she blasted Friedan for losing touch later in life AND YET, DEAR READER. AND. YET. ...more

title: Scandal in Spring        (Wallflowers, #4)
author: Kleypas, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've never read a romance before, but was convinced to try one on for size after a dear friend, who has read many a romance in her day, recommended a I've never read a romance before, but was convinced to try one on for size after a dear friend, who has read many a romance in her day, recommended a few to me. As this friend put it to me later: "romance books are comfort reads," and she couldn't be more correct in that. In a way it was very refreshing to open up a book and know that there would be a happy ending and the good guys would win and love would prevail.What I really enjoyed:This book has many characters. We're talking at least 10 distinct people running around a fancy Victorian house having a fancy Victorian time. Yet every single character has a unique voice. And I'm not talking Stephen King unique where he forces intense accents where they don't belong; I'm talking true unique voices where each character is their own person and has their own way of addressing others. It proves that Lisa Kleypas is a good writer. If you've ever thought romance as a genre is inherently poorly written, you're wrong. The narrative can be flowery, sure, but not cloyingly so. What I'm trying to say is: this book is well-crafted, and Kleypas has a handle on narration more than authors out there winning accolades and getting high-powered s. Also, when there are miscommunications the characters ACTUALLY TALK TO ONE ANOTHER INSTEAD OF RUNNING AWAY. Do you hear me, every chick flick ever made??? Have a DIALOGUE when there is a misunderstanding. Criminy !The plot is as follows: Daisy needs to find a husband, or her dad is going to marry her off to his (suitably young) business partner. Her dad calls her a parasite which, like, I have to agree. She just wants to hang out in beautiful houses reading books. That's an expensive lifestyle. So Daisy, her sister, and her brother-in-law try and find her a match. However, the business partner who was once an uggo is now a hunka-hunka muscle man. Maybe Daisy isn't so opposed to the arrangement after all...Scandal in Spring is a fun and lighthearted romp of a read. My major qualm with the book is that it tries to introduce high, mortal stakes, which was pointless. We all know this is going to be a happy ending, Kleypas. You don't have to do that. Also, the hunka-hunka muscle man's love for Daisy got borderline weird/creepy/obsessive. But borderline, so we can forgive it. If this  doesn't make sense - it's because I have COVID. Sorry about that....more

title: The It Girl
author: Ware, Ruth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Everything I want to say about this book is a spoiler. Before I give everything away, I want to say the following:Recent mystery novels give you one, Everything I want to say about this book is a spoiler. Before I give everything away, I want to say the following:Recent mystery novels give you one, maybe two suspects. Ruth Ware gave us a good 5 believable suspects in The It Girl, and that didn't go unnoticed. This is a murder mystery; an exploding genre in recent years. Most of these books follow the tragic, wonderful young woman getting murdered. Not so here. The "It" Girl in question isn't sympathetic in the least, which was refreshing. Shitty people get murdered too. It still not okay, but I think we're all bored of the flawless victim.Hannah, our main character/narrator, is also shitty. Like, really shitty. I might actually... hate her? But to get into that, I'd need to spoil the book. So here we go.(view spoiler)[The It Girl is a flash-forward-flash-back book. For the first half of the novel, we volley between Hannah and her 5 BFFs as they begin their freshman year of college (the BFFs in question being Will, Ryan, Hugh, Emily, and April), and Hannah 10yrs in the future. Why 10yrs? Because April was murdered at the end of their freshman year, and Hannah was a key witness who put the primary suspect in prison. Now, while Hannah is married to Will and they're expecting their first child, the man convicted of April's murder has died in prison. He protested his innocence to the end. The death makes Hannah start to wonder "hhmmm... what if I was wrong," and also some podcaster comes along and basically TELLS her she was wrong. She starts to internalize it, and so begins pulling on threads that unravel almost as fast as her sanity.Because Hannah is unstable. I'm not sure if she's poorly written or if Ware did this intentionally, but Hannah is just a dreadful person and I don't care a lick about her. Here's why:1. She ran away from school. Trauma is horrible. I can't imagine what it's like to lose your freshman roommate to a murder AND to walk in on that murder. But, even in fiction, I can't abide someone abandoning their life and their future when horrible things happen. You can't let this rotten, awful world get between you and what you want. Hannah did.2. Every time suspicion shifts to a different person Hannah "can see it crystal clear." Anyone and everyone is a suspect to Hannah, because her head is so up in the clouds and she's so gullible and lacking critical thought that it's inevitable that she can run away with the mere whisper of motive or possible access to murdering April. Take a second! Slow down! Why are you so stupid?? 3. Ryan is one of her dearest friends. He has a horrible, debilitating stroke in his 20s. And Hannah does... nothing. She doesn't keep in touch. She doesn't see what he or his wife or their two tiny babies need. She just doesn't attend to her friend. But when she starts looking back at April's murder she decides it's totally appropriate to show up at his house unannounced and drill him with questions and call him early in the morning TO ACCUSE HER OWN HUSBAND OF A 10YR OLD MURDER. Leave Ryan alone!! With friends like these...4. At the close of the novel there's this great fight-to-the-death. Hugh, the murderer, is trying to shoot Hannah, but then lo! Hannah's husband, who she just that morning accused of being a murderer, appears and begins to wrestle him. What does Hannah do? Continues to stand at the edge of a literal cliff, paralyzed by inaction. Eventually the gun is pushed kind of close to her, so she makes a half-effort to retrieve it, but is unsuccessful. This book should have been called Hannah the Plodding Waste of Space.5. You can't take a bath when you're pregnant unless it's less than 100 degrees. You're not supposed to drink that much coffee. Is pregnancy-shaming this fictional character as low as a person can go? Well, what about victim blaming her? Because that's what Ruth Ware did to her own creation.The man who wasted away in prison for April's murder was a porter from their school: John Neville. Why is he a suspect? Mostly because he was seen leaving April's room minutes before she was found dead. But also because HE STALKED AND ASSAULTED HANNAH AND IT SEEMED LIKE HE WAS GOING TO RAPE HER AT SOME POINT?!?! Once John Neville no longer seemed to be a suspect Ware just sort of shrugged him off in her narrative. She even made him... sympathetic? Toward the close of the novel Hannah says:"I condemned [Neville] for being old, and weird and awkward - and that's on me, don't you understand? That will forever be on me."WHAT?!?! WHAT?!?!?! WHAT?!?!?!At one point, earlier in the novel, Hannah mentions that multiple women had complained about Neville's stalking and inappropriate behavior. This man was dangerous and should NOT have been working at a school. Should he have died in prison? I suppose not. But him going to prison seems like a WHEN not an IF BECAUSE AGAIN, HE ASSAULTED AND TRIED TO RAPE HANNAH.And, again, the man didn't deserve to rot in prison for a murder her didn't commit, but this isn't black-and-white, like Ware seems to try to force it to be at the close of her book. This man was problematic and awful in so many ways.Hannah accused her husband, Will, of murdering April. His response was to say "What do you think," LAUGH IN HER FACE, AND RUN AT HER. There's a red herring, and then there's absolute lunacy. Then, when Will is actually innocent, they're just cool and in love again? HOW?!?!?! SHE JUST ACCUSED YOU OF MURDER AND THEN YOU ACTED LIKE A MURDERER. Get a divorce. Jesus Christ. Honestly I wish Hugh had gotten away with it all.Moral of the story: don't prank people. Or, if you're gonna prank them, like, put an acorn in their shoe or something.  (hide spoiler)]...more

Thrills and danger and depression ensue. If you're a Stephen King person, this is one of his cornerstone tales. That said, it certainly isn't a stand-out book. Also: fuck the government. title: Know My Name
author: Miller, Chanel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Gut-wrenching. Honest. Unabashed. Required reading. Chanel Miller did something that feels like it should be impossible: she wrote an entire book abouGut-wrenching. Honest. Unabashed. Required reading. Chanel Miller did something that feels like it should be impossible: she wrote an entire book about her sexual assault with poise, passion, anger, and hope. She walked us through almost 3 years of her life: from the day she spontaneously decided to go to a Stanford party, through Brock Turner's release from jail and the appeals and the bullshit that followed. It's an incredibly brave and beautiful and horrifying piece of writing that everyone should be reading, even though it'll fuck with your head (seriously, I've been irritable and teary for days and I couldn't figure out why until I realized every time I would sit down to read more of this book I would burst into tears). Also, this book should have ended on page 275. Page 275 tells the parable of the spider and the centipede. It's a wonderful wrap on where Miller has been and where she's going. When I turned the page and realized I had 2 more chapters left, I was a little perplexed. Two more chapters of... what?Of Donald Trump, Bill Cosby, and Brett Kavanaugh.And maybe it's petty for me to knock a star off for this, but giving us a timeline of high-profile sexual aggressors was just so exhausting after everything we had just been through with Miller. And, unlike the rest of the book, it was impersonal and really just a rehashing of a history with which most folks who pick up this book are familiar. Plus, by dragging us into politics, she risks alienating conservative women who could have otherwise found comfort in this book. I'm not saying Miller doesn't have the right to speak her mind about what a misogynistic dumbass Donald Trump is; I'm just saying that aim never seemed to be the central thesis of the book, and we (read: I) didn't need it. I skimmed the last two chapters. I should say, though, that the coda about Stanford found in these last 2 chapters is important: how they responded to Miller after Brock Turner was released, and how completely they failed to provide support or to even use her quote suggestions on the goddamn plaque where the sexual assault took place. Fuck you, Stanford....more

title: An Immense World: How Animal Senses Reveal the Hidden Realms Around Us
author: Yong, Ed
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The thesis of this book is overwhelming: let's look at a scattershot of creatures on this Earth: insects, birds, dogs, elephants, sharks, whales, batsThe thesis of this book is overwhelming: let's look at a scattershot of creatures on this Earth: insects, birds, dogs, elephants, sharks, whales, bats, otters, and on and on. The purpose? To re-sketch the world in the minds of humans, by describing the primary ways in which other beings perceive it. If someone pitched this book to me I'd probably laugh. Where does one even begin? How do you choose the species on which to focus? How are you going to lay the book out? Is it going to be a million pages? And doesn't that sound tedious as hell?Well, color me embarrassed, because my skepticism was misplaced. As long as you think of Yong's book as a series of vignettes, centered around a very loose "be-in-awe-of-the-world" theme, you're going to love this book. Did you know zebras are black-and-white striped because it confuses African biting flies? Did you know there's a HUGE scientific debate about how birds perceive magnetic fields, and how this field enables them to migrate? Did you know...I could go on. Just ask my husband. This book is full of fascinating trivia. More, though, it's a love story in exalation of our natural world. It's also an earnest warning of all we stand to lose in the face of climate change, and in the face of a world that we are making increasingly brighter and louder. Everyone, and I mean everyone, should read An Immense World. I laugh. I cried. I angered. It really is a masterpiece. I have to end by shouting out Yong's acknowledgments. He kicks it off by thanking his wife for coming up with the idea for his book, for supporting him, for being an incredible person who makes the people around her better. He loves his wife so much. It's beautiful. ...more

review: Still relevant.Magnificent. Bradbury distills the hubris of man into a series of vignettes spanning a couple dozen years as folks attempt to colonize Still relevant.Magnificent. Bradbury distills the hubris of man into a series of vignettes spanning a couple dozen years as folks attempt to colonize Mars. I don't want to describe much else, lest I give something away, but this book easily became one of my favorites. He captures human nature so effortlessly, and accurately predicted the future including, but not limited to, smart homes. A genius. We should have listened to him.On human rigidity: Anything that's strange is no good to the average American.On censorship:All the beautiful literary lies and flights of fancy must be shot in mid-air! So they lined them up against a library wall one Sunday morning thirty years ago, in 2006; they lined them up, St. Nicholas and the Headless Horseman and Snow White and Rumpelstiltskin and Mother Goose - oh, what a wailing! - and shot them down, and burned the paper castles and the fairy frogs and old kings and the people who lived happily ever after (for of course it was a fact that nobody lived happily ever after!), and Once Upon A Time became No More!And on how everything we say we stand for is a goddamn lie (which, reading today, June 24, 2022, was absolutely gutting):"I was looking for Earthian logic, common sense, good government, peace, and responsibility.""All that up there?""No. I didn't find it. review: This book was sad and made me feel bad.Since our hero's a poetI -nah, just joshing ya. None of us want Review-As-Poem. Conversations with Friends is aThis book was sad and made me feel bad.Since our hero's a poetI -nah, just joshing ya. None of us want Review-As-Poem. Conversations with Friends is a book about a bunch of selfish and miserable people living out their selfish and miserable lives in Dublin. We have four characters: Melissa, Nick, Bobbi, and Frances. Frances is our main character, so let's save her for last.Melissa is a two-dimensional megabitch who appears in the novel only to be a foil for Frances. Poor Melissa.Nick is a 32yr old baby who is emotionally manipulative while simultaneously being passive AF. How? Beats me.Bobbi is a borderline abusive friend/ex of Frances'. Bobbi is really troublesome, because she is so horrible to everyone in her life... but it's supposed to be funny? #cancelBobbiAnd then there's Frances. Frances is a self-mutilating manic depressive who watches with numb ambivalence as things happen to and around her. It's honestly not worth a deep dive. My main issues with her were: if you're so poor GET A JOB. If you're so worried about your dad DO SOMETHING. If you're in pain SEE A DOCTOR. If these people hurt you YOU CAN LEAVE THEM. She's 20, so she's young and naive, but this was on a whole different level. She lives in a flat in Dublin for free and has her tuition taken care of but doesn't get an allowance to eat for a month and doesn't know what to do. Getting a job doesn't even cross her mind? And, girl, there's always free food at the university. Be creative. Also, just in general GROW THE FUCK UP. If I'm being honest, my main hang up with this book is how it clashes with what I think is good or right behavior. If someone who experienced what happens in this book read it, it would probably resonate, and might be a powerful, literary experience. That's certainly what happened to me with Normal People. All I could think about while reading this book was how badly I wanted to shake Frances out of her passive stupor. It was infuriating. ...more

title: Into Every Generation a Slayer Is Born: How Buffy Staked Our Hearts
author: Katz, Evan Ross
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What even is this book?I am a BIG Buffy fan. Huge. I've watched the series through several times, and have watched my favorites episodes 10+ times. I What even is this book?I am a BIG Buffy fan. Huge. I've watched the series through several times, and have watched my favorites episodes 10+ times. I know a decent amount about the show, and so was very excited when I heard this book was coming out. I put a hold at the library a full MONTH before the book even came out.All I gotta say is: I am so happy I didn't spend a cent on this pile of garbage. Get ready for a rant. Here are some of my biggest complaints:1) A full third of this book is just Evan Ross Katz summarizing each season of the show. He EXTENSIVELY quotes full scenes from episodes. He's not even breaking them down. He's just like: this happened, then this happened. Check out this scene!  I very much doubt folks are picking up this book unless they've watched the show. Did he have a page count to meet or something? This was asinine. 2) Despite summarizing the entire fucking series... he doesn't know it? One tiny example: he says the character Andrew is Tucker Wells' cousins. They're brothers!!! Evan Ross Katz clearly needs to watch the show again.3) Every opinion Evan Ross Katz has about the show is correct, and any deviating opinions are stupid. Are you a Spike/Buffy fan rather than an Angel/Buffy fan? Well, then, you're the dumbest dumb to ever dumb, according to Evan Ross Katz. Like, what? Art is subjective? Sit the fuck down.4) He is incredibly cruel regarding some the cast members who made themselves available to be interviewed. The most insidious example of this was when Evan Ross Katz was talking to James Marsters about playing Spike. I'm gonna pull a page out of Katz's book, and quote extensively here:But my real disdain for Spike is informed by something James Marsters said in a 2001 E! special titled Buffy's Back... "The first time Spike saw Buffy, he was hunting her, which has a very sexual undertone," he says. "And I played that very heavily. It's kind of the same thing [as] some man hunting a woman at a bar, looking at her dancing, walking across the bar, and just noticing her. It's both sexual and violent. And I played that." I get that a vampire has no soul, and for them violence isn't just palatable, it's tasty. But the comparison in real life, and the use of the words "hunting" and "violent" spoke volumes about Marsters's [sic] worldview at the time, which, if we're keeping it 100, feels grossly misaligned with the show's themes of female empowerment. I'm going to do something that Katz never does in his book: I'm going to break this down.Firstly, Katz contradicts this last sentence later in the book. He questions whether the show is actually about female empowerment, so... is it grossly misaligned? Make up your mind. Katz also later discusses, in depth, the fact that James Marsters approached the character of Spike using method acting. He needed to get into the mind of something evil, and so he chose the closest real-world example he could find: predatory men at bars. This is a very real thing. Does Evan Ross Katz think it's not? Or, does he think vampires are real and Marsters should have pulled from them??? Evan Ross Katz appears to be trying to suggest that James Marsters is a bad person because he was trying to do his job and portray a character who is a bad man... and this is the only example he could come up with. Go ahead and watch the interview being referenced. We don't hear the question James Marsters was even asked. How leading was it? And how does it have a single thing to do with James Marsters as a person? This says way more to me about Evan Ross Katz than it does about James Marsters.5) Evan Ross Katz is a terrible interviewer, and doesn't know the first thing about pulling quotes. He'll transcribe paragraphs and paragraphs of quotes, completely unpolished, every "uh" and "ah" intact. What a dick.6) In addition to interviewing cast and crew, he interviewed a few random people who have no business being quoted so extensively in the book. What the fuck do I care what Claire Saffitz has to say about Buffy the Vampire Slayer? I barely even trust what she has to say about cookies, and baking is her literal job. He also interviews Kristin Russo who doesn't even like the show. Has Evan Ross Katz even listened to her podcast? She is objectively not an authority on the show at all. Why were there 10+ pages of sound bytes from her? 7) There's an entire chapter about Buffy's wardrobe, and an entire chapter about how much Evan Ross Katz loves Sarah Michelle Gellar... where of course he had to quote every single compliment she has ever paid him. Gag me.8) The final chapter hints at some interpersonal issues on set. As some folks may know: Nicholas Brendan has had some personal issues, there are rumors that Alyson Hannigan and Sarah Michelle Gellar never got along, David Boreanez wants nothing to do with the show anymore... but Katz just briefly mentions this and moves on. $10 Sarah Michelle Gellar asked him to dance around these actual interesting behind-the-scene bits. Or the fact that he just briefly mentions that there was an on-set rule that Michelle Trachtenberg wasn't allowed to be left in a room with Joss Whedon alone? He just mentions that and changes the subject? What the what???9) Eliza Dushku, David Boreanez, Alyson Hannigan, and Michelle Trachtenberg all declined to talk to him. He blames it on the Joss Whedon issues that have bubbled up over the past year or so. I think they just knew he's a terrible writer and a terrible person and thus made the absolutely correct decision to not talk to this guy.All this to say: Into Every Generation... was an easy paycheck for Evan Ross Katz to chat with Sarah Michelle Gellar and summarize a show he likes. Really, truly, don't waste your time. Watch some older interviews with cast members, and certainly watch the show, but this book will make you dumber if you try to read it....more

title: The Essex Serpent
author: Perry, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I saw a ridiculous trailer for the miniseries adaption (starring Claire Danes and Tom Hiddleston?? How'd they manage that??), and THEN saw how rabidlyI saw a ridiculous trailer for the miniseries adaption (starring Claire Danes and Tom Hiddleston?? How'd they manage that??), and THEN saw how rabidly divided folks are on Goodreads. I had no choice. I had to read it for myself.--Well, I guess I'm an outlier. I neither loved it nor hated it. This was a perfectly "meh" book. Sarah Perry attempted to do SO MUCH with her narrative and so universally fell short. I don't mean that to sound cruel, but, well, here we are.It's tough to put my finger on what exactly The Essex Serpent is about, because I'm not sure it knows its primary story line. When the book opens, we meet a London surgeon who is traveling to the funeral of one of his patients. So... is he the main character? He is excited to see the widow, because he's in love with her. Why? We don't know. The motivations of every character is unclear, so we better get used to it.When the surgeon gets to the funeral, the narrative starts to focus on the widow (who I'm going to call Claire Danes going forward, because she's partially to blame for my reading this book). So... is Claire Danes the main character?Claire Danes, her sociopathic son, and her platonic companion (except when it's totally not platonic) flee London for the seaside. At this point, we are accosted by characters. A rich couple who find Claire Danes an oddity worth studying, a quirky hovel man who talks to his goats more than people, a gaggle of children, a rich man who is in love with Danes' companion, a stabbing survivor who is ALSO in love with Danes' companion, the surgeon's BFF... like... do we need all these characters?!?! No. We could have halved these characters and still achieved the same narration. But instead we have to juggle all these barely fleshed out folks and their various motivations and flaws. Lastly, we meet Tom Hiddleston (this is also his fault). Tom Hiddleston is a parishioner who lives in a sleepy little village with his frail wife and their 3 children. Hiddleston's village is beginning to quake, because a few unfortunate incidents have inspired the town to blame The Essex Serpent, a mythical creature of local legend. So legendary is this Serpent, that it has been carved into one of the pews of Hiddleston's very church.What follows is a muddled mess of plot. Is the Serpent real, or are the locals just itching for a witch hunt? Will Danes' companion choose a man? It's a weird situation to place the companion in, because her chief motivation seems to be the workers' rights movement of late 19th century London, but that chief motivation drains away as LOVE is introduced into the equation. Which, like, gross. Speaking of gross, Hiddleston and Danes begin to grow attracted to one another, but Hiddleston is married. I can get behind this kind of conflict; love and attraction and marriage are complicated. But Hiddleston's wife is ILL. Like, SUPER ILL, and he's plumb ignoring it. So, he becomes a wholly repugnant character, for seemingly no reason (because motivation, etc. is unclear). And... IS HE THE MAIN CHARACTER??!?! WHO KNOWS!Here's what I'll say: some of the writing is beautiful; Perry knows her prose. But without a clear plot, even that falls flat. Why are the characters doing any of these things? Who are they? What brought them here? The book is 400+ pages and I don't have the answers to these questions. Also, this book needs WAY more Serpent. Like, 500% more Serpent....more

title: The Witch's Heart
author: Gornichec, Genevieve*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Genevieve Gornichec wanted to write Circe, Norse myth style. The problem is folks don't know Norse myths the way they know The Odyssey. Following a peGenevieve Gornichec wanted to write Circe, Norse myth style. The problem is folks don't know Norse myths the way they know The Odyssey. Following a person hiding in the woods whilst wars and adventures and creation happens was frustrating. Circe was a fresh lens on a well known tale. The Witch's Heart felt like being stuck inside on a beautiful day while your friends play in the street outside. Nose pressed up to the glass you want so badly to go out there and see what's up. But your shitty aunt is visiting so you have to stay inside with her and eat her shitty soup and listen to her shitty stories about what a victim she is.Because that's what the protagonist is: a passive victim who just lets things happen to her. We are supposed to believe she's powerful with the magics but really all I see her doing is feeling sorry for herself and making soup. She's such a bummer and the bummer is self-inflicted.I also have to say this is the very first book I've ever read where every character sounds the same. We've got 3 main characters and a handful of secondaries it was hard to tell who was talking when a clump got together because they all had the same voice. Yet this book gets 3 stars, why ? Because, at the end of the day, it's a story about a woman who wants to lead a quiet life but continues to get dragged into the fray because she is too important, even as she craves anonymity and peace. I am annoyed with Gornichec because I think this book could have been so much more : it could have been an approachable introduction into underrepresented creation myths, and/or a story about a strong woman, and/or a story about purposeful destruction in the desperate hope for a better future. It was none of those things, but I loved Angrbora anyway....more

title: My Life on the Road
author: Steinem, Gloria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Gloria Steinem was born the same year as my Oma. It's kind of dumbfounding, because all of the things for which I forgive my Oma (her antiquated viewsGloria Steinem was born the same year as my Oma. It's kind of dumbfounding, because all of the things for which I forgive my Oma (her antiquated views on things like immigration and abortion rights, say), Gloria Steinem and I seem completely aligned. It just goes to show: maybe we shouldn't be so willing to let the bullshit of the older generations slide.My Life on the Road is a book of essays, lists, and reflections. It's not particularly cohesive, but the meandering nature sort of matches the meandering of Steinem's life. The beginning was strong. Steinem spoke to her upbringing, the wanderlust of her father, and how she unwittingly followed in his footsteps. As the book progressed, it began to get more repetitive and long-winded. The middle sections about political candidates with whom Steinem has worked with/campaigned for got sort of exhausting. Yes, Steinem, I know I'm supposed to vote and get involved. Her messaging, though important, felt misplaced in this book. The people who would benefit from her instruction would never pick this book up in the first place.It honestly felt like she started out thinking this was going to be a memoir, but, as she was writing, she realized she wanted to tell a larger story about fighting for rights and getting involved in community and politics. When she wrote about the former the book felt put-together; it had life. As she attempted to tackle the latter she sort of lost the thread, and the book became dull.Steinem is an impressively accomplished and inspiring woman, but we might be better served listening to past interviews and speeches rather than reading this book. Gah, I feel like such an asshole for writing that. Do what you want. For me, this book dragged....more

review: I feel tricked. This book was not what I thought. I thought I was getting all eels all the time. I got maybe 30% eels. There should be a disclaimer onI feel tricked. This book was not what I thought. I thought I was getting all eels all the time. I got maybe 30% eels. There should be a disclaimer on books that deal with grief. I didn't know we'd be tackling loss and I wasn't prepared.There should be a disclaimer on books that examine the hopelessness of our future. I was likewise unprepared to stare down that barrel.I guess the world of eels is still opaque, so Svensson had to go down some tangential rabbit holes. But I didn't need the biographies of all the scientists who ever tackled the question of the eel. This book made me mad at scientists. Destruction in the name of answering an otherwise kind of irrelevant question was infuriating.But eels are cool. Until they're all dead. And soon we'll be dead. And nothing matters....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book enlightens its reader about some very interesting facts on fungus : why we are so attracted to truffles; how plants and fungus work togetherThis book enlightens its reader about some very interesting facts on fungus : why we are so attracted to truffles; how plants and fungus work together under the ground; how fungus has persisted and evolved through millennia; the ways we can use fungus to create fibers/material, alcohol, food, or medicine; etc. At some points I was singularly engaged, but at many other points I found my mind sliding to other things. Why? Because the book is sooooo dry in a lot of places. As is the razor-thin line with much nonfiction, Entangled Life reads more as though the intended audience was stodgy academics and not the layperson. I wouldn't say I don't recommend this book, I just wouldn't blame anyone for skimming in places. title: Let's Get Physical: How Women Discovered Exercise and Reshaped the World
author: Friedman, Danielle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Danielle Friedman was curious about the history of Pilates, and decided to go down a bit of an internet rabbit hole. The rabbit hole turned into a serDanielle Friedman was curious about the history of Pilates, and decided to go down a bit of an internet rabbit hole. The rabbit hole turned into a series of tunnels that culminated in Let's Get Physical the story of how white, 20th century, American women found and embraced exercise. I've seen some squabbling on the internet about how Friedman's book is only that: white, 20th century American women. Personally, I do not have much of an issue with her chosen scope. Exercise was, and in many ways still is, a hobby steeped in privilege. Because of this, a book on the subject will inherently skew white. And Friedman is upfront about this as she writes. She circles back again and again to how exclusive exercise can be: from bespoke studios to expensive workout wear to the female image these trends advertise... it's all a reflection of a very narrow version of Woman. Her final chapter of the book speaks to how exercise culture as a whole is contemporarily attempting to change its image to be more inclusive of race, ethnicity, size, and socioeconomic status. But it's very new, and that's why the women we see in prior chapters look so similar. Let's Get Physical primarily focuses on Pilates, Barre, running, Jazzercise, the exercise video craze of the 80s and 90s (Buns of Steel, Jane Fonda workouts), and yoga. I would have loved more on the running chapter, because it's the exercise I enjoy most in the bunch, and because it's such a fascinating and upsetting history (a woman was ATTACKED by one of the DIRECTORS of the Boston Marathon when he saw she was running the race. And then Friedman inserts a footnote that they ultimately became friends?! What?! Google "Katherine Switzer" "Boston Marathon" and tell me you don't need 50 pages on how in the heck Friedman could say these two became anything one could label "friend"). I also would have loved more of a breakdown of casual competitions such as triathlon. But that would have opened many other cans of worms and I understand that would have required so much more research. Guess we'll need a volume 2 ;)For folks who find enjoyment in moving their bodies: read this book. It's also a great encapsulation of how far we've come with women's rights, and how much farther we still need to go....more

title: Tin Man
author: Winman, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An incredibly depressing reflection on love and its different forms.When I started this book I was put off by its rambling, passive voice. After a fewAn incredibly depressing reflection on love and its different forms.When I started this book I was put off by its rambling, passive voice. After a few pages, I understood Winman's choice. This book is an internal meditation; the narration should look like someone's inner dialogue, with alternating legato and staccato thoughts and scenes. Tin Man tells the story of two men: Ellis and Michael. The first half of the book follows Ellis, older and alone, though we're not quite sure why he's so solitary... at first. Later, he finds the notebook of his once something-more-than-a friend Michael. The second half is us reading Michael's diary along with Ellis.Winman manages to capture several types of love in this book. First, we see the love between Ellis and his mother, and between his mother and Michael. That innocent, supportive, love-with-abandon that a good mother can provide to any child who is lucky enough to find themselves under her wing. This shifts to the different types of love Ellis and Michael have for one another. Ellis' love for Michael is complicated, straddling friendship and something more. Michael's love for Ellis is all-encompassing. He will take whatever Ellis will give him. As adults, Ellis meets Annie. Again, Winman deftly captures how each feels about the other, because Michael is as much a part of their marriage, even if he doesn't have a ring as physical proof. Winman also captures love-as-loss, love-as-fear. It's incredible that she packed so much in such a slim novel.If you don't want to cry, don't read this book. But if you've got the stomach for something heartbreaking, you really can't do better than Winman's Tin Man....more

title: Duma Key
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Who knew ghost ships and ghost limbs could be so... boring.Because that's where I came down on this book when I finished it last night: it's boring!I Who knew ghost ships and ghost limbs could be so... boring.Because that's where I came down on this book when I finished it last night: it's boring!I went into Duma Key with no real concept of plot. I just remembered my Oma reading it when it first came out and talking about the crazy nightmares she had while reading it. Crazy nightmares? Count me in.Duma Key is the story of Edgar Freemantle (feels like a fake name). Edgar is a pretty wealthy construction guy who gets super smashed at a job site. After being apparently straight up ABUSIVE to his wife after the accident, the marriage falls apart. So, since he's got the cash, he takes the advice of his doctor and runs away from the pieces of his cold Minnesota life for the warm bath that is the Florida Keys. The fictional Duma Key where he makes his temporary home is relatively abandoned. Why? Because people don't want to go to this sleepy island when they could party somewhere else? Because it's hAuNtEd?!?!??! Anywho, he picks up drawing, because he was a doodler in his past life, right? So why not start drawing as a way to pass the time. But his drawing sessions are black-out-possessions and what he creates in his Art Fugues are brilliant... but in a horrifying way. And... wait... are the paintings some sort of clairvoyance? Are they alive? hAuNtEd?!?!??!You'd think most of the narrative would follow Edgar as he tried to unpack his spooky gift and its implications. Well. You'd be wrong. Most of the narrative is about Edgar eating and how he loves his younger daughter WAY MORE than his older daughter for no apparent reason and how his ex-wife is a bitch and how much his body hurts after getting smashy smashed. It's really befuddling just how boring this book was. The last 150 pages tried to ramp up the drama and scares but it was STILL peppered with eating and naps and hip pain and cracks and his eldest, less-loved daughter and just... why? Stephen King has always been long-winded, but this just felt gratuitous. Sometimes repetition serves the narrative. Not here. AND LOVE YOUR ELDEST DAUGHTER, YOU JERK. Also the Big Bad? Big yawn. It reminded me of Gachnar. IYKYK....more

title: Big Friendship: How We Keep Each Other Close
author: Sow, Aminatou*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not for me - kept getting annoyed - had to skim to quell said annoyance.Looking back, it's unclear what I thought I was getting into with Big FriendshNot for me - kept getting annoyed - had to skim to quell said annoyance.Looking back, it's unclear what I thought I was getting into with Big Friendship ...maybe an intellectual discussion about adult friendships, how we create new bonds, and how childhood bonds fray? And, to be fair, Aminatou Sow and Ann Friedman do try to deliver on this front at least a little. They spoke to sociologists/psychologists/historians and pepper anecdotes throughout the book. That's all they are, though: anecdotes. And those anecdotes are smushed between large retrospectives as the two authors pen mini-memoirs, and then slapdash connect one another to their memories. It's a clumsy read, especially because the narrative kept switching from "we/us" to "Aminatou/Ann." They really should have stuck with third person narration, because this choice just didn't work.It also felt kinda... braggy? That's such a stupid critique of a memoir-meets-meditation-on-friendship. By definition it's going to fall into the category of Navel Gazing. But I couldn't help but be put off by Sow and Friedman by the end. The frequency with which they'd be like "oh, then we and our 26 closest friends went on a retreat together," or "so we gathered 10 friends and we..." or "everyone has 50 people they can call when shit hits the fan" just felt so out of touch. If someone went to this book looking for warm, comforting words about friendships in adulthood, they'd leave this book with frostbite. We get it. You guys have a lot of friends. Cool. I listened to their podcast, "Call Your Girlfriend," pretty regularly, but their banter and sophisticated, philosophical discussions were nowhere to be found in this book. Again, I really don't know why I came here in the first place, so I can't say I'm disappointed, I'm just... can you ever just be whelmed? Maybe in Europe?...more

title: Bleak House
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Society and the laws that guide it are rotten mess of entitlement, greed, and stupidity. Dickens comes back to this again and again in the staggering Society and the laws that guide it are rotten mess of entitlement, greed, and stupidity. Dickens comes back to this again and again in the staggering 991 page Bleak House. Sometimes I felt he went a little long on domestic vignettes that lent nothing to characterization and plot, and sometimes the characters felt more like anthropomorphized concepts than actual people who could actually exist. Nevertheless, Bleak House is a scathing opus on classism, the legal system, and modern civilization itself. And now, for a dramatic synopsis of Bleak House:Esther is a timid, bound-by-duty young girl who is raised by her aunt. Her aunt hates her. Why? Hold that thought. Some random dude pays for Esther to get away from her aunt so bye bye bitch and HELLO two rich cousins (cousins to each other, not to Esther) who seem like maybe they want to bone? Anywho, the trio move into random dude's house. Random dude can't be real: he's so nice and generous and bachelor-y without being skeevy (for now). Is there something sinister lurking beneath? But, wait, we're changing perspectives. Let's pan to the mean London streets to meet little homeless Jo who no one cares about because he's got too much dirt on him. Get going, Jo. You're not wanted here. Sure you're small and pathetic and hungry and cold but the Inspector told you to get gone so SCOOT. Anyway, look at these rich people. Aren't they beautiful? But wait... what are these secrets and betrayal and murder lurking underneath? HOLD FOR A SPONTANEOUS COMBUSTION. Esther's narrative is back and getting knotted up with both rich and poor perspectives. She tries to help one while not getting pulled down by the other. Which is which? Why not both depending on her mood? And is she in love? Or will she eschew happiness for duty? And what of those cousins? Is one of them barfing blood because he's so obsessed with an inheritance he can't quite reach? And, wait, Esther, did you just get SMALLPOX?? Smallbox will make you an uggo, you know. But, whoa, are you going to use your uggo-ness to manipulate a bunch of bastards to do what you want? GET IT, GIRL. Ahem.A couple of times it seemed Dickens was going to make a BIG STATEMENT about how the dominant society Others so-called undesirables, but then he ultimately skirted around it. That was a bummer. But, if you ask me, he was still ahead of his time. And I really enjoyed this book. ...more

title: The Final Girl Support Group
author: Hendrix, Grady*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fun and mindless and not as good as either Grady Hendrix's earlier My Best Friend's Exorcism and/or the movies that served as inspiration, The Final GFun and mindless and not as good as either Grady Hendrix's earlier My Best Friend's Exorcism and/or the movies that served as inspiration, The Final Girl Support Group is a hat tip toward, and light commentary on, our obsession with slasher flicks. Let's break it down.Grady Hendrix's book is based on the question: "what if the female survivors from several of the most popular horror/slasher flicks live in the same reality together, and have collectively started a support group to manage the trauma of living beyond the horrors in their movies? Also, what if all of their horrors were turned into movies in this reality too?" Our narrator is Lynnette, a middle aged (all of the women are middle aged because the book takes place in 2010 and the horrors of each character took place approximately when their inspo movies were released in the 70s/80s/90s) woman who survived a Christmas-themed murder spree (aka the movie Silent Night, Deadly Night). The book slowly introduces each of the other women in the support group: Adrienne (Friday the 13th), Dani (Halloween), Julia (Scream), Marilyn (Texas Chainsaw Massacre), and Heather (Nightmare on Elm Street). They also briefly mention someone named Chrissy who "betrayed" the group and whose trauma, in this reality, was adapted into movies called Gnomecoming. Unlike all the other women, I'm not sure which real-life movie Gnomecoming is based on. Leprechaun? I googled it and the masses aren't in agreement. There are a lot of ideas: a combination of Prom and Trolls 2, perhaps? Who knows. Moving on. The women are all very different from one another, especially with how they've managed their trauma: a paranoid, an addict, an advocate, an armor-yourself-with-millions-of-dollars type, a contemplative introvert, and an insists-on-being-normal type. When we meet them they started this group 15+ years ago, and some of them are itching to move on from the events that seek to define them. But then, like any good horror movie, the bad guys seem to rise from the dead...It's an easy/campy read that was great for a plane ride. Grady Hendrix makes a few weak attempts to comment on slasher movies, our obsession with them, and what that obsession says about how we value life; particularly the lives of women. But those attempts fall quite short, especially when they're coming out of the mouths of deranged characters. If anything, these attempts felt more like the rantings at the end of particularly meta slash movies, just not as good. That is, this book points to our obsession with violence and fame and then blazes on through anyway, completely ignoring any contradictions in its wake. If you're a horror/slasher buff, this book is definitely fun, but you aren't going to bend any brain cells getting through it.Also, I just need to say I am very confused by his inclusion of Nightmare on Elm Street. There are so many slasher movies out there but Nightmare on Elm Street, at least to me, is pure horror. And to introduce something so blatantly supernatural and hardly do anything with that was weird and disappointing. If there's gonna be magic in this world, give us magic. Don't talk about "The Night King" and barely even give us a taste! You could have chosen Saw or The Strangers, Hostel... I could go on. Hell, he could have even tapped into the grand universe of Stephen King. Carrie, Cujo, or Christine would all have been far more believable supernatural occurrences than Freddy Krueger. What if he had used The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon??? That would have been amazing. But I guess that's a book not a movie. Sigh. I wonder if he chose Krueger because he was picturing a television series based on this book (that's happening, you know)? Both of Hendrix's books have read to me like he was thinking about seeing his work on the screen as he was writing. But we're on a tangent now, and we have things to do. Read this book, or don't. Live you life. Ok bye. ...more

title: Born to Run: A Hidden Tribe, Superathletes, and the Greatest Race the World Has Never Seen
author: McDougall, Christopher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In Born to Run, Christopher McDougall tells a rambling story with passion and heart... and some dubious science thrown in for a good measure.Do you liIn Born to Run, Christopher McDougall tells a rambling story with passion and heart... and some dubious science thrown in for a good measure.Do you like disjointed stories? Too bad, because McDougall's book jumps from topic-to-topic with frustrating frequency. Wait! Don't go! That might sound annoying (and sometimes it was), but McDougall holds it together. It's like a friend telling a long story over a beer. Sometimes they get side-tracked by context/backstory, but the tale always comes around. The main through line in this narrative is a man known as Caballo Blanco. You see, the impetus of Born to Run came when McDougall was nursing a string of running injuries. He refused to quit the sport, despite doctor recommendations, so he went looking for something revolutionary. That's when he heard about the Tarahumara and their culture of running. Caballo Blanco promised to be the key to getting an introduction to any Tarahumara and the secrets they may have.Along this journey we learn about McDougall's relationship with running, about popular theories on why people run, about evolution, about several ultra-races and the athletes who compete in them, and receive a overview of the Tarahumara themselves. It's all interesting, but you'll be deep into a nail-biting race and then McDougall breaks in the middle with a random chapter on sneakers. DUDE. WHY. But that just goes to show what an engaging story McDougall weaves: I was so invested in that race story I didn't want to be torn away.Back to those sneakers... that's where we get to the dubious science of this book. Though it really only comprises 2 chapters, McDougall does veer into some weird-and-sometimes-contradictory territory on what runners should and should not be doing. He seems to be really into the barefoot running movement, and subscribes to the hypothesis that humans evolved to be able to rundown / exhaust their prey in order to obtain meat. He then also tells us we should all be vegetarians (which, as a vegetarian + some fish my husband catches person myself, didn't offend me at all. It just gave me a bit of whiplash to be told "we run for meat because meat is life" and then "but if you want to be a runner don't eat it"). He also essentially suggests that running can cure every disease ever. It can't, but as someone who also loves running, I assume that wild assertion was written shortly after a run when his brain was shorting out on endorphins (wait, I just Googled it. Make that endocannabinoids).McDougall also got a BIT sexist about poor Ann Trason, because she was allegedly a little rude to the Tarahumara at Leadsville '94. Listen, Trason had been hearing misogynistic bullshit about the Tarahumara for weeks. Was it all fabricated by the odious, fame-seeking Rick Fisher? Yes. But she didn't know that! So she quipped at them "how does it feel to compete with a woman?" Big whoop. Let's leave the snide comments aside, eh? You have no idea what it's like to be a female athlete, McDougall. I beg you to sit down.Okay, last complaint and we'll move on. In my opinion, the biggest whoops McDougall makes is talking about how running injuries have skyrocketed in recent years. He tries to suggest that new, fancy running sneakers are to blame. What proof does he have? None, save for the barefoot running preference he has. He completely ignores what seems to me to be the biggest factor: this book was written from 2006 - 2009. Running was exploding in popularity at that time. Could it be that folks were getting injured more often because there were just so many more runners lacing up and heading out for the first time? I started college in 2006 and graduated in 2010. In 2006, very few people were out there running around campus with me. By 2010, I was whipping around runners hitting the pavement with insane strides that surely ended up injuring them. That's the problem, isn't it? People going for runs without paying attention to their stride, their feet, their backs, their breath. But McDougall doesn't even consider that. He's just like "stupid sneakers go run in nothing lol." face palmI lied. One last thing: he says regular yoga practice increases injury. No study cited. I'm calling total bullshit on this. Yoga has objectively helped me. Training/recovery needs are individualistic, and this is dangerous. These are missteps, sure, but they appear to me to stem mainly from ignorance, so I forgive him. And I need to forgive him, because, at the end of the day, I really enjoyed this book. Look past these 2 wildly inaccurate chapters and its core message is incredible. It's a message McDougall lost sight of when he started jibbering on about barefoot running and cancer cures, but I took it to heart: running is about fun. It's about finding joy in moving your body, and being curious in your limits and abilities. Feel the sun on your face, the breeze in your hair. Embrace challenge. Running, above all else, should just be about your connection with your body and your mind. That looks different for everyone, which is why folks not only fall in love with different types of running, but also prefer different types of gear/sneakers/weather/elevation/etc. on their runs. And I really, really love that. I also really love many of the people McDougall introduces us to: Scott Jurek, Arnulfo Quimare, Manuel Luna, Caballo Blanco... they all sound like good-hearted people who became connected by a passion that is often enjoyed alone. I do think McDougall takes it a smidge too far when he suggests that being a runner inherently makes you a good person (look at the front few rows of people at any race and tell me they wouldn't punch you in the face if it meant crossing the finish line before you), but I get what he's trying to say: that the people he met on the journey to write this book brim with love and kindness. They deserve to be celebrated. The end of the book brought tears to my eyes, because I wanted to give everyone a big, sweaty, post-run hug. I don't think you have to be a runner to really enjoy this book. This book is more about human experience than anything else. But I would urge folks to take the science-y portions with a grain of salt. Further reading (I'd recommend not reading these until after you've completed the book, should you plan to read it):great article about Caballo Blancogreat article about Arnulfo Quimarevideo footage of Leadville '94...more

title: The Flatshare
author: O'Leary, Beth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you need a book for when your brain cannot brain, but doesn't want to be insulted that it cannot do its job; if you need a book that is going to giIf you need a book for when your brain cannot brain, but doesn't want to be insulted that it cannot do its job; if you need a book that is going to give you chick flick, but a chick flick with people who are decidedly imperfect, then I The Flatshare is the ticket. Author Beth O'Leary does brush up against some serious and dark themes (abuse, death, regret), but she's sort of looking at them side-long. We see them, but only at a glance. Not enough for it to really burrow into our brains. Because, remember, our brains CANNOT brain.Does this happen in real life? Do people SHARE BEDS with strangers in expensive cities? I live in the woods, so this feels fantastical... I certainly hope it is. Imagine going to bed and a stranger's hairs are all over fgksjgaoriapogj.Because that's the basic premise of the story: Tiffy Moore needs a very cheap place to live very quickly, so she answers an advert to share a one bedroom apartment with a night nurse. Since they have opposite schedules, and since the night nurse has a significant other to cohabitate with on the weekends, this will work out fine (how?!?!??!?!?!?). When the night nurse turns out to be a hottie man, well, all the better? I don't know, man, the hair on the pillow...To suggest I can write a real  on this book is kind of a joke. I liked Leon a lot. I liked that O'Leary was able to write distinct voices for him and for Tiffy. Tiffy is objectively a Bad Friend, but I don't have to hang out with her so its fine. ---------------------------------------------------------This week is going to be incredibly difficult. Luckily, my buddy Steph was there with a recommendation for a book that won't require much brain power, but will act as a form of escapism while traveling to, and waiting at, the hospital. Thank you, thank you, thank you....more

title: What I Talk About When I Talk About Running
author: Murakami, Haruki
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I run in order to acquire a void writes Haruki Murakami at the beginning of his slim memoir What I Talk About When I Talk About Running (permission toI run in order to acquire a void writes Haruki Murakami at the beginning of his slim memoir What I Talk About When I Talk About Running (permission to riff on Raymond Carver granted from his widow, in case you were worried).I've only read one Murakami book, The Wind-Up Bird Chronicles, and I did not particularly like it. My complaints were chiefly 1) plot holes and 2) portrayal of women. The translation, however, was beautiful. I enjoyed the lyricism of the book, even if I did not particularly enjoy the subject matter. So when I saw that Murakami wrote a memoir, and one about running (as avid runner myself), it seemed like a slam dunk. He wouldn't really be describing women (sure enough, his wife appears ~twice in the whole thing), and it's his life, so plot holes were kind of a non-issue.I'm not sure if Murakami writes nonfiction in a drastically different fashion than fiction, or if translator Philip Gabriel isn't particularly good at his job, but this book was not well-written. It's very much "this happened, then this happened," type writing, like a child writing their "What I Did This Summer" essay for their teacher.Despite that wicked burn, I want to be clear: I enjoyed this book, and I think fellow runners/triathletes would enjoy it too. I initially picked up running to acquire that void Murakami mentions, and that void continues to soothe me. Reading about someone's world melting away as the miles tick by was comforting, and reading someone's bewilderment their first time swimming in a triathlon was hilarious. I also loved this passage:Most of what I know about writing I've learned through running every day. These are practical, physical lessons. How much can I push myself. How much rest is appropriate - and how much is too much? How far can I take something and still keep it decent and consistent? When does it become narrow-minded and inflexible? How much should I be aware of the world outside, and how much should I focus on my inner world? To what extent should I be confident in my abilities, and when should I start doubting myself? Being 33 years old myself, I didn't love this passage:That's how I started running. Thirty-three - that's how old I was then. Still young enough, though no longer a *young man.* The age that Jesus Christ died. The age that Scott Fitzgerald started to go downhill. That age may be a kind of crossroads in life.No thank you, sir. But, also, weirdly, thank you. ...more

title: Lab Girl
author: Jahren, Hope*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A memoir titled Lab Girl should have included commentary on how women are treated in STEM, and how complicated it is for scientists to secure funding A memoir titled Lab Girl should have included commentary on how women are treated in STEM, and how complicated it is for scientists to secure funding and do the projects that will have the greatest good, rather than resigning themselves to projects that will receive the most money. Right? Am I crazy for expecting that?Hope Jahren's narrative coasts along the surface of her life and the work that she does, never looking to closely at any one thing. The book was predominately a series of vignettes reminiscing on the antics of Jahren and her long time lab partner, Bill. The book jacket describes Bill as her "best friend," but I beg to differ. Bill is ostensibly homeless for the majority of the book and Jahren is just like "isn't this funny?" Like, no, man, Bill can't eat. This isn't funny. This is a perfect opportunity to talk about how scientists are treated, and you missed your shot.There's also a long section about her pregnancy and her child. Why? This book was not as advertised.Sprinkled throughout were very tiny "chapters" (like, ~2 pages a pop) discussing the lives of trees. Those were interesting, but they were too few and far between and they were also quite odd. Jahren is trying to make us, the layman reader, feel guilty for the fate of the planet. It's not us - it's the massive corporations, the heads of which are not picking up your book so lay off, will you? In addition, these tiny "chapters" talk about the propagation of trees like every single seed that a tree sends out into the world is trying so hard to become a tree, and so few succeed. I'm all for anthropomorphizing, but, like, does Jahren view every single sperm as a thinking organism trying so hard to become a baby? It was just way off the mark for me.People need to stop writing memoirs just to write them. Or, more specifically, I need to stop reading memoirs. ...more

title: Madam: The Biography of Polly Adler, Icon of the Jazz Age
author: Applegate, Debby*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Debby Applegate, may the gods bless you. Madam took a mammoth amount of research to write. Applegate not only researched Polly Adler, but also the RusDebby Applegate, may the gods bless you. Madam took a mammoth amount of research to write. Applegate not only researched Polly Adler, but also the Russian village where Adler was born, New York City the place in the 1920s and 30s, the politics of Adler's world, and the biographies of many key public figures of the time, including mobsters, policemen, and musicians. I can see Applegate sitting down to write, then thinking "wait, who is the police commissioner, like, really?" Then going down a 2-day rabbit hole reading everything she can about the man, circling back to write, and having to rinse and repeat dozens and dozens of times as Adler's world unfurled before her.Writing nonfiction is so difficult. You want to paint an accurate picture, but you also have to trim the fat and fill in blanks in order to create a compelling narrative, and that's where Applegate fell short for me. I think she got so bogged down in researching everything that was going on around Polly Adler, she was so preoccupied with the framework of Polly Adler, that she sort of lost sight of Polly Adler the person. Who, you know, was the whole point of the book, or so it was billed. Part of the issue seems to be all of the secrecy and rumor surrounding Polly Adler. Adler published a memoir, sure, but can you really believe said memoir? And, if so little is definitively out there about Ms. Adler, isn't it better to just write what we know is truth?I'm gonna say no.Sorry. I think about Robert Massie's book on Catherine the Great. He took leaps and made assumptions in that book to make it a truly fantastic biography. For whatever reason, Applegate was unwilling to make leaps, or draw conclusions, and her book suffers from that reluctance. You could easily say "sources disagree, but" and give us the goods. At the end of 500 pages, I don't feel as though I know who Polly Adler was. What I do have is a rich description of what New York City was like in the 1920s and 30s. Applegate also spent a lot of time fleshing out organized crime. To a certain extent, it makes sense. Ms. Adler was dealing in an illegal business, so organized crime was going to be a factor in her life. But Applegate spent too much time talking about how this mobster hated that mobster and those mobsters tried to gun down these mobsters and just, like, who cares? There were so many names flying around who had very little to do with Polly Adler. And, again, isn't this a book about Polly Adler?I'm going to do what Applegate didn't, and draw a conclusion here. I think Applegate did so much research to ensure accuracy of time and place that she lost sight of her subject matter. She had so much detail about all these people and events from her research, that she decided to include them all, despite their only tangential relation to the point of the book she was writing. I get it: you did all that work and want to "show" that work, as it were. But the book dragged in places because of this exhaustive inclusion that rarely circled back to Polly Adler the person.This became frustrating as the book marched on, because we were spending so much time with male mobsters, but Applegate never really unpacked what I was interested in: being a woman in the 1920s dealing in prostitution where women are abused and murdered regularly. There are several scenes in Madam where Polly Adler and/or the women she employs are abused by customers, but Applegate takes the anthropological approach with these scenes. She doesn't comment on or unpack these injustices. She records them and moves on. We spend so much time learning about the powerful men in the book, and so little time learning about the women beneath, or sometimes on top, of them. Would providing that context and commentary be an impossible ask for an author? These women were, in most cases, intentionally anonymous. But we could explore what it was like to be Woman back then, and we could, again, draw conclusions to try to breathe color and life into these women who deserve to, finally, have voices. It was disappointing to get so much detail about the peripheral men in Polly Adler's life, but so little about the women surrounding her. To be fair, the final page of the book is a thunderclap of genius, speaking to what few avenues of power women had during Polly Adler's time. But that is ONE page in a 500 book, and it just demonstrates that Applegate has the writing chops to really break down Polly Adler for us, and didn't. TL;DR : meticulously researched and generally well-written but it isn't about Polly Adler so much as as snapshot of New York City in the 1920s and 30s....more

title: Braiding Sweetgrass: Indigenous Wisdom, Scientific Knowledge and the Teachings of Plants
author: Kimmerer, Robin Wall
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Robin Wall Kimmerer's Braided Sweetgrass is Walden meets Rachel Carson meets a poetry collection. It's a beautiful, thoughtful bundle of essays about Robin Wall Kimmerer's Braided Sweetgrass is Walden meets Rachel Carson meets a poetry collection. It's a beautiful, thoughtful bundle of essays about the natural world, how we should open our eyes to it, and what's at stake if we do not. It's also part indigenous folklore, and plea to recognize the indigenous people of America. My favorite part: Dr. Wall Kimmerer dissecting how we refer to natural beings such as plants. She urges us to use words that animate, to breathe the life these beings have into the words we use to describe them. It was perfection. My least favorite part: Dr. Wall Kimmerer spends a couple of chapters talking about the cedar trees on the west coast. Maybe it's because she's not from there, and so does not have the same relationship to the environment out there, but these chapters kind of plodded. Overall, though, this book is lyrical, earnest, fantastic. It'll break your heart while simultaneously slow you down so you can see and appreciate the natural world unfolding around you. Side rant: Dr. Wall Kimmerer is angry about climate change and how little regard "we" hold for the world. It's not fair, but this got under my skin. Why? Because it's not "we;" it's the giant corporations raping the world for their profits. I'm sick and tired of people telling me that I personally need to do more. I compost. I grow my own food and get my produce from a local CSA half the year while shopping in season and eating frozen produce the other half. I have an all-electric + wood burning stove house. I don't drive often, and fly once, MAYBE twice a year. I recycle, and make most of my food from scratch ... what I'm trying to say is WELCOME TO THE OLIGARCHY EAT THE RICH. ...more
