review: Consider me the carnival crier for The Song of Achilles :Come one! Come all! This book has just the ticket for what you seek! It has love, betrayal, wConsider me the carnival crier for The Song of Achilles :Come one! Come all! This book has just the ticket for what you seek! It has love, betrayal, war, loss, action, sex, and more! Sad little boys, sad old men, strong and silent women... not yet convinced? This book has angry gods, sacrifice, self-actualization, madness, grief, joy......if you still require swaying, that ol' thumper of a heart must be kaputt. There is no hope for you. Move along. There's a good carnival goer. In her acknowledgments, Madeline Miller says it took her 10 years to write The Song of Achilles. Before reading the book, I scoffed a bit. She majored in these themes in college, and the book is not a large one. 10 years?! But, at the close, I completely understand. Because Madeline Miller considered every. Single. Word. This book was so thoughtfully constructed, and it shows. Because it's perfect.Broad strokes: Our narrator is Patroclus: a neglected, sickly little prince boy, who was given to the father of Achilles for raising. Patroclus and Achilles grow close, and grow up and go to the Trojan War together.That's... that's all I'm going to say. It's weird to consider spoilers for a retelling of a Greek myth, but I had never heard the name Patroclus before opening these pages. If you are like me, I hope you know nothing else until you sit down with the book yourself.Carnival's closed. Go off and read.------------------------------------------------------------Is it detrimental to the brain be reading this book while simultaneously listening to Stephen Fry's Mythos? ...I mean... probably......more

title: The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo
author: Reid, Taylor Jenkins*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Familiar without being boring, The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo is the story of a "sexpot" (their word, not mine) 50s and 60s actress who is finally Familiar without being boring, The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo is the story of a "sexpot" (their word, not mine) 50s and 60s actress who is finally ready to tell her story in 2017, when she is old and tired and has had enough. We see her humble beginnings to arrival to Hollywood to meteoric rise to decision to step away from the spotlight.The book does a few things very well. The sexism of the film industry? Author Taylor Jenkins Reid is ON it. Evelyn Hugo grapples with that teeter-totter of using the leverage her beauty affords, without losing herself in the myth that her beauty is all that she is. That internal power struggle, and the seedy people external to Hugo who perpetuate it, were very well done. It was more depth than I ever would have expected from a fluff novel.On that depth note: Hugo's relationships are heartbreaking and, for the most part, well-written. Each of the 7 have their own unique expectations and shortcomings, baldly described, though they did become more unbelievable as the book went on. Husband #7 would just never happen, so, that was kind of annoying. I wasn't a huge fan of the narration style. Evelyn Hugo is orally retelling the story of her life to a journalist, so the sections about her life are first person. This felt like a poor choice, because no way are you going to remember the back and forth of conversations the way they're told in the pages of this book. Also, the dialogue was... not very believable (just like those latter husbands, eh? Guess there's a lot of brain suspending in this one, folks). But, whatever. Hollywood, right?Speaking of that journalist, we don't get very much at all about her as a person. So the idea that I'm supposed to care about her toward the end was a shock. Guess what? I don't. Because you didn't either, dear author. You, like most of the characters in your book, were too busy staring at Evelyn Hugo. Those complaints aside, I found this book to be a lot of fun. It's a great beach or airport read, or just something to throw at your eyes when the brain wants sleepy nightnight time. ...more

title: The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
author: Sagan, Carl
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Carl Sagan was ticked off when he wrote this book. Ticked off at the government, ticked off at our educational systems, ticked off at our children, anCarl Sagan was ticked off when he wrote this book. Ticked off at the government, ticked off at our educational systems, ticked off at our children, and ticked off at the uncurious-yet-superstitious minds of his contemporaries. So he sat down and published this series of essays (some of which he'd previously published in journals/magazines; some of which he had been workshopping with his Cornell students).I came to this book because of his chapter on witchcraft. I stayed for the sass.I transcribed some favorite passages at the bottom of this , but here's a round-up of my thoughts before we let Sagan speak for himself:1. This book should actually be called "Aliens don't care about Earth, your butt, or your crops. Also, science and education are good." Why? Because the first HALF of this book is pretty laser-focused on alien abduction and crop circles. I guess this was more popular in the mid-90s than it is in the 2020s (remember the pilot of South Park?), but, even if that's true, it was a little much to harp on alien interaction with humans so much. We get it, man, move on.2. I really, really enjoyed that passages that broke out religion vs. science, and why we should always trust science. He admonishes us for not searching for logical answers, for not using scientific method to address our questions about the universe. A bearded man in the sky, you say?! PROVE IT. I laughed out loud a few times.3. Sagan spends a bit of the book talking about the American education system. I agreed with some of what he had to say, specifically, that we should be compensating and supporting our educators in such a way that they are allotted the funds and creative license to ensure their topics are interesting to their student body. It was a fantastic look at what our government values (military) and what it doesn't (education). That said, Sagan then goes on a tirade about how American children are given too much free time and should be in school 250+ days out of the year and how they're lazy and that, my buds, rubbed me the wrong way. Free play is important too. Creative, "open" time for the mind to just do its thing is equally valuable. Geez louise. So, while there were some fantastic nuggets of in this section, it got bogged down in the weird "ALWAYS BE IN THE CLASSROOM, YOU STUPID BABIES" rhetoric.4. His unpacking of how America treats women and POC was ahead of its time. Bravo.All this to say: the parts that were great were so great I interrupted my husband from whatever he was doing to read them out loud. But there were some lengthy, clunky sections (re: Aliens and CHAIN CHILDREN TO THEIR SCHOOL DESKS) that really dragged down the central themes of the book. And what was that central theme? Be curious. Ask questions. Don't assume that what you've always known to be true is infallible. Learn. Communicate. Be a member of this society. And wow does that slap in the face of all we've been through since 2016. And now, for the book to speak for itself:I have a foreboding of an America in my children's or grandchildren's time - when the United States is a service and information economy... when awesome technological powers are in the hands of a very few, and no one representing the public interest can ever grasp the issues; when the people have lost the ability to set their own agendas or knowledgably question those in authority; when... our critical faculties in decline, unable to distinguish between what feels good and what's true, we slide, almost without noticing, back into superstition and darkness. The American system of jurisprudence recognizes a wide range of factors, predispositions, prejudices, and experiences that might cloud our judgment, or affect our objectivity - sometimes even without our knowing it. It goes to great, perhaps even extravagant, lengths to safeguard the process of judgment in a criminal trial from the human weaknesses of those who must decide on innocence or guilt. Even then, of course, the process sometimes fails. Why would we settle for anything less when interrogating the natural world, or when attempting to decide on vital matters of politics, economics, religion, and ethics?In our time, with total fabrication of realistic stills, motion pictures, and videotapes technologically within reach, with television in every home, and with critical thinking in decline, restructuring societal memories even without much attention from the secret police seems possible. What I'm imagining here is not that each of us has a budget of memories implanted in special therapeutic sessions by state-appointed psychiatrists, but rather that small numbers of people will have so much control over news stories, history books, and deeply affecting images as to work major changes in collective attitudes.Yes, Alden Capital, Facebook, and the Kochs, Carl Sagan saw you. The question is: will anyone else?...more

title: The Stone Sky        (The Broken Earth, #3)
author: Jemisin, N.K.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those as-I-wrote-it-I-lobbed-off-a-star s. Why? Because the ending is strong, and so I was like "wow! 4 stars!" But as I recappedThis is one of those as-I-wrote-it-I-lobbed-off-a-star s. Why? Because the ending is strong, and so I was like "wow! 4 stars!" But as I recapped my feelings and the book as a whole I realized: "wow, no."Here's where The Stone Sky falls short:Our main characters are just stuck in these anger ruts. They're kicking rocks, all pissed off, and after 2 whole books of that, I wanted more characterization. I think N.K. Jemisin was done with this shit and wanted to move on, and so did her characters, apparently. We were given another narrative in this third and final installment. However, unlike the unique lenses that were introduced in The Obelisk Gate, this new perspective did not provide much insight into anything at all. It gave us an answer to a big "how," but that answer could have been an email.I praised books 1 & 2 for their stark, no-nonsense narration. Jemisin isn't a flowery writer, so she's not going to fake it. I dug that. She isn't flowery in book #3, either, but she is trying to unpack the methodology behind all the magic-y, sci-fi-y stuff in her world and it. Is. Clunky. And boring! And, because she isn't a descriptive writer, it actually brings up more questions than it answers.Despite these complaints, The Stone Sky was still a solid conclusion to an otherwise pretty great trilogy. And, again, she did end the book strongly. We need books like this, that provide no-bullshit commentary on human selfishness and greed and, I mean, look around you. It's what we're living. Here's a favorite passage:But then they wanted more magic than just what their own lives, or the accumulated aeons of life and death of the Earth's surface, could provide. And when they saw how much magic brimmed just beneath that surface, ripe for the taking......more

title: Mythos
author: Fry, Stephen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am listening to the audible version (read by Stephen Fry himself) on my runs... so this'll take me, oh, I don't know, a year to finish??--After 9 moI am listening to the audible version (read by Stephen Fry himself) on my runs... so this'll take me, oh, I don't know, a year to finish??--After 9 months, I have finished listening to Mythos. It was, indeed, a great running companion.I knew many Greek myths vaguely; Stephen Fry takes a couple dozen of these stories and tells them in a way that is fluid. We have recurring characters who fight and love and live together. Origin stories such as why the bee has a stinger or why we call spiders arachnids, how the Trojan war began with a golden apple, just how badass I always knew Artemis was... I feel as though this book gave me a wealth of cultural knowledge.It's important to note that Fry takes liberties in his book - he even addresses as much at the close. But, as he states, these are oral stories that have been passed down for a millennia; they've changed a bit with each retelling. I prefer that he pick his preferred interpretation than bog us down with "some say this, others say that, others still say this other thing." He does skirt into that from time to time, but mostly when we're talking about etymology, and I'm down for nerding out about words. It gets a little silly at times, but thus is Stephen Fry. He's keeping the whimsy even while torture one another.Any interest in learning more about Greek gods, but in a light, funny way? I really don't think there's a better book out there. ...more

title: The Obelisk Gate        (The Broken Earth, #2)
author: Jemisin, N.K.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Still yes.I went into The Obelisk Gate with pretty tepid expectations. It's the second installment of a trilogy, you know? Most books that fall into tStill yes.I went into The Obelisk Gate with pretty tepid expectations. It's the second installment of a trilogy, you know? Most books that fall into that category are sort of... well... filler. The author is trying to bridge the gap between the set up of the first book and the climax of the third book, and so #2 falls a little flat. N.K. Jemisin deftly stepped around this issue because:1. The fractured timeline in the first book left plenty to unpack in installment #2.2. She added two new voices to steer different chapters, fleshing out the world and introducing fresh characters, personalities, and conflicts.Unlike book #1, book #2 is far more laser-focused. Jemisin is getting to the meat of Seasons, what this world once was, and what it could be in the future. She also gets into the weeds on what orogeny is. This could have been tedious and boring, but Jemisin's blunt writing style means that we aren't getting bogged down in flowery bullshit about a made-up thing. Jemisin also doesn't try to ground her explanations in reality. We're dealing with magic, with nature, with Father Earth. We can explain without trying to ground those explanations in reality. Let magic be magic, you know? I dig that.Her main characters are chaotic good. They try to do the right thing, but they are also looking out for themselves and will make tough decisions. They are flawed. They are brilliant. They are tired and angry. They are persistent. They are women. ...more

title: Basic Writings of Nietzsche
author: Nietzsche, Friedrich
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I decided reading a bit of Nietzsche on the side when my brain felt like firing would be fun... because I hate myself.---------------------------I losI decided reading a bit of Nietzsche on the side when my brain felt like firing would be fun... because I hate myself.---------------------------I lost steam with this book, and it took me a while to limp through it. And maybe Nietzsche didn't deserve that. Nietzsche was a fascinating man who was brave enough to think critically about the people and the societal structures around him. For that reason, I think he should be read and understood. His nuggets on religion electrified me. The concept that what is "moral," "good," or "right" has been defined by the elite and is not reflective of the populous? Genius. His urging that man seek his pleasure and purpose is something we still haven't fully realized.But, on the other hand, maybe Nietzsche did deserve my reluctant limping. Because therein lies the problem: his urging that MAN seek HIS pleasure. Nietzsche can be as sexist little shit. And yeah, ok, a victim of his time or whatever, but I found myself rolling my eyes at him sometimes, and it made working through his works somewhat arduous. Take this from Beyond Good and Evil:Woman has much reason for shame; so much pedantry, superficiality, schoolmarmishness, petty presumption, petty licentiousness and immodesty lies concealed in woman-one only needs to study her behavior with children!-and so far all this was at bottom best repressed and kept under control by fear of man. Woe when "the eternally boring in woman" -she is rich in that!- is permitted to venture forth!JFC, Nietzsche. What were you, the OG incel? Despite this, there are some great quotes. A couple of favorites:Nothing has been exercised and cultivated better and longer among men so far than obedience."I have done that," says my memory. "I cannot have done that," says my pride, and remains inexorable. Eventually-memory yields.Christianity has been the most calamitous kind of arrogance yet.The Christian resolve to find the world ugly and bad has made the world ugly and bad.  PS. I completely skipped The Case of Wagner. Oops/oh well/sorry not sorry....more

title: Barbarian Days: A Surfing Life
author: Finnegan, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A Pulitzer? Really?Barbarian Days is an entertaining memoir about William Finnegan, a white man who was born in 1952. The book starts out when he is iA Pulitzer? Really?Barbarian Days is an entertaining memoir about William Finnegan, a white man who was born in 1952. The book starts out when he is in 8th grade, and he and his family has moved from California to Hawaii. He doesn't fit in, save for in the water. And that's that. We follow him from 1966 through 2014, as he chases those waves that feel like home. Barbarian Days is, above all else, a book about surfing... and that's kind of what bothered me? That sounds insane, I know. It's right there in the byline: "A Surfing Life." But it's how Finnegan presented the rest of his world around his surfing obsession that really grinds my gears.William Finnegan traveled the entire world on a shoestring budget looking for the perfect wave. This is a thing only a privileged Boomer White Man could do... and Finnegan doesn't acknowledge this or unpack this once in 447 pages. He tells "funny" anecdotes about how he shows up on doorsteps in far flung places, where the people give him and his surfing buddy Bryan food and shelter in exchange for... nothing? He mentions giving someone a glass plate once? I don't know, man, but they are full-on taking advantage of these people and their hospitality and Finnegan doesn't acknowledge that. He's just like "and then we slept in our nice, Western manufactured mosquito nets after we ate all their food LOL." Yikes.He regales us with this time they canoed out to a remote island but he and Bryan couldn't fish for shit, so the locals who canoed them out there fish for them. Like, bitch, why are you even out here?!?! Stop making these people take care of you!! What is this, a trip for babies?!?!?Ahem.One of the excerpts I hated the most went as follows:Gene was pushing sixty. His girlfriend was a knockout but not happy. I overheard her telling the wife of a Parker executive that she was a half-Fijian orphan, and therefore a social outcast in the homogenous Tong. She had turned to prostitution, she said. She was now desperate to get away from Gene. "Help me! Help me!" she pleaded.The executive's wife looked stricken. I couldn't hear what she said to the girl, but I was standing there when she approached Gene. She timidly tried to make conversation, mentioning that she had heard that his young friend was half-Fijian.Gene snarled, "I don't care what she told you, honey, she's a n****r." [my censure]Brad came by that night on his horse. I asked him if the police could be trusted to enforce the law against Parker Oil's employees. He gave me a long, thoughtful look, and then shook his head. "They're with the king," he said. Gene's desperate girlfriend would be the one arrested it charges were laid. And then he changes the subject to Brad and that's the last we hear of this.It's almost as if he's acting as an anthropologist, all "I can look but I can't get involved." Like, bitch, what? HELP THIS GIRL. You have SO MUCH power, demonstrated by all the preceding pages where you blatantly took advantage of the kindness of others. God forbid you pay it forward and help a teenage prostitute being raped by a 60 year old white man?!?! Or, at the very least, now that you've had time to reflect, write an extra paragraph about how your lack of action was shameful??? But, no, you just drop the interaction here and wander away. And he does this several times over the course of the book. You know what this tells me? That he hasn't grown or changed from the 20-something selfish asshole he was then. He jokingly recalls how shit he was to women and to his family, and how all he cared about was the surf. He eventually heads back to the states and does just fine, because he's a White Man Boomer, but he also doesn't unpack THAT, even though he published the book in 2015. Because, say it with me now: selfish asshole. Here's what I have to say: William Finnegan can write, and he's got a fantastic memory (it also helps that he and the people around him journaled and kept all the letters they wrote to one another). But he's incapable of real reflection. Even at the end, where he's still surfing even though he's old and he's got a kid and he's near-death-ing it in the water over and over because he's all used up now on the surfboard. Why did you have a kid if you're still going out there smashing your body against rocks?!?! Grow the fuck up!Ugh, I'm so mad, but this book does still get 3 stars. I need help....more

title: The Plot
author: Korelitz, Jean Hanff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: That's it. I'm done with bandwagon books.I compared this book to The Girl on a Train several times during the (blissfully short) course of reading thiThat's it. I'm done with bandwagon books.I compared this book to The Girl on a Train several times during the (blissfully short) course of reading this mediocre bundle of pages. Because it sucks, and The Girl on a Train sucks too.And, let's be clear, that's not exactly fair. Unlike Paula Hawkins, Jean Hanff Korelitz can actually write decent prose. Unfortunately, a rose-scented turd is still, you know, a turd.To everyone who wants to write a mystery:1. You need to have several characters. Otherwise we all know whodunnit instantly. It's called deduction. Hasn't anyone read Agatha Christie?!?!2. If hints are going to be in the protagonist's own book that he wrote, WHY DOESN'T HE KNOW HIS OWN BOOK?!?! I'm sitting over here, knowing the twist since PAGE 80, and he's over here on PAGE 280 going "oooohhhhhhhhhhhh, THAT'S what's going on." YOU LITERALLY SAID IT WAS IN YOUR BOOK. WHAT ARE YOU TALKING ABOUT. This is a library book, so I didn't chuck it across the room. But bboooyyyy was I tempted.3. Writers just shouldn't write about writers. This doesn't pertain to mysteries, I guess, just to stories in general. But I hate the navely-gaze-y-ness of writers on writers. Remember Magpie Murders? I sure as hell try to forget about that book every. Single. Day.We all know the broad strokes of the plot of... uhh... The Plot at this point, yeah? A washed-up writer is floundering when he decides to steal a story plot. And stealing has consequences.It's tired, I knew that, but Stephen King blurbed it and that creepy madness king suckered me into snagging a copy. King, you minx, why do you do these things to me? This book was just awful in how basic it was. It's a mystery for someone who has never, ever read a mystery before. AND THE STAKES ARE SO LOW. Actually, this might be why King liked it. Because The Plot also reminds me of Lisey's Story. Was this because there's a magical, alternate reality in The Plot? Ha. No. There's not even much a reality here. Because the protagonist's actions make zero sense. None. Zilch. He wastes a ton of money and time trying to unravel who is harassing him... and to what end? And why? Jean Hanff Korelitz says it herself: you can't own an idea. So... why doesn't the protagonist just come clean to his publisher and move on with his (pretty fabulous) life? We don't know. Hanff Korelitz doesn't unpack this. I guess he's just the most fucking stupid person on the planet. And I guess I'm up there too since I stayed with this book to the end....more

title: Billy Summers
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Billy Summers is not the type of book people think of when they think about Stephen King. There is only the faintest whiff of the supernatural, and, tBilly Summers is not the type of book people think of when they think about Stephen King. There is only the faintest whiff of the supernatural, and, though there is some violence, I'd say it falls in the tame pile in the larger King canon.King's trying something different you see. He's going to tell us a story about a hitman. I liked this book for its plot. Billy Summers takes a job, and there are consequences. It's not aliens or vampires or an apocalypse or a stealer-of-faces that causes the conflict and the action. It's purely the decisions of Billy Summers. That's something quite different for King. Even in books like 11/22/63 the main character is reacting to external forces more often than not. Billy Summers has very much made his own bed.And yet.And yet the book was... just okay? I'm surprised to see those words appear on the screen, actually, because the ending was actually pretty tight, which is a shocker. Stephen King books usually unspool wwaaayyy before the final scenes. This one stayed on message. Probably because there wasn't anything for Owen King to smush an alien into.My problem is motive.There's not a lot of it.We learn a lot about Billy Summers... but we don't actually see under the curtain to his motives. What drives him. What his life is like. He just sort of... there. There's The Before. And then there's The Now. But what happened to get him from Before to Now? I have no idea.The co-star of the book (who I will not name here because minor spoiler and you're welcome) likewise not only has a thin motive... but they abandon their life because of trauma. And that part really bothered me. The trauma and the reactions of the characters to that trauma is upsetting, to put it mildly. I... I can't imagine people reacting the way Summers and this secondary character react. The entire existence of this co-star is troubling. There were better background stories to get them where King wanted them to go, and I have no idea why no one pointed any of those out to King. But, then again, who is giving King notes these days? His books sell.Ok, I'm getting salty. I guess where I fall on this whole thing is: I like King. I like his books. I like that this story didn't fall apart. But when it comes to hitman thrillers, they aren't his wheelhouse, so the story just didn't sweep me away. I prefer my King books monster-y, and prefer my hitman books King-less.(view spoiler)[ Older men and younger women? Just don't do it. A 21yr old who suffered through trauma does NOT want to fuck a hitman in his 40s. Gross. (hide spoiler)]...more

title: Beautiful World, Where Are You
author: Rooney, Sally*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is not totally clear to me what the point of this book is.You know in creative writing classes, where the teacher asks you why the reader should caIt is not totally clear to me what the point of this book is.You know in creative writing classes, where the teacher asks you why the reader should care? I'm not sure Sally Rooney asked herself this.I have a theory about this book: it's part memoir for Sally Rooney, part excerpts from her diary.This isn't a good thing.Beautiful World, Where Are You follows two friends and the unfolding of their separate lives in their late 20s. Alice wrote a smash hit book when she was younger (ahem), and had a bit of a breakdown underneath the constant scrutiny and expectations that come with wild fame at a young age. She runs from Dublin and what she's used to to a house by the sea to collect herself and return to her work. To reset. There she meets a working-class man named Felix, who is an absolute douche. He treats her like he could take her or leave her, whatever. And Alice, I guess in a reflection of her self-worth, just lets it happen. The Alice/Felix story made me feel icky. Like when you have a friend and their significant other starts to pick on them in front of you. Like, stop doing that! I'm THEIR friend. You're gross! So, that's half the book.The other half follows Eileen, still in Dublin after Alice left, still working a job that pays her nothing in an apartment she hates watching everyone else grow up and move on while she's feeling uncomfortably stagnant. She recently got out of a serious, live-in relationship, and doesn't know where to turn. So she turns to her childhood-friend-and-sometimes-fuck-buddy Simon. Rooney makes Simon religious... and it's not clear why? Simon is your average man in his mid-30s, save for the fact that he goes to church every Sunday and once planned to join the church as he life's cause. But this doesn't actually add texture to the character, so why? I assume it's because Simon is based on someone very specific in her life. I have to say, I liked the Eileen/Simon storyline. What I loved about Normal People was Rooney's ability to flesh out a relationship where both people are afraid to get hurt, so they hide portions of themselves from the other. This leads to unintentional misunderstandings and, whoops irony, hurt. It's so real, and she does it so well. This, and Eileen and Alice's relationship (which we don't get enough of) is why the book gets 3 stars. To transition the reader from Alice chapters to Eileen chapters, the perspectives are broken up with mini-chapters, which are supposed to be emails sent between the two women. These were straight up diary entries of Rooney's that she just slapped into the book. How could they not be? They are rants about climate change, religion, babies, politics, philosophy. They're the debates you hear in a college cafeteria. They were exhausting, and, I'm sorry, not how friends write to each other. They were speeches. They were life view proclamations. It was so cringey at times I had to skim them. Also, none of them were revolutionary. They were the views most people between the ages of 20-35 have on the world. So... why? (so asks the creative writing TA inside me). To fill up a page requirement? We may never know. TL;DR - if you like Rooney, sure, read it. But this book fell very short of the raw desperation of Normal PeopleA friend lent me this book, and had one page dog-eared. The below is from that page, which may be one of the best pages in the whole book (yes, I'm likely biased because I received a signal this was important to someone I love, but ah, well, aren't we all?):I just want everything to be like it was, and for us to be young again and live near each other and nothing to be different.and, later in this same scene:If you weren't my friend I wouldn't know who I was.We need more stories about friendship.(view spoiler)[one more thing: there was that rant about bringing children into this world at the beginning of the book. Then, at the end, Eileen is pregnant and excited about it. Okay, fine, people's minds change, especially in the face of an unplanned pregnancy. But Rooney didn't stop there, she was all: I could not stomach the idea of having an abortion just because I'm afraid of climate change. For me (and maybe only for me) it would be a sort of sick, insane thing to do, a way of mutilating my real life as a gesture of submission to an imagined future. I don't want to belong to a political movement that makes me view my own body with suspicion and terror. No matter what we think or fear about the future of civilisation, women all over the world will go on having babies, and I belong with them, and any child I might have belongs with their children... I feel it, and I know it to be true."  Say it with me, say it loud, say it proud: fuck you, Sally Rooney! (hide spoiler)]...more

title: The Fifth Season        (The Broken Earth, #1)
author: Jemisin, N.K.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Yes.This is going to be vague, and I'm not sorry. There are a lot of reveals in this book. And, yes, a lot of those reveals are kinda sorta obvious, bYes.This is going to be vague, and I'm not sorry. There are a lot of reveals in this book. And, yes, a lot of those reveals are kinda sorta obvious, but it's more fun if you don't get a hint before you even turn the first page. Here's what I WILL say: N.K. Jemisin is great at writing unique voices. There are many characters here, and they have different personalities. A lot of books, especially sweeping epics, suffer from sameness of dialogue across their main players. Not so. N.J. Jeminsin's mind contains multitudes.Can get get a hearty HEAR HEAR for nonlinear stories/fractured timelines. I really, really can't get enough of that shit.Okay, so The Fifth Season is a story following Damaya, Syenite, and Essun. They are connected to the Earth in a very cool, very sci-fi-y way. Their world is being torn apart by some sort of ongoing climate crisis that hits every now again... there could have 1,000 years of peace... and then a fifth season hits that wipes out countless people. It's something that is constantly hanging over the heads of everyone alive. Will this be the year of a Fifth Season? Will they be spared, killed instantly, or forced to roam to try and start anew? Damaya, Syenite, and Essun are just trying to survive. They're trying to live. They're trying......but now we're getting ahead of ourselves, aren't we?This is everything I scream about when reading sci-fi/fantasy. The breaking of gender norms. Strength across the board. Drives that are utterly independent from interpersonal relationships.I.Loved.This.Book. [my one complaint is that Jemisin utilizes the present tense for the bulk of this book... but every now and again she forgets, because it's an unusual choice. It is VERY jarring when there's a rando tense shift. Another (minor) complaint is the simplicity of the narrative. It's not fair, but your girl loves a flowery passage. Jemisin is a utilitarian writer. Not a bad thing, but, again, a bit jarring.]...more

review: In her final installment of The Winternight Trilogy Katherine Arden did everything I hoped she would. Arden did not betray main character Vasya in ordIn her final installment of The Winternight Trilogy Katherine Arden did everything I hoped she would. Arden did not betray main character Vasya in order to fit her into specific tropes. Since Arden already had buy-in from her readers at this point, she also went harder into the broader historical framework of this story: battles and people and events that truly did happen in medieval Russia are peppered in The Winter of the Witch. Arden also really went for the jugular with Christianity which I. Was. HERE. For.Look, how am I supposed to express my feelings toward this trilogy without giving anything away? Suffice to say Arden put her degree to work. She weaved historical events with folklore for a fresh fantasy trilogy with a fiercely independent woman at the center of it all. This is what fantasy is supposed to be. YOU HEAR ME, ROTHFUSS AND SANDERSON?! GO KICK ROCKS!Ahem.Seriously, though. title: Song of Solomon
author: Morrison, Toni
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Toni Morrison's Song of Solomon is the tale of the Dead family. This last name, given to them by a drunken white man who was registering freed slaves,Toni Morrison's Song of Solomon is the tale of the Dead family. This last name, given to them by a drunken white man who was registering freed slaves, is just one of the many peculiarities of the family. The mother, Ruth, is a lonely, loved-starved woman who accepts affection wherever it comes from, however improper. The father, Macon Dead Jr, is constantly struggling to be rich enough and powerful enough to protect his family from the world around them. Aunt Pilate is a force of nature who, despite all she's survived, crumples under the mention of her late father. And then there's Macon Dead III called "Milkman," a spoiled young man who straddles the world of social injustice and revolution, while also remaining partially shielded by his family's wealth and love. It's a Bildingsroman, but one quite different than those that came before. Milkman searches past, present, and future, to try and scratch the itch of indifference that has settled over his entire life. I enjoyed it, though that the hunting scene went on 5ever and I wasn't about it. Look, I understand that it represents this pivotal shift in Milkman as he lands on who he wants to be but that didn't make it any less boring and ANYWAYS. All that's left to say is: sing. ...more

title: A Thousand Ships
author: Haynes, Natalie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's nothing new to take a classic and reform its structure to tell the story of Woman. Wide Sargasso Sea may be the most famous example; Circe might It's nothing new to take a classic and reform its structure to tell the story of Woman. Wide Sargasso Sea may be the most famous example; Circe might be the closest to Haynes' work here in A Thousand Ships (and may be why Haynes avoided telling the sorceress' story). It's familiarity is part of its charm; I loved this book from the start.We begin at the end: with the fall of Troy. It's a story almost all of us know: the Trojans brought a wooden horse into the walls of their city, the horse was full of Greeks, the Greeks climbed out in the night and burned the city to the ground from the inside. Now, though, we see this through the eyes of a woman waking in the night, trying to make sense of what is happening, and what has become of her son and husband. That's much of this book: women thinking after sons and husbands. Their anger, their grief... their very lives are so often overlooked when we tell stories of war. Not here. We hear from royalty, from deities and goddesses, from slaves, and from the ever-patient wife of Odysseus, Penelope. Calliope is hilarious, Penelope is exasperated, Hecabe stoically breaks apart, Cassandra is silently, miserably, mad. Some women get several chapters, while others get a mere page, but all of it is powerful and well done. All of these women have a story to tell; I thank Haynes for giving them voices in a tale so well-trodden by men....more

title: Firefly Lane        (Firefly Lane, #1)
author: Hannah, Kristin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's true what they say, that your reception of a particular book is predicated on the environment in which it is read. I finished this book the nightIt's true what they say, that your reception of a particular book is predicated on the environment in which it is read. I finished this book the night of Thursday, September 9. I had spent the past week at a friend's lakehouse. And this book? It's the perfect lakehouse read. You can put it down mid-sentence, which I often did, and jump right back in hours later. It's not well-written, the plot goes down easy... it's perfect fluff. So, after turning the final page (and reading the admittedly powerful afterword) I powered up my phone and gave it a whopping 3 stars.This book so doesn't deserve that. Hence the 2-star rating you see before you. I needed time away from a lake to realize:This book is not good.BUT. This book is a perfect half-listening read... if you're picking up what I'm putting down.Firefly Lane follows two women from 14yrs old through to their mid-4os. These women are about the age of Kristin Hannah herself, and, basking in the nostalgia of her youth, Hannah beats us over the head with cultural references. It really dragged down the book. It's one thing to mention, say, Pogs in passing (a cultural touchstone of my 90s youth). It's a totally different thing to spend paragraphs talking about the clothing and the soft drinks and the music on the radio. Wwaayyy too heavy-handed. Waayyy too clunky. It made me wonder if Hannah had a television show deal in mind all along, thinking to herself "and now Goodbye Yellow Brick Road swells in the background" or "the camera pans on the bell bottoms/halter top/70s-tastic hair combo I've just described in mind-numbing detail". The two women of the book, Kate and Tully, represent two starkly different paths a cis-gendered woman can take: family, or power. Hannah has loudly taken a side as to which path she thinks is better.Also, despite spending almost 500 pages with these characters... they somehow still boiled down to their lowest common denominators of loving men and loving nostalgia. Not a great look.I could keep shitting on the book, but I won't. Because, despite everything I said above, it is still readable and entertaining... in a certain setting. Kate and Tully don't shatter any ceilings, but they're a perfectly acceptable way to pass the time. Am I making any sense? I'm not sure. This certainly wasn't what I was expecting after having read The Nightingale but it didn't suck. Does that... help? I'm just talking in circles now, aren't I?I know, I know, I said I'd stop shitting on it. But I can't help myself. Here were the worst parts of the book:Then he left her there, standing alone, surrounded by word ghostsWHAT?!?! The turn-of-phrase "surrounded by the ghosts of words left unsaid" is something I've DEFINITELY read before... but Hannah goes with "word ghosts." Is that the worst thing I've ever read? I honestly don't know. Twenty-five-year-old college-educated women were expected to dream of more money and higher positions on the corporate ladder and running the very companies that had refused to hire their mothers. Husbands were to be avoided in the pre-thirty years. There was always time for marriage and children; was the common refrain. You don't give up YOU for THEM. But what if you wanted THEM more than you wanted a singular, powerful you? No one ever talked about that.I don't agree with this. Women contemporary to this character don't feel this way (I asked aunts and in-laws and the parents of close friends). So wtf is Hannah talking about? This smacks of anti-feminism, if I'm being honest. Are you starting to get a feel for which path Hannah likes better? It could have been a lonely time - after all, who wanted to see the sights of a magical city like New York alone?Plenty of people. New York is a great city to explore alone. Being alone is a perfectly acceptable way to live a fulfilling life. Stop projecting loneliness onto everyone who is alone. Jesus fucking Christ. ...more

title: Chilling Adventures of Sabrina #1
author: Aguirre-Sacasa, Roberto
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sabrina the Teenage Witch started out as a pithy teen navigating life and love as a 1960s witch. She later became a 1970s cartoon (pretty unwatchable,Sabrina the Teenage Witch started out as a pithy teen navigating life and love as a 1960s witch. She later became a 1970s cartoon (pretty unwatchable, IMO), a hit, live-action television show, a cartoon again, a comic again... basically, she keeps getting resurrected over and over because who doesn't love a blonde who can't get her spells quite right?...That last bit was supposed to be sardonic. Did it convey?As a child of the 90s, the live-action television show was my first foray into the world of Sabrina Spellman. Half-witch, half-mortal, she tried to straddle both worlds, however imperfectly and full of pineapples that trying was. It was fun, but it hardly resembled what witches were purported to do, historically speaking. It had fewer teeth than The Muensters or The Addams Family.To wrassle that sweet, sweet nostalgia, I started watching the 2018 Netflix reboot, The Chilling Adventures of Sabrina. Watching it I thought to myself "huh, this is dark AF. I'm digging it... but this so is not what the creators had in mind... was it?"So I went back to the comics of the 1960s and, no, Chilling Adventures is something utterly its own in the hall of Sabrinas. It's real and gritty and dark and... good. After getting properly hooked on the show, I decided to double-back to its namesake, the comics that started coming out way back in 2014.And, holy hell, this first addition is pretty good. Sabrina's aunts aren't just there as comedy - they have their own, dark drives. And Sabrina's dad is... well... let's just say he's not the benevolent advice giver who lives in a book like I'm used to. Bloody, occult-y, and full of fun, historical Easter eggs, (penises turned into birds is a REAL THING witches were accused of in medieval times, FYI. So was cannibalism, which is how the witches eat, it seems), I recommend these comics indeed. ...more

For the wound of what happened yesterday to scab over....But what if it gets worse?You know whDon't read this right now.Give it... a couple of years? For the wound of what happened yesterday to scab over....But what if it gets worse?You know what? Eff it. Read this book. Right now. Get angry.Sex and the Constitution, a book about our laws and how they've been interpreted to both oppress and liberate us, was published in early 2017.That was before Kavanaugh.That was before Coney Barrett.That was before September 1, 2021, when Texas effectively banned all abortions. Geoffrey Stone worked incredibly hard to pull together a book like this. One that begins in Ancient Greece and Rome, and then hovers over the 1970s - present day. He's here to tell us how we got where we're going; how fragile our rights are. He backs up his opinions in the few places where his opinions come through (he's a lawyer through-and-through, after all), then backs up those sources with more sources. He talks us through laws on obscenity, women's rights, sodomy, abortion rights, and LGBTQ+ rights.I devoured this book, and I didn't think I would. I figured some of it would be dull/outside my scope of interest. I was wrong. I also, shockingly, cried when I finished reading it last night. Why? Because we've taken so many steps backwards since this book was published 4 very long years ago. Stone was tentatively hopeful that we wouldn't land where we are today.So get angry.Get up. title: Gulp: Adventures on the Alimentary Canal
author: Roach, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Mary Roach was the darling of pop science writing before it became as popular as it is today. I've read a few of her books (I still think Stiff is fanMary Roach was the darling of pop science writing before it became as popular as it is today. I've read a few of her books (I still think Stiff is fantastic and should be read by all), and so decided to re-dip a toe into her world.I don't know if I got older, or she got worse, but I didn't enjoy this one as much as I had hoped.The first few chapters I loved. Did you know that a penguin can store fish in their stomachs for days as they walk back to their family? This is so they can regurgitate those same fish to feed the crew. Fascinating. How we and pets smell and taste? Also fascinating. I really, really enjoyed these chapters.As we traveled down the body canal, however, my interest began to wane. She spent far more time on farts and poop than on eating/digesting/sensing, and that was kind of a bummer for me. I don't know if she ran out of material or if she just loves poop, but these chapters were kind of boring and also somehow a bit repetitive. The thing that really didn't work for me, however, was all her snarky remarks about the experts she consulted with over the course of writing this book. Why? Why comment on the physical appearance of every single person you met? Is it vanity? Is it cruelty? It adds absolutely nothing to the narrative, so it has to be a defect with Roach... I just can't figure out what it is. It's like the mean girls I distanced myself from in high school: once you have to have a neg for every single person, you stop being someone I want to spend time with. So, too, am I done reading Mary Roach. ...more

title: She Who Became the Sun        (The Radiant Emperor, #1)
author: Parker-Chan, Shelley*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Hey, hello, everyone writing fantasy?This is what fantasy should be.GTFO of here, Sanderson.Shelley Parker-Chan created a rich, beautiful world in thiHey, hello, everyone writing fantasy?This is what fantasy should be.GTFO of here, Sanderson.Shelley Parker-Chan created a rich, beautiful world in this first installment of her Radiant Emperor trilogy. Okay, yeah, there are really only 2 women in the whole book, which is kind of a bummer (though #3, Madam Zhang, is a badass; I'm really hoping we get more of her in the subsequent books). That said, our main character is Zhu Chongba, a young woman who assumed her brother's identity after he died when they were children. Zhu is seeking her destiny: to be great, and to not be the nothing that being a young woman in the 1300s would have otherwise dictated. Zhu Chongba is great. She tries so hard to remove herself from humanity because she doesn't understand it and finds it hard and cruel and just a tool for her to get to her destiny. At the same time, those who love her are trying to pull her into the full technicolor that life can be. Zhu's counterpart is Ouyang, a eunuch Mongol general whose entire family was slaughtered by the father of the man who he now serves. Ouyang is also seeking his destiny: to avenge his ancestors, whose bloodline was unceremoniously cut-off. Ouyang feels even though he desperately doesn't want to; a poignant opposite to how Zhu feels the world around her. I love them both. They are both flawed and hell-bent on a murky purpose to the point that the rest of their vision is fogged in. This book is a just the first installment of what appears to be a sweeping epic. I look forward to the sequel, and will be thinking of Zhu and Ouyang often in the interim....more

title: Swimming To Antarctica: Tales of a Long-Distance Swimmer
author: Cox, Lynne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The fact that Lynne Cox is not a household name is because our society is broken. We failed her. Even my mother and mother-in-law, who are about the sThe fact that Lynne Cox is not a household name is because our society is broken. We failed her. Even my mother and mother-in-law, who are about the same age as her, could hardly remember who she is and what she accomplished. Society doesn't value female athletes, and it doesn't value females who don't fit their very narrow and damaging vision of what constitutes "beautiful." It's a sin. Lynn Cox deserves better.That makes this book all the more remarkable. Despite a lack of support, Cox smashed world records and successfully completed several swims no one had even attempted before. Despite a lack of recognition, her book resonates with a humble poise, and an awe for the natural world. This book was written in 2004. Most of the swims she chronicles happened before 1992. A lot of people could have grown bitter over those intervening years. Not Cox. She is grateful for what her body can do, what the world has shown her, and the love, joy, and acceptance she received from all the random "little people" she met during her adventures.What do I mean by "little people?" I mean the every man, the folks who heard what she was attempting and opened their homes, who waited on the shore with slippers, who cheered her on as she cut through water temperatures as low as 32(?!?!?!) degrees. Because Cox received basically no support from corporations or folks who actually had money to throw around. If she had been a man, I guaran-fucking-tee she would have been sponsored up the wazoo. As it was, she emptied her bank account multiple times because she had conviction. She felt what she was doing was important to demonstrating the capabilities of the human body and spirit. If I had been in her shoes, I know I would have given up. At certain times she had a mere handful of people believing in her, but she pushed through. She lived with her parents and worked odd jobs to fund her swims. Corporate America should be ashamed.I'm gonna throw more shade on Corporate America. The most exciting/interesting/incredible part of the book is when she chronicles her Bering Strait swim. After 11yrs of attempting to get permission from both the US and the Soviet Union, she finally resolved to complete it, with or without permission, in 1987. She had a very modest sponsorship from Alaskan Airlines, but other than that no one was willing to help her financially. She was going to attempt a swim in 38 degree water while the iron curtain was still down and the Berlin wall still stood and not a single American company was willing to throw her some funds. Meanwhile, the Soviet-fucking-Union spent more than $1M to facilitate her crossing. THAT'S RIGHT. In the Soviet Union vs. USA tensions, this point goes to the Soviet Union. Just wild. Greedy, stingy, sexist corporate America strikes again! Eat the rich/welcome to the oligarchy/etc./etc.Lynne Cox is an American hero. Her name should be more well known than someone like Tom Brady. What has Tom Brady even really done? Thrown a lil toy to some friends who ran with that toy? Lynne Cox swam in icy waters to bridge a literal and metaphorical gap between nations. Seriously. She swam the Bering Strait on August 7, 1987. Reagan and Gorbachev met in December 1987. It has been called "The Swim That Lifted the Iron Curtain." Again, I can't believe how humble and kind her book reads for all the slights she's suffered over the years. I am furious on her behalf. For me, Lynne Cox is the pinnacle of what people can be: strong, persistent, kind, open, awe inspiring. Brava, Lynne Cox....more

Andrea Lankford provides an unflinching account of her experience and the experiences of her friends who served as National Park Rangers during the 1990s. She cautions folks to treat the natural environment with respect. She breaks down some of the horrifying things that have happened at National Parks, particularly the Grand Canyon and Yosemite NP, where she was stationed during her tenure with the agency. She's a strong writer, and her narrative style of vignettes with recurring characters was perfect. This book gets graphic. This book gets depressing. This book is both a warning and an exaltation of the natural world. It should be required reading for any/everyone before they're allowed to enter a park/begin a hiking trail. title: Lisey's Story
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Lisey's Story is the newest Stephen King book to get the adaptation treatment. What's different is that King adapted this one himself. A recent NY TimLisey's Story is the newest Stephen King book to get the adaptation treatment. What's different is that King adapted this one himself. A recent NY Times article quoted King: "I held onto [Lisey's Story], never expecting I would do anything with it. But I love this book. Ordinarily, I send them off the way you send a kid to college. You hope they do well, but you’re hands off. If they do a great job, you can say, “That was based on my material.” If not, you can say they screwed up. If you’re going to be in it, you’re going to be in it all the way. That’s a big commitment once you get to be 70."I mention this to underscore the following: Stephen King really, really likes this book. I wonder if it's due to the personal nature of the plot: A widow is attempting to come to terms with the death of her famous-writer husband. In that same NY Times article, King spoke to the inspiration of the book:"I had double pneumonia, and I was in the hospital for a long time. I was very ill, and my wife took the opportunity to redecorate my study, which was old and beat up... After I came out of the hospital, she said: “Maybe you don’t want to go in your office. You won’t like it.” Of course I went up there, and it’s in a transitional state. All the books had been packed in boxes to go back on the shelves. I was on different medications and looked around the office and thought maybe I was dead. That’s what would happen: You’d have to clean out everything after the person died."Does King see himself as the late Scott Landon? Does he see his wife Tabitha as Lisey Landon, sorting through her husband's things? He claims not, but I do not understand how this book can be one of his favorites. It's probably one of my least.So, Lisey's husband Scott has been dead for two years. She hasn't gotten around to cleaning out his stuff because it's too painful. A visit from an academic seeking to acquire the contents of Scott's study for his university, however, prompts her to speed the heck up. Oh, and also there's a crazy person. And also there's an alternate dimension.I did very much enjoy the pieces of the novel that retell Scott's childhood. Those are tight, devastating, gripping. Also, King's world building of the alternate dimension "Boo'ya Moon" is very well done. I can perfectly picture this other world, despite how fantastical it is, and I very much enjoyed those sections of the book.And yet.Because one of the central themes of this book is dealing with grief, we waffle between flashbacks and the present day. We also deal with fragmented thoughts, as grief is wont to do. This can be done well in print. Unfortunately, King doesn't quite hit the mark. There's repetition, and then there's rep.et.tit.ion. King could have illustrated a circular/obsessed/grief addled mind without filling the book with 50+ pages of repetition. It was tedious, and I would start to skim after hitting a passage that had already been repeated 3+ times. Or, how about this passage:Amanda flipped this motorist - almost certainly a man, probably wearing a baseball cap and needing a shave - a double bird, raising her fists to shoulder height and pumping the middle fingers briskly without looking around."Great technique," Lisey said. "Someday it'll get you raped and murdered."I fucking hate that passage. Then there's the main character herself. You see, nothing Lisey does makes any damn sense. I am open to suspending disbelief... but I'm not open to just shrugging off common sense. Lisey is arguably one of the stupidest characters I have ever read, and I am very, very angry with her. I'll go into it, but it'll spoil the whole dang book.(view spoiler)[For the sake of brevity, let's just talk about the biggest, stupidest thing about Lisey.Pretend you're a woman in her 60s living alone in Maine. A crazy man comes, threatens your life if you don't do X, and makes it clear that he's going to torture/kill you even if you DO do X.Which sounds like the better idea?1. Call the police, get your tight-knit community/nearby sisters to help you box up your husband's works so nothing bad befalls them, then going to live temporarily with one of your sisters until the cops arrest the madman. Make sure you're never alone, and trust in your local cops. You're a white woman, after all, and the madman already murdered and stuffed a cat in your mailbox. The police are gonna get him.Or2. Call the police, but then decide you don't need them. You don't need your sisters either... well... maybe the catatonic/crazy one. Anyway, you'll hide what's going on from everyone and Home Alone trap that madman, transport him to Boo'ya Moon, and watch one as he is devoured by your late husband's horrific monster called "Long Boy." But, and you know this, in following this plan the Long Boy will mark you, and you will live the rest of your days in fear, covering mirrors and avoiding reflections, knowing that one day the Long Boy may claim you the way it tried to claim your husband until he took his last, rattling, breath.WHICH PLAN IS BETTER??!?!?!?!??! WHY IN THE HELL DID SHE CHOOSE BEING ETERNALLY STALKED BY THE MOST HORRIFYING MONSTER ANYONE HAS EVER SEEN?!?!Lisey is so stupid, I hope the Long Boy does end up getting her. (hide spoiler)]...more

review: I can't rate this book because I can't read it.It's not Michelle Zauner's fault. I stumbled across this book when I started reading a rave  in sI can't rate this book because I can't read it.It's not Michelle Zauner's fault. I stumbled across this book when I started reading a rave  in some publication. I generally find s to be too revealing of their subject, so I didn't really know what this book was about. From the few sentences I had espied, I thought I was jumping into the memoir of what it is like to come of age and struggle to marry both your Korean and your American heritage. That was enough for me to make that library resy. And, hey, that may very well be what this book is about, but the entire memoir is told through the lens of Zauner's grief surrounding the loss of her mother.I am incapable of reading about the death of a mother right now.I thought maybe I could limp through it, but Zauner is like so many people when wading through grief: she is preaching. She's yelling at her readers to love and hug their mothers before they wake up one day and can't. And I? I can't support someone who does that. It totally discounts all of us who have/had abusive and/or neglectful and/or manipulative mothers. As the sun sets on year 4 of my own mother's slow, painful, and traumatizing death at the hands of her addiction, the last thing I need is a stranger casting judgment on what my grief looks like. ...more

title: Guards! Guards!        (Discworld, #8)
author: Pratchett, Terry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another delightfully whacky installment of Disc World. It'd been a while since I last read Pratchett. I had to get re-accustomed to how he plays with Another delightfully whacky installment of Disc World. It'd been a while since I last read Pratchett. I had to get re-accustomed to how he plays with language, which was a fun, cerebral experiment in and of itself. Guards! Guards is scathing social commentary disguised as a silly book.The Night Watch of Ankh-Morpork is a joke. Everything is regulated in the city, including crime, so The Night Watch bumbles around drunk, and no one looks to them for anything resembling law and order... until the dragon.Carrot is large human, adopted by dwarves, who is sent to Ankh-Morpork as a sort of Rumspringa. He joins The Night Watch assuming that such a post is noble. He re-introduces laws and rules to his fellow watch members... which is helpful when the dragon comes.The society of Elucidated Brethren is headed up by the Supreme Grand Master, who is sick and tired of the way Ankh-Morpork is run. You see, he wants all the power. And what will get him that? Why, a dragon of course.The Librarian is going to find that friggin' stolen book and you better not say monkey about it.So, there you have it. Chaos and an ill-fated power grab all surrounding a dragon. A romp of a read, to be sure, but the only parts that matter, in my opinion, were the parts where Pratchett slapped us in the face with how depraved humanity actually is:We were dragons. We were supposed to be cruel, cunning, heartless and terrible. But this much I can tell you, you ape... we never burned and tortured and ripped one another apart and called it morality.And"I believe you find life such a problem because you think there are the good people and the bad people," said the man. "You're wrong, of course. There are, always and only, the bad people, but some of them are on opposite sides."And, this same speaker, after being told that people aren't evil, they're just afraid and alone:"Of course you have to believe that, I appreciate. Otherwise you'd go quite mad. Otherwise you'd think you're standing on a feather-thin bridge over the vaults of Hell. Otherwise existence would be a dark agony and the only hope would be that there is no life after death. I quite understand."..."Do you believe all that, sir?" he said. "About the endless evil and the sheer blackness?""Indeed, indeed... It is the only logical conclusion.""But you get out of bed every morning, sir?""Hmm? Yes? What is your point?""I'd just like to know *why*, sir.""Oh, do go away... There's a good fellow."Bravo....more

title: HHhH
author: Binet, Laurent
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Just because something is innovative, does not make it good.Listen, there are ten bazillion books on WWII. Maybe the reason HHhH has gotten so much prJust because something is innovative, does not make it good.Listen, there are ten bazillion books on WWII. Maybe the reason HHhH has gotten so much praise is because it tackles an over-written-about subject in a unique way. But, like, why?Here's the book in a nutshell:A choppy, stream-of-consciousness peek into the act of writing a book. Author Laurent Binet spends pages just chatting about his girlfriends. He spends pages worrying that his book won't actually have anything unique to say. He spends pages fleshing out his insecurities and his biases and his life. That is not what I came here for. I cam here for the assassination attempt. And while the book ultimately gets there (the last third of the novel is relatively tight, and the prose of the ending bumped this up to 3-stars in my brain), we had to wade through a lot of silliness to get there.Binet asserts that historians should only write about what can be confirmed as fact. He's basically saying that no one should extrapolate in order to create narration. I heartedly disagree. I think that's stupid. I think this book, as a whole, is kinda stupid. I enjoyed that last third, but only begrudgingly.So that's a big ol' meh from me, dawg. ...more

title: The Low, Low Woods
author: Machado, Carmen Maria*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A garbled premise with garbled characters, The Low, Low Woods really didn't do it for me. Look, Carmen Maria Machado is a great writer. Her short storA garbled premise with garbled characters, The Low, Low Woods really didn't do it for me. Look, Carmen Maria Machado is a great writer. Her short story collection Her Body and Other Parties and her memoir In The Dream House are both fantastic. It just seems like her crazy cool mind doesn't translate to graphic novelization.The Low, Low Woods tells the story of two teenage friends growing up in Shudder-to-Think, Pennsylvania. It echoes Centralia in that the town sits atop an underground mine fire... or does it? Machado attempts to weave the supernatural into a very real, very upsetting reality, and it just doesn't work. The main characters also don't work. El and Octavia are best friends, but weird, messy best friends, and their friendship isn't unpacked at all. They're both queer, and Machado blurs the lines between best friends and something more on multiple occasions. I get it, that happens. It happened to me in high school... but not with my BEST friend... because... she's my best friend... so... I mean... yuck. Does Machado not remember what it was like to come out in the early aughts and have female friends be like "but you don't like me, right?" Like, don't flatter yourself. And also, don't blur that. It felt weird/dated/I didn't like it at all. One of the central themes of The Low, Low Woods is "men are monsters." Meaning all men. There is no texture or depth to this idea, so fell utterly flat for me. All men? Really? All men rape and murder? C'mon. I also really, really hated the depiction of witches & witchcraft, but we won't go into that. (view spoiler)[I will, however, say the shift from "all men are monsters" to "but everything wrong in the town is the fault of a brutally raped witch child" was the absolutely wrong plot move. What. the. fuck. Not only was that all horrible, but it also muddied the theme of the GD story. Why??? Why?!?!?!??!?! (hide spoiler)]I don't enjoy stories that are tragedy porn just for tragedy porn's sake. The Low, Low Woods threw a lot of fucked up shit at my eyeballs for seemingly no reason. That wasn't cool. This story wasn't cool. I - I just...I need a drink....more

review: This is the most tremendous work of investigative journalism I have ever read. Heather Ann Thompson dedicated a decade of her life sifting through docThis is the most tremendous work of investigative journalism I have ever read. Heather Ann Thompson dedicated a decade of her life sifting through documents and giving voices to so many people who were stomped on by our government, our law enforcement, our society. She turned over every stone she could find. She didn't shy away from the horrifying bullshit of this event, and all the tendriling bullshit that spun out over decades. Our systems are broken. It's built to disenfranchise, it's built to keep us in the dirt. Thank you, Heather Ann Thompson. I wish things would change faster. I hope everyone reads at least parts of this book. Be warned, though: this book is a slog. The preparation for the trials, the trials themselves, every bureaucratic set-back... it's all laid out in minute detail. I'm a POS, so I skimmed some of it, because I didn't want to kill myself. That doesn't take away from how important this book is, just know that this is a mammoth undertaking. ...more

title: In the Dream House
author: Machado, Carmen Maria*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am devastated... and I am cherishing that devastation. Carmen Maria Machado says right at the top her narrative: every story of abuse is unique. SheI am devastated... and I am cherishing that devastation. Carmen Maria Machado says right at the top her narrative: every story of abuse is unique. She does not expect her story to resonate with most people. She does expect some pushback in the form of "that's not how I experienced it." And she understands. She is pre-emptively apologetic if this book misses the mark for those searching for a narrative that mirrors their own abuse experience, but also if this book hits a little too close to home.In the Dream House is a fractured narrative detailing Carmen Maria Machado's real-life abusive relationship with an unnamed woman. The fracturing feels necessary. When you are in an abusive relationship and have turtled into yourself that far, sometimes all you can see of your own life is snippets. You surface for a cruel remark, for crying yourself to sleep, for the waves of shame, for those moments of peace when your significant other isn't around and you feel safe... but you cannot possibly take all of that in at once. Fracturing is required. Like re-breaking a bone to ensure it sets properly, you pre-emptively break yourself so that, when the relationship is finally, mercifully, over, you can heal back to something resembling yourself.Eerie parallels between my abuse story and Machado's abuse story:- The fallout after not picking up a phone call from your long distance girlfriend. This almost always results in many subsequent phone calls and voicemails, the latter of which become increasingly threatening as time goes on. If you went and saw a 2hr movie at the theater, and forgot to turn your phone back on IMMEDIATELY after the credits start to roll? You could be in for a world of pain... and maybe even the middle-of-the-night arrival of said girlfriend.- Having your long distance girlfriend apply to your school, and not get accepted. The avalanche of relief I felt when my ex didn't get accepted to my undergrad program was so much I cried from that, too. Machado's description of that experience: the relief, the shame of the relief, the fear that they'll somehow detect your relief... ugh. - Crying so much on the phone with your girlfriend that the tears get inside and break the phone. Yup. Both Machado and myself did that stupid shit. - This passage: She makes you tell her what is wrong with you. This is a favorite activity; even better than her telling you what is wrong with you. Years later, it's a habit that's hard to break.- This passage: You can feel her anger; you can't see her but the smell of her changes, like a cheap dish towel left on a live electric burner.- And this passage: She loves to walk away from you in places where you know no one, where you have no power, where you can't simply get up and go somewhere.I was able to get out from underneath my abusive relationship in January 2009, but I still feel reverberations from that 3 year span where I was essentially controlled by another person. Like Machado, I don't regret it. It made me into who I am, and who I am got me to the life I have now. I don't want a different life, so I cannot regret those 3 years.There was something so profoundly moving about reading a book written by another queer woman who found herself utterly lost in a person to the point where she temporary lost sight of herself. Machado is so vulnerable and honest about the secrets you horde and the shame that suffocates you in an abusive relationship. I cannot adequately articulate how grateful I am that she put her experience into words, so that I could feel less alone with mine.As her dedication reads: if you need this book, it is for you....more

title: Bloodchild and Other Stories
author: Butler, Octavia E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's unfair to  a short story collection when some stories were fantastic and some stories didn't land. Do they all deserve their own stars??? LIt's unfair to  a short story collection when some stories were fantastic and some stories didn't land. Do they all deserve their own stars??? LET'S DO THIS."Bloodchild" was fantastic. A slow-burn reveal of how humans and an alien species have achieved co-existence in this fictional reality. It has love and horror and it was fantastic. 5 stars."The Evening and the Morning and the Night" was a tough read in a post-COVID world, but was also fantastic. A young woman reveals her disease to the reader, how it came to be, and how the world has learned to manage those who suffer like her. 4.5 stars."Near of Kin" fell short. A young woman is packing up her mother's home after her mother passed. Things are revealed. This is Octavia Butler's formula: she drops us in the middle of a scene, then let's it blossom around us. Honestly, they're best read, then immediately re-read, so you can appreciate those extra layers that are only apparent once you've actually identified the heart of the story. But, in "Near of Kin," the reveal was blase, despite Butler's strong writing. 3 stars. "Speech Sounds" was another jarring story in the face of COVID, but I love the idea of a plague that can take speech and/or word comprehension. It was wrenching. 4 stars. "Crossover" was a yucky combo of depression and boring despite a supernatural spin. No thanks. 2 stars."Positive Obsession" is an essay of Butler's that functions as a sort mini, becoming-a-writer autobiography. It's just fantastic. Take this section: But still I'm asked, what good is any form of literature to Black people? What good is science fiction's thinking about the present, the future, and the past? What good is its tendency to warn or to consider alternative ways of thinking and doing? What good is its examination of the possible effects of science and technology, or social organization and political direction? At its best, science fiction stimulates imagination and creativity. It gets the reader and writer off the beaten track, off the narrow, narrow footpath of what "everyone is saying, doing, thinking - whoever "everyone" happens to be this year. And what good is all this to Black people? 5 stars"Furor Scribendi" is a 4 page essay that is just saying "if you want to write then write. A lot." 2.5 stars."Amnesty" is a too-long story about a human conducting a new recruit orientation for other humans to serve an alien race. Oh my god is was so dull and nothing happens and the one real character in the story was so one dimensional. Yeesh. 1.5 stars."The Book of Martha" is a dialogue between Martha and God. Butler provides afterwords at the close of each of her stories. For "Book of Martha" she said the inspiration came from the idea of utopias, and what if God demanded a human cook up a utopia that would work. I mean... I like that concept, but I really disliked this story. Partly because God isn't real, partly because the writing fell flat in this one. 1 star. And that's how we get to 3 stars, folks. ...more
