title: We Keep the Dead Close: A Murder at Harvard and a Half Century of Silence
author: Cooper, Becky*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On January 7, 1969, the body of Jane Britton was discovered in her Harvard apartment. While there were 4 likely suspects, and while the press went craOn January 7, 1969, the body of Jane Britton was discovered in her Harvard apartment. While there were 4 likely suspects, and while the press went crazy over the seemingly ritualistic details of the murder, law enforcement failed to make an arrest. And, as weeks bled into months bled into years, Jane Britton's name was lost to time. Her story slowly morphed into a grotesque myth whispered in the halls of Harvard: a young woman was murdered in the 60s. That professor over there? He totally did it. Becky Cooper heard this story from a friend's boyfriend. It was creepy, but she kind of forgot about it. Then, randomly, the story surfaced in Cooper's life a second time. That second conversation sparked in Cooper a sort of obsession. She dedicated the next 10 years of her life looking into Jane Britton, trying to unravel the mysteries surrounding the late archeology graduate student.I oscillate between 3 of 4 stars for this book. Why the indecision? I can list them in a handy pro/con list:Pro:Parts of the narration really sing.Con:The way author Becky Cooper formatted her book is clunky and awkward. I had to keep reminding myself who different people were. She would spend dozens of pages fleshing out the life of one suspect. Then talk about herself for a while. Then spend dozens of pages talking about a different suspect. It was jarring. Cooper would jump from 1969, to sometime in the early 2010s, to 2018, and back again. Whiplash, much?Pro:The ending was tidy and tight. This is what made the book a 4-star-er for me.Con:The meandering prose the author spent on herself and her personal journey of self-discovery felt awkward and forced.Pro:Becky Cooper and I are the same exact age, so, in a way, I felt as though parts of her floundering echoed my own.Neutral:The murder victim, Jane Britton, still feels like a grainy sketch to me. I know much more about Becky Cooper than I know about Jane Britton. Should that have happened? Should the author have allowed her memoir bits to overshadow the silenced woman she attempted to give a voice? I don't have an answer to that question. Cooper had access to Britton's journals, to her brother, to her best friends. I would think Cooper could have been more verbose about Britton as a person... but maybe she couldn't be. Or maybe she chose to protect parts of Britton. I just... I don't know. Neutral:Cooper very clearly became emotionally involved with several people closest to the murder of Jane Britton. It seemed at times that Britton cultivated a vast network of step-grandparents as she cold called Britton's family, friends, and murder suspects. I give Cooper credit for her guts, and I also wonder if that bonding colored her writing in a way that veers steeply away from investigative journalism. One glaring oversight for me is Cooper not unpacking the system failures she uncovered:1. Harvard's refusal to install basic safety features in a building they owned, which is objectively partially responsible for the murder2. The insane level of law enforcement incompetency. (view spoiler)[The revelation at the tail-end of the book? That a cop planted evidence and attempted to pin the murder on some random man in Britton's periphery? That that same cop continues to be celebrated by the larger law enforcement body despite being CAUGHT doing something so despicable? I wanted more of that. I wanted Cooper to eviscerate those responsible. But she didn't. Considering how close she got to so many people in the 10yrs she worked on this book I get it, I guess. But it felt as though so much was left unsaid in that area, and that this silence does a bit of disservice to Britton's memory. (hide spoiler)] At the end of the day, I am happy this book exists, and I think Cooper did a pretty good job. I applaud her for breathing interest and life back into a senseless killing of a Promising Young Woman (tm). So many women become nameless victims, like Britton had become when Cooper was first introduced to her story. Let's bring these names to light. Let's remember. ...more

title: Belonging: A German Reckons with History and Home
author: Krug, Nora
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In a what are you reading/what are you watching conversation my German professor buddy told me about this book. "I might teach it," she said. "Feel liIn a what are you reading/what are you watching conversation my German professor buddy told me about this book. "I might teach it," she said. "Feel like reading it and telling me what you think?"At 288 pages, Nora Krug's multimedia/graphic novel Belonging isn't exactly a time sink. I said yes, knowing absolutely nothing about this book. I'm not sure what I was expecting going into it, but it certainly wasn't the emotionally poignant sucker punch I received. Born in Germany in 1977 and moving to New York in her 20s, Krug straddles two worlds. She very much grew up feeling a very particular aftershock of World War II."I understood that THE WAR was a loud and deadly event," she writes. "We learned that the German word for RACE should only be used to distinguish animal species, and ETHNIC only in the context of genocides... we didn't learn that tens of thousands of Germans had been killed for resisting the Nazi regime (because it would have made our grandparents who didn't resist look guiltier in comparison?), or that 150,000 men of Jewish descent had fought in the WEHRMACHT (because their participation would have made us feel less guilty?) ...Because we never learned about contemporary Jewish culture, we associated the word JUDE strictly with the Holocaust and we understood that it could be uttered only in a whisper."When she moves to New York, Krug is overwhelmed by the pride in German heritage she witnesses. A parade of people waving small German flags makes her uncomfortable. She is still trying to actively mask her German accent when talking with strangers. Listening to Americans who knew so much about their familial history made Krug realize she didn't actually know a whole lot about her own......so she decided to find out.That context alone can tell you that what Krug found out was a smidge... difficult. It... yeah.I call this book a multimedia book rather than a straight up graphic novel because Krug intersperses photocopies of letters and discharge papers. She pastes in old photographs. She presses flowers on the edges. It's a beautiful book to look at, and her small, loopy handwriting and delicate drawings are the perfect contrast to reading about the hate and fear of World War II. It's an especially scary right now, considering the current global political climate.We don't talk much about the non-Jewish German experience in World War II. For all of the books that have come out, for all of the films we've seen... JoJo Rabbit is the only one I can think of, I think? And that's pretty new to the canon. As Krug puts it: Germans aren't allowed to talk about their experiences, they are meant only to feel shame. In her search through the past, though, Krug gave us a glimpse into how gray that shame can be. And for that I thank her.PS. I gave this 4 stars rather than 5 because, while beautiful, this book is friggin' confusing. Krug looks into both sides of her family, and keeps jumping from one side to the other. It was wildly difficult to keep track of which grandfather/aunt/cousin she was talking about now, and how they related to the wider web of family. I wish she had split this book between maternal and paternal, so you got one full story, and then another full story. Her way made everything muddy and confusing... though maybe that was the point? ...more

title: The House in the Cerulean Sea        (The House in the Cerulean Sea, #1)
author: Klune, T.J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really wish I had read ...Cerulean Sea before ...Whispering Door. TJ Klune basically wrote the same characters into two books, but made worse versioI really wish I had read ...Cerulean Sea before ...Whispering Door. TJ Klune basically wrote the same characters into two books, but made worse versions of them for ...Whispering Door. I understand why people like ...Cerulean Sea. It is kind of like a cozy blanket of a book. Linus Baker is a stuck in the routine of life, going to his job, returning to his home alone, not diverting from his habits and his perception of the world as its been presented to him. He isn't curious, but this isn't because of indifference. It seems he's developed a lack of curiosity as armor against the monotony and disappointment of his existence. When the Extremely Upper Management of his firm sends him on a month-long assignment to a technicolor island, his world explodes. But, you know, in a good way. The young children, particularly Chauncey and Sal, are perfect characters. They both made me cry. A book that makes me cry surely deserves more than 3 stars, no?I admit, I was conflicted.Here's where I ended up.TJ Klune isn't a good writer. I'm sorry, but it's true. His prose lack, he's very repetitive, and he struggles to develop the growth arc of his characters. Because of this last piece, we're left at the end of his tales going "wait... how did we get here?" His love story in ...Cerulean Sea made a little more sense than ...Whispering Door, but it was still woefully underdeveloped. I honestly wish TJ Klune would sell his ideas to good authors. Like a song writer sells their wares to voices that bring the heart and the depth: Klune has great ideas, but isn't able to fully bring them to life.That doesn't make this a bad book. It contains within it a really lovely message about loving yourself for who you are, about the family you choose, about seeking community regardless of what the outside world has told you about yourself. It beseeches its readers to stay curious and never give up on finding love and acceptance if that's what you want. It's out there, Klune tells us, you just have to go find it. And wow, what a powerful message. It's just, well, Klune's writing doesn't add anything shiny or sparkly to this message. It's there, yes, and Klune repeats it several times lest we find ourselves too dense to pick it up. But I walked away from this book sort of feeling like that message had been said to me in a monotone voice. I still heard it, but it lacked the punch it should have had.Also, if Sal "bit his lip" or Talia "preened" one more time I was going to start a petition to wipe the respective phrase and word from our collective consciousness. Use a thesaurus goddamnit. Wow, okay, that got angry. To be repetitive like our buddy Klune: ...Cerulean Sea is a nice story poorly told. ...more

title: Butter: A Rich History
author: Khosrova, Elaine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I haven't quite finished this book, but the only section I have left, "Making It," is simply an instructional on how to make/brown/clarify your own buI haven't quite finished this book, but the only section I have left, "Making It," is simply an instructional on how to make/brown/clarify your own butter... so... I think I'm qualified to weigh in at this point.Elaine Khosrova, for her part, is certainly qualified to write this book. A CIA (not the spy one) alumna and former staff writer at several food magazines, she has spent quite some time with the golden fat that gives brownies their shiny, crackly tops, and pie crusts the ideal tender flakiness (sorry vegans). The book is laid out well. We begin with a vignette in Bhutan, where a family collects the morning yak milk. From there, Khosrova walks us through how humans began making and consuming butter in the first place, the many uses of butter in and out of the culinary universe, the rise of butter's popularity, the rise of butter industrialization, the "fat ban" in the latter half of the 20th century, the artisanal reboot of butter in the 21st, and, finally, a closing vignette at the CIA (still not the spy one). Khosrova dedicates the final ~75 pages of her book to recipes where butter is the star ingredient: crumb cake, shortbread, puff pastry, butterscotch pudding, lemon curd. And even gives us appendixes on recommended butters and how to say butter in a myriad of languages. She's betraying what a Type A person she is and I love it.Okay, if I loved it, what's with the stingy star giving? Do I realize I only gave this book 3 stars?Ugh, I know. And I'm so upset about it. You see, I really really loved most of this book. The history of butter? Fascinating! And I could read anecdotes such as these forever:Some of the ways early Swedish farmwives helped ensure their dairy luck against spirits and stealers were by breathing into the milking pail before commencing to milk or passing the milk pail over the fire three times. More extreme measures also existed, particularly around the widespread belief that, by making a pact with the devil, a witch could virtually steal the milk of other farmers, without ever having to cross their property. According to Swedish lore, once that deal was struck, the person (invariably a woman) invoked the milk theft ritually, by standing naked on a tall pile of manure and calling out, "The milk is mine as far as my cry is heard."But my love of this book was dashed to pieces once we got to chapter 9: The Modern Buttersmith: Small Batches, Big Fans. In it she provides mini profiles on several artisanal buttersmiths, mainly in the USA and Western Europe. The TL;DR version of this chapter is as follows:We are moving away from industrialized, poor quality butter, and can start to get the good stuff. Here are some people making the good stuff. 99% of us will never, ever taste the good stuff, because restaurants serving billionaires buy up their entire supply and leave nothing for everyone else.And she just tells us that. Like it's a good thing.HOW IS THAT A GOOD THING.Like, I get it. It's great that individuals who excel in their craft are compensated well. And it's exciting that people can make a decent living farming again. That's good. Important, even, as we turn our collective eye toward minimizing climate change and sourcing our foods locally. But this shit isn't local. This is a billionaire getting his rich butter private jet-ed to his favorite restaurant hundreds if not thousands miles away. And that? I mean... fuck that. That is a perfect example of exactly what is wrong in our society. These buttersmiths are making a product and then shipping it out of the community to service the rich. Everyone else can go on eating the supermarket brand stuff that Khosrova herself says isn't very good at all. But fuck us, right? We didn't win at capitalism, so we don't deserve the stuff.To be fair, Khosrova didn't tell me to go fuck myself in her book. But it kind of felt like that, since she refused to touch the classism here with a 10 foot pole. I know this book is about butter, but you brought class into it by talking about French Laundry. I'll never eat at French Laundry... most of us won't. And there's a glaring reason as to WHY we won't be. To ignore it was negligent. Our society is broken; butter is just another canary is this toxic coal mine. Whew. So, yeah. A good book that made a colossal mistake by introducing how broken the current butter market is and refusing to comment on that fact. Eat the rich!...more

title: Dune        (Dune, #1)
author: Herbert, Frank
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I would never, ever take away from Dune what it does so well: world building. Frank Herbert created Arrakis richly. I understand the environment, the I would never, ever take away from Dune what it does so well: world building. Frank Herbert created Arrakis richly. I understand the environment, the perils, the stark and water-starved existence on this planet. He also has a great imagination: for weapons, for creatures, for supernatural abilities of man.So, yes, Dune is objectively a cornerstone of contemporary science fiction. I will not deny it its place in the canon.But something that is foundational does not necessary stand the test of time.My old, boring song-and-dance about the portrayal of women in the science fiction and fantasy genres is old hat. Suffice to say it did not surprise me at all that there is a total of ONE fleshed out female in 600+ pages of book. This one female, Jessica, starts out strong. She is a "Bene Gesserit," a class of women, sometimes called "witch," who are able to command people to obey by carefully controlling their voices. They are adept at reading people, at anticipating what someone is about to do. This has all the makings of a strong, kickass female character. And Jessica is... for the most part. But her relationship with other women is fraught with issue (this book does NOT pass The Bechdel test). This is seen most clearly at the close of the book. (view spoiler)[Jessica sidles up to Chani, her son's concubine (Herbert's word), as her son, Paul, moves to marry a princess in order to stop war and take control. Jessica says: "Think on it, Chani: the princess will have the name, yet she'll live as less than a concubine-never to know the moment of tenderness from the man to whom she's bound. While we, Chai, we who carry the name of the concubine-history will call us wives." AND THAT'S THE END OF THE BOOK. This is fucking horrible. The princess is a stranger to Jessica. She has not wronged Jessica, Paul, or any of the Fremen in any way. Her only crime thusfar is being the daughter of the Emperor. Who cares though, right? Let's pit the few women in this book against each other because all that matters is who gets the love of a man.At the risk of being dramatic: this utterly ruined Jessica for me. (hide spoiler)]Second, boring critique of sci-fi/fantasy: the (always male) protagonist is a lawful good character who is the smartest/strongest/bestest at everything. Paul might be the worst iteration of that I've ever seen.The meat of the story, Paul going into the desert and realizing his "terrible purpose," starts when he is fifteen years old. Do you remember what you were like at fifteen? Because, let me tell you, I was not felling grown men who fight in the greatest army the galaxy has ever seen WITHOUT EVEN GETTING A SCRATCH. I was not able to spend five seconds in another culture and figure out exactly how to fit in. I was not able to see the future for reasons that are not adequately explored. Sure, Herbert tries to wave all this off with veiled references to Paul having a Bene Gesserit mother who "chose" to have a son when she was ordered to have a daughter. Also, Paul has this ineffable divinity, and Herbert thinks that should be good enough for us. I'm all for some mystery; you don't have to spoon feed me everything. But for a man who so richly built his world, it was baffling that he'd build characters and then be like "and also they can see the future because I said so and also destiny."Dune boils down to the following for me: a beautifully crafted fictional world that houses little cardboard people lacking depth. Also, this one guy is basically a god but don't look too closely as to why.Gurney Halleck is great. There should have been more of him. -Fin...more

title: The Secret Lives of Church Ladies
author: Philyaw, Deesha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My neglectful, starved-for-love alcoholic mother is currently dying. To say my current positioning in life swayed my feelings on this book could arguaMy neglectful, starved-for-love alcoholic mother is currently dying. To say my current positioning in life swayed my feelings on this book could arguably the biggest understatement I've ever made. I straight up skimmed the final story, "When Eddie Levert Comes to Town," because reading about a character known only as "Daughter" because she's lost her individuality in the throes of caring for a dying mother was too damn much for me to bear. Meanwhile, "Jael" just wasn't my cup of tea. Call-and-answer journaling between great-grandmother and fucked up great-granddaughter where we really don't learn much about any of the characters? Their drives? Their hopes? Like, we're reading Jael's journal... right? Shouldn't we... know more? As I think more on this, my  really really isn't fair. Because these two stories are two of the final stories in the collection. The rest of it shouldn't suffer just cause I didn't like them and also I'm all messed up right now? "Dear Sister" was an incredibly clever short story about family, about loss, about who matters."Peach Cobbler," while also delving deep into toxic mother/daughter relationships, really fleshed out its characters. Olivia is the hero of this entire collection: smart, driven. She takes her mashed up self-worth and confusion about love is and turns it into useful spite. Girl, I see you. I hear you. I am you. "How to Make Love to a Physicist" is a woman's gradual acceptance that she is worthy of love, written out as a confessional. The main drive of this book is the relationship between mother and daughter, and the scars it can leave. So, yeah, I might have to re-read this when I'm not... well... yeah....more

title: Scar Tissue
author: Kiedis, Anthony
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I... I have no words.Nah, just kidding. I have, like, a lot. So unlike me, I know.Red Hot Chili Peppers has been one of my all-time favorite bands eveI... I have no words.Nah, just kidding. I have, like, a lot. So unlike me, I know.Red Hot Chili Peppers has been one of my all-time favorite bands ever since I started forging out on my own and picking out "my" music. My dad got me into classic rock: Led Zeppelin, The Beatles, The Rolling Stones. He also got me into classical: Mozart, Strauss, Tchaikovsky. My mom, on the other hand, got me into crooners: Carole King, Billy Joel, The Carpenters; while also introducing me to classic pop: The Beach Boys, The Monkees, The Supremes. At the ripe age of 7, in 1996, I started developing my own taste. Considering the mishmash of parental influence, it surprised no one that I was blasting Spice Girls and Backstreet Boys back-to-back with Nirvana and Red Hot Chili Peppers.What I'm trying to impress is: I've been a fan. When a high school boyfriend burned me a CD with Suck My Kiss on it, I knew it was love.My husband, knowing my fandom, has been trying to get me to read this book for a few years. He read it back in college, and thought I'd really enjoy it. I finally relented, in this, the year of our lord(TM) 2020.Some parts I really enjoyed... and some parts... I... well... fuck, okay, let's just get into it. Anthony Kiedis' autobiography, ghost written by Larry Sloman, spans from when Kiedis was a wee babe in the late 60s/early 70s, all the way up to the "present," ie the early 2000s. He was born to very young parents whose tumultuous relationship did not last long. Complaint #1: Kiedis is very cavalier about the fact that his dad repeatedly abandoned his mother and himself. I mean, I understand forgiveness, but, like, take your dad to task, man. He's a real piece of shit.Speaking of his dad being a piece of shit: his dad would take him to clubs when he was very young (like, younger than 12), and allowed him to smoke weed back then too. When Kiedis was approaching his 12th birthday, he asked his dad if he could have sex with the 18yr old girl who was hanging around the house sometimes. His dad was like "sure, son, 11yrs old is the time to lose your virginity." The 18yr old girl was for it, apparently, so 11yr old Anthony Kiedis was raped by an adult woman.Kiedis' reflection on this goes: She guided me the whole way, and she was very loving and gentle, and it was all pretty natural... It was a fun thing to do, and I never felt traumatized then, but I think subconsciously it was probably something that always stuck with me in a weird way. I didn't wake up the next morning going "Geez, what the hell was that?" I woke up wanting to go brag about it to my friends...Kiedis doesn't unpack the rape more than this.In the "second half of 10th grade," which, to my estimations, puts Kiedis at 15yrs old, he gets crazily injured, and is laid up at home. He says:I spent the next few weeks horizontal in my own bed. I got some lovely visitations from a friend of my father's named Lark, who was a beautiful, relatively successful twenty-something actress. She came by at all hours, during the day, late at night, whenever, just to fix me up sexually... I had to keep telling her to be real careful, but I was getting absolutely ridden by a wild nymphomaniac banshee.Kiedis has now been raped by two different adult women.By the time Kiedis reaches adulthood himself, and is touring with his band, he is laser-focused on sex and drugs. He tells one story about a "Marilyn Monroe-esque vixen" who he has sex with a few times. When she reveals that she is actually only 14yrs old, he recalls:So we had sex one more time, and she gave me an interesting compliment that I never forgot. She said, "When you make love to me, it's like you're a professional.Now you're the rapist, Kiedis. He then meets Ione Leitch, a girl he dates for ~1yr, who he met "a few days before her sixteenth birthday." Statutory rape. Again. A 24yr old dating a 16yr old is... yeech. Hard subject change: at one point Kiedis just casually puts in the book "I never wore a seatbelt. Still don't." Which reeeaalllyy pissed me off. I assume all these young idiots read this book and stopped wearing seatbelts in order to be cool... like Anthony Kiedis. Why are you acting like not wearing a seatbelt is cool, asshole?Listen, this book is interesting. Kiedis is very honest about his drug addiction, and there are some fantastic looks into the relationships between famous bands of the early 90s. However, I walked away from this book with the following tastes in my mouth:1. Anthony Kiedis has experienced and doled out a lot of trauma. Considering the tenor of this book, he hadn't even begun to try to work through any of that as of 2004 (the publication of this autobiography). And, considering he had a son in 2017 with an 18yr old (he was 41), I don't think he ever really tried.2. Anthony Kiedis is a narcissist.3. Poor Flea. Kiedis says he realizes he was a real piece of shit to his bandmates and his family and everyone who cares/d about him. But those are just words. There is no evidence that Kiedis ever actually attempted to make amends with anyone, nor does it seem like he was ever really there for anyone the way they were there for him. Considering his narcissistic personality, I'm pretty sure Kiedis would be trumpeting any/all efforts he made. But he's uncharacteristically silent on that front. So, I'm left to conclude that Anthony Kiedis is a really bad, albeit traumatized, person.I honestly don't know if I'd recommend this to anyone. Despite not having yet read it, I'd probably say you're better off reading Flea's Acid for the Children. Scar Tissue is a drug and sex riddled story of depravity written by a man incapable of reflecting on what his actions have done to other people, and how the trauma of his youth paved the way for him being a real POS. If you're into that, go for it. But Flea deserves the royalties more, so get this book from the library.PS. Another ridiculous part of this book was Kiedis talking about grinding it in the beginnings of Red Hot Chili Peppers. Sonny Bono was your godfather. Cher was your babysitter. The clubs your dad took you to as a prepubescent were crawling with the likes of Led Zeppelin. You were always in the middle of it, man. Don't play.PPS. This quote: We got into trouble with Warner's again when we used Gavin for our "Aeroplane" video. He came up with a super treatment: an expansive ode to Busby Berkeley, feature a huge chorus line of half-naked, hot-costumed Mexican cholitas, tough gangster girls with heavy makeup and sweeping hair. We wanted lots of semi-nudity and sexy dancing and chewing of gum and blowing of bubbles... But a lady from Warner's was supervising the shoot, and it turned out that she was a PC feminist.WTF is a "PC feminist?" That offensive, throwaway comment really, truly underscores for me how much of a clueless asshole Anthony Kiedis is. ...more

title: Fathoms: The World in the Whale
author: Giggs, Rebecca
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Forget it. I'm out.I picked up this book because I thought Giggs was going to delve into the make-up of the oceans, the habits of whales, the symbiosiForget it. I'm out.I picked up this book because I thought Giggs was going to delve into the make-up of the oceans, the habits of whales, the symbiosis of whales with their environment...That is so not what this book is.I read the first 3 chapters.Chapter 1 predominately focuses on the gory history of whaling. Chapter 2 is part whale life (gestation, migration, etc.), which was GREAT. However, a lot of that chapter was also about the people on a whale watching boat with the author during an excursion (boring, stupid), and more about how humans have decimated both whale populations and their main food source (depressing, hopeless). Chapter 3 had some information on evolution (v. cool) and whales in culture (still cool). BUT the majority of the chapter was about the author's experience in a museum she used to visit as a child. And, at that point, I was so done with the fractured narration I had to put the book down.Honestly, if the book wasn't written by a drunken grad student, I may have limped on, but everything detailed above, + everything detailed below, was too much to take.Drunken grad student? Well, if you didn't read my update WHILE I was still trying to read this book, I shared that I had to stop reading this book at night. Why? Because I had to keep a post-it and pen next to me while I was reading for jotting down the words I didn't know. Since I have a strict no-screens-before-bed policy, I had to wait until the next day to look those words up. This made me feel stupid. So I'd lay in bed, thinking "holy shit... am I stupid?" The next morning I would look up these words and realize: nope, I'm not stupid. Rebecca Giggs just wrote this book with a thesaurus open in her lap... and some of her archaic vocabulary wasn't even used correctly. So, instant flashbacks to college when assholes with word-of-the-day calendars taking Philosophy 101 would spew nonsense over buckets of Keystone. Here are some words I didn't know. When I asked some of my (fellow English MA) friends, none of them knew any of these words either. That should tell you something, Giggs. If you Google synonyms, then see the word hasn't been used in 200yrs... maybe don't. It makes both you and your book off-putting.-Exigencies-Insuperable -Midden-Pellucid-Peregrinations (this was one of the words that was used incorrectly) I could go on, but you get the gist. For a taste, this was the sentence which made me groan out loud and retire this book forever. Now I'll never know nuffin' 'bout whales:Maybe what whales convey is the endlessness of the distant past: a tide of time that subducts outside of the realms of human life, and unfurls toward the bluesome distance of life's fair origins.You used subducts incorrectly, and bluesome isn't a word. Most people didn't come to this book for your attempts at poetry. You are not Shakespeare, making up words and shit. Stay in your lane. Write a book that teaches us things. Or, better yet, don't write at all....more

title: With Billie
author: Blackburn, Julia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This may be a personal pick-up-put-down record. In anticipation of the film "The United States vs. Billie Holiday," I wanted to read a biography on thThis may be a personal pick-up-put-down record. In anticipation of the film "The United States vs. Billie Holiday," I wanted to read a biography on the jazz legend. Doing some preliminary research on biographies out there, I was... unimpressed. There wasn't much to choose from, and what was there had met lukewarm s. When a recent New Yorker article mentioned Julia Blackburn's With Billie, my decision was made for me. If my favorite news outlet was citing this book, it had to be the one to read... right?To say this book is unreadable feels histrionic. Other people have read this book... so clearly it can be read... but... like... why put yourself through it?Julia Blackburn decided to write a biography on Billie Holiday, and was given access to all the notes and interviews completed by prior Holiday bio hopeful Linda Kuehl. As Blackburn puts it, Kuehl never got through the first chapters. It seems, to Blackburn, that Kuehl lacked the skills to actually write the book, and was better at the information gathering portion of the process. When Kuehl committed suicide, her research sat for ~30 years until Blackburn came around to save it. What I'm trying to say is: Blackburn copied someone else's homework and also thought she did it better.The fact that Blackburn throws shade on the late Kuehl is hilarious, in the most literal sense (that is, it's so amusing it threatens to drive one insane). Blackburn's book is a hodge podge of contradictory quotes from those who knew Billie Holiday or followed parallel timelines to the woman. It reads nonsensically, because Blackburn was unable to put these notes together in a cohesive format. Blackburn often jumps in with her own observations, which usually amount to "what you just read has been contradicted by people, so, who knows what is true," or "this person was clearly high/drunk when they were remembering, so, take this with a grain of salt." Great. Helpful.Speaking of high/drunk, Blackburn is such a holier-than-thou shamer in this book. A lot of the people who were interviewed by Kuehl were involved with drugs and/or prostitution, and Blackburn is overtly sticking her nose in the air about this. Like, bitch, what do you expect? When you've been ground into the dirt by systemic racism and oppression, but you still need money to live, you have no choice but to turn to self-employment. In the 1930s? That looks a lot like drugs and prostitution. Apologize. It's also clear from the text that Blackburn is judging Holiday for the fact that she often found herself in abusive relationships, going as far as to note that some people claimed Holiday enjoyed being abused. Blackburn, as far as I read, doesn't even try to unpack what this meant with regards to Holiday's feeling of self-worth or depression. Nor does she unpack the archaic outlooks on abuse that many of Kuehl's aged interviewees likely held. So, that's great and not problematic at all......I've read oral histories before. Live from New York is a book I consistently recommend to people. But this isn't an oral history. This isn't even a biography. It's a hurried mess of cut/paste first-person anecdotes that are immediately contradicted by the next person. It's not clear if Blackburn was too lazy or just too poor a writer to turn this into an actual book, but lord knows I'm not hanging around to try and find out....more

title: Into the Wild
author: Krakauer, Jon*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I never got around to seeing the 2007 film adaptation of this book and, while this book has been on my radar for decades, I just never got around to rI never got around to seeing the 2007 film adaptation of this book and, while this book has been on my radar for decades, I just never got around to reading it. I knew it would be upsetting, not just because it chronicles the death of a young man who didn't have to die, but because I would see so much of myself and those I love in Chris McCandless. I surround myself with men who thrive in the outdoors, and I am never happier than when I am camping deep in the woods. So, reading this? Felt like it would be an emotional experience. Well, I finally read the book, and, unsurprisingly, I did cry at the end.I'm going to "spoil" below, because 1. it's a true story and 2. it's an older book at this point. If you don't want to know what happened to Chris McCandless, don't read on. In the early 90s, a young man named Chris McCandless graduated from Emory University, packed up his car, and headed west. He lived off of the land, off of the kindness of strangers, and off his cunning for a year. The whole time he had a final goal in mind: get up to Alaska and live wild. His family had no idea where he had disappeared to, and he had adopted the moniker Alexander Supertramp. Intelligent and gregarious, McCandless successfully hitch-hiked from South Dakota to the Stampede Trail outside of Denali National Park. There, he bunked down in an abandoned bus, with no map and few provisions, determined to live off what Alaska had to offer. After roughly 113 days, in August 1992, Chris McCandless perished in the wilderness of Alaska, due to a suspected combination of ingesting toxic seeds and starvation.The book is devastating for a number of reasons:1. McCandless, though he thought he was in the wilderness, was actually less than 6 miles from what we would call civilization. He was near Denali National Park, near a few privately owned seasonal cabins, and near a bucket-and-pulley system for fording the Teklanika River.2. His family seems to have genuinely loved him and been worried about him. They just tried to make him into someone he wasn't... as parents often do, and McCandless' response was to flee.3. He was very intelligent and was actually surviving successfully in the wilderness. It was a combination of bad luck and brashness that seems to have killed him.4. He actually tried to exit the Stampede Trail roughly one month prior to his death. The Teklanika River was in full flood mode at that time, though, and so he decided to return to his base camp and wait the river out. Little did he know, that the aforementioned bucket-and-pulley system was not too far down the river from where he attempted to ford it. He could have left. Instead he died. Krakauer was the exact person to write this story, as he saw so much of himself in the story of McCandless. It's tragic that McCandless became a cautionary tale instead of our next Thoreau or Muir. PS. In doing some research after finishing the book, I read that the bus where McCandless bunked and died was removed from the Stampede Trail as of June 2020, because unprepared trekkers kept going out there and requiring emergency evacuation services. PLEASE, if you want to do backcountry camping and hiking, read up, be prepared, and PRACTICE. Don't waste the time, money, and safety of others because you need them to save your dumb ass. ...more

title: The Girl in the Tower        (The Winternight Trilogy, #2)
author: Arden, Katherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The follow up to The Bear and the Nightingale sees Vasya attempting to live in the wilds, negotiate with spirits, and better her knowledge of the partThe follow up to The Bear and the Nightingale sees Vasya attempting to live in the wilds, negotiate with spirits, and better her knowledge of the part-friend-part-enemy-part-lover Frost Demon Morozko. Vasya is still fierce, independent, and intuitive. However, she must now hide her womanness, because this is medieval Russia, and women are meant to be locked away from prying eyes (perhaps... locked... in a tower?!?!). Arden is still tackling the cage that can be gender in The Girl in the Tower. She also begins to lean more heavily into the fantasy aspect of her world. Since the reader already has the groundwork from book #1, here we are introduced to the layered world of cheryti, or Russian Folklore. We meet more spirits of the ancient world, and Arden begins to tease how they may influence Man. We also get battle and village scenes, to flesh out the society Vasya must navigate through. As has been lamented by many before me, and by past versions of myself, describing the middle installment of a trilogy is incredibly difficult. You don't want to give too much away, and don't want to put your projections for book #3 out there, for fear of a two-for-one deal of spoilers. Suffice to say Arden has stayed true to a strong female fantasy series, and I thank her for it.(view spoiler)[If I liked the book so much, why only 4 stars? Well, it's because of that clunky romance between Vasya and Morozko. Do they actually have feelings for each other, or are their interludes a byproduct of her wearing his necklace? Is he actually becoming human, or is he just presenting himself as most human to more entice her? Do they actually want to kiss, or are they compelled by external, spiritual forces? It just feels kinda icky and coerced to me. Vasya did not have a choice to wear the necklace, and the necklace bound herself to him. Despite how strong she is, is she just, ultimately, his puppet? Arden attempts to clear this up when Vasya shatters the necklace and when Morozko is all "I didn't expect... you," but that scene didn't mop up all the gross on the floor of my brain when it comes to that relationship. Also, was the Tamara twist of book 2 (a great twist, btw) a nod to what Vasya's fate will be? We've known since book 1 that book 3 will likely be the death of Vasya... what will that look like? And will it ruin her for me? I'm not sure I'm ready to find out.  (hide spoiler)]...more

title: Homegoing
author: Gyasi, Yaa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: No notes.Seriously, though, Yaa Gyasi's Homegoing is one of the best books I have ever read. Homegoing spans hundreds of years beginning in the 1700s No notes.Seriously, though, Yaa Gyasi's Homegoing is one of the best books I have ever read. Homegoing spans hundreds of years beginning in the 1700s and ending around the year 2000. Each chapter is a vignette of the next generation of a particular extended family. I didn't want each chapter to end, because I knew I wouldn't really see that character ever again, and I loved every. Single. Chapter. Gyasi clearly did a lot of research to capture the enormity of history she tackles: Fantes vs Asantes, slave ships, the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850, convict leasing... she tackles so many horrible topics, but she does it gently, with grace. Sometimes you read a book like Homegoing and it just feels like gratuitous tragedy porn. Gyasi is thoughtful with her scenes: she is only graphic when the narrative demands it, and is subtle where an upsetting scene need only be hinted out rather than dragged out in nauseating detail. I thank her for that. Others have ed this book far more competently than I ever could:Isabel Wilkerson, NY TimesLaura Miller, The New Yorker If I had to pick a favorite chapter, it would be "Yaw." Why? Well, see for yourself:This is the problem of history. We cannot know that which we were not there to see and hear and experience for ourselves. We must rely upon the words of others... We believe the [story of the] one who has the power. He is the one who gets to write the story. So when you study history, you must always ask yourself, Whose story am I missing? Whose voice was suppressed so that this voice could come forth?And:Yaw wasn't certain that he believed in forgiveness. He heard the word most on the few days he went to the white man's church... it had begun to seem to him like a word the white men brought with them when they first came to Africa. A trick their Christians had learned and spoke loudly and freely about to the people of the Gold Coast. Forgiveness, they shouted, all the while committing their wrongs... Forgiveness was an act done after the fact, a piece of the bad deed's future....more

title: A Libertarian Walks Into a Bear: The Utopian Plot to Liberate an American Town
author: Hongoltz-Hetling, Matthew*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The town of Grafton, NH, doesn't sound like much of a town at all. Almost all of the public spaces have shuttered and/or fallen into disrepair, becausThe town of Grafton, NH, doesn't sound like much of a town at all. Almost all of the public spaces have shuttered and/or fallen into disrepair, because the citizens of Grafton hate one thing above all: taxes. Screw the roads, screw having a fire department, screw having access to information (aka a library). Payment into these things should be voluntary. If people really wanted them, they would voluntarily pay for them.Well, no one pays. But they sure as hell complain.It is not clear just how many years author and journalist Matthew Hongoltz-Hetling spent trying to crack into the psychology of the citizens of Grafton, but he paints a picture that extends as far back as the 1700s, all the way up to late 2019 (the book was published in 2020). He documents how bustling the town was in the 19th century, thanks to farming and mining, and how it grew sleepy as the 20th century roared into view. By the 1970s Grafton was all but abandoned... until the libertarians came to town. When it comes to ideals, the libertarian view isn't half bad: personal autonomy, anti-capitalism, freedom of choice, skepticism of authority... but like most political philosophies, the libertarian view can quickly be perverted into something wildly broken and inefficient. This crystalized in the town of Grafton, NH. Libertarians flocked to the town thanks to its low taxes and lack of oversight. However, those who took up residence didn't want to deal with paying for things like a fire department or snow plowing. They just wanted to hunker down with their guns and live and let live.Also, there are very unafraid bears living in the town.Hongoltz-Hetling tries to be fair to the people he interviewed, despite how crazy they seem to an outsider (read: me). He also tries to be fair to the bears, and I gotta say I was conflicted about them myself. I understand needing to cull populations that get out of control; we made ourselves to be gods and have to get comfortable playing god. Our intervention on this planet has resulted in broken ecosystems, and we gotta step up. That said, unlike deer, bears hold a special place in my heart. So it's hard for me to think about killing them, even for the greater ecological good. Fair he may be, but Hongoltz-Hetling oversteps in his narrative, to a distracting degree. He spends an entire chapter talking about typhus and toxoplasmosis, ultimately suggesting that the bears and the people of Grafton alike owe their fearlessness and aggression, respectively, to being infected with toxoplasmosis. He has absolutely 0 proof that this is the case. Most people infected present with absolutely no signs or symptoms. I worked at a vet clinic for a decade, and let me tell you, most people have toxoplasmosis. It doesn't make you more inclined to own a gun or be aggressive, and Hongoltz-Hetling was wildly irresponsible putting this theory forth, even with his hedging language that it's just a hypothesis. A quick bit of googling shows me that a lot of black bears also have toxoplasmosis... it is not unique to the bears of Grafton, NH. Suggesting that their odd behavior stems from the infection is nonsensical. You're not a scientist, man, stay in your lane.My other, rather petty complaint was how Hongoltz-Hetling attempted to be hip with his audience. Chapter-ending quips like: "but maybe bears (it was totally bears)" made me feel like I was sitting through one of my dad's bad jokes. It was slightly uncomfortable, and definitely took me out of the book. I came here to learn about a sociological experiment and about some unique bears... not to have the writer insert himself with his fun&cool asides.At the end of the day, A Libertarian Walks into a Bear is a lighthearted book about what modern day community experiments look like, as well as a cautionary tale of how human interaction with the environment really fucks up the environment. But this book wasn't anything brain shattering. I'll be lending out my copy, sure, but I won't be banging down doors demanding folks buy their own. ...more

title: The Bear and the Nightingale        (The Winternight Trilogy, #1)
author: Arden, Katherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you're looking for escapism (and, I mean, who isn't right now?), Katherine Arden has cooked up something pprreeetttyyy great for us.A friend of minIf you're looking for escapism (and, I mean, who isn't right now?), Katherine Arden has cooked up something pprreeetttyyy great for us.A friend of mine has been reading this book this year (he's a really, really slow reader). Each time we'd catch up, he'd recommend it to me. I'd smile and nod but, honestly, the way he described it just didn't tickle my fancy. A girl in a cold forest listening to fairy tales while her in-constant-winter town ails? Sounds... kinda boring. And depressing. But after the 10th time he mentioned it (his not finishing it after 10+ months was not a ringing endorsement, by the way), I figured what the hell, if it got him to shh about it already. If nothing else, I could impress said friend with my superior reading skills.As the book began, it seemed like I wasn't going to enjoy it. It read more YA than anything else, and felt a smidge plodding. As I described it to my husband in those first 50 pages: "I mean, it's fun. But it's just kinda... there. It's good brain candy, I guess?"But then Arden got into religion, and I fell in love.Firstly, the main character, Vasilisa/Vasya, is a friggin' heroine. She is young, but she is fiercely independent and intelligent and clever. I'm a broken record in saying so much fantasy relegates women to the sidelines. In The Bear and the Nightingale, Arden acknowledges this trope through the other women in Vasya's life. However, Arden simultaneously shatters through feminine cliches with each action Vasya takes. It is so damn refreshing to read a woman who is brave, who doesn't need a man, who knows that she is enough.The thing that really hooked me, as previously mentioned, is Arden's commentary on religion. One of the chief conflicts of this first installment of her trilogy is when the new priest arrives in town. Konstantin is young, handsome, charismatic, and bored AF having been transferred from Moscow to this sleepy, frigid land. So Konstantin decides he is going to Christian up the joint, hard. Arden effortlessly depicts what early Christianity looked like in rural communities of old. While people accepted the idea of Christianity, they also kept to their old religions: leaving offerings for the spirits, respecting the pagan customs. Konstantin is not about that, and uses fear (you know, something new and different for Christianity), to scare the townsfolk away from tradition.This is fantasy book, however, and so those spirits, the ones the townsfolk abandon, are very real. And, having neglected their customs, the townspeople begin to suffer.I just love how Arden plays with the tension between new religion and old religion. It is so well done, and using the lens of a young woman, still innocent yet becoming more curious, was masterful. I'd hate to say more lest I give too much away, but Vasya is the female hero I've been waiting for. While everyone else cowers behind their new God, she alone will try and save her people. ...more

title: The Running Man
author: Bachman, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I picked up The Running Man I was not expecting a social commentary that remains relevant almost 40 years after publication. King's stories rarelWhen I picked up The Running Man I was not expecting a social commentary that remains relevant almost 40 years after publication. King's stories rarely get me thinking, they (and this may be cruel, but) rarely have anything of actual importance to say. Imagine my surprise.The Running Man takes place in a version of 2025. Here, most people live in incredible poverty. Sick from pollution, unable to work decent jobs, even when they are otherwise qualified. Most people are written off as drug addicts, "maggots," the scourge of "good society." This "good society" consists of a small number of (white, wealthy) people, who live above the muck and the smog.Ben Richards, one of these so-called "maggots," cannot afford medicine for his baby daughter. To give her a shot at life, he heads over to the Games Network. Here, a "maggot" can have a real shot at good money. Sure, you might be maimed or killed in this new breed of reality television, but your corpse will be rich.The shocking thing about this book (written in 1982) is how much our current reality kind of feels like a precursor to a Running Man type of existence. Will we, now, correct course? Or will we turn Stephen King into a Cassandra?PS. There is still some weird race shit in this book. Because of course there is. It's Stephen King. Honestly, if it weren't for that, this book probably deserve 5 stars.PPS. Read this. Then read Bradbury's The Pedestrian. Then read Orwell's 1984. Then start the goddamned revolution. ...more

title: The Long Walk
author: Bachman, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've heard this story referenced as the inspiration for many watch-the-kiddies-kill-each-other tales, and finally, finally I got around to reading it.I've heard this story referenced as the inspiration for many watch-the-kiddies-kill-each-other tales, and finally, finally I got around to reading it. Because what's a dystopian year without a dystopian book to complement it?Stephen King wrote The Long Walk as a freshman in college. As he tells it, he submitted the story somewhere, and, upon receiving a rejection letter, stored the thing until many years had passed and his publisher asked him if he had more planned for his shiny new pseudonym "Richard Bachman." Out came the manuscript, spinoffs, and film adaption hopes from the likes of George Romero. It makes you wonder how many good manuscripts are just molding away in trunks, external hard drives, the cloud, etc. The Long Walk chronicles an American competition. 100 men are chosen, from applications willingly submitted, to compete in a Walk. Starting in Maine, the Walk continues south until there's only one man left standing. That final contestant is the Winner. His prize? Anything he wants. Seem too good to be true? Is there a catch, mayhaps? How very astute of you. There is a catch, for the losers. But I'm not about to tell you what it is.King is tackling a lot in this slim novel. He is commenting on class disparity, on exploitation, on one's inability to assess risk when wealth and fame is on the line. Told through the eyes of one contestant, Garraty, King details men at their bravado-est, and their most vulnerable and broken down. The Long Walk is Marx, pulp edition.I could only give it 3 stars due to the normal King shortcomings. The racial tension he inserts into his book is unsettling. Not in a "you really made me think about that," but in a "fuck, man, you shouldn't be writing that." The gender tension is equally icky. I mean, I get it, we're in the head of a teenage boy. But it's not to my taste, and so it colored how I received the book. The Long Walk is also sketchy. That is, the history of the world he's created sits in the reader's mind as a faint sketch, rather than rich and deep. It's likely intentional, but I could have used a bit more meat to the concept of the Walk and the society that created it; it would have made Garraty's journey all the more harrowing and meaningful. ...more

title: The Poems of Emily Dickinson
author: Dickinson, Emily
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 years after embarking on reading every single Emily Dickinson poem, I've completed my mission. Rating poetry is arbitrary; it's the most subjectiv3.5 years after embarking on reading every single Emily Dickinson poem, I've completed my mission. Rating poetry is arbitrary; it's the most subjective type of writing. Yet here we are.I don't always "get" Emily Dickinson. Sometimes she's writing about bees and I'm like "what are we even doing here?" But other times she hits hard.1789 poems and I earmarked my favorites. Here's a few of my favorite lines:You love me - you are sure -I shall not fear mistake -I shall not cheated wake -Some grinning morn - To find the Sunrise left - And Orchards - unbereft -And Dollie - gone!--I've nothing Else - to bring, You know-So I keep bringing These -Just as the Nights keep fetching StarsTo our familiar eyes ---I can wade Grief -Whole Pools of it -I'm used to that - But the least push of Joy Breaks up my feet - And I tip - drunken - --Sunshine was a sweet place - I liked to stay -But Morn - did'nt want me - now -So- Good night - Day!--She dealt her pretty words like Blades - How glittering they shone -And every One unbared a NerveOr wantoned with a Bone - --'Tis not that Dying hurts us so -'Tis Living - hurts us more - --So fleet thou wert, when present - So infinite - when gone ---Behind Me - dips EternityBefore Me - Immortality -Myself - the Term between - -- I was so happy I forgotTo shut the Door And it went outAnd I am all alone ---That she forgot me was the leastI felt it second painThat I was worthy to forgetWas most I thought upon--We envy the despairThat devastated childhood's realm,So easy to repair....more

title: You Never Forget Your First: A Biography of George Washington
author: Coe, Alexis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This gets filed under "history lite." This book is a biography, sure, but it reads like My First Biography. It's got a bunch of charts and graphs, andThis gets filed under "history lite." This book is a biography, sure, but it reads like My First Biography. It's got a bunch of charts and graphs, and wide margins and blank pages, so, though it clocks in at about 200 pages, it's more like ~170. I'm not trying to shit on Alexis Coe for the slightness of her book; she set out to provide a broad/basic retelling of George Washington's life, and achieved that goal. Plus, where she does focus in are areas that have only been lightly touched by those who came before her. Namely, his relationship to women and slavery. I would have liked more meat to the book, hence the rating, but I do appreciate her unique view and voice in well-traversed territory. Alexis Cole joins a veritable choir of voices, mostly male, who have weighed in on George Washington's life and legacy. She begins her book by knocking out some myths that are untrue (no cherry trees were felled; his teeth were made, not of wood, but of animal ivory and slave teeth), and let's us know that most biographers (who she calls "thigh men," which is hilarious and which I will not explain) focus on what a pillar of America he is, and gloss over the fact that he was, like, human, and thus had flaws... and some bad ones at that.Retelling a biography in  form is boring to even think about, so I won't do it. What I will do is say that I very much enjoyed Coe's bravery in standing up in a room of reverie and yelling "MOTHER MARY WASN'T A FRIGID BITCH. MARTHA WASN'T COLD AND BARREN. WASHINGTON WASN'T BRAVE FOR PUTTING THAT THING ABOUT FREEING SLAVES IN HIS WILL."1. Relying solely on first-person accounts and historical documents, there is no evidence that Mary was a shitty mom. All of that seems to have been made up by the thigh men in the intervening years. Did/do they hate women? I mean, probably.2. In the same vein, a lot of historians have blamed Martha for George Washington not having any biological children. It's important to note that Martha came into the marriage with two children from her previous marriage, and that there is nothing in the historical documents to suggest that she was no longer able to have kids. PLUS, Washington had suffered from many illnesses in his youth that could have rendered him impotent. But the thigh men can't handle that their boi Washington wasn't anything but virile, and so they heap bullshit on Martha. PS. maybe they just didn't want to have more kids? That's also possible, but whatever #pulloutworkswhendonecorrectly3. Many of Washington's contemporaries were freeing their slaves and were on the "right" side of history during his lifetime. His inability to move abolition forward while he was in office is inexcusable. Additionally, his whole "once Martha's dead my slaves can be free" was fucked up for a couple of reasons. a) just free them, dude. b) Martha lived in fear of his slaves until her death, because she was their only obstacle to freedom, and she treated them with fear aka shittily. c) After so many years of marriage, Martha's slaves and Washington's slaves had married and had kids with one another. When Martha died, she gave her slaves away, seemingly at random, to several family members, while Washington's slaves went free. Families were ripped apart; many never saw one another again. So, yea, a wealthy (he often cried poverty, but was full of shit) white man in the 18th century wasn't a great dude. Shocker. ...more

title: Catherine the Great: Portrait of a Woman
author: Massie, Robert K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Because "World History," as it was taught to me in secondary school, consisted solely of Mesopotamia and ancient Egypt/Greece/Rome, I know very littleBecause "World History," as it was taught to me in secondary school, consisted solely of Mesopotamia and ancient Egypt/Greece/Rome, I know very little about Russian history. Most of what I know, actually, stems from that smash 1997 animated feature Anastasia. It's not clear how much of that had, you know, anything to do with reality (talking bats? Rasputin as zombie? But, hey, I learned the word "dasvidaniya" so... points?), but Romanov, at least, is a name I recognize. I didn't come to Catherine the Great, however, due to her ties to the Ramonovs (her husband was a descendant). I sought this book out because, when discussing historical female badasses, Catherine's name consistently tops the list. It felt downright negligent to not know anything about the (German!) woman who claimed the Russian throne and changed how the rest of the world saw the empire.Born Princess Sophie Friederike Auguste von Anhalt-Zerbst-Dornburg (try saying that 10 times fast), Catherine's mother was quick to try and find a suitable match for her daughter. You see, Catherine's mother wanted to be rich and powerful and, having failed to marry into that herself, she decided to offer up her daughter to the highest (read: richest) bidder. Enter her second cousin, Peter. An emotionally abused child who channeled that negligence into cruelty and petulance, Peter treated Catherine as equal parts playmate, mother, and servant. With Empress Elizabeth still ruling, Peter and Catherine found themselves under the thumb of a increasingly embittered, power consolidating woman. This may be an unfair view of Elizabeth. In fact, a lot of the views of historical figures who weren't Catherine didn't necessarily feel fair in this book. Author Robert Massie seems to be not a little bit infatuated with his subject, and it shows with his heavy narrative of "Catherine was treated poorly by a lot of people but she was a badass MF and showed them what's what." While I'm not suggesting the book is historically inaccurate, I do find it curious that Massie takes Catherine at her word in her memoirs, etc. It seems to me she would publicly paint herself in the best light, and, considering how she ruled, I'm skeptical of her being as innocent as she portrays herself before becoming Empress.How did she become Empress? Oh, you know, just overthrowing her husband after a mere 7 months of his ruling.Once she nabs that throne, Catherine outlines sweeping, progressive reforms, most of which get scaled wwaayyy the fuck back (sound familiar? Looks like it's not just democracies that stagnate under the weight of bureaucracy). She did, however, bring Western art and culture to Russia, embracing the teaches of the Enlightenment, even if those teachings didn't extend to the used and abused peasants and serfs in her empire (points to Massie for not shying away from how dirty Catherine did those serfs). Catherine also significantly extended the Russian empire, sending men who adored her to distant lands.Speaking of adoring men, Catherine. Gets. Laid. We always have to read about grossies like King Henry VIII (I mean, they made a friggin' rhyme about him killing off his wives), but we don't read about Catherine banging her way through all these hot, young officers, discarding them after a few years for a newer model? In the 18th century? Get it, girl. Read this, just keep in the back of your mind that Catherine might have been significantly more devious than Massie makes her out to be. Adoring men, indeed. ...more

title: The House of Government: A Saga of the Russian Revolution
author: Slezkine, Yuri
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is totally disingenuous to ping this book as "read," but I think I deserve credit for the limping I was able to do. The House of Government was namIt is totally disingenuous to ping this book as "read," but I think I deserve credit for the limping I was able to do. The House of Government was name-dropped in an article I was reading. After skimming a book jacket that promised "A vivid account of the personal and public lives of Bolshevik true believers... [the] conversion to Communism and... children's loss of faith and the fall of the Soviet Union," I was on board, and reserved it from our newly re-opened library. I don't know much about Russian history; now's a good as time as any to learn. My first shock was being handed a book so thick you could easily concuss someone with it. I hadn't looked at the page count, and so wasn't expecting such a magnum opus, despite a comparison to Tolstoy that that same book jacket had made.Then I opened it.The first part was all about geography and societal set-up. It reminded me of Victor Hugo; you want to get to the meat of the story, but he just wants to tell you about flying buttresses for 20 pages. However, I appreciated that Yuri Slezkine wanted to paint a rich picture of the living conditions pre-revolution, so my eyes marched forward.The second part was entirely about religion. I had absolutely 0 interest in this, and blatantly skipped that part.The third part started to get into what I would call "the good stuff:" the tsar is overthrown, etc. But Slezkine is writing the driest recounting of history here, and feels the need to provide names and backgrounds for the hundreds of players in the social and political spheres. He also assumes a certain level of background knowledge on the part of his readers, which is laughable when you remember he spent 50 pages on fucking Christianity. I couldn't do it. Life is too damn short. I returned the book to the library.I am positive that this book is a banger for some people. I know, for instance, that the 1K+ paged book The Brontes isn't devoured by others like it was by me. But, unfortunately, I'm just not enough of a Russian history nerd to have the pre-requisites to follow this story, nor do I have the patience to slog through the type of minutia in which Slezkine seems to excel. This book is written for some one(s) out there... but it ain't me, babe....more

title: Devolution: A Firsthand Account of the Rainier Sasquatch Massacre
author: Brooks, Max*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Bigfoot is not a well-traversed topic in the horror genre. Unlike World War Z and The Zombie Survival Guide, Brooks did not have to contend with a verBigfoot is not a well-traversed topic in the horror genre. Unlike World War Z and The Zombie Survival Guide, Brooks did not have to contend with a veritable library of canon when constructing his furry monsters. For this reason, I had relatively high hopes for this book.Oh well.Devolution is the story of a tiny eco-village, Greenloop, nestled in the wilderness outside of Mount Rainier. After an eruption cuts them off from supplies and escape back to civilization, this small group tries to figure out how to survive. Also, there seems to be something else living in the woods... (ppssst. It's Bigfoot.)My broad issues are as follows: narration, characterization, pace. NarrationThe book is split into 3 lenses, as recounted by a reporter. The first is the reporter's interviews with a park ranger. The second is interviews with Kate's brother. Who is Kate? Well, the last, and the bulk of the book, is the recovered diary of Greenloop resident Kate Holland. There. That's your Kate.Brooks tries very hard to create an environment of urgency, of stress. Which is why the diary format was the absolute wrong choice for this book. The residents of Greenloop are moving at a lightning pace to try and set up gardens and fortify themselves against attacks and Kate (view spoiler)[who becomes their fucking master and commander (hide spoiler)] wastes so much time writing in her goddamn journal. Her husband, Dan, is frantically rewiring their smart houses, and she's just sitting there, journaling away. And, as the tension mounts, and as the threats seemingly become more real, this vision of someone tucking away to journal becomes more ridiculous. (view spoiler)[The part that made me actually groan out loud is toward the climax. Kate's specification in the town has become weapons expert. She is sitting, creating all of these different weapons in the workshop (which is set far away from where everyone else is holed up) when she decides to start journaling. Instead of, you know, making as many weapons as possible. Then, she starts to hear the hooting/grunting of the approaching predators. She journals until they get so loud she realizes it's time to fight and she better get over to the Common House, where everyone else is ANXIOUSLY AWAITING GETTING WEAPONS SO THEY CAN DEFEND THEMSELVES FROM AN ENEMY THAT IS FUCKING AT THEIR GATES. Oh, and when she gets to the Common House THEY'RE ALL ASLEEP. So she was journaling, listening to the predators get closer, all the while her community and her HUSBAND were sleeping, trusting her to wake them in time to get ready?! What the actual fuck. THEN, when it's all over, when everyone is dead except her and Pal, she just... stops? Brooks tries to cover this up with the brother being like "she stopped writing after the epic battle because it was the end of one chapter and she was beginning a new chapter." Plot, meet cop-out. Journaling helps with trauma, that's the reason Kate is keeping a journal to begin with, because her therapist told her it would help with the sussing out of things. Then, when she experiences real, horrifying trauma, she gives up the pen? Maybe it's because the horrifying trauma is partially the journal's fault?! Nah, Kate is too dumb for that. It's because Brooks picked a stupid narration form and had to stop somewhere (hide spoiler)]. I'm going to make it about me for a second. I am a regular journaler. I've been journaling since I was in grade school. And guess what? When shit is going down? I do not journal. When I'm camping with my husband? I don't sit there and journal away while he constructs our shelter and makes us food. I'm there working with him. The idea that someone who is racing against the clocks of winter and predators would sit down and journal constantly is fucking stupid. She mentions so many times that she's not sleeping. (view spoiler)[ This lack of sleep even results in REINHARDT'S MURDER (hide spoiler)]. Yet, she spends hours (considering the length of her journal entries) writing. Like, no. CharacterizationKate, the main character, is utterly unlikable. Mostly because of the whole "I'm gonna sit here and journal while everyone else is running around," but also for the waffling in her characterization. She is equal parts the leader, and the stupidest fucking person to ever exist. (view spoiler)[ She knows how deadly the predators are, and yet SHE GOES UP INTO THE WOODS ALONE. What?! She knows they're attracted to movement and light, yet she INSISTS ON WATCHING EVERYTHING THAT HAPPENS THROUGH THE WINDOWS. She becomes the weapons expert, BUT ONLY AFTER MOSTAR SAVES HER LIFE FROM HER OWN STUPIDITY AND INSISTS THAT SHE LEARN. Also, that learning happened, what, a day before the final battle? Bitch, please.  (hide spoiler)]. Also, why does she have to know the calories in everything/be workout and body obsessed? I am a healthy woman, who works out daily. I do not know the calories of everything. I could just be petty at this point, but this felt goddamn sexist to me. Mostar, the real hero of the story, is strong, capable, calculating. Yet, for some reason, she insists on helping the stupidest fucking person to ever exist, Kate. (view spoiler)[ I think Brooks was trying to suggest that Mostar saw her lost daughter in Kate. But we'll never know, because he chose the fucking diary route of narration. Another thing that really, really bothered me is that Kate is objectively stupid, yet it was Kate who realized she could use the 3D printer to fabricate weapons. No. Mostar would have figured that out after Day 1. How dare you do Mostar like that, Brooks (hide spoiler)]. The diary narration does not allow us to learn much about Mostar, and Kate doesn't bother to try and learn anything about the person single-handedly saving her, because she doesn't care (she actually says that multiple times in her journal. That it seems like Mostar wants to tell her about her past, but Kate doesn't want to ask, so doesn't, and so Mostar doesn't say anything). Mostar is a great character. Too bad Brooks didn't bother to do anything with her.The community of Greenloop was created by a couple, known collectively as the Durants. And they make NO SENSE AT ALL. (view spoiler)[The first day after the eruption they do some brief recon and then... hide in their house? One of them slowly decomposing in his own filth and the other perpetually working out on the elliptical? Like... what? Also, the fact that everyone is pooling their resources and battening down the hatches, yet they don't bang down the Durants door to demand supplies/their assistance? That's fucking stupid. Only when shit is getting really bad do they go, and only then to try and protect the couple. No one is that altruistic. Brooks spends so much of the book laying out how we're all animals and how we're all capable of "devolution" if the situation warrants it. Yet they just let the Durants be while they're restricting calories and fortifying a barracks. Right. Whatever.  (hide spoiler)]PaceI think Brooks just didn't have enough material in his brain, which is why the pace is as follows: here we are in this new community OH NO ERUPTION OH NO THE WOODS OH NO OH NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO. He doesn't spend much time at all fleshing out his characters. Not even Kate, whose diary we're reading. All I know about her is that she didn't really like her husband and she counts calories and she has anxiety. Wow. Way to go. There was very little fleshing out of the environment. And this is definitely not a "slow burn" horror. We get one nice dinner and then it's BOOM BANG BRAINS AGAINST THE PAVEMENT. I say I have a problem with the pace, but as I write this I realize there isn't really a pace to have a problem with. Fin....more

title: Great Expectations
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Why did no one tell me that Great Expectations was so funny?? There is absolutely 0 point in running down the plot of one of the most famous works of Why did no one tell me that Great Expectations was so funny?? There is absolutely 0 point in running down the plot of one of the most famous works of literature. So I'll save it for my niece when she turns, like, 10.But here is why you should read it, if you haven't already:Dickens is an unapologetic dick to his protagonist Pip. Pip is quintessential young-man-growing-up: thinks he's entitled to everything, doesn't realize what an ass he's being, follows his fancies rather than acknowledging reality. And he gets kicked in the butt for it again and again. It's a great read. You love to hate Pip. You feel kind of bad for him because he's just a bumbling kid, but you still love it. Sure, the book is written as a retrospective, and you can feel the remorse of current-day-narrator-Pip as he recounts his youthful foibles. But, like, screw you Pip.Similarly, Ms. Havisham and Estella are mustache-twirling-ly cruel. I hated them too, and enjoyed every minute of that hating. Sometimes books have a swath of unlikable characters and it's exhausting to read. But Dickens has somehow managed to cram a bunch of assholes between his pages and you can't help but continue to turn the page. Post Script: I own an old/random edition of this book (it doesn't have a publishing date, and was clearly written on a typewriter. Thank you estate sales), which contains both endings Dickens wrote: his original ending, and then the initially publicized ending (a friend of his suggested he not go with the original, because it was too dark). Unsurprisingly, the original ending is much better than the originally publicized and far more optimistic ending. So, if you get a version that only provides one ending, pop on the internet and make sure you know both!...more
