title: In the Woods        (Dublin Murder Squad, #1)
author: French, Tana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm still reeling with uncertainty: did I like this book? Did I really like this book? Did I, actually, dislike it? You tell me.In the Woods is a firsI'm still reeling with uncertainty: did I like this book? Did I really like this book? Did I, actually, dislike it? You tell me.In the Woods is a first person narration; a story told by Adam Robert Ryan (he goes by Rob, now, thanks), a murder detective in Dublin. A young girl is murdered in the rural town of Knocknaree, and Rob and his partner Cassie are on the case. But, of all things, Rob grew up in Knocknaree. What's more: when he was 12 he and his two best friends disappeared into the woods one day, and Rob was the only child seen again. The reader watches as thwaw two plots twist and weave between one another. Is there something supernatural at play? Are the old disappearances and this new murder connected? Will the return of the prodigal son (Rob) uncover secrets left dormant for decades? French's writing style keeps you turning those pages. She's written a rich landscape with dozens of characters. Most whodunnits are very dialogue and plot-point heavy. But French's prose elevate the detective genre to something I didn't realize I wanted it to be.But, listen, I wanted to know what happened to the present-day (2007) young girl, sure, but far, far more intriguing was what happened twenty years ago: how did Rob's two friends just disappear? Why were his shoes, when he was found back then, filled with someone else's blood? Why were there three large rips in the back of his shirt? This was the really interesting thread of the book, in my opinion. 1984 captured my interest far more than 2007. That's not to knock the 2007 plot. I didn't see the reveal(s) coming, which is always welcome, and those aforementioned dozens of characters are well fleshed-out. These days, whodunnits have, like, three central characters, and you're like "well, shit, okay, it's one of these three, clearly. Way to narrow it down." But French has a veritable amphitheater full of potential murderers. To that I say: bravo.But now we get to the bit that sets my teeth on edge. The main character? Rob Ryan? Suuuccckkksss. He's the goddamn worst. He's sexist, for one. Every woman he meets he wants pull to himself and shelter them from the storms of life. Like, listen dude. We're not all delicate flowers who need a man to protect us. Including his own partner! The badass, totally independent Cassie. He's supposed to know her, they're best friends, but he can't see beyond her boobs. And, for him, boobs = needs a man as a buffer for this cruel, cruel world. French is a woman, so I assume she wrote Rob like this intentionally, but it made me so angry I sometimes had to put the book down in disgust. Also, Rob is objectively terrible at his job, which was also really difficult to read. The number of times he compromises the investigation or does something borderline illegal is enough to drive a reader insane. Again, this has to be intentional, but it was exhausting to be trapped with a frustrating narrator with no redeemable qualities and a shitty attitude for 400 pages. TL/DR: The prose are beautiful, it's a well-written and surprising whodunnit, but the main character is a shitbird of a person from whom you walk away with vehement hate.There is one other thing that monumentally annoyed me, but it spoils everything, so... you've been warned.(view spoiler)[As I previously mentioned, I was far more invested in the 1984 disappearances. Was it truly something supernatural? Did the religious import of the wood result in some sort of swallowing of Jamie and Peter back then? Was it a deranged teenager? Or maybe just your run-of-the-mill serial killer/pedophile? Well, we'll never know, because French writes it all away by having Rob Ryan state he'll never remember what happened that day, and that all the evidence is degraded/the detectives on that case let it go/no one cares. Well, I care! I had to hop onto Wikipedia to see if the disappearances ever crop up in her other books, but they don't, and I am sorely disappointed. I'm almost certain I know why French didn't tie up this thread. Like most monster reveals, the truth is so much less sensational than the fear and anticipation of the unknown. French decided that leaving Jamie and Peter as a question mark would spare her the risk of writing a shitty/boring/contrived ending. But I hate that, and it made me mad, and so here we are at three stars.  (hide spoiler)]...more

title: So You've Been Publicly Shamed
author: Ronson, Jon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What is shame? Why do we feel it? How does it destroy us? And how can we move past it?Jon Ronson isn't going to answer these questions, but he's got sWhat is shame? Why do we feel it? How does it destroy us? And how can we move past it?Jon Ronson isn't going to answer these questions, but he's got some fun anecdotes for us.Ronson's writing style if very engaging. He meanders around this central topic, dropping asides, going down rabbit holes only to lose interest and go "next!" I could see how reading him might be frustrating, but it only piques my interest in certain topics more, resulting in further research and reading up on the microtopics he briefly introduces. Only in a Ronson book will you read about the porn industry and then immediately swivel to internet reputation businesses and then swivel to prison systems and then to a woman who made a bad joke on Twitter. Maybe this isn't his intent: to make us curious and do our own research, but I'd rather no one tell me if his writing style is purely due to ADD.In So You've Been Publicly Shamed Ronson begins with his own shame: a Twitter bot using his face and name, tweeting out random crap about food and porn. From there, he wonders about the concept of shame in the first place, launching the reader into several stories of reputations taken down by the masses of the internet. A corporation shamed on Twitter after doing something reprehensible can be a force for good; that same shaming culture causing someone to lose their livelihood over a bad joke? Maybe not so much. Ronson suggests that maybe we think before we heap judgment onto others; before we allow our legal systems to use shame as punishment. In an age of instant gratification, maybe just, like, stop a sec.For me, the most interesting portion of this book centered around profound shaming in childhood (read: shame as abuse), and how that plays out in crime once that individual has grown. The trope of the picked-on kid having a hit list in adulthood is worn out, sure, but it exists for a reason. The fact that shaming plays out in courts and in prisons? Is that really helping us?Who and how we shame has the potential to shape our society. Ronson wants us to ask the question: what sort of society do we wish to be? ...more

title: Little Fires Everywhere
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If nothing else, Little Fires Everywhere was exactly what I expected it to be. That is: easy-to-digest fluff that didn't make me feel much of anythingIf nothing else, Little Fires Everywhere was exactly what I expected it to be. That is: easy-to-digest fluff that didn't make me feel much of anything, in a world where I'm feeling a bit too much a bit too often.General premise is a standard trope: cool, poor, single mom and her quiet daughter move into an upper crust neighborhood, presumably for good, after 15+ years on the road. The daughter falls in with a rich family (read: rich boy has crush), and drama between said families ensues. Little Fires Everywhere is a perfectly passable way to spend some time, but a good novel it is not. The characters are not well-developed. Who is Mrs. Richardson, really? We get the briefest of glimpses into her formative years, but it is very clear author Celeste Ng had a richer idea of the character in her head, and just chose not to share that version with us. Mia is a walking GD contradiction. Self-sabatoging but with a heart a gold, but that heart really only shines for people who are not her daughter? She could provide appropriately for her daughter, but chooses not to because, well, it's not really clear why. For "her art," I guess. Whatever. Dude, I hated Mia. Mia's quiet daughter, Pearl, is a cardboard cut-out character. No depth whatsoever, and, honestly the same could be said for the 4 Richardson children. Even Izzy, the precocious black sheep, has no real substance, there is no real unpacking as to why she is the way that she is, and at the close of the book I was just kinda like "uuh... well.. okay then I guess?"The conflicts are boring. I mean, Ng gets credit for bringing abortion to the stage. Even in 2020 people are still scared to talk about abortion (don't even get me started with the 2016 Gilmore Girls revival. Rory. You can terminate this pregnancy). But even that aspect of the book felt more like a device to get to what Ng thought was a "better" conflict (it wasn't), and the direct fallout from that decision was only vaguely touched upon. The other conflicts: a hidden past, a King Solomon dilemma, a forbidden love, were yawn-tastic.The book just isn't well-written. This borders on being mean for the sake of it, but Ng doesn't provide lush detail in her prose, yet fails to provide the snappy/blunt dialogue of a Hemingway. So, yea, blase at best.All-in-all, if you're looking for something to shut your brain off, this is definitely it. You can read this after downing a bottle of wine and not miss much in the way of important plot points or beautiful language. Cause, you know, there is none.Spoiler bone-to-pick below.(view spoiler)[Yea, so, the thing I disliked most about this book was the "conflict" between Linda and Mark Mccullough, and Bebe. Apparently this is a hot button thing, and, based on the length of time Ng spent on this secondary plot, something Ng probably watched play out in real life. But for me I was just sitting there like "yo, she's not a fit mother, clearly, and she abandoned her baby. What selfish woman would do a take-backsy and choose a life of poverty and uncertainty and fear for their child over comfort and security?" This might be my social deviance showing, but it just seemed so clear cut: The Mcculloughs should have the baby, and Bebe sucks. I had a neighbor who fostered kids - kids who had been malnourished and lived in fear before arriving at my neighbor's door. When their bio mom would come around it was awful on so many levels. Those children deserved safety. All children deserve safety. People should think twice about having kids if they cannot provide that safety. Do you know what it's like to have to go over expenses with your mother when you're 12yrs old and worry about food? It's not fair and- holy shit, okay, we're unpacking my stuff now. Best leave that for the therapist. So much for not feeling much of anything. But, yea, fuck Bebe.  (hide spoiler)]...more

title: The Way of Kings        (The Stormlight Archive, #1)
author: Sanderson, Brandon*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Way of Kings was entertaining enough that I didn't abandon it despite its 1200+ page count. I didn't like it enough, however, to ever plan to readThe Way of Kings was entertaining enough that I didn't abandon it despite its 1200+ page count. I didn't like it enough, however, to ever plan to read another installment, despite the massive cliff hanger it ended on. Author Brandon Sanderson has created a fantasy world all its own in his Stormlight Archive series. From what we can see in this first installment, Sanderson's world is populated by several races of humans, fighting one another as well as fighting their natural environment. They are also ravaged by what they call High Storms - crazy wind/rain storms that can kill a man left out alone. A man, you say? Not women? We'll get to Sanderson's women in due time.Book #1 here primarily focuses on:Kaladin: a warrior-turned-slaveDalinar: brother of a king, who is all into war and shit... or is he?Shallan: a young woman, looking to become a scholar... maybeKaladin takes up the lion share of the narrative. He spends much of the book on "The Shattered Plains," a cracked, desert-esque landscape, where two races of people are fighting over "gemhearts," actual hearts they cut out of creatures. It's gross... and kind of stupid. We watch Kaladin as he struggles with his Lawful Good personality. The sheer amount of times he goes "No!!!!!!!!!" is distracting. We get it, man, you're living through war. But, this is why Lawful Good isn't a popular choice when creating a D&D character. It's boring. It's exhausting. Kaladin doesn't think logically, he thinks along the lines of some random, masculine honor code he cooked up, that really only makes sense to him. He is supposed to be our hero, and I hate him.One of the many reasons I hate Kaladin, is because much of Sanderson's race structure is filtered through him. To call the characters in this book racist is an understatement. These characters are goddamn bigots. I started taking screenshots of particular fucked up passages, just to keep it all straight. Take the following, where Kaladin meets a parshman, one of the more abused races in the book:He glanced over his shoulder at the parshman. He was a little taller than most, his face a little wider, but they all looked about the same to Kaladin.They also start to straight up torture that same parshman later, but I won't bore you with how horrifying that was. Oh, and did I mention that parshman have skin of black with red marbling? Right.There's also this whole lighteyes vs. darkeyes thing that... I mean... why? Can you guess which is inferior?While we're talking about Kaladin, let's mention the battles scenes. There are dozens. They are long winded. They are boring. It's interesting, because even though one warrior in this book becomes increasingly repulsed by war, Sanderson seems to revel in it. This book did not need to be as long as it was. I started skimming the battle passages early on. So let's skip over to Shallan: the main, and one of only three fleshed out female characters in, again a 1,200+ page novel. Shallan is a young girl who pursues a wardship under Jasnah, a scholar and relatively badass woman (the third and final woman is royal matriarch Navani, who is really only there to try and bang Dalinar). Shallan is vapid and mostly thinks about marriage and drawing, so we're not really going to talk about her. Instead, we're going to talk about Jasnah. Jasnah is not religious, she is brilliant, she is a magic wielder. But, because she is Woman, her pursuits and intelligence are mostly filtered through how she interacts with male scholars and with her uncle, Dalinar. What's more, at one point Jasnah purposely goes out and confronts these 4 murderer guys, and all Shallan can think about is how Jasnah, by going to confront them, was asking to be murdered. That's right, everyone. Shallan is all you can't just go and confront bad guys and not expect them to try and murder you. That's just asking for it. Fuck the fuck off, Sanderson. If you were trying to draw this rape parallel to achieve something meaningful, you failed. This utterly offended me.Speaking of offending me, for reasons we won't get into Shallan finds herself with a mortal wound on her arm at one point. She's ultimately fine, but everyone thinks she did it on purpose... to commit suicide over a guy. They actually joke about it in front of her. The guy in question visits her at her sick bed with treats and Jasnah makes fun of him by saying: "I'm sorry I drove you to suicide. Here's some bread." Again, Sanderson, if you were trying to say something meaningful about how women are perceived, etc., you didn't. Despite how exhaustive you are about battles, you drop shit like this without unpacking it at all. Sanderson leaves hints throughout the book that maybe the bigotry and sexism will ultimately be turned on its head in this series. Dalinar's growing disillusionment with war is probably going to result in some sort of crazy revelation 5 books down the line, and Sanderson has already dropped hints in book #1 here that maybe lighteyes are not inherently better than darkeyes... but who wants to read tens of thousands of pages of racist bullshit just to find out in the end that racism is bad, mmk?I am so sick and tired of fantasy using the medieval model for their story telling. It is FANTASY. It could be ANYTHING. To always go back to women in subservient roles (in this series, women have to hide a hand, called a "safehand," at all times. What the actual fuck), to always have slaves and racism... didn't Ursula Le Guin teach anybody anything?There's so much more to unpack here: the "spren," pixie-like entities that live on/in most things; Stormlight and the magic within; whatever-the-fuck a "Truthless" is. But I don't care, so we won't go there. A (white, male) friend of mine just happened to start reading this book shortly after me. I complained to him about the whole outdated set-up of "darks" and "Woman" being less-than. You know what he said to me? That he. Hadn't. Noticed. The only thing that had offended him was that men don't read or write in this world, because it is womanly.Hahahahahhahahahahhaha.......Also, this clunky and also sexist simile:It was done with nonchalance, like a woman pausing to wipe a spot on the counter....more

title: Tyll
author: Kehlmann, Daniel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Translated from its original German, Tyll smacks of medieval, even with the story of Tyll moved from his original ~15th century setting (yes, this booTranslated from its original German, Tyll smacks of medieval, even with the story of Tyll moved from his original ~15th century setting (yes, this book is based on a character already existing) and dropped into the 17th during the 30 years war. A disjointed timeline (my favorite) Daniel Kehlmann takes the reader on a journey through Tyll's life, beginning in the prime of his performing years, bouncing back to his childhood, then toward the end of his journey, and there and back again. I want everyone to read this book, if for nothing else than as a study in translation. Ross Benjamin manages to retain the lyricism of the text, despite having to take the original grammar and completely flip it and reverse it. The translations of German to English I had to do in college were clunky at best. Benjamin reminds us what a nuanced and difficult job translation can be, and the magic it brings when done correctly.Tyll is a man, brought up the son of a poor miller with a curious mind, who goes on an adventure rather than see his fate out in anonymity. Through a serious of seemingly random occurrences, in different shades of malevolent, Tyll grows and learns the tricks of the performer trade, and of living on one's own in the forests and streets. There is witchcraft, religion, science, royalty; there are made up and historical figures interacting and arguing; there are prose in praise of nature, and prose in warning of the cruelty of humans.What I really want to talk to you about, though, are the death scenes. There are many, and they are beautiful. There is the person who is executed, the person who slips away in old age, but the shining star of Tyll is the character who becomes ill and, feverishly, comes in and out of consciousness, trying to make sense of what is happening. I will leave you with a sample, in hopes it will convince you to go out and buy this book. You know, when we're allowed out of our homes. He heard the choir and thought of the fairy tale about the spindle that his mother had once told him. Suddenly it seemed very important, but his memory wouldn't put it in the correct order: when you unwound thread from the spindle, a piece of life was unwound too, and the quicker you turned it, say ,because you were in a hurry or because something was hurting you or because things were not the way you wanted, the quicker life went by too, and the man in the fairy tale had already come to the end of the thread, and everything was over and yet had hardly even begun....more

title: Giovanni's Room
author: Baldwin, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How subtle, the timid self-loathing that comes along with realizing you are not the person you wanted to be; that you're not the person others expect How subtle, the timid self-loathing that comes along with realizing you are not the person you wanted to be; that you're not the person others expect you to be. To capture that feeling on paper? Is nothing short of remarkable. James Baldwin brought this manuscript to publisher Knopf, and Knopf told him to burn the book rather than actually allow it to come to life. They advised that the book would ruin him, and attempted, in the way only Big Publishing can, to silence him.Well, Baldwin published Giovanni's Room anyway, and we are all better for it, though, also, devastated.Because, truly, if I had to pick one work to describe Giovanni's Room, it would be "devastating." Baldwin perfectly captures the suicidal ideation; the self-deprecation and hatred that society forces on a person who is considered Other. Giovanni's Room follows David, a (white) American living in Paris, as he reflects on his life and his choices one significant night in his tiny, dirty European apartment. He internally recounts his childhood, his relationships, and Giovanni, the man who awakened in him everything he fought to keep asleep. The reader bounces from present-day David, thinking on the past and unraveling, ever so slightly, to past-David, traipsing through Paris and trying to balance who he should be and what makes him happy. One can feel the poignant internal struggle in Baldwin himself, to accept himself, even if the rest of the world had not yet realized that who one loves does not define their character. It's heartbreaking, and a reminder that, even all these years later, we still have so much more to learn about love and acceptance. Favorite quote:People who believe that they are strong-willed and the masters of their destiny can only continue to believe this by becoming specialists in self-deception. Their decisions are not really decisions at all - a real decision makes one humble, one knows that it is at the mercy of more things than can be named - but elaborate systems of evasion, of illusion, designed to make themselves and the world appear to be what they and the world are not....more

title: Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know About the People We Don’t Know
author: Gladwell, Malcolm
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There comes a point where you've read so many sociology/psychology pop-nonfiction books, that you know all the science/experiments behind the anecdoteThere comes a point where you've read so many sociology/psychology pop-nonfiction books, that you know all the science/experiments behind the anecdotes the author totes out to back up the theme of their book. What I'm trying to say is: the science Malcolm Gladwell covers isn't new ground for me. However, his thesis is wildly important for all of us to think on. Malcolm Gladwell is a behemoth in the nonfiction world. He's spent the past 20+ years writing about how and why humans think, act, and interact the way that they do. In Talking to Strangers, Galdwell attempts to unpack how we cooperate and deceive one another, and what this says about the framework of modern day trust in our society. The reader dips into vignettes about Adolf Hitler, Fidel Castro, Bernie Madoff, and Slyiva Plath, to name a few. He unpacks how inept our lawyers and law enforcement officers are at picking out liars and truth-tellers, and how physical presentations of anxiety, deception, etc. are just constructs, and do not actually tell us the underlying truth of any given person. He touches on suicide as opportunity (which was, in my opinion, the most fascinating part of the book); what constitutes consciousness and consent; and how we regularly, daily, misunderstand one another. There are some really tough parts of this book. Gladwell covers the Sandra Bland case, as well as the case of sexual assault against Brock Turner. These stories are not for the weak-stomached, but they represent important ground as one unpacks the human social experience. While not a groundbreaking book, I'd honestly love to see it taught in high schools. Talking to Strangers is a critical eye on how we relate to and interact with strangers and intimates alike, and where our society might be headed if we don't pull up and re-examine ourselves and how we treat and interpret others. ...more

title: Virginia Woolf
author: Lee, Hermione
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was a bit of a slog. Well, duh you say. it's an 893 page biography. It's inevitable that it would be a bit of slogYou're not wrong. But justThis book was a bit of a slog. Well, duh you say. it's an 893 page biography. It's inevitable that it would be a bit of slogYou're not wrong. But just this summer I read Robert Massie's 625 page Catherine the Great and positively ripped through it. Juliet Barker's The Brontes is an intimidating 1003 pages, and I was almost sad when it ended. All this defending to say: I am no stranger to the verbose biography. But this was... just... look, I don't want to say that it was painful. But bits of this book weren't not painful.I picked up this book because Virginia Woolf has written, to me, the most tragic, most beautiful, and most layered prose. Period. Every single book of hers makes me cry, and I can't  any of her books without quoting extensively from them. That said, I knew very, very little about Virginia Woolf the person, save her suicide note and that she put rocks in her pockets and walked into a lake or something.**it was actually one rock and she threw herself into a river.A tiny gripe about this book is that it is NOT linear most of the time. The first chapter just explains the houses Virginia Woolf lived in. Chapters like "Madness" - where Lee bops around about all of Virginia's different breakdowns; and "Abuses" - where Lee talks about Virginia's half brothers and the sexual assault she likely suffered by their hands, squiggle all over Virginia's timeline. Not only is this jarring, but it also means that this book repeats itself at times. Not cute for a book as big as this one. My #1 gripe, however, is that this book is both wildly granular, and yet still held Virginia Woolf at arms length. Walking away from this book I know so much I didn't need to know, but feel as though I was never able to really peer behind the curtain of Virginia Woolf the person.Lee spent an entire chapter going over Leonard's (Virginia's husband) various investments and the financial yield they provided the household. Why? Why was this necessary? There was also an entire chapter on the printing press Virginia and Leonard owned. I'm talking make, model, how it worked. WHY, LEE, WHY?!Yet, despite that level of detail, and despite the public nature of Virginia Woolf's diaries, the letters between herself and her friends, and letters between her friends and other friends ABOUT her, Lee shied away from really unpacking Virginia. Her sexual relationships with women, and how she felt about herself and her place in the world are still totally foreign to me after reading this book. Virginia Woolf was an anxious, neurotic, slightly racist, slightly classist genius, who survived several breakdowns until one ultimately got the best of her. That's all I really took away from this experience. More about those takeaways though:Racism: the Dreadnought hoax. Classism: I honestly don't want to go into it, but basically she hated everyone who worked for her and called them horrible things for no reason. Even the woman who worked for her with whom was likely sleeping was not immune to her sharp tongue.Familial relationships: Virginia was creepily close with her sister Vanessa, and with Vanessa's children... especially the daughter Angelica. This comes across VERY clearly even in a narrative like Lee's, where it sometimes feels like she's watching Virginia through the wrong end of the telescope. So that was... kinda gross. At this point I feel about Virginia Woolf the way I feel about Tom Cruise: I love their work, but they're objectively shitty people.Don't meet your heroes and all that.Look, Hermione Lee deserves major kudos for her work. Writing a biography on Virginia Woolf was undoubtedly a massive, and sometimes frustrating, undertaking. Because of this, it seems as though Lee got in her own way a bit, and got too bogged down in insignificant details (say, the make and model of Virginia's printing press), which obscured what this book was really supposed to be about. I commend Lee, but I was relieved when I turned the final page. ...more

title: Uncanny Valley
author: Wiener, Anna*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Everyone was freaking out about this book, so I decided I'd try to be cool and jump on the bandwagon early, the better to impress acquaintances duringEveryone was freaking out about this book, so I decided I'd try to be cool and jump on the bandwagon early, the better to impress acquaintances during forced small talk.Well, I gotta re-think my casual verbal banter, because all I came away with upon finishing Uncanny Valley was: "meh."Anna Wiener graduated from college into the recession, and struggled at NYC publishing jobs that paid basically nothing and expected her to thank them for it. I feel this deeply, because this was me. I did so much work for NYC publishing houses FOR FREE in my early 20s, because they made me feel like I had to, because they had this bizarre pay-your-dues mentality. They made me think if I worked my for-money job and then did free work for them at night, eventually they'd pay me $25K (with no benefits) to be able to not afford NYC. And I was excited about that! That is, until I realized I needed to, you know, eat and make rent. ENOUGH ABOUT ME. Wiener had that same realization: food and shelter are kinda great, and so she jumped ship and moved onto an e-book start-up. From there, she bopped around to a couple of different start-ups, moved to San Francisco, and struggled with whether she "belonged" in a sea of male computer science majors.I'm not going to undercut the importance of a book like this existing. While it's a poorly kept secret that Silicon Valley has a gender gap even Gandalf couldn't make his way out of, having a book by a woman who actually worked within that gap can help move it back into conversations. This could maybe, just maybe, help to ultimately mitigate all that inequality bullshit. However, Wiener's writing just... it isn't great, man. It reads like a freshman seminar essay. You know the kind: their High School English teacher encouraged them write, so they think they're the next Faulkner and just dump all their thoughts onto a page. The result is garbled rambling. You, the overworked, underpaid TA, have to liberally exercise your red pen and crush their dreams: they're not Faulkner; they're just a mediocre writer like the majority of us. I would get bored reading another Wiener description of a to-go lunch, of another string of emojis popping up in the company's group chat, and then I'd realize that I had turned 3 pages without remembering anything. Her writing just isn't compelling; her lens isn't unique.In those same freshman seminars, one of the first things that poor TA says is: "ask yourself: does this need to be written? And am I the one to write it?" In this case, this book does need to be written, but by someone else. Sorry, Wiener (lol)....more

title: Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland
author: Keefe, Patrick Radden
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I did NOT learn about The Troubles. Not in high school, not in college. Even now, as an adult whose job requires me to log into multiple news sources I did NOT learn about The Troubles. Not in high school, not in college. Even now, as an adult whose job requires me to log into multiple news sources daily, I knew very, very little about the history of Northern Ireland.But then Derry Girls came out. Wildly clever thing, that Derry Girls. Take the trope of a bunch of young women coming-of-age, going to high school, shenanigans with nuns, then fold it into the violence and fear and uncertainty of all of thing happening in the 1990s when The Troubles were still very much a thing. So, Patrick Radden Keefe's Say Nothing was published at the exact right moment, when people were already talking about this particular bit of history, and realizing how little the broader public knows.Keefe researched the ever-loving shit out of this book. Seriously. The notes at the back end take up roughly 100 pages. He begins with a brief history of Protestant vs. Catholic; loyalist vs. republican, then focuses on the hot beds of the 1970s - early 2000s. After that, he even takes the reader up to 2018; it feels like he likely researched this book up to the day he finished writing. It's that contemporary, it's that well researched.Then what the fuck, B, you might be saying. You gave this book 3 stars. What, ya running out or something?No. I have one giant complaint about this book, and it might not be fair, but it is the reason I took so long to finish the book.Because of the scope of this conflict, Keefe introduces dozens and dozens of people as the book goes on. Sometimes you meet someone, they disappear for 80 pages, and then come back. However, because of the saturation of names in Say Nothing, it was nearly impossible to keep everyone straight. I wish Keefe had begun each chapter with a sort of spider-ing graphic of who the players were going to be in that chapter, and how they related to the primary characters of Jean McConville (one of the Disappeared), Brendan Hughes (IRA), Gerry Adams (IRA), and Dolours Price (IRA). I kept getting confused, flipping through the book, checking up on Wikipedia, and, in some cases, just rolling my eyes and giving up, accepting that I just wasn't going to ever understand how this puzzle piece fit into the broader tapestry. I acknowledge that this might not be fair. Keefe is taking on a colossal undertaking with this book, and he did do a great job. But, like many nonfictions, Say Nothing sometimes gets mired in the details. The need for accuracy detracts from narrative. A good thing for a journalist, but a cumbersome thing for a reader. This book is definitely worth a read, for the information you'll get out of it alone. However, maybe keep a notebook next to you. You know, so you don't get super lost/confused/frustrated like me. ...more

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
author: Owens, Delia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's a well worn plot: something bad happens to someone beloved in a small town, and the social outcast is suspected. Where the Crawdads Sing could haIt's a well worn plot: something bad happens to someone beloved in a small town, and the social outcast is suspected. Where the Crawdads Sing could have been a drag to read if it had simply followed the deep ruts books before it had made. However, Delia Owens achieves enough originality and depth of character to sidestep tedium and come out with an entertaining, if relatively predictable, story.The reader needs to suspend a bit of disbelief within these pages. We meet main character Kya at ~6yrs old, as her mother abandons her family of 5 children with their alcoholic, abusive father. Following this abandonment, each sibling systematically leaves the home, leaving their helpless youngest sibling, Kya, to fend for herself (this was incredibly hard for me to read. I could have NEVER left my brothers when they were tiny bbs. But I do know these things happen. See Educated, amirite?). Anyway, the alcoholic father ultimately disappears, so Kya has to figure out how to keep the house up and eat regularly and just generally survive. She lives in a shack in North Carolina marshes, and the townsfolk judge such people as subhuman. However, the idea that not a single person would attempt to take in a clearly abandoned small child is sort of unbelievable. Owens briefly talks about racism and classicism in her book (the timeline of which spans, for the most part, from 1952-1970), but Kya is white, and is coming into town as a barefoot, starving, beautiful child. It's difficult for me to fully buy into the idea that no one, save for a dock worker called "Jumpin'" and his wife Mabel, provide any assistance, preferring for this little kid to perish in the elements and the wilds.Moving on. Kya grows up on her lonesome, uneducated, illiterate, the seagulls she wastes precious food on as her only "family." But then a fellow kid takes an interest in her, a friendship forms, and she becomes more socially acceptable. As she ages and gets mega-hot, she catches the eye of football star/total D-bag Chase, who wakes up dead one morning in 1969 and, whoopsie! the town thinks it's gotta be Kya, The Marsh Girl (now 24yrs old).There's not much more to say about the plot without giving things away. If you're reading this and thinking "what do you mean she becomes more socially acceptable?" I mean this bitch learns to read, learns the Latin words for everything around her, becomes smarter than most of the people she interacts with in town. Unlikely? You're telling me. But the reader spends so much time in Kya's head as she navigates profound loneliness, that you want her to be a genius, so you forgive Owens for the fantastical nature of her protagonist. I've been sassy up until this point, and it might seem like I didn't enjoy this book. But I really did: the way that I enjoy listening to the Top 100 radio station or sitting down with my sister-in-law to watch reality television. It's not my cup of tea all the time, but sometimes there's a gem in the fluff, one that's truly engaging. Kya, despite the unsubstantiated genius stuff, is beautifully written. Tragic, curious, longing, she effortlessly pulls at your heart strings. Her internal struggles with childhood friend Tate and with D-bag Chase are relateable for anyone who has been in love, and can leave the reader breathless with hope and sadness. Do I wish Owens stopped talking about how gorgeous Kya was? Yea. Stop objectifying your main character, and we don't need a blow-by-blow of what she wore every day. And if I had to read the phrase "her first instinct was to run/hide" one more time, I was going to go bananas. But Where the Crawdads Sing was still compulsively readable and satisfying. All of this is to say: sometimes things are recycled, and the new things they become are beautiful, interesting, and entertaining, even if echoes of its past can be clearly seen....more

title: Pleasure Activism: The Politics of Feeling Good
author: Brown, Adrienne Maree
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was written for Adrienne Maree Brown by Adrienne Maree Brown. It was an excuse to interview people she likes and admires, and and excuse to This book was written for Adrienne Maree Brown by Adrienne Maree Brown. It was an excuse to interview people she likes and admires, and and excuse to talk about how woke she is.I'm not saying that's a bad thing. On the contrary, sex positivity is something that is sorely lacked. Sex isn't something a lot of people are comfortable talking about... even with their romantic partner(s). And there were some bits in this book I enjoyed: the pole dancer who loves what they do; the unpacking of polygamy and how it isn't a bad thing as long as you communicate, check in with each other, and work at it; the importance of masterbation for a healthy relationship with yourself and your sexual partners. But all-in-all the book was... just... boring? That feels like a ridiculous thing to say about a book called Pleasure Activism, but there it is. I thought this book was boring. I don't care about how much Adrienne Maree Brown loves herself, because I don't know her, and her "journey" and the "journeys" of the people she interviews weren't written with any real flare. They just sort of... plopped.Pleasure Activism reminds me of a writing assignment your therapist gives you. It's great to do for yourself, sometimes good to share with friends and get their perspectives... hell, you might even write their perspectives down. But, in truth, no one actually cares, so keep it to yourself....more

title: The Secret Commonwealth        (The Book of Dust, #2)
author: Pullman, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I began reading this in tandem with the television show, which maybe wasn't the wisest choice. I see similar flaws in both, and my hatred of the show I began reading this in tandem with the television show, which maybe wasn't the wisest choice. I see similar flaws in both, and my hatred of the show leaked out and made me more critical of the book than maybe I would have been, had BBC and HBO not bastardized something I love so completely. The Secret Commonwealth picks up with Lyra when she is 20 years old. It's been almost a decade since we saw her last, and the trauma of her childhood journey to the north and everything that followed is something she is still unpacking. She goes to university, but retains a space at Jordan College, where she continues on with professor Malcom Polstead, the housemaid Alice, and Hannah, the alethiometer teacher. At the beginning of the book we witness a murder, and that murder, coupled with nebulous prophecy stuff that is still tailing Lyra, leads her to run away (again) to search for answers (again); this time, with PTSD! It is written as the first of two parts, so many plot points are purposely left unanswered. So, in lieu of walking us down the line of the plot, plot, plot of this book, I'm going to instead tell you all of the things I didn't like. WARNING: this means minor spoilers, but nothing that you don't realize/aren't told early on in this 600+ page book. Malcolm didn't show up in the original trilogy, but we are told in The Secret Commonwealth that he had taught Lyra at Jordan College, after he had completed his studies. We know from The Book of Dust that he was the ~10yr old boy who ferried infant Lyra to safety. To reiterate: Malcolm took care of Lyra when she was a baby: diaper changing, the whole 9 yards. Then he stayed on at Jordan College and watched her grow up. Taught a 9yr old precocious child when he was ~19. So it is extra disgusting that he is now in love with her. Repugnant, skin crawlingly gross. Like... why, Pullman? Why???The explanation for Lyra's strained relationship with Pan is very, very thin. Pullman tells us it's due to Pan being left on the shores of The Land of the Dead, but they both knew that it was something she had to do, and they had still loved each other at the close of The Amber Spyglass. What changed between then and now? And, what's more, Pan is Lyra. So does she, like, hate herself? Why isn't that explored then in this book? Lyra curses at Pan they ignore each other... it's totally out of character and very disturbing if you remember that implications from the original trilogy. I'm not sure Pullman does remember. He's changed what the daemon/human relationship is, and not for the better. Word to the wise: don't fuck with canon.Speaking of things not explored - this book is just BOOM plot device BOOM plot device, hurtling pell mell into the next conflict, without any real reflection or narrative weave; something Pullman was so good at in the original trilogy. He also introduces WAY too many characters... it took until halfway through the book for me to adequately keep all the secondary characters straight in my head. Condense, man. You don't need that many characters, and you don't need to have so many dramatic things happening. Pick a few conflicts for fuckssake.In contrast, something that is explored far too thoroughly is how all the males in the book want to bang Lyra. Men leer at her, there's a goddamn rape attempt... pretty much every male character makes some internal comment about her looks. It's really, really unnecessary, and was uncomfortable to read. This discomfort was not a "wow, the author made me really think about the objectification of women" thing, but rather a "wow, I think the old man author wants to bang his 20yr old fictional creation" thing. Yeech. Also, you didn't need to mention her period, man. Just... don't.The refugee crisis stuff felt forced and weird and, again unnecessary. Maybe it's another lead up to the third book, but you can't have 600+ pages of nothing but filler. Why even bring this conflict in?Writing this  actually caused me to dock a star, down from 3 to 2. It's the nostalgia that makes me apologetic, but, looking back at The Secret Commonwealth, there really wasn't anything I liked about the book. Lyra utterly ignores the alethiometer, because she's "forgotten" how to read it. That's never unpacked, and it's really annoying. Is this meant to be an overarching allegory for how we lose our sense of wonder and imagination when we become adults? If so, it was done very clumsily. I've always adored Philip Pullman, and I have no idea what has happened, but it hurts me. To take a beloved character like Lyra and strip her down to depressed hot chick who is floundering around is a goddamn disgrace. STOP REVISITING THINGS THAT WERE GOOD AS THEY WERE. YOU MONSTERS....more

title: High School
author: Quin, Tegan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Tegan and Sara the band defines an era for me. Their album "So Jealous" came out in 2004, the year I turned 16, the year I openly dated a girl in highTegan and Sara the band defines an era for me. Their album "So Jealous" came out in 2004, the year I turned 16, the year I openly dated a girl in high school, the year I began to settle into the idea of being queer and began to permanently shedding the strict Christian household I had grown up in. It was the year I began to accept that I didn't have to hate myself and that I could find happiness in just being me. I had a long road to walk, and I definitely backslid into self-loathing multiple times over the years, but "So Jealous" was, in a lot of ways, a sort of background track to the struggle it was to find and accept myself.High School documents Tegan and Sara's Grade 10 - Grade 12. A three year period where they discovered drugs, guitar playing, and began to discover themselves. Despite the decades that separate the writers from the content, the book reads with the same desperate anger and hope that defines high school for so many people. Reading about sleepovers with the girl who is your friend... but who you also kiss once the lights go out, and the roiling in your belly that comes with that, shot me back to my own experiences, my own fear, my own pushed limits. They write with an open honesty that is so rare in memoirs. They are aware they made mistakes, that they were sometimes unfair to the people they cared about, and they pour all of that into their writing, as though they were in fact still in high school and confessing to a diary rather than to their editor. High School doesn't shy away from the darker and uglier parts of growing up. Tegan and Sara go back and forth, each writing a chapter. They write clearly and objectively about how cruel teenagers can be to their family and to their friends. What's more: they're honest about finding footing with each other, the huge fights they had, and the scars they still carry from being so close to each other during their formative years. Having a sibling is hard enough, being a twin brings to the table a unique set of conflicts.Read this book. I don't care where you fall on the sexuality spectrum, or whether their music means something to you. If you went through high school, if you were homeschooled, if you're an alien who just beamed down to Earth... just read this. ...more

title: King Lear
author: Shakespeare, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is this... required reading for estate lawyers?Can we encourage all aging folks to read this?King Lear felt more contemporary than any of his plays, aIs this... required reading for estate lawyers?Can we encourage all aging folks to read this?King Lear felt more contemporary than any of his plays, as far as I can remember (it's been a few years since I've read him, but I have recently attended our local Shakespeare in the Park so... does that count?). Lear is sizing up his daughters, and makes the mistake of putting his eggs in selfish baskets. The message seems to be: children can be greedy little shits when they see their parents getting older. They smell blood in the water. To double up on this sentiment, we get the parallel story of Lear's buddy, Gloucester. Gloucester has two sons: one legitimate, one less-than-legitimate (though he loves the latter equally). The less-than-legitimate son (let's just call him a bastard, eh? It's fitting) is all concerned about his inheritance. So he decides to poison his father against his brother.Maybe it's because I'm watching my mother and her sister battle it out over THEIR mother's assets while that poor woman is still alive, but I really, really loved this play. The greed, the madness, the regret, the loss of control. It was masterful. It was beautiful. Brava.Reading this after The Year of Lear was particularly great, because of all the juicy background I had on the play. Plus, the library edition of King Lear provided both the 1608 Quarto and the 1623 Folio. It was fascinating to flip between the two, comparing the different the endings. Personally, I find the 1608 version superior. Having Lear speak the line: Break, heart, I prithee, break! was positively wrenching.PS. I didn't realize that King Lear is where Roland and The Dark Tower came from. That was a fun lil' Easter egg for a Stephen King fan. Speaking of, I haven't read all of those yet... hmm... be it a sign ?!?!...more

title: The Institute
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 30 pages into this book I realized the following:Stephen King had watched Stranger Things, and had thought to himself "but what if the story just foll30 pages into this book I realized the following:Stephen King had watched Stranger Things, and had thought to himself "but what if the story just followed all of the kids housed in the building Eleven came from?" Then he switched from Netflix to the news, saw our real government putting real kids in cages, and was like "fuck it, I'm going live." I thought this immediate revelation would cheapen the book for me, make it feel formulaic and contrived and too on the nose re: the current political climate. But it wasn't that (though King lets you know time and time again how much he hates Trump. Which, like, good. I hate him too). Even more impressive, however, is that King did not go off the rails in this book. It's a goddamn miracle: the plot was actually pretty tight. He speaks to the laziness that comes with complacency, how the notion of infallibility can be the downfall of even the biggest machines, and how we don't often see the trees for the forest (ie taking a bonafide genius to your broken down Institute because you're Too Big To Fail. Again. You'd think it'd be too on the nose. But it ain't). Plus, Owen wasn't involved so there wasn't a JK LOL IT'S JUST ALIENS thing at the end... or at least... not until a sequel is written. King writes children well. The precociousness; the innocence coupled with random bursts of wisdom far exceeding years. He nails the fact that children are always listening, even if you think they aren't/think they couldn't possibly understand. The Institute primarily follows Luke Ellis, a 12yr old who is an actual, bonafide genius. He is also a little telekinetic, which results in his involuntary residence at, you guessed it, the Institute. There Luke makes friends with fellow residents: spirited Kalisha, dissenting Nick, jokester George, and Avery, a very young, very gifted telepath. The adults within the Institute are cartoon-mustache-twirling-ly evil, which almost feels unbelievable at times. That being said, King seems to want to highlight the farthest extents of cruelty, and specifically cruelty toward children. And while it sometimes feels too bananas to be true, one must remember that part of the inspiration for this book was REAL LIVE EVENTS RIGHT HERE IN MODERN AMERICA. So I guess I should shut up about things I don't know. People are evil. I've just been lucky enough to not experience it first hand. One could argue that not all that much actually happens in this book. A lot of the text simply King describing the Institute, coupled with long, internal monologues carried on by the main characters. Surprisingly enough, I liked that. Again, some of the characterizations felt unbelievable, but King works hard to flesh out at least the primary players in his book. So, even though there are really only 7 scenes in this book (view spoiler)[Meet Tim, Meet Luke, Luke at Institute, Luke leaves Institute, Luke and Tim meet, final battle, epilogue (hide spoiler)], the story didn't feel plodding or overdrawn. Impressive again, because this is King we're talking about, and have you ever actually read It? On a nano level, I want to make a comment about language. King uses the phrase "Great events turn on small hinges" a few times in this book. Then, later, he refers to a group of ~6 people as "hinges." It's like a plea: a few people can make big changes, if only they act. Will you?So, long story short, this is the best of recent Stephen King in my opinion. No clowns or cursed burial grounds or vampires here. Just people being straight up shit, which is arguably the scariest of all. Oh, and stick around for the author's note at the end of the book. I teared up. It was a beautiful tribute and proves yet again how cool King is. But, hey, Stephen King? You may be cool but STOP TRYING TO WRITE IN WHAT YOU DEEM A "BLACK" VOICE. IT'S WEIRD AND CRINGY AND KINDA RACIST! Also, just don't use the N-word. Not even once. Not even to bring home a point about those living in the back half of Back half. It doesn't enhance the narrative, and I actually had a visceral reaction to that word on the paper. Just. Stop. Okay?...more

title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
author: Walker, Matthew
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you don't want to read this book, here's all you need to know:-You're likely not sleeping enough.-Sleeping less than 7hrs isn't cool or impressive.If you don't want to read this book, here's all you need to know:-You're likely not sleeping enough.-Sleeping less than 7hrs isn't cool or impressive. It's killing you.-Alcohol, blue LEDs, and refined sugar are all bad for you, especially when it comes to "good" sleep.-Society has become an anti-sleep entity, robbing our children of their natural circadian rhythms, and forcing "night owls" to wake up early, while expecting "morning larks" to stay out late at night. But, really, you should read this book. For one, it's full of a lot of really fascinating tidbits. Example: you know how you don't sleep well the first night in a hotel, or in a novel environment? That's because, when we don't feel "safe" when going to sleep, one half of our brain sleeps more lightly than the other. So you scientifically aren't sleeping as well. Aside from some fun "did you know" conversation starters, this book allows you to think more critically about how you prioritize sleep in your life. It also gives a rundown of what sleep does for us, why we dream, what sleep paralysis actually is, and tips for those who have trouble sleeping achieve more restful nights.I really enjoyed this book. The only reason I can't give it a full 5 stars is because of the frequency with which author Matthew Walker describes scientists depriving rats and other animals of sleep. Reading about humans killing animals to better understand what lack of sleep does to the body is very upsetting, at least for me. I have a hard time thinking about experimentation on animals, even though, rationally, I know that's how we've achieved modern day medicine and contemporary psychology/psychiatry. I just... ugh... **shudder**...more

title: The Tiger's Wife
author: Obreht, Téa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When it comes to men, I have a type: nerdy, funny, self-loathing, difficulty expressing emotions.When it comes to books, it seems I also have a type: When it comes to men, I have a type: nerdy, funny, self-loathing, difficulty expressing emotions.When it comes to books, it seems I also have a type: fractured timelines, multi-generational story telling, magical realism. The Tiger's Wife is just my type.Tea Obreht brings us a book that opens on a young doctor, Natalia, who has just found out about her grandfather's death. From there, the book splinters out into three separate stories:1. Natalia, present day, grappling with the death of her grandfather and attempting to assist an orphanage and the people in the surrounding area.2. The story her grandfather purportedly told her about The Deathless Man - a person he met multiple times throughout his life.3. The story her grandfather partially told her about The Tiger's Wife, a woman who had lived in his village when he was a boy. I say partially, because the narrator indicates she had to travel around talking to multiple people from her grandfather's village to get the complete tale, and all the variations thereof. It's a beautifully written book that tackles society's varying relationship with death, losing the person who meant the most to us, superstition, fear as a driver for the things that we do (or don't do)... My one gripe about the book is the idea that the narrator received the stories of The Deathless Man and The Tiger's Wife verbally from her grandfather and others. The rich details and backgrounds make this pretty much impossible, so the reader is either left to think 1. the narrator is lying/filling in gaps with untruths or 2. that the author didn't think it through before putting pen to paper. Considering the earnestness of the narrator, I unfortunately have to land on the latter. The book would have read much better if these stories has been written as sort of asides to the reader, rather than as stories the narrator tells us; stories totally separate from Natalia's personal experiences.This gripe, however, does not take away from the lyricism of Obreht's composition, or from the beauty of the story as a whole. The opening of the book, for those who are on the fence about reading it:The forty days of the soul begin on the morning after death. That first night, before its forty days begin, the soul lies still against sweated-on pillows and watches the living fold the hands and close the eyes, choke the room with smoke and silence to keep the new soul from the doors and the windows and the cracks in the floor so that it does not run out of the house like a river....more

title: Three Women
author: Taddeo, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You'll likely get angry reading this book.For some people, that's enough to forego cracking Three Women open. And I get it. We're living in a world whYou'll likely get angry reading this book.For some people, that's enough to forego cracking Three Women open. And I get it. We're living in a world where sexual assault is dinner table conversation, where female sexuality is finally getting its moment in the spotlight, and that can be uncomfortable, because female sexuality has been repressed/oppressed/forced since... well... forever. I'd argue, however, that the anger that comes with Three Women is a good, productive kind of anger. It's an anger that says, "I know what that feels like, and no one helped me figure out how to unpack that either." It's an anger that says, "yes, this is still happening, and yes, we do need to talk about it."Lisa Taddeo followed, you guessed it, three women over a series of years as they navigated their lives, their respective sexualities, and their romantic entanglements. The reader meets Maggie, the woman who was in a sexual relationship with a teacher when she was in high school; Lina, a woman who had a traumatic sexual experience as a teenager, and now struggles with a loveless marriage and a lover who, while he sets her ablaze, seems only tepid about the affair himself; and Sloane, a woman who allowed her husband to decide the open-door-policy of their bedroom, and is trying to make sense of what that means for her happiness, for her sense of self-worth, for her actualization. While these three women had totally different upbringings and formative experiences, they struggle with a remarkably similar set of problems. Where does your partners happiness end and yours begins? When do things stop being amicable, going-along-with-it, and start being a draining, dangerous, repressive agent? How do you know if you're happy? If you were ever happy? How do you explore your own needs without suffocating under the fear of being selfish, of not being fun, or being a "nag?" Taddeo isn't merely giving these women a voice, she is unpacking universal questions that women struggle with as it pertains to their sexuality, with three very unique lenses. I've read some critiques on this book, specifically with regards to who Maggie, Lina, and Sloane are. That is: white, ci-gendered, straight(ish), and middle class. Listen, the topic of this book is an empty space, and we could use a lot of different voices on it. However, such a critique feels rather blinded. Taddeo followed these women for years. It is very likely that she had a more, for lack of a better term, diverse, set of candidates on the outset, but as time went on, they likely ultimately dropped out of the project. Why? Perhaps because Taddeo, being white, ci-gendered, straight(ish), and middle class herself, inherently didn't understand something and inadvertently disrespected/hurt the feelings of these other subjects. Perhaps divulging such intimate and difficult details to someone who is, generally speaking, "other," was too uncomfortable an experience. What I'm trying to say is: it doesn't surprise me that Taddeo was only able to hold onto women not unlike herself. Such a project, that requires such safe-space feelings, is monumentally difficult, and Taddeo is lucky she even got three women, white, ci-gendered, straight(ish), and middle class though they may be. All this to say: yes, you'll likely get angry reading this book. But think of what that anger could ultimately become. ...more

title: Normal People
author: Rooney, Sally*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do you remember the first time you fell in love? You wanted so desperately to be accepted by that other person, that you often weren't totally honest,Do you remember the first time you fell in love? You wanted so desperately to be accepted by that other person, that you often weren't totally honest, often held a part of yourself back. You were driven by the fear that you would somehow lose the affection of that other person if you were too open, too vulnerable. Sally Rooney has harnessed that breathless first love feeling in her book Normal People. Over the course several pivotal years, main characters Connell and Marianne attempt to find themselves as they mature, and, though they sometimes try to fight it, they keep coming back to one another. Despite how much they grow in other ways, they are unable to fully give who they are to the other. "Don't let them see you cry" takes on a whole different meaning as they try and protect themselves from their feelings.The book is told from the perspective of both characters, so the reader has a first hand view into how miscommunications happen; how the need to protect the heart ironically leads to more pain. Rooney doesn't use quotations around her speech, so internal and external voices blur. You're never quite sure what the characters are saying to one another, and what they're holding back, until it's too late. My only complaint about the book is that is sort of plods at the end, and it didn't give me what I wanted at the close... but maybe that's the point: when you hold yourself back, you never get what you want.Favorite lines:She wants to tell him things. But it's too late now, and anyway it has never done her any good to tell anyone.xFor weeks now she has had this feeling, the feeling of moving around inside a protective film, floating like mercury. The outside world touches against her outside skin, but not the other part of herself, inside.xIn school they were both in the same place, both confused and somehow suffering, and ever since then she has believed that if they could return to that place together it would be the same....more

review: This book is meant for people who have children.That might sound weird, but it's true. As someone who is in a monogamous marriage wherein we revealed This book is meant for people who have children.That might sound weird, but it's true. As someone who is in a monogamous marriage wherein we revealed to each other, like, a month into the relationship, that we didn't want children, this book felt... elementary, too simple, too "welcome to a world where adults who happily do not have children exist too." I don't need that. I know that. I live that. There were excerpts where I felt more seen than I've ever felt in my life - reading about other people grappling with the aggression that erupts when people hear someone isn't having children. It also led to a bonding moment between my BFF and I, because she has but one child, and receives similar aggression from others pressuring her to have a second child. That pressure = we're selfish, we'll regret it, etc. etc. The bonding and the "yes! me too!" moments aside, this book was just kinda repetitive and "yea, duh," to me. HOWEVER - people who DO have kids or who plan to have kids should 1000% read this book. It has the potential to open the larger social eyes to how fucking rude people are without even realizing it. ...more

review: People kept asking me "how are you liking that book?" upon seeing it on the coffee table or my mentioning it in discussion. "Like" isn't the word I woPeople kept asking me "how are you liking that book?" upon seeing it on the coffee table or my mentioning it in discussion. "Like" isn't the word I would use for my feelings about Voices from Chernobyl. The book is profoundly upsetting; graphic in its illustrations of bodies breaking down, of household pets mass murdered; and infuriating in the secrets and inaction of a government pretending everything is okay while people around them are dying. But all of those feelings are vital - they make sure we don't become numb to atrocities, to disasters, to hardships. Honestly, this book should be mandatory reading for high school students, and for every single person in government. Alexievich lets the survivors keep their voices; something their government tried to take away from them, and for that we are all the richer (even if we need anti-depressants afterward). ...more

title: Circe
author: Miller, Madeline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Greek myths of old are sexist AF.They're products of their time, right? Written by men, about men. The women, both mortal and immortal, fall into The Greek myths of old are sexist AF.They're products of their time, right? Written by men, about men. The women, both mortal and immortal, fall into a few, very well-defined categories:1. Loyal & steadfast partner2. Blushing, innocent virgin3. Cunning man-hater4. Old croneIt's tough to read these stories as a woman. The rape, the neglect, the central focus for all Woman being Man.Well, Madeline Miller is taking it back for us, ladies. Retellings can be laborious to read or write, but Miller seems to have been born to tell the story of Circe, removed from the clutches of the male pen (ahem). Banish ye, Madonna vs. Whore, we've actually, for once, have dynamic women in Greek mythology.Miller begins at Circe's inception between her father Helios and her mother Perse (who her mother was is debated, but Miller makes stances, damnit. Plus, I think Hecate would have been harder to write, so...). From there the reader watches the lonely Circe, not beautiful enough for the men, not clever or cruel enough for the women. Miller is masterful at writing the desperation of a neglected child searching for love, and when Circe thinks she's found it, she breaks open the rest of her life.I don't want to walk you down the path of Circe's story, both ancient canon and refurbished by Miller. What would be the point of your reading the story, then? Suffice to say Miller paints a rich world, with familiar Greek characters playing out their parts around Circe, the mocked and underestimated daughter of the god of the sun. Ceaselessly hopeful, the first person narration of Circe draws you ever closer into her search for someone who will listen, someone who will care. As she hones her magics and grows stronger, she simultaneously shrinks back, afraid of scorn, of pain, of a fate even worse than what was already doled out to her. Miller has taken a famed Greek nymph/sorceress and freed her from her ancient cage of lover of Odysseus and transmutator of men. She becomes whole, with her own hopes, fears, and passions. Homer and his bros could have never written a character so utterly Woman. ...more

title: The Sun Is a Compass: A 4,000-Mile Journey into the Alaskan Wilds
author: Van Hemert, Caroline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Does your dream vacation involve getting stalked by a hungry bear? What about not showering for weeks on end? Or camping in the ice and snow? For CaroDoes your dream vacation involve getting stalked by a hungry bear? What about not showering for weeks on end? Or camping in the ice and snow? For Caroline Van Hemert and her husband Pat, it was thoughts of this trip that kept them sane as they toiled at their day jobs. Finally, in 2012, the couple packed off, in boats Pat made himself, and set sail for the Arctic.The passion Van Hemert has for the wilderness is contagious. Her narrative so crisply captures the awe she feels as humpback whales create a bubble net just off shore, as she hikes through territories that show no trace of humanity... save for the countdown climate change has put on these natural wonders.As an ornithologist, Van Hemert cannot help but describe the birds she sees, and provide brief histories of their temperaments and habits. It reads naturally, as Van Hemert effortlessly brings you into the landscape, the creatures, that world.There are heartbreaking passages that speak to climate change and how precarious this landscape is: hawk nests slide down cliffs, where the fledglings will surely die; bears are more hungry, their food sources slowly disappearing; some animals are new to the Arctic, migrating due to the weather pattern changes, and attempting to master the land. It's informative, it's wrenching, it's beautiful.Van Hemert isn't just here to talk about the beauty of nature and the importance of preserving it; she also talks about her father's illness, and about her and Pat's relationship; that simple-yet-complicated love that comes with being married and doing something difficult together. She is honest with her readers, and it shows in the best ways possible. Listen, I really suck at gushing, but this book was incredible. It's a memoir, yes, but it is so much more than that. It is bringing into focus a wondrous world that most people rarely interact with, and is imploring us to take notice before it disappears. ...more

review: Basically Taylor Jenkins Reid listened to Fleetwood Mac's "Rumors" and thought to herself okay, but, like, what if I fictionalized this and made it boBasically Taylor Jenkins Reid listened to Fleetwood Mac's "Rumors" and thought to herself okay, but, like, what if I fictionalized this and made it boring? AND SO, THIS BOOK WAS BORN.Sex, drugs, and rock 'n roll are the things that have fascinated us since Elvis brought the blues to the white folk. And a fictionalized oral history of the late 60s early 70s sounds like an easy sell. Which is why Jenkins Reid was able to get this published: it certainly wasn't due to literary prowess.Motivations for actions aren't clear, loves and losses aren't fleshed out; it's just broad strokes, the most meager of outlines. As my friend said: "it reads like she just wanted to get enough out on the page to get a movie deal." She is so right. Billy is just boring.Daisy is defined entirely by her love of drugs... and then of something else which has no motivation.Eddie is just angry. Full stop.Pete and Warren are shadows. The only redeeming part of this book are the characters Graham and Karen. They are real, messy, and I wish the writing of this book had tracked with the potential of the two of these characters.(view spoiler)[And the reveal that the narrator is Billy and Camila's daughter, Julia, fell so radically flat. To have the narrator just bust in: 'oh, sorry, I'm the only one who can vouch for this part of the story so I just want you to know I'm here and I agree...' seriously?! Also, what was the motivation for writing in the first place? At first it seems like she just wants to capture everything about her parents, but then it seems like she was using it as a device to get closer to the mother she recently lost and that doesn't make any sense since Camila was involved for the majority of the writing AND that the book revolved around Daisy and Billy and NOT Camila and Billy... I mean, what the shit. (hide spoiler)]...more

title: The Wise Man’s Fear        (The Kingkiller Chronicle, #2)
author: Rothfuss, Patrick*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I HAVE A PROBLEM.I really wanted to dislike the first book, but I really didn't. It was fun and full of adventure and intrigue. The main character havI HAVE A PROBLEM.I really wanted to dislike the first book, but I really didn't. It was fun and full of adventure and intrigue. The main character having 0 flaws, while stupid, surprisingly didn't detract from the narrative.One thing I didn't mention when ing the first book was women. Why? For one, there aren't many. You could chalk this up to the embracing of "traditional" fantasy, where the society is medieval-fashioned: women take care of the home and rarely have any power. But, let's be real, you're building a fantastical universe, the women can be whatever you want, and not having them simply means the author doesn't know how to write them. What's more, the few women who did make an appearance in The Name of the Wind were sort of cold and distant. I figured that was Rothfuss' answer to a strong woman: one who didn't pay much mind to the main character.Nope.As I began reading The Wise Man's Fear, I noticed that the women, now, were really just serving the main character, and didn't have motivations and strengths of their own. Also, lines like "I'm nervous as a new whore," or "don't look at me, she went crazy on her own," were pretty fucked up. But I forged ahead with the book, hoping it'd get better.In the interim, I went to the (male) friend who recommended this series and asked him if he noticed the difference in the female perspective between books. He said no, but he also told me (and this is gossip, so I don't know if this is true and don't care enough to do my own research) that Rothfuss had had no experience with women when he wrote the first book, but had experienced women by the time The Wise Man's Fear was ready to hit the shelves.As I continued reading, this made sense.The women are really just there to move Kvothe along, and to bang him.The one section that really got me riled was when Kvothe spends some time in the ancient land of Adem. This land is characterized by schools which focus on a certain kind of fighting, and the characters Kvothe meets there are overwhelmingly female. This was exciting: women soldiers teaching other women soldiers! Maybe I was wrong all along! However, rather than fleshing out any of these women or speaking to their strengths, Rothfuss chooses instead to have these strong, powerful women all try and bone the main character. (view spoiler)[Even his teacher is all "oh, you have a boner? want me to take care of that for you?" WHAT THE ACTUAL FUCK. Rothfuss tries to play it off by saying that this culture doesn't think about physical intimacy the way others do but c'mon. This is utterly ridiculous and totally undercuts the female experience of this book. (hide spoiler)]Aside from his inability to write women (I could go on forEVER; I took a lot of notes), the book was still entertaining. Entertaining enough where I wasn't upset by the time I turned the last page. However, there are some weird leaps. Kvothe gets incredibly violent in a couple of scenes, without any real character build-up to him having a capacity for such savagery. Kvothe is able to win over strangers after committing questionable acts without much questioning, which undercuts the whole "stranger danger" that Rothfuss has established between cultures. Additionally, the 0 flaws thing from book #1 carries over to The Wise Man's Fear. But, unlike book #1, it now feels clunky and ridiculous. He is able to do all of these things that easily? All conflicts occur externally, rather than Kvothe making any mistakes? And he's just so clever that these are just merely nuisances he quickly flicks away, rather than there being anything substantially difficult? It went from lazy writing but still fun to utterly unbelievable and annoying. I honestly don't know if I could read another book by Rothfuss.(view spoiler)[PS. is it just me, or did Rothfuss totally show his hand toward the end. Kvothe goes to Elodin asking what it says about someone when they keep changing their name, referring to Denna. Elodin, thinking Kvothe is talking about himself, goes WHAT HAVE YOU DONE. You know what that means? The Kvothe who is telling his story at the inn changed his "true" name in order to hide most efficiently, or just because he just no longer wants to be Kvothe. That is why he is losing his ability to fight; why he seems to be changing/weakening so rapidly. Is something to help restore his original "true" name in that lockless box? Likely. (hide spoiler)]...more
