review: The world is a cruel place. It is violent and isolating and bewildering. While it comforts and understands, it subtlely threatens and demands. In the The world is a cruel place. It is violent and isolating and bewildering. While it comforts and understands, it subtlely threatens and demands. In the 21st century we have no escape; no opportunity for privacy; there is a persistent lens focused in on our every move. The world is ending, the government is controlling us, the 1% continues to crush us beneath their heel.Now, take these sentiments and put them into a graphic novel. Nick Drnaso focuses on the disappearance of one woman, Sabrina, and the ripple effect that disappearance has. Through radio broadcasts; news reports; and the reactions of her boyfriend, his best friend, and Sabrina's sister, Drnaso unpacks not only how our lives weave together, but how toxic media can be, and how numb to tragedy we have all become. It's beautiful, it's disturbing, it's real. ...more

title: Sons of Cain: A History of Serial Killers from the Stone Age to the Present
author: Vronsky, Peter*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Peter Vronsky has been writing about serial killers for quite some time. After tackling the well-worn tracks of the "Golden Era" and of Jack the RippePeter Vronsky has been writing about serial killers for quite some time. After tackling the well-worn tracks of the "Golden Era" and of Jack the Ripper, he decided to go further back into history, to talk about what our earliest known serial killers looked like and who, with the correct application of the definition, could be considered a serial killer despite their not showing up in any Wikipedia list.I'll say this: Sons of Cain is graphic. Very graphic. Nauseatingly graphic. Skip-some-lines-because-you-can't-handle-the-truth graphic. Not my cup of tea, but I think Vronsky did this on purpose. Contemporary culture has been ramping up its obsession with serial killing and psychopaths/sociopaths. I can come into work, listen to dozens of podcasts on the subject (My Favorite Murder, And That's Why We Drink, Criminal... I mean, I could go on for days), then go home, and watch shows like "Mindhunter" or "You," then go to bed reading a book like The Silence of the Lamps or American Psycho. However, all of the examples I've cited above cut out the really gruesome details; they achieve some some light white-washing so as to not lose the fascination of the general public. This? Is a disservice. We've become so obsessed with something we don't actually understand. Penn Badgley got (understandably) pissed off when everyone was swooning over his character Joe in "You." Why? Because he's a goddamn murderer, butchering innocent people due to X (I'm not going to attempt to diagnose anyone, even a fictional character. B don't play). Vronsky is looking us in the eye and saying: "you like this stuff? Alright. But how much do you really know about this stuff? Because it is fucked. These people are fucked. And I'm gonna show you just how fucked all of this is." So, yea, I had to skim some of the book because of that, but I respect him for shoving back in my face the fact that all of this is incredibly real and incredibly disturbing.To the book itself: if you're looking for an unpacking of the likes of Ted Bundy or Edmond Kemper or any of those "big American names," this isn't the book for you. Vronsky spends a lot of time in Europe during the 17th and 18th centuries, talking about the ideas of vampires and werewolves, and how those myths were actually earlier serial killers. He spends a whole chapter talking about how the witch craze in the 17th century was a church-and-state sanctioned serial killing of women, which was a fascinating and well-researched spin on the topic. He puts forth the argument that all people are inherently serial killers, and only through socializing/parenting do we "unlearn" this natural disposition. Reductive? Yes. Leaning hard on nature vs. nurture? Yes. But it's very interesting to mull over, so kudos to Vronsky. He attempts to unpack how a generation of WWII veteran fathers bred a exponential uptick in serial killers, which was fascinating (though he failed to speak to the 1950s over-bearing mother trope, which might have been oversight, or might have been intentional because that's a whole lot more to research, but I'd argue the coupling of PTSD with must-have-perfect-home-where's-my-valium is an important relationship to note).I wouldn't recommend this to many people, save my law enforcement father. It's upsetting, and as a woman it makes you even edgier than you already are (yes, I started carrying my knife in my purse rather than leaving it in my hiking pack after reading this). However, if the psychology and history of how we got to where we are with regards to serial killers and the current fervor over entertainment about serial killers is something you think about, you might want to read Sons of Cain. Just make sure you have a strong stomach, or a strong skimming eye. ...more

title: A History of Witchcraft: Sorcerers, Heretics, and Pagans
author: Russell, Jeffrey Burton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am fascinated by the history of witchcraft. Not the torture, or the feminist subculture that came out of it, or the pop-culture translations. No, I I am fascinated by the history of witchcraft. Not the torture, or the feminist subculture that came out of it, or the pop-culture translations. No, I am fascinated by the psychology behind it: what drove people to accuse other people of being witches, and what it actually meant to be "witch" over the centuries.Luckily, Burton Russell has some thoughts on the subject.Beginning with ancient civilizations in Africa, Burton Russell explores the idea of sorcerer, of healer, of medicine man, and how Christianity took these ideas and distorted them to create a cohesive Christian culture. He moves to continental Western Europe, and ultimately to Great Britain and the United States of America. As he unspools the height of the "witch-craze" (14th - 17th centuries), he provides glimpses into what drove such hatred and violence: the fear of the Other, the misogyny, and the unstable economic and political times. From there, he races toward the 18th - 20th centuries, the revival of interest in witchcraft, the creation of Wicca, and how the past and present speak to each other.It's a fascinating book, and one I'll likely read again for all those bits I may have missed the first time around....more

So you make it; you follow the instructions to the letter, you take it out of the oven, anxiously anticipating when it will be cool enough to take that first bite. You cut yourself a slice, you're so excited......and it tastes like a pile of garbage wreathed in farts.That's The Woman in the Window.All of the elements are there: an unreliable narrator struggling with personal drama, who isn't sure what is real and what isn't, who is friend and who is enemy. The foundation of the story is solid, for sure, too bad the writing is like building with sand.Okay, enough analogies. I'M OUT. ...more

title: The Indifferent Stars Above: The Harrowing Saga of a Donner Party Bride
author: Brown, Daniel James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been made to feel a touch uncomfortable when say I loved this book. Chatting with friends it has gone a little something like:Friend: Read anythiI've been made to feel a touch uncomfortable when say I loved this book. Chatting with friends it has gone a little something like:Friend: Read anything good lately?Me: Yes! I actually just finished this nonfiction about the Donner party that was excellent!Friend: Isn't that... about... eating people...?Me: Well, I mean, yea, if you wanna be reductive. But there's so much more to it! And - hey - wait - where are you going? Why are you running?True, the subject matter is a bit macabre, but Daniel James Brown is a master story teller. He begins his narrative before the journey even commenced, explaining the backgrounds of the people he focuses in on, and providing vital historical context. This focus on context becomes the tool which made this book stand out for me. Brown might talk about, say, a gun accidentally going off as the company hikes along the plains. But he doesn't stop there. He then explains what guns were like back then, why they often accidentally discharged, and other details as he sees fit. This may sound tediously parenthetical, but I assure you it is not. It feels a seamless way to illustrate the significance of decisions and mistakes made as the Donner party trudged toward their fate. It puts a spotlight on Brown's passion for his project, and just how much research he did to make this book the success it is.Is this book upsetting? Yes, and the squeamish or the happy ending types may not want to read this particular work. However, if the infamy of the Donner party does not send you running away, I could not recommend this book more. It's a historical recounting, sure, but it is also a poignant look into our humanity, our will to survive, and the lasting scars that come with survival. ...more

title: A Confederacy of Dunces
author: Toole, John Kennedy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What I'm having real trouble with when it comes to this book is: where exactly do people find the humor in this book? Reviews use the words "hystericaWhat I'm having real trouble with when it comes to this book is: where exactly do people find the humor in this book? Reviews use the words "hysterical" and "hilarious." I just found the novel deeply sad.Whether or not Toole intended it, his main character Ignatius Reilly reads as someone who has a severe, undiagnosed mental disorder. Are we supposed to laugh at him? Maybe in the 60s, when Toole wrote the book, but I can't laugh at him today. At the start of the novel I was laughing, because Ignatius writes ridiculous letters and waxes poetic about ridiculous things. I thought he was being satirical, but as you read on you realize that the character Ignatius means the things he says, and that's just so goddamn depressing. The NY Times  of this book (in 1981) would disagree with me - stating that this book is successful in satire. I see satire in the Levys, and in the hot dog stand company owner... but that's kind of it. Should I set fire to my English MA?What's also depressing is Ignatius' relationship with his mother. He verbally abuses her, she physically abuses him back. He is 30yrs old, living at home, with no job aspirations, and she is spending what little money she has on buying him cakes and tickets to the movies and his every whim. This is... funny? To whom?We are also expected to laugh at a police man who is slowly dying due to his department's mistreatment of him.And a black man attempting to stay out of jail. His crime? The color of his skin. Was this a harsh look at racial relationships by Toole? It isn't obvious, which is incredibly problematic for me. The 60s is too late in history for me to forgive opaque racism like this. Minor characters such as the petty thief George and Mrs. Levy manage to illicit weak chuckles, but I couldn't find myself appreciating this when sandwiched between slut shaming and rampant homophobia. I'm honestly open to a deeper read of the text, if anyone can present it to me. However, every book  I've read has left me going "wait, but you haven't shown me the satire," and, since Toole did not live to see the publication of his novel, we'll never know what it was he intended. ...more

title: Half of a Yellow Sun
author: Adichie, Chimamanda Ngozi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book will destroy you... in the best way possible. Following the Biafran War/Nigerian Civil War (1967-1970), Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie tracks 5 peThis book will destroy you... in the best way possible. Following the Biafran War/Nigerian Civil War (1967-1970), Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie tracks 5 people as they bend and break in a nation rocked by violence and starvation.The narrative oscillates between the early 60s (peace time) and the late 60s (war time). As a sucker for disjointed timelines, I relished the foreshadowing in the early 60s, and the hint of transgressions and resentments not yet seen in the late 60s. Adichie is a master of language; writing in a way that pulls your heart taut, that makes you ache, that makes you cry. I had to wake my husband up to read him the following line:"Death would be a complete knowingness, but what frightened him was this: not knowing beforehand what it was he would know."Adichie picks her characters carefully, ensuring the best cross-section of experience. We have the twins Olanna and Kainene, who come from a rich family, their only exposure to "the bush" when they visit an Aunt. There's Olanna's paramour, Odenigbo, an Igbo intellectual who believes in "The Cause," and separating from Nigeria. Meanwhile, Kainene is romantically involved with Richard, an Englishman who originally came to Africa for inspiration for his novel, but stays for love. Lastly, Ugwu is Odenibgo's houseboy, struggling to exist both within his humble upbringing and his Master's high society life. To explain more is to give away the richness of narrative, the complicated relationships that ebb and flow, the tragedy and heartbreak. Suffice to say this is the best book I've read in years; I only wish I had found it sooner....more

author: Guinn, Jeff
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm embarrassed to say that, prior to picking this book up, all I really knew about Jim Jones and Jonestown was the insensitive phrase "don't drink thI'm embarrassed to say that, prior to picking this book up, all I really knew about Jim Jones and Jonestown was the insensitive phrase "don't drink the Kool-Aid." How is that even an okay phrase, considering how many people died that day by the hands of one power-hungry, god-complex-ed man?This book is well-researched... exhausting-ly so. It begins with the background of Jones' parents and takes the reader through to Jonestown and the aftermath of his "experiment." Two of Jones' sons agreed to be interviewed by Jeff Guinn, as well as several of Jones' followers who broke off from the church in time to avoid Jonestown. What I've learned from this book, and several other books/documentaries of this ilk, is that most cults start off as an ideal: people who are dissatisfied with how society spits on the middle class and how it focuses on capitalism are searching for something more equal, more connected to the Earth. I totally get that - and could totally get behind that. But power gets to even the most altruistic-seeming minds, and poisons the well. While there is no question that Jones always had a darker ulterior motive to his church and his following, it is exceedingly sad to think of all those people who were simply searching for a better life, and ended up losing out on life entirely. ...more

title: The Gift of Fear: Survival Signals That Protect Us from Violence
author: Becker, Gavin de
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Yoooooooooo this book sucks!Gavin de Becker spent his professional career attempting to protect women from violence. So how in the hell did he become Yoooooooooo this book sucks!Gavin de Becker spent his professional career attempting to protect women from violence. So how in the hell did he become so damn sexist?!I went into this book looking for academic discourse on violence inflicted on people by people. I wanted to read about how to see and react warning signs, how to de-escalate potentially dangerous situations, and perhaps read up on some of the psychology behind violence.That is so not what this book is about.This book is about stating the obvious with no actual practical applications, while managing to tell women they're stupid in one overly long, overly graphic narrative. Let's break down some of the more egregious passages, shall we?"Cynthia is a substitute schoolteacher, a funny, beautiful woman totally unlike the dull and much-harassed substitutes most of us recall from our school years."Hi. You are objectifying this woman for no reason. Nice."I encourage women to ask other women for help when they need it, and it’s likewise safer to accept an offer from a woman than from a man. (Unfortunately, women rarely make such offers to other women, and I wish more would.)"What the actual fuck. How do you have any sort of reliable statistic stating that women rarely offer to help other women. You don't offer any evidence, so we'll have to assume you're a big, fat liar who thinks women are useless. It is insulting. It is disgusting. Shame on you, sir.When discussing how a man woke up in the middle of the night to a noise, went downstairs to investigate, didn't find anything, and ultimately woke up a second time to a man standing over him with a gun:"Had he responded to his fear with respect, he would have found the intruder before the intruder found his gun. If he had said, in effect, 'Since I feel fear, I know there is some reason, so what is it?'"So... wait... you're telling me every time I hear a noise in my house it's a murderer and I should stay up all night waiting for the attack? What in the hell is de Becker trying to get at with this passage (we don't know, because he never elaborates on the point of this or HOW one respects fear without being a slave to it). He spends a decent chunk of the book telling women that they are worried about the possibility of violence, which manifests fear for no reason, and we all need to chill the fuck out. But for some reason a random noise in the night (which happens to all of us at some point) is cause to ASSUME there is a murderer in the house?! How is that logic?! I'm thinking it was because it was a MAN who heard the noise, and that MEN should trust their fear while WOMEN are afraid of possibility rather than actuality. Because what else am I supposed to take away from this? SERIOUSLY. TELL ME.In general, de Becker tells us that the warning signs of violence are "obvious," but that is patently untrue. Each person is unique, and each person reacts to levels of engagement/non-engagement differently. To claim there is one universal way to handle people is naive and, quite frankly, dangerous. He also goes on to claim that the police are relatively useless in many cases... so what does knowing these warning signs actually do for us? Who knows - certainly not de Becker. And finally:"I believe that the first time a woman is hit, she is a victim and the second time, she is a volunteer"Fuck you....more

review: Elizabeth Holmes never heard no, assumed she could continue to lie and sail through life, and finally Icarus-ed. That's an incredibly reductive way toElizabeth Holmes never heard no, assumed she could continue to lie and sail through life, and finally Icarus-ed. That's an incredibly reductive way to describe the rise and fall of the company Theranos. Do you want to have an at-home blood testing device that would wirelessly tell you whether you need to change your medications, whether something is wrong, and/or whether your diabetic body can eat that piece of cake? Sounds incredible... and possibly too good to be true?The lies, the hubris, the lack of care for the safety of the public... Holmes isn't in prison yet, but there's still time.Author Carreyrou is the journalist who broke the story in the WSJ, and assisted with the melting of Holmes' wings. He writes like a journalist: "this happened, then this, then this," and there are so many players in this narrative that one can sometimes forget who is who. That being said, Bad Blood is a fascinating insight into the Silicon world of start-ups, and what some people will do to rise to the top. ...more

review: Columbia was rocking with class wars, Pablo Escobar, and violence ~30 years ago. What if neither of them really understood the rocking of their country, or their respective positions in the fray? title: Shopping for Porcupine: A Life in Arctic Alaska
author: Kantner, Seth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Seth Kantner isn't a writer. Yeah, yeah, I know he won an award for his first book Ordinary Wolves, but I am going to argue it was for the original leSeth Kantner isn't a writer. Yeah, yeah, I know he won an award for his first book Ordinary Wolves, but I am going to argue it was for the original lens he brings, rather than acknowledgment of verbal prowess.Because here's the thing: Kantner doesn't need to be a writer to make this book interesting. His life is so original compared to what we in the lower 48 experience, that the book is interesting just by way of being written by this particular man. Kantner was born and raised in Northern Alaska. His father had moved up to Alaska, in love with the wildness of the landscape, and successfully started a family of "whiteboys" up there (Kantner's parents now live in Hawaii, and I do wonder what spurred that change). Life is extreme, the land vast and sometimes lonely. You need to pay close attention to the horizon at all times: what is going on with the caribou, with the clouds, etc., to ensure your comfortable survival. Living in handmade sod igloos and regularly having mice scurry across your face in the night doesn't sound like a barrel of laughs to me, but Kantner embraces where he is from, and writes un-apologetically about animal skin tack boards in the kitchen and eating bowls of bear fat for a meal. I did enjoy that, as the memoir winds down, Kantner takes the time to discuss the changing landscape and how climate change has negatively effected his community. Kantner isn't just here to entertain us with stories of hunting moose and navigating tundra - he's here to remind us just how much is at stake to lose. I have two questions after reading this book that weren't answered: what's the bathroom situation, and do you ever really see your feet?...more

title: King Leopold's Ghost
author: Hochschild, Adam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Lovingly and meticulously researched, King Leopold's Ghost may very well be the best nonfiction book I have ever read. King Leopold II of Belgium was Lovingly and meticulously researched, King Leopold's Ghost may very well be the best nonfiction book I have ever read. King Leopold II of Belgium was feeling left out because he'd missed the boat on other land grabs... so he set sights on Africa and, particularly, the Congo. After securing claim and sending explorers check out the loot, the world suddenly and aggressively became obsessed with rubber.And thus kicked off a reign of terror, tyranny, and torture, the reverberations of which can still be felt today. The cast of real characters that walk through Adam Hochschild's book are too ridiculous to NOT be real. Take, for instance, lawyer Colonel Henry I. Kowalsky. A large, flamboyant, narcoleptic, who drove everyone in his circle bonkers. He pissed off famous gunfighter Wyatt Earp to the point that Earp threatened to shoot him. The next time Earp and Kowalsky met, Earp pulled his pistol, but Kowalsky's only reaction was to fall asleep. Earp reportedly stormed away, saying, "What can you do with a man who goes to sleep just when you're going to kill him!"Wikipedia purports that the book was refused by nine of the ten U.S. publishing houses to which an outline was submitted. Shocked how not shocked I am at that.Knowledge is power, and Hochschild worked hard, so read this friggin' book. My two favorite lines:The world we live in - its divisions and conflicts, its widening gap between rich and poor, its seemingly inexplicable outbursts of violence - is shaped far less by what we celebrate and mythologize than by the painful events we try to forget.And:At the time of the Congo controversy a hundred years ago, the idea of full human rights, political, social, and economic, was a profound threat to the established order of most countries on earth. It still is today....more

title: The Haunting of Hill House
author: Jackson, Shirley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In a rare flair of festivity, I snatched Shirley Jackson's The Haunting of Hill House off of a library display highlighting the spook genre (don't worIn a rare flair of festivity, I snatched Shirley Jackson's The Haunting of Hill House off of a library display highlighting the spook genre (don't worry, the books were put there for the snatching). Having read The Lottery and We Have Always Lived in the Castle, I felt marginally introduced to Jackson, but didn't quite get the hype. Yea, The Lottery has one of the most famous twists in literary history, but We Have Always Lived in the Castle, at least to me, sort of plodded along, and didn't have any of the thrill/chill factor that had been touted out by s and the masses.Not so with The Haunting of Hill House. The story centers around Eleanor; a woman who hasn't had much happen to her in her life, who receives an invitation from a Dr. Montague to spend her summer at Hill House. She is desperate to have experiences of her own, to actually live, so she accepts, along with the gregarious Theodora and the roguish heir to Hill House, Luke. And a haunting they will go.Beautiful prose, clever slips into first person narrative, and a haunting described so damn well that I actually needed to stop reading it before bed, The Haunting of Hill House is clearly a pillar of the horror genre. It's not surprising that Jackson's masterpiece has been adapted several times over and, when not directly ripped from, is inspiration for many other haunted house iterations. I loved it, I'll read it again, and I implore you to do the same.I leave you with the first, magnificent, paragraph:No live organism can continue for long to exist sanely under conditions of absolute reality; even larks and katydids are supposed, by some, to dream. Hill House, not sane, stood by itself against its hills, holding darkness within; it had stood so for eighty years and might stand for eighty more. Within, walls continued upright, bricks met neatly, floors were firm, and doors were sensibly shut; silence lay steadily against the wood and stone of Hill House, and whatever walked there, walked alone....more

Cause the hippies were, like, totally out to brainwash us....Michael Pollan's book seeks to do several things: it chronicles the history of psychedelics (and when we say psychedelics, we are mostly talking about psychobilin aka mushrooms, and LSD), moves to his own experiences with the drugs, transitions to current clinical studies, and pontificates on the future of psychedelics. Pollan did a lot of work on this book, and we're all the better for it.Addiction, anxiety, depression... these are struggles which plague the human condition. What if something was discovered by American medicine 60+ years ago that can help? title: From the Corner of the Oval
author: Dorey-Stein, Beck
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I guess I'm secure enough in my literary preferences, since I had no problem carrying this book around in public. The hot pink cover was... a choice.II guess I'm secure enough in my literary preferences, since I had no problem carrying this book around in public. The hot pink cover was... a choice.I went into this wanting a rage read. I figured this would be an easy book to dislike, hate even, and hate with glee. The vibes I had going into this book was that Beck Dorey-Stein used her being a stenographer at the White House to get a book deal, then used that book deal to whine about her relationships. While those vibes weren't totally off the mark, I was bowled over by one thing:Dorey-Stein can actually write.It's undercut by the fact that she keeps bringing up how she wants to be a writer (sidebar: can we just decide, right here and now, that memoir-ists are no longer allowed to bring this up? Like, clearly you wanted to be a writer BECAUSE DUH, I'M READING YOUR BOOK. YOU ARE ONE), but still, she can write, which is more than I can say for a lot of other memoirs I've read. The story begins in 2011, as Dorey-Stein is attempting to find a job in DC, floundering as most 20somethings do. When she responds to a Craigslist ad, she is shocked to realize she is about to interview at the White House, for a job as one of Obama's stenographers. The reader then follows her for 5yrs, as she rides out Obama's second term and tries to find herself within the clique-y, partying life of White House staffdom.I gotta know: is her experience the universal White House staffer experience? I've heard tale that the show Veep is the most accurate portrayal of what goes on "up on the hill," but is everyone truly just going out and getting smashed and boning each other all the time? Cause, like, I think I chose the wrong early 20s career path, guys.Other than some poignant sentiments dropped by Obama, and Dorey-Stein's Saved By the Bell-esque addresses to the camera when something historically significant/sad happens (think of all the shootings that happened between 2011 - 2017), this book is really about Dorey-Stein's on-again-off-again affair with a senior staffer she pseudonyms Jason, but who the internet hive mind has decided was either Dan Pfeiffer or Marvin Nicholson. Dorey-Stein is very eyes-open about the toxicity of this 5yr affair, in part, I'd have to guess, because she has the journals to reflect on (when I look at my journals from college and the pining I did... **shudder**). It's a very unapologetic account of what emotional abuse can look like, and how we can accept the love we think we deserve. I applaud her bravery for laying bare how helpless she was in the face of someone she loved, who didn't love her back. We could all learn to be a little kinder to one another, and to treat the hearts that are handed to us with care. So, don't go into this book expecting a holistic look into working for Obama in his second term, and what White House life is like. Go into it because you like coming-of-age stories, because DC is a cool city, and because we all need to take a step back and be more gentle, more patient... just better. ...more

We don't need 100 pages dedicated to these practices), but all-in-all this was a fascinating book which cracks open the door to how our brains and bodies protect us: from our pasts and from ourselves, and how sometimes that protection holds us back from growing and changing and living. ...more

title: The Secret History
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Five rich kids at a small, elite college in Vermont are taking all their courses with an eccentric Classics professor. Then a poor and average 6th joiFive rich kids at a small, elite college in Vermont are taking all their courses with an eccentric Classics professor. Then a poor and average 6th joins their ranks. Like all good college students, they want to test their limits, expand their minds, have experiences no one else has had......LIKE MURDER WHHOOAOAOAOAOAAAA.This book sounded promising to me. Like Dead Poet's Society revved up a notch. That's not what this is.There are 6 characters to care about: the scary tall one, the fat loud one, the boy twin, the girl twin, the gay one (is that reductive of me? Apparently not, because even with a gay character the book manages to be homophobic and tone deaf), and the poor one aka our narrator. The narrator really wants to get into the classics clubs because they all seem so exotic to him: they wear tweed! And smoke! And eat out at fine dining clubs (I mean, where are we, an F. Scott Fitzgerald novel?! This is the fucking 1990s). So the narrator petitions the eccentric professor (twice) and joins their ranks, lying about who he is and where he is from to fit in (always great when you need to lie to make friends). The group cavorts, never really doing their work, just lazing about in their excesses (again, I see you, Fitzgerald), until the tall scary one decides they gotta do some weird shit to, like heighten their state of being or whatever.Cool.So they go frolicking into the woods and weird stuff happens which leads to death and lying and the tall scary one KILLS A FRIGGIN' DOG FOR NO REASON AND HIM BEING A SOCIOPATH IS NEVER UNPACKED. The narrator hardly thinks what is going on is odd or bad. We get a time jump at the end which should have served as, I don't know, something. But there is practically zero reflection on just how terribly their time together at college went. The characters also don't grow. They're just... trapped. Because Donna Tartt is trying to be Fitzgerald, but worse.The writing was decent and I liked excerpts because of her language, but all-in-all this is a story about rich kids being rich and getting away with literal murder just because they're rich. Oh and the richness is absurd. Buying last-minute international flights and racking up hundreds upon hundreds of dollars at restaurants and, like, jesus, your credit cards are going to catch on fire, aren't they?Oh, and incest is thrown in there for funsies with no unpacking of it BECAUSE THAT MAKES SENSE.Thanks a lot, Donna.The hero of this story is Judy Poovey - THANK YOU FOR BEING A NORMAL COLLEGE STUDENT WITH A NORMAL ARC. author: Westover, Tara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Too often memoirs are written about nothing. Someone just wants to complain about their blase childhood, or a standard divorce (I'm looking at you EatToo often memoirs are written about nothing. Someone just wants to complain about their blase childhood, or a standard divorce (I'm looking at you Eat, Pray, Love, you ssuuuccckkk), and us sheeple pick up the book at read it because... why? Because we like knowing that the conflict was real? Because we want to validate our fellow man? Whatever.Tara Westover is not here to complain. She's here to educate.Ms. Westover grew up in a rural corner of the States, home "schooled" by her mother and taught religion by her father. Her father, a bipolar zealot, ruled the home with fear and ultimate power. The figures of authority in her childhood frighten and cow not just child Tara on the page but adult me sitting in bed reading. She went through a lot of shit, guys. What's more: never once in this book does she step back and pat herself on the back for breaking out, or step back to be like "see?! See how hard it was!?" No. She is humble to the final page, making excuses for the terrible actions of others; noting that her memory isn't perfect and she doesn't want to mis-characterize anything; stating how lucky she is to have gotten where she has, failing to see, even in her final sentences, how she earned and deserved the honors she has received in academia......I'm pretty sure it's not a literary tool. I think she just really is that cool. Beautifully written, heartbreaking and captivating material, this might be the best memoir that has come out in 50+ years. Now go read it. ...more

title: The Left Hand of Darkness
author: Le Guin, Ursula K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An alien being arrives at planet Gethen, a world run by androgynous people, who have the ability to be either male or female, depending on how they coAn alien being arrives at planet Gethen, a world run by androgynous people, who have the ability to be either male or female, depending on how they couple "in kemmer," or when they are in heat. The alien being, Genly Ai, has been tasked with getting the people of Gethen to join a sort of intergalactic society, but in his voyage is swept up by the politics and nuances of a world utterly unknown to him. It is exceedingly difficult to explain this story without giving anything away. Genly Ai is a clever narrator, providing both the raw awe and curiosity that comes from learning about people so different from him, as well as a critical lens into how they run their world. Genly Ai's narration is joined by:1. The narration of Therem Harth rem ir Estraven, a political big wig in one of the sub-societies of this world. Estraven, as he (though the people of Gethen do not have a defined sex, they are almost always referred to with male pronouns) is often referenced in the book, struggles with trying to understand Genly Ai, while preserving his love of country. He is beautifully complicated and unfailingly optimistic.2. Folk tales native to Gethen, which provide the reader with some societal context, as well as a glimpse into the religion and moralities of this world. This book requires slow and careful reading. Le Guin hasn't created an entirely new language, but, like A Clockwork Orange, she has provided just enough new words to slow the reader down as new landscapes are described, as high courts are established, as the players involved are introduced. This brings me to my biggest gripe about the book: many characters in this book have a Tolstoy-esque list of nick/pet/secondary names, so much so that I found myself flipping back and forth during the first half of the book, trying to remember who belonged to which names. I will say, though, when I complained about this to a friend, she said:"Don't you think that the utilization of different names represents the level intimacy certain characters have with others, which only provides more richness to the narrative?"Well fuck, color me embarrassed. She's right, but I still hate having to flip back and forth!Le Guin deals with sex and gender, loyalty and betrayal, honor and duty, all in a slim 300 pages. The Left Hand of Darkness rings particularly true in American society today, to the point where I found myself furiously scribbling down passages to remember. I leave you with those now:…Tibe dismissed it with scorn. He was after something surer, the sure, quick, and lasting way to make people into a nation: war. His ideas concerning it could not have been too precise, but they were quite sound. The only other means of mobilizing people rapidly and entirely is with a new religion; none was handy; he would make do [sic] with war. In the beginning there was the sun and the ice, and there was no shadow. In the end when we are done, the sun will devour itself and shadow will eat light, and there will be nothing left but the ice and the darkness.I wondered, not for the first time, what patriotism is, what the love of country truly consists of, how the yearning loyalty that has shaken my friend’s voice arises, and how so real a love can become, too often, so foolish and vile a bigotry. Where does it go wrong? And, finally:Light is the left hand of darknessand darkness the right hand of light.Two are one, life and death, lyingtogether like lovers in kemmer,like hands joined together,like the end and the way ...more

title: You Think It, I'll Say It
author: Sittenfeld, Curtis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is so uncomfortable... for all the right reasons.I didn't read Sittenfeld's novel Prep, so when a friend lent me this book to read, with a "This book is so uncomfortable... for all the right reasons.I didn't read Sittenfeld's novel Prep, so when a friend lent me this book to read, with a "god why am I lending you a book you're always so friggin' harsh about books" look on her face, I really went in with zero expectations. That is, I was definitely not expecting to get slapped in the face with painfully honest accounts about how we as people treat one another - how two-faced we can be, how angry, how utterly vengeful all while wearing a smile on our faces.My favorite in the collection, "Bad Latch," tells the story of two women who attend the same prenatal classes, then the same mommy-and-baby classes, and accounts one's internal viewing of the other. It's a frank introspection on how we as people weave stories about others we meet ever-so-briefly, and how so completely wrong we can be in our first impressions. Also, I had read "The Prairie Wife" in a New Yorker last year, and loved the account of coming into your sexuality just as much the second time as I had the first. There are so few stories about queerness that do so with subtlety, and as a queer woman I thank Sittenfeld ten times over for this story. If you can put aside the squeamishness that comes along with reading something so cruelly real, then go run and read this book. If more of us read collections like this, we might come out the other side a little kinder. ...more

title: Pachinko
author: Lee, Min Jin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Why is it that, as an American youth, I learned about the Civil War approximately 718 times. Yet I had absolutely no idea about the extended tension bWhy is it that, as an American youth, I learned about the Civil War approximately 718 times. Yet I had absolutely no idea about the extended tension between Japanese and Koreans, about how the WWII through Korean War period was a one marked by so much suffering. An American character at the close of Pachinko states she never learned about internment camps, never studied Hiroshima in her history classes. We don't talk about these traumatic histories; we have to learn about them through the softening lens of historical fiction. So, way to go, public education system. Pachinko spans over 100 years (~1893 - 1989), following one Korean family. We begin with Hoonie, born with a cleft palate to innkeeper parents. Despite the social repercussions that come with this deformity, Hoonie is matched with farmer's daughter Yangjin. As Japan annexes Korea, as Korean ghettos languish in Japan, as WWII bombs shake their adopted country, as the Korean War bursts onto the stage, this tendril-ing family continues their fight for survival, for acceptance, for stability. In these 500+ pages, Hoonie & Yangjin's daughter, grandsons, and great-grandson live out their lives as best they can, interacting with and pushing against the machine of time and progress. I don't know what to say that hasn't been unpacked by others before me. This book is wildly depressing. The cruelty of children and adults alike, the sexism, the racism, the bigotry... it's a lot to take in. But Pachinko is so beautifully written you'll persevere. Because it's important. Because reading it might make us just a little bit kinder, a smidge more patient. My only real complaint about this book is the characters Ayame and Hanna, though unpacking that bristling requires some minor spoilers, so... (view spoiler)[Hanna, I guess, serves a purpose in the narrative. She's an example what happens to a "forgotten woman," as it were, in this society. But she didn't have to be one, so reading her was just kind of infuriating, especially at the end, with her calling Solomon and being ssuuppeerrr manipulative. Seriously? Ugh.As for Ayame, like, we already knew Haruki was gay. We didn't need to see it through his wife's eyes for one, brief chapter. If Min Jin Lee really needed us to see that park where everyone is banging, we could have seen Haruki's first experience there or something.I gotta say, though, even these complaints didn't really take away from the book experience. I just skimmed the Hanna bits at the end cause life is short to be angry at a fictional character. (hide spoiler)]PS., I didn't know what Pachinko was before reading this book. So... yea. title: Her Body and Other Parties: Stories
author: Machado, Carmen Maria*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Magical realism at its best, Her Body and Other Parties tackles queerness, genderedness, and what it is to be both strong and afraid.I could document Magical realism at its best, Her Body and Other Parties tackles queerness, genderedness, and what it is to be both strong and afraid.I could document each and every story for you, because they were all great, but instead I will highlight the below:The Husband Stitch is a creepy story following the life of a woman who wears a green ribbon. Coupled with her story is a collection of fairy tale-esque anecdotes which bring home the supernatural elements and make for one of the most delightful short stories I have ever read.Inventory is a count of each lover the narrator ever had as she attempts to survive a humanity decimating plague. Desperate, tender, tough... we learn so much about this woman without ever really meeting her at allReal Women Have Bodies has an ending which still haunts me.Eight Bites was the one story that made me cry. A middle-aged woman, tired of feeling tired, sees her sisters go through a successful weight loss procedure and decides to undergo it herself. The procedure, though also successful, has one unwanted consequence which elicits from the woman horror, anger, and, at the end, utter sadness. A final pitch: Machado should be commended for how she doesn't make any of her queer characters a "thing." They just happen to be queer; something we don't see in any media. Being queer in media means you have to hold a banner, or encapsulate all the stereotypes, and it's exhausting. Not so with the parade of characters Machado has created. From one queer woman to another: thank you. ...more

title: I'll Be Gone in the Dark
author: McNamara, Michelle
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I devoured this book, partly because I needed to read it quickly: choosing a nonfiction about a monster who creeps into the houses of women while theyI devoured this book, partly because I needed to read it quickly: choosing a nonfiction about a monster who creeps into the houses of women while they sleep and attacks them is horrible enough. Reading it the week your husband is out of town for work and also you live in the woods? Yea, not ranking as one of my best ideas. All I could think is "wow, I never thought about it before, but truly no one would hear me scream out here." Yeesh. Michelle McNamara worked with generations of detectives who were assigned to the case of the EARS-ON/Original Nightstalker/Ransacker (all of the names he was given before McNamara coined "Golden State Killer"), as well as with a robust online network of hobbyist sleuths. Over a number of years she put together this comprehensive, well-written, and gripping account of the 50 odd rapes and 10 murders the Golden State Killer committed in the 1970s and 80s. She weaves narrative of the lives of the victims and the crimes themselves, then she pivots to interviews with detectives who were there, and summarizes new technologies to try and detail how the responsible could be caught today (I think that phrasing, "the responsible," which McNamara uses in the book after reading it in a police report, is the best way to describe The Golden State Killer).If you ever look at the news, you may know that a man has been arrested as the suspected "responsible" since the publishing of this book. A better ending than the book itself leaves us with, which is hopeful and angry all at the same time. McNamara was a true professional in her craft, and was taken from us too soon. This book will no doubt live on in the halls of incredible true crime fiction, along with Capote and Bugliosi. And to all you other hobbyist sleuths out there: keep looking. There are plenty other responsibles to catch. ...more

title: Erotic Stories for Punjabi Widows
author: Jaswal, Balli Kaur*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's a sad world we live in that I am happily surprised I liked this book as much as I did. Over the years the genre of chick flick has spiraled down It's a sad world we live in that I am happily surprised I liked this book as much as I did. Over the years the genre of chick flick has spiraled down a drain of "what, how do you string a sentence together?" and "life only matters as much as when you get married and have children."Yuck.A 20something Indian woman trying to find herself in London while also trying to stay connected with her family and heritage but without losing her sense of self and modernity could have missed the boat on female empowerment entirely. Lucky for us, Jaswal is actually a woman who likes women. And in the chick flick world? That's been harder to come by.Nikki is a college dropout working at a pub and giving her sister shit for considering an arranged marriage. While Nikki has affection for her Indian culture, she's not so sold on the whole subservience thing. She answers an ad to teach at what is essentially an Indian community center, and things get a little... ah... raunchy.Oh, and there's also a death shrouded in mystery and some really, really scary dudes stomping around trying to make sure the women don't have fun.Jaswal does an impressive job of balancing young-woman-finding-herself meets a commentary on Indian culture meets a commentary on domestic abuse and Womens Rights meets smutty stories as means of empowerment. It's a critical, important societal lens that's been packaged so that people who shy away from things that matter might actually accidentally learn something. Who would have thought dirty stories would be the Trojan horse for feminism? (Actually - I kind of did - if you want to read my Masters thesis...)...more

review: Somebody or something is going after the magical folk: the Tooth Fairy, Hogfather (read: Santa Claus)... you know, those who aren't "supposed" to be rSomebody or something is going after the magical folk: the Tooth Fairy, Hogfather (read: Santa Claus)... you know, those who aren't "supposed" to be real; those who adults shouldn't even be able to see...But don't worry, Death and his granddaughter are on the case.Like all things Terry Pratchett, describing the plot, the menagerie of characters, the madness that is contained between the pages of Hogfather, would only bewilder. Instead, I leave you with my favorite scene from the book, and perhaps from most books:“All right," said Susan. "I'm not stupid. You're saying humans need... fantasies to make life bearable."REALLY? AS IF IT WAS SOME KIND OF PINK PILL? NO. HUMANS NEED FANTASY TO BE HUMAN. TO BE THE PLACE WHERE THE FALLING ANGEL MEETS THE RISING APE."Tooth fairies? Hogfathers? Little—"YES. AS PRACTICE. YOU HAVE TO START OUT LEARNING TO BELIEVE THE LITTLE LIES."So we can believe the big ones?"YES. JUSTICE. MERCY. DUTY. THAT SORT OF THING."They're not the same at all!"YOU THINK SO? THEN TAKE THE UNIVERSE AND GRIND IT DOWN TO THE FINEST POWDER AND SIEVE IT THROUGH THE FINEST SIEVE AND THEN SHOW ME ONE ATOM OF JUSTICE, ONE MOLECULE OF MERCY. AND YET—Death waved a hand. AND YET YOU ACT AS IF THERE IS SOME IDEAL ORDER IN THE WORLD, AS IF THERE IS SOME...SOME RIGHTNESS IN THE UNIVERSE BY WHICH IT MAY BE JUDGED."Yes, but people have got to believe that, or what's the point—"MY POINT EXACTLY.”...more

title: The Snowman        (Harry Hole, #7)
author: Nesbø, Jo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you're going to write a murder mystery, you've got to make sure that the hints dropped in the book pointing toward the murderer don't leave plot hoIf you're going to write a murder mystery, you've got to make sure that the hints dropped in the book pointing toward the murderer don't leave plot holes so large that one tips straight into them and falls forever.I knew from ~page 38 who the killer was, thanks to an error in editing. I spent the rest of the book hoping that a surprise would come... it didn't.What's more, while this book is a stand alone in a larger series, there are characters mentioned and pasts stirred up just enough to be annoying. It didn't make me want to read other Nesbo books, it just made me yearn for concise writing.Also there are way too many characters with insane names... but that might just be a Norway thing.All griping aside, this is a decent read (can you believe I said that?). Harry Hole is a cliche, alcoholic, always-gets-his-way-even-when-he's-punching-through-things detective who has seen some shit, loved and lost, and is sick of it all. But he's fun. He wants a serial killer, he wants something to kick him in the pants. And then boom, The Snowman appears in his town, toying with him, begging him to find the truth. Commence more punching. While that sounds contrived, it's actually alright. The characters as fleshed out well, and the scenes between Harry and his ex-lover Rakel are so poignant they caused me physical pain. The red herrings were interesting, the motive was interesting (despite how obvious it was), and when you get to the climax of the story it's impossible to put down.I just want something to wow me... but I think my expectations have grown too tall. ...more

title: Blood, Bones, and Butter: The Inadvertent Education of a Reluctant Chef
author: Hamilton, Gabrielle
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's unclear what Gabrielle Hamilton's intent was with this book. To get things off of her chest? To demonstrate her scrapiness and right to be at theIt's unclear what Gabrielle Hamilton's intent was with this book. To get things off of her chest? To demonstrate her scrapiness and right to be at the table? Whatever the intent, the result was a whiny memoir that lacked what it had billed: details of being a chef.The beginning was interesting: how she grew up, the details of her French mother making very French dishes for the family. But from there the book begins to spiral. We get a glimpse of Ms. Hamilton working in a kitchen or two in NYC, but then she goes on a ~2yr backpacking tour of the world, which she manages to gloss over, focusing instead on being cold and hungry in Amsterdam (um... playing the smallest violin for you? You got to travel the fucking world; check your privilege/you didn't have to go), and the fact that her mother's friend let her work at her cafe in France. When she gets back from her travels we get the barest of glimpses into the beginnings of her restaurant, Prune, but then the entire second half of her book focuses on her unfulfilling marriage and her kids. The interludes about Italian mothers cooking Italian foods were delightful, but too few and far between. This book should NOT be considered a chef memoir. It's a memoir written by a woman who happens to be a chef. Really, the book should have been titled "Bores, Snores, and Butter: How one woman led a pretty good life, but all she can think about is her absentee parents and her poor decision to marry an Italian man she didn't love. Oh, and she happens to be a chef." ...more

title: How to Cook a Wolf
author: Fisher, M.F.K.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The edition of How to Cook a Wolf presented to me by my library was the second printing, in 1942. This, my friends, is the OG version of the how-to-guThe edition of How to Cook a Wolf presented to me by my library was the second printing, in 1942. This, my friends, is the OG version of the how-to-guide, without any of MFK Fisher's later face palms at her younger self.The purpose of How to Cook a Wolf is to teach its readers how to make due with what they have on hand when nourishment is difficult to procure. Published in 1942, Fisher was talking, primarily, about war rationing and general hunger secondary to the poverty that still clung to folks post-Great Depression. These pages hold dozens of recipes for the 1942 household. My two favorites were:1. Something she calls "sludge." It's a thick oatmeal-type food that is made using grain and, if you can afford it (and/or even find it), meat. You leave it somewhere cool and dark and can eat of it exclusively if that's all your circumstances allow. 2. "A vodka." If you can't get your hands on legitimate spirits, says MFK Fisher, go to a druggist and just get a quart of "alcohol" and mix it together with some lemon rind and diluters. WHAT. WHAT. WHAT.It was especially interesting to read post-COVID panic-buying. We didn't have to contend with sugar rations or anything of that ilk, even in the worst of it. Reading a book that lays out how to make the little bit of "before" that a household was allotted really brought things into perspective. There's a bit of weird classism in this book (which is odd, since parts of this book dictate how one can survive when one has nothing) and also some racism, because, you know, 1942. But if you can look past those How to Cook a Wolf quite an interesting peer into the past. Also, shocker, there is a bit of sexism in this book. One of the wilder things I read was Fisher urging women to always have a mirror with a shelf attached in the kitchen so one could powder her nose quickly even if company arrives unexpected. Nah, bitch, I ain't powdering nothing in the kitchen. She also suggests one moisturizes their hands with butter and their meatloaf mixture... which... gag. ...more

title: Give a Girl a Knife
author: Thielen, Amy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Listen, man, I wanted to talk about the NYC food world: the helter skelter of it, the curses and the drugs and the late nights. Basically, I had hopedListen, man, I wanted to talk about the NYC food world: the helter skelter of it, the curses and the drugs and the late nights. Basically, I had hoped Amy Thielen would give me the female version of what Anthony Bourdain delivered in Kitchen Confidential. It's no secret that women in the back of the restaurant deal with rampant sexism, aggression, and stark wage difference. I wanted Thielen to unpack that. She had spent a friggin' decade working in some of the best kitchens in the city... wouldn't she have some shit to shovel?If she does, she Febreezed the crap out of it and left it alone. Give a Girl a Knife is more a personal journey story than a discussion on the craft of cooking. The book should really be called Give a Girl a Pen and Maybe She'll Tell You About Food but Mostly She'll Talk About Her Husband. Is that too harsh? I guess maybe I'm a little sorry. The book was fine, even good at times. But she starts us in the exciting throes of NYC, only to walk us all the way back to her childhood halfway through. Then we're forced to sit through her entire growing up and her and husband Aaron's life in their no-electricity cabin. Honestly, I sometimes got confused where we were in her timeline, because she jumped back and forth a few times and didn't exactly give us time markers for orientation. At the end of the day we have an okay memoir about a woman who also happened to be a chef at one time. Now, who out there is going to bubble to the top and give us the goods? ...more

author: Ferrante, Elena
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I mean, whatever.I can see the interest/positive buzz around this book. It is a (sometimes painfully) honest account about how women who are friends cI mean, whatever.I can see the interest/positive buzz around this book. It is a (sometimes painfully) honest account about how women who are friends can love one another, be jealous of one another, hurt one another, and grow with one another through adolescence into adulthood. Having friends myself who I have grown up with, I can read passages and see myself on either Elena's or Lila's side of the story. It brought back some shame I had long forgotten, as well as some old angers and resentments I have since put behind me. That being said, the story itself just didn't sparkle for me. Does that make sense? Is it too unicorn-esque? What I'm trying to say is that, while narrator Elena is trying to paint a picture for us, it feels very plodding "this happened then this happened and this is what the street looked like and here are all of the neighborhood kids we hung out with." It's... cold. It feels one step removed. While the anger and the hurt and the love is spelled out for us through the prose, there is nothing that is felt inherently. With a novel circling around something as emotionally charged as female friendship, you'd expect passion and earnest. Instead, Elena is simply providing an account of her childhood, without reliving it. The heart, it seems, was taken out of a novel which requires just that it in order to, again, sparkle. ...more

title: Kids These Days: Human Capital and the Making of Millennials
author: Harris, Malcolm*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am the same age as the author. I am called Millennial, snowflake, selfish, etc. It's a tired diatribe: every generation rolls their eyes at the geneI am the same age as the author. I am called Millennial, snowflake, selfish, etc. It's a tired diatribe: every generation rolls their eyes at the generation coming up next. Is it... a right of passage? An expectation? Whatever it is, Harris wants the world to know that if we keep doing this society as a whole is doomed. This book basically reads as a follows: here is what you think, here is what is actually happening, here is how you old people are assholes. It can be funny, it can be snarky, it can be eye-roll-inducing, and even, in a passage or two, informative. But basically we know all of this already: we are all on anti-depressants, we'll never see pensions or retirement funds, and we are more fucked than any generation before us. Great.I'd recommend it for fellow late-20s-early-30s folks who are struggling to save, to feel fully adult, and to mitigate the bullshit we get from older coworkers/family members/etc. But it's really written by a Millennial for a Millennial to remind us that we're not crazy, and also that the world is coming to a bitter, bitter end. ...more

title: La Belle Sauvage        (The Book of Dust, #1)
author: Pullman, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's tough to sit here and say I am lukewarm about Pullman's newest book. Pullman got me through my adolescence - Lyra was a strong, young, female chaIt's tough to sit here and say I am lukewarm about Pullman's newest book. Pullman got me through my adolescence - Lyra was a strong, young, female character I could look to when I was feeling small or not listened to or too young to make a difference. The His Dark Materials trilogy rocked me in the best possible way. They've stood the test of time: reading them when I was 13, then in college, and just recently in my late 20s, the characters have not dulled for me, the language does not feel dumbed down (they are, after all, YA books), and the messages of agency and science still punch home.What, then, do we say about La Belle Sauvage a book which follows young Malcolm as he stumbles into adventure? He is a pawn, where Lyra was fiercely independent. He is naive and wide-eyed, where Lyra was shrewd and cunning. Perhaps Pullman wants to give us this juxtaposition for later books, but I cannot help but feel that La Belle Sauvage is simply here to set us up for what's to come; not only do I feel that, I hope that, or else this new trilogy will be massively disappointing.The plot is fledgling. Malcolm likes to sit and listen: to the nuns, to the patrons of his father's restaurant. This listening lands him in a precarious position with a woman whose job it is to read one of the few athleiometers in the world. Through a series of being in the right (or wrong) place at the right (or wrong) time, he finds himself struggling to survive a massive flood and bad people with coworker-at-the-restaurant Alice......I mean, OK sure, but is that it? Is that all? After all of these years I wanted to be rocked by Pullman's newest novel. Instead, it's just the tiniest shift, like small waves lapping on the side of Malcolm's boat. ...more

title: The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle
author: Murakami, Haruki
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let's start positive, shall we?The English translation of The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle was done beautifully - there is no question in my mind on the quaLet's start positive, shall we?The English translation of The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle was done beautifully - there is no question in my mind on the quality of the prose. Also, there are vignettes in the novel that I really loved, most specifically the stories from Mr. Honda's war-time friend. They are raw, harrowing, masterful.But the plot proper? We follow the main character. First, he loses his cat. Then, a sex caller calls him for I guess no reason. Then, odd occurrences keep happening to him which aren't well-explained and all involve women. There are several magical elements to the story as well, which also aren't explained. And the main character blunders for years through his isolated life, simply letting things happen to him.And the flaws.First, the women. I could probably spend an hour railing against how Murakami writes the women in his book, but I'll spare you. Here's the line up:A wife whose motivations and emotions and drives are never fleshed outA female sex caller who is never explainedA woman who has... telepathy? Something akin to that? Who doesn't explain what her powers are, why she's interested in the main character, or what she does outside of helping men.Another woman who only describes herself in terms of the sex she has with men.Another woman who becomes preoccupied with the main character for no reason other than she is compelled to buy clothes for him so he is better dressed.A 16yr old girl who strikes up a towing-the-line inappropriate relationship with the main character.Thanks, Murakami, for allowing your women to exist outside the frame of Man. OH WAIT. The main character is also never worried about his missing cat, which speaks to something deeply fucked up within him.I'd get into the plot holes, but it'd spoil too much.(view spoiler)[So... what happened to Malta? Why didn't the explain that? And who exactly was the sex caller? And did Creta really have a child who was "half" the main character's? That's not how genetics work. And did Mr. Honda's war-time buddy finally receive the peace of death? And what the hell happened with Nutmeg's husband?!?! You talk about someone getting so brutally murdered but we have no idea who/why?! NONE of the magical elements are explored properly. We need just suspend our disbelief. That's infuriating. I know that magic cannot be explained fully, but fucking give us something. And lastly, Kumiko's sentence, according to the main character, will either be suspended or be "light." WHAT?! SHE JUST MURDERED AN ESTEEMED POLITICIAN SHE IS GOING AWAY FOR LIFE. These are just the plot holes I thought of in one minute. If I bothered to think about this anymore, I'm sure I would come up with many, many more. (hide spoiler)]Suffice to say I do not understand the hype of this book, and I have to ask if all positivity surrounding it came from men. ...more

title: The Glass Castle
author: Walls, Jeannette*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Jeannette Walls has been through some shit, and she has no problem telling you about it.With the Brie Larson film recently out, is there really a poinJeannette Walls has been through some shit, and she has no problem telling you about it.With the Brie Larson film recently out, is there really a point in explaining The Glass Castle? Walls grew up one of four children (the second oldest, the second daughter) in incredible poverty. Her family often squatted and, when they were actually paying rent, lived in all manner of buildings which were, despite everything, warmly called "home." Her parents had a tempestuous relationship with both each other and with their children: her father had an alcohol addiction which led him to be cruel and abusive to the mother, while the mother played the part of resentful homemaker, more interested in creating art than providing for the children who languished hungry and under-cared for. I will never look at a chicken carcass the same way after reading Walls.Her descriptions are incredible, though I suppose that sort of childhood sticks with you. Walls explains that, no matter how sick, she would always go to school, because at school there was heat and food - two things that home often lacked. She worked hard to make a future for herself, though the guilt of "getting out" seeps through the narrative at times.I do wonder about her youngest sister, though, by the sounds of it, Walls wonders about her as well. ...more

title: We Tell Ourselves Stories in Order to Live: Collected Nonfiction
author: Didion, Joan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I hate to call this book a slog, but my god. At 1100+ pages and dense topics to cover, it took me a very, very long time to finish this anthology. DidI hate to call this book a slog, but my god. At 1100+ pages and dense topics to cover, it took me a very, very long time to finish this anthology. Didion is massively important to the American canon. I am rather ashamed I never read her before. That being said, while I would implore everyone to read her, I would caution against reading this. We Tell Ourselves Stories in Order to Live contains 7 of her books. While each one is an interesting compilation of articles, reading them all together over the span of 1.5 months was a lot, especially considering the depressing realities Didion is touching on. Slouching Toward Bethlehem is an excellent collection of how the end of the 1960s rocked the nation. It touches on senseless crime, on drugs, on the listlessness that can set in. The White Album becomes more of an introspective. Didion writes some personal essays, but still stays true to her reporting background. Salvador is investigative journalism through-and-through, with some Didion flair inserted for good measure.Miami I didn't much like, I have to say.After Henry sort of drags a bit, since I do not care about the celebrities of yesteryear. Political Fictions was infuriating. In a good way. Nothing has *&$(%*@(# changed in American politics in the past 30 years.Where I was From Is memoir-esque, and I'm sure good on its own. But after reading everything preceding it all I really wanted was a nap.So read her, but pick one up one at a time, and leave some space between. Didion has some amazing insights and observations to share with us, but we need to be able to pay attention. ...more

title: Magpie Murders        (Susan Ryeland, #1)
author: Horowitz, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: WHAT DID I JUST SUBJECT MYSELF TO?!I don't understand. I don't understand so utterly that I'm actually angry at the close of this book.So, Magpie MurdWHAT DID I JUST SUBJECT MYSELF TO?!I don't understand. I don't understand so utterly that I'm actually angry at the close of this book.So, Magpie Murders opens up with the editor of fictional author, Alan Conway, telling us how she felt after finishing Mr. Conway's newest manuscript. She asks us to see for ourselves, and we spent ~250 uninterrupted pages reading that exact manuscript.The murder mystery fictional Conway wrote is... fine? I guess? It's pretty contrived, but I muscled through it hoping that getting back to the editor's story would yield something more original and, well, good.NOPE.We get back to the "real" story line and are met with an editor who is... writing to us (who is us? The police? WE DON'T KNOW), I guess, about how the manuscript is incomplete and how good the story we all just read together was (uh, no). And, hey, if she's an editor... WHY THE FUCK CAN'T SHE WRITE?! Holy christ... does Horowitz not allow anyone to edit his work? But more on that later.Unsurprisingly, fictional author Alan Conway has purportedly committed suicide right after editor Susan finishes reading the manuscript.So Susan goes to her boss and is all "where are the rest of the pages." And her boss is all "Dunno, crazy about the deadness though, amirite?!"Susan decides she is going to go out to Alan Conway's house to try and find the missing pages ('cause that's appropriate and makes sense...) and somehow falls into a detective role herself as she inserts herself into the lives of everyone Alan Conway knew because HE MAY HAVE BEEN MURDERED OOOOOOOHOHHHHHHOHOHOHHH.Shoot me. Seriously. Shoot me cause I'd like to be murdered myself. This whodunnit is so wildly obvious with gaping plot holes you fall into and break your legs and the writing is so completely uninspired and how do books like this get published and maybe I shouldn't be reading anything that was published after the first Twilight book came out because I'm pretty sure that is what spurred this idea that writers don't need to be edited.This book should not exist. And I'm not even going to get into the ending, because fuck you you should have to be subjected to this madness too rather than have me spell it out for you. Here are some samplings. I took them solely from Susan-the-editors narrative because that one is SO MUCH WORSE than Alan Conway's fake manuscript. Detailing the arrival to Alan Conway's house:"I don't need to go into all the details of Alan's computer. I wasn't interested in emails, his Google history or the fact that he played electronic Scrabble. All I wanted was the manuscript. He used Word for Mac and we quickly found the last two novels."I pull this because none of this needs to exist. This rambling bullshit adds exactly nothing to the story. If I were grading a student's creative writing piece I would take a red pen to all of this with the note "what does this contribute to the story?" That question is rhetorical though because the answer is NOTHING. Susan on her sister:"The two of us live in different worlds. She's much slimmer than I am and takes more care with her appearance. She dresses in sensible clothes, which she buys from catalogues, and has her hair done once a fortnight."...Why? We know very little about Susan, so maybe this was Horowitz's half-assed attempt to flesh her out but these are the most stupid musings on a sibling that have ever been put on paper.This shit:"It was a perfect excuse to take out the MGB Roadster that I'd bought myself six years ago, on my fortieth birthday. It was a ridiculous car but I'd known I had to have it the moment I saw it for sale outside a garage in Highgate: a 1969 model, manual with overdrive, and an in-your-face, pillar-box red with black trim."WHO CARES ABOUT THIS CAR?!?!?! WHAT DOES THIS HAVE TO DO WITH ANYTHING?!And this shit:"A waiter went past with a tray and I snatched a glass of white whine. It was warm and sluggish, a Pinot Grigio, I think."How does "warm and sluggish" describe any wine, let alone allow Susan to discern it is a Pinot Grigio... she thinks. GgggggoooooooddddddddI WASTED A WEEK OF MY LIFE READING THIS. I DEMAND RESTITUTION....more

title: The House of the Spirits
author: Allende, Isabel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not a lot of books have several strong female characters. Even fewer have their male characters sort of bumble around the strength of the females. ForNot a lot of books have several strong female characters. Even fewer have their male characters sort of bumble around the strength of the females. For that reason alone, Allende is a genius.The House of the Spirits is her first book, so it's got that earnest, poetic weave to it that characterizes many inaugural novels. The story follows three women: Clara, Blanca, and Alba; different generations of women in the same family who work through passion, loss, political upheaval, and the cruelty of men. I'd really hate to go into descriptions of each woman and what they endure, because quite frankly I don't want to ruin any part of the story. I will bring up a couple of the questions that surfaced for me in reading this book, and will not provide my answers, in the hopes it entices you to read it yourself (can you tell I chose this book for book club?):What does it say about Allende's characterization of men that Clara's daughter has a successful story arc with a happy ending, while her sons fade into confusion?How do we feel about a rapist becoming a sympathetic character by the close of the novel? (This question is honestly one of the only reasons I give this book 4 stars instead of 5. I am having a very difficult time reconciling this.)As an American reader, how does Allende's lens into Latin culture inform what we know about countries outside of our own? What does Ferula's character tell us about being a queer latina?Who was chopping onions while I was reading this book, because seriously, it's beautiful. That scene where a man who unrequitedly loves a woman has to perform an abortion on that woman to save both her and her lover?! I mean, jesus Allende, how astonishingly heartbreakingly human....more

review: Can we talk for a second about racism?Sometimes my father makes some pretty off-center jokes. I will apologize for him, usually referencing his age anCan we talk for a second about racism?Sometimes my father makes some pretty off-center jokes. I will apologize for him, usually referencing his age and the time he grew up in for the reason why he can come out with really off-color comments. Even when I'm doing it, I know I shouldn't be, that it's 2017 and he isn't senile and there really is NO excuse for some of the things coming out of his mouth. But I do it.I do not feel about Stephen King the way I feel about my father. I cannot make excuses for him.This book was written in 1988. A little late in the century, I think, to be so rampagingly racist against Romani people. But here we are, with a 200+ page book about a "gypsy curse" causing a fat, rich, Connecticut dude to lose a shit ton of weight until he (hopefully) dies for his transgressions.Oh, and did I tell you? This is my father's favorite Stephen King book.The references to their acts, their smells, their food, their dress. The sexualization of the one female Romani who gets to speak through the course of the novel. The absolutely horrible Romani "accent" King's writing affects at certain points in the story. It's grating, it's offensive, it's inexcusable. Okay, sure, the story is interesting. Fat man crosses Romani family. Romani family seeks their revenge. Fat man is less fat. Fat man tails Romani family. Fat man taps a friend who can maybe help him be fat again. A conclusion is reached. But the main character is hardly fleshed out, as are his compatriots, as is pretty much everyone we meet. No one has any DRIVE or PASSIONS or REMORSE in this book I don't friggin' get it!!...more
