author: Roy, Arundhati*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There comes a time in our lives when we do not have time for the things that demand it most. Say one of the most talented writers of our time comes ouThere comes a time in our lives when we do not have time for the things that demand it most. Say one of the most talented writers of our time comes out with her second work of fiction. It is a dense 400 pages, spanning many years, revolutions, death, destruction... it is a culmination of her nonfiction research, condensed and beautified by the lenses of many characters who feel all too real. The lyricism of her first work is still there, still palatable, still intoxicating.And yet, you cannot bring yourself to pick up the novel. You recognize the importance of the book: weaving a traumatic national history that is underrepresented with the love and loss and torment of singular lives. But on each occasion you find yourself with the time to read... you do something else. You edge around the novel, too deep and dark for you, too real, too demanding of your attention and your emotion.And then the library needs it back. And there is such a long wait list......and so it goes. I feel terrible that I could not finish this book in the time the library allotted me. Maybe some other time, when I haven't recently come off 700 pages of pure depression. ...more

title: Still Life        (Chief Inspector Armand Gamache, #1)
author: Penny, Louise*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How often does a murder mystery reference Margaret Atwood? We must be reading a Canadian novel.Louise Penny has a long Armand Gamache series going on:How often does a murder mystery reference Margaret Atwood? We must be reading a Canadian novel.Louise Penny has a long Armand Gamache series going on: a seen-it-all-yet-still-optimistic-about-people middle aged man working through the greater Montreal area's homicides. His friendly/stern personality endears most people to him, and it's through this bonding with others that he is able to entrench himself into those who knew the victims most, and thus solve the crime and save the day.This first introduction to Gamache, Still Life involves a sleepy little village called Three Pines and the death of an older woman named Jane, with whom no one had any qualms and who was perhaps killed in a hunting accident rather than in cold-blood... but what do you think?There were a lot of weird bits about this book:1. The novel focuses a lot on the couple Clara and Peter, as Clara was sort of surrogate daughter to the late Jane. But their relationship makes no sense. They don't communicate, they become angry with one another easily, the narrator acknowledges that they're a pair that doesn't make sense... yet Penny makes no attempt to explain why their relationship is so unhealthy, or if it will ever get better. This was incredibly frustrating and I'm still frustrated. I actually developed a bit of an eye twitch reading over this passive aggressive couple.2. There's a lot of fat shaming in this book. It just felt mean. 3. The way Penny addresses homosexuality is borderline offensive. She dances around it, and leaves it hanging out there as to whether or not it's okay to be anything other than a white, heterosexual man. I mean... really?4. What was the point of Yvette Nichol as a character? A foil for Gamache? A way to humanize him and illustrate that his judgment isn't always sound? Maybe she crops up in the other novels and becomes a more central character, but she feels like a waste of space in Still Life. Okay, but out-of-place characters and weird stances on certain types of people aside, this book is just... fine, I guess. The murderer reveal wasn't a surprise, and that always sucks, but the more befuddling aspect of this book is Penny's diction. Everything is just so dang flowery in this book, and it doesn't jive well with a murder mystery. I think Penny would have much preferred writing about the fall foliage in Canada over actually having to send the plot forward. And that, too. There isn't much happening between death and reveal of murderer. There's a lot of description of food and drink, and some description of art (why is it that almost every resident of Three Pines is an artist? Is that a joke? Do they have plumbers? Doctors? What the actual hell?), but the story lacks the suspense a mystery really should have. Maybe I'm just grumpy, or maybe I'm right. I guess we'll never know. ...more

title: Skeleton Crew
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Like all Stephen King short story collections, Skeleton Crew is a mixed bag. We open up with The Mist, which is a suspenseful and masterfully written Like all Stephen King short story collections, Skeleton Crew is a mixed bag. We open up with The Mist, which is a suspenseful and masterfully written horror/mystery of what is going on beyond grocery store doors. I saw the movie and hated it, but the short story made me wish they'd try again - King captures the uncertainty and paranoia that so quickly blooms in groups of people during times of crises.But couple hundred pages in we read The Wedding Gig, an out-of-place period piece on mobs which is peppered with racism and fat shaming and feels anti-woman. I hated it.Then we get The Jaunt, a science fiction short discussing... worm holes? Maybe? The specifics are intentionally vague, but a way to portal places has been discovered. What happens between the opening and the ending, however? Is a blissful mystery. It was hair-raisingly creepy. It was amazing.And so it goes. I loved Gramma because it was delightfully creepy and the innocent young boy narrator really fleshed out the dry-mouth fear of the story. But Survivor Type was so friggin' disgusting I actually had to skim it (which maybe is impressive? But jesus I don't need to read that). The Reach was a perfect way to end the collection - no horror here; a story of living a long life and loss and the fantastical elements of love. But Here There Be Tygers, only the second piece in the collection, made no sense to me and didn't need to exist at all. If you're a Stephen King fan like me, I'd recommend reading Skeleton Crew. While there were some stories in here I could do without (I'm looking at you, For Owen), this was my favorite short story collection of his I've read so far due to the strength of the well written installments. ...more

title: The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo
author: Schumer, Amy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the nature v. nurture debate, Amy Schumer is leaning pretty hard into nurture. She talks about having a complicated relationship with food - its heIn the nature v. nurture debate, Amy Schumer is leaning pretty hard into nurture. She talks about having a complicated relationship with food - its her mother's fault for never allowing junk food in the house. Her skittish-ness with relationships? Parents had a weird divorce and her mom is manipulative and pretty terrible.Join the fucking club, kid. The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo is Schumer's personal therapy session, where things in her life are just happening to her, and she works really hard to be the super awesome person she is today....The book is very self-aggrandizing. Reading about being a wildly rich child who then struggled with poverty and became super rich again doesn't rouse the sympathy I think Schumer expected. All of the "I'm taking it back!" rants about abusive relationships and getting too drunk etc. etc. just caused me to bristle rather than to endear the narrator to me at all. I guess I just don't like Amy Schumer, which is fine for both of us.Written in the mini-essays format of many memoirs before it, The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo jumps around Schumer's life from when she was a little kid to the most present day she could offer. Schumer attempts to pepper in life advice at the end of her chapters, but they just come off preachy.Example: Schumer tells the story of how she wrote an article for Men's Health and how they mocked it up with a bunch of pictures of hot, skinny models.She could have taken this experience and talked about how women are too often utilized as objects. Instead, she rants about how they didn't ask her to model for the article. I mean, really? You have an opportunity to highlight how all women are treated, but you make it about you?Example: Schumer notes the shooting that happened at a showing of Trainwreck, and two girls died.She could have used her time to talk about the families and the girls. She instead discusses how it affected her and how she overcame the tragedy....Uuhhhh...The navel-gazing "I can drink really expensive wine now and I shower my friends with $$ and all of these famous people want to hang out with me and isn't being rich and famous awesome?" was maddening. Why didn't her editor take her aside and say "now Amy, very few people can relate to this, and you sound like an asshole." ?Who knows, maybe the editor did. Maybe Schumer steamrolled her like it seems to steamroll a lot of other people in her life. Bashing aside, I have to say I really liked the excerpts from her childhood journals, with present day footnotes. Those were actually funny. ...more

title: Wyrd Sisters        (Discworld, #6; Witches, #2)
author: Pratchett, Terry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Imagine someone who can capture effervescence with a sentence, who can be poignant and witty simultaneously. Now imagine that person writes a novel whImagine someone who can capture effervescence with a sentence, who can be poignant and witty simultaneously. Now imagine that person writes a novel which weaves together several fairy tale stories and Shakespeare plays together into a rollercoaster narrative of awesome.Didja your brain follow that? Well, then you're starting to understand what it's like to read Terry Pratchett.This is the 3.5th (or is it "rd"?) Pratchett book I've read (Good Omens only counts as one half, I'd think) and it is hands down my favorite. The Color of Magic is a lot of fun and Mort, though original and delightfully quirky, got a little plodding at times. Wyrd Sisters, on the other hand, was nothing short of a masterpiece of fantasy. It may be my college education getting excitable at the work out it received from so many literary references packed into such a slight novel, but I really, really enjoyed this book. It was, I think the most fun I've ever had reading something.Wyrd Sisters tells the tale of a mad king and his devilish wife, angrily/crazily ruling over a kingdom wherein three witches live and argue about what exactly it is to be a witch. As royalty and magic begin to butt heads, we meet a troop of performers, a too-clever Fool, and a Guild of Burglers.If this sounds weird and confusing then good, it should. The story bounces all over, with side tangents and a sentient forest and demons getting all bent out of shape about being summoned. It's a book that maybe shouldn't be read in public, unless you're totally cool with laughing for no reason and having people look at you oddly. Which, I mean, you really should be okay with. Screw those people....more

title: The Worst Hard Time: The Untold Story of Those Who Survived the Great American Dust Bowl
author: Egan, Timothy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading this book now, with the current climate in America, was a big 'ol punch in the gut. I'd heard the phrase "dirty thirties" before. I knew that Reading this book now, with the current climate in America, was a big 'ol punch in the gut. I'd heard the phrase "dirty thirties" before. I knew that The Dust Bowl had been a thing. But I had no idea the extent of it, how the rest of the country reacted, and the longitudinal changes that came from it. It's unsurprising that we were devastating the land with abandon back then, though it sucks that we've learned essentially nothing from The Dust Bowl, and continue to flip off the Earth while mining it for all of its useful bits without thinking about the future. The TL;DR is as follows: a bunch of white people went out west to get away from the pollution of the cities and to make it as farmers. They killed all the bison and chased all the indigenous people off of the land. Wheat became a Big Deal, and so more white people hopped trains west to try and make some cash during the wheat boom. Long term residents of the area (NE, KS, OK, TX, and some of CO) warned that the rainy seasons of the 20s were abnormal, and that the area might not be able to support the massive amounts of wheat being planted. But hubris reined, and the interlopers ripped out all of the naturally occurring crop (mostly buffalo grass), to plant their wheat. First, the price of wheat began to plummet. Then the rains stopped, and the area sunk into another drought spell, not uncommon for the area. The plains no longer contained the buffalo grass which "kept the ground in place," as folks were saying, and so prairie winds ripped through and lifted topsoil off of the ground and into the air at higher and higher rates as the years of drought ticked by. That swirling topsoil would slam back to earth, covering houses, killing children and the elderly with "dust pneumonia," and generally wreaking havoc. The "dust spells" as they were called, even made their way out easy to NY and DC. Eventually, FDR and time created the change needed to try and heal the area, though, as of the book's publishing (2006), parts of the great plains are still totally barren; forever scarred by our selfishness. The really fucked up thing about this book is the stubbornness of the people. So many were wildly unwilling to stop ripping out the buffalo grass. They insisted that the wheat prices would bounce back, that the droughts were temporary, that they hadn't done anything wrong. Wheat was rotting at the train stations of the great plains while people in cities starved. It hit me hard, thinking about the footage of so much milk being dumped at the beginning stages of COVID, while people lost their jobs and went hungry. Our country still sucks at reacting to a crisis. And we, as a whole, still suck at taking care of the planet. We'll deserve it when it turns on us for good, and then the Squid People will rise....more

title: Cork Dork: A Wine-Fueled Adventure Among the Obsessive Sommeliers, Big Bottle Hunters, and Rogue Scientists Who Taught Me to Live for Taste
author: Bosker, Bianca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The science, history, and culture of wine is quite an interesting and under-researched topic. Sommeliers are an intriguing group of humans who dedicatThe science, history, and culture of wine is quite an interesting and under-researched topic. Sommeliers are an intriguing group of humans who dedicate their lives to unpacking the nuance of taste and experience for those who can afford to frequent a restaurant which would employ one. Bianca Bosker could have written a really excellent book about all of this, had she not insisted on inserting personal bullshit that makes her come off as a pretentious Basic Bitch who muscles her way into places she shouldn't be.I could end there, but I'll go further: there are chapters of Cork Dork which sing. Bosker flexes her journalism background as she educates her reader on how restaurants came to be, what the first sommeliers were like, and how our bodies interact with smell and taste. I really enjoyed the discussion of smell as a "forgotten" sense, and how other cultures, which rely more heavily on smell, can pick up faint odors that the standard American would completely overlook. It's not just a history lesson, it's an acknowledgment that we experience things too rushed, that we need to take a step back and savor. It's advice not just for the palate, but for the soul, and I tip my hat to that introspection on American culture.That being said, the Bosker we meet in the book is the type of person who takes up the whole sidewalk with her friends, who inserts herself into conversations she has no business being in, who loudly makes the party about her, who incorrectly corrects people when they're just trying to tell an anecdote. She's the girl at the party I always hate, but have to invite, because she's friends with BlahBlah and we'll never hear the end of it if she's slighted. Also, she'll probably show up even if she's not invited and make more if a scene than if an invitation had been extended. It's insane to me that Bosker is able to portray herself so objectively terrible... but she does. Everything about her own musings, experiences, and friendships made me want to hurl. Maybe I did, and just blocked it out. But the refrain of "I was a big-wig journalist and gave it up to try this wine thing out because how hard can it be even when people dedicate their lives to it and I just want to drink" is infuriating. I'd love to know how many friends she lost after this book came out, because she sounds like the worst. Tasting Notes: Aged notes hit the spot, but the aftertaste is unpleasantly sour.Pair With: Hate mail and a skinny-mocha-chocha-locha-latte, because that's the shit girls like Bosca drink....more

author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I guess Atwood and I just don't get along. At this point, I've read ~8 of her books, and I've only really enjoyed two, and really disliked a couple ofI guess Atwood and I just don't get along. At this point, I've read ~8 of her books, and I've only really enjoyed two, and really disliked a couple of them. Hag-Seed is a tale of madness, of prisons, of weird white woman "ghetto" slang, of revenge. It's packaging is convoluted: let's tell the story of The Tempest as envisioned by an eccentric artistic director named Felix who finds himself teaching theater to inmates. Felix's own madness is leaking at the seams (and that madness is quite boring, honestly), and he's obsessed with a decade old slight. The plot is incredibly slow moving until we arrive at opening night of the play, wherein Felix's revenge is realized, and The Tempest is told thrice over: his interpretation as acted out by the inmates, the weird English-class-esque analysis that happens afterward, and the summary Atwood provides us at the end. It fell flat, it was too thickly layered with half thought out motivations. It plodded and sputtered and it was just all around meh. Sorry, Atwood, you're just not the girl for me. ...more

title: Wuthering Heights
author: Brontë, Emily
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh, Emily Bronte. Lonely and dreamy, writing stories with younger sister Anne until dying at the too-young age of 30. Though I was introduced to her sOh, Emily Bronte. Lonely and dreamy, writing stories with younger sister Anne until dying at the too-young age of 30. Though I was introduced to her sisters in school (Charlotte in high school and Anne in graduate school), Emily was never prescribed reading. It's odd, because Wuthering Heights contains within it all the tropes, conflicts, and symbolism for which a classroom yearns. The story opens on our narrator as he decides to take up residence at what we'll call "The Grange." He subsequently walks to Wuthering Heights to meet his landlord, Heathcliff. Heathcliff a gruff, angry, asshole of a man, and the family dynamic at The Heights is confusing and piques the narrator's interest in a macabre sort of way. After an unplanned, nightmarish night spent at Wuthering Heights (which smacks of the attic in Jane Eyre and gets me wondering about how much the girls shared and, also, how much of their real lives they pulled into fantasy) the narrator begs the housekeeper at The Grange, Nelly, to tell the story of why Heathcliff is the worst.Luckily for us, Nelly agrees.We focus on Heathcliff as a child, the young Catherine currently living in Wuthering Heights, and our narrator's ruminations over it all. No character in this book, save Nelly, is truly likable. They are selfish and cunning and guarded. It makes them real. These people wander about, out for themselves, attempting to ruin others. Hareton, my favorite character, almost brought me to tears with how he is treated at certain points in the novel and, though most novels of the time had happy endings, Emily leaves a bit of a cloud over her characters once we leave them. It's a warning to watch out for yourself, and a reminder that people, despite how well you think you know them, can be so very cruel. Also, PS., I know marrying cousins was pretty normal in the 19th century but holy crap there is SO MUCH COUSIN SEX IN THIS BOOK. Just as a warning. ...more

title: The Nix
author: Hill, Nathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The title The Nix does not refer to Nixon, as I originally thought. Nor does it refer to nixing something, as in "nope, nix it." No, this Nix is a fanThe title The Nix does not refer to Nixon, as I originally thought. Nor does it refer to nixing something, as in "nope, nix it." No, this Nix is a fantastical nordic horse which appears to children, beckons them onto its back, and then gallops them off of cliffs and to their deaths.That's only scratching the surface of how dark this book can get. Nathan Hill's narration style is completely immersive. His story shuffles through a few narrators: 1. SamThe main character, if we have to pick one. Sam gets two story lines: one where he is a pre-teen, before his mother leaves him, who meets twins Bishop and Bethany and becomes completely entwined in their lives. The other captures him at 30, floundering in the aftermath of his decisions, and having his mother thrust back into his life. 2. FayeA 17 year old in 1968, graduating high school, entering college, and attempting to balance what is expected of her and what she really wants in life. We get a brief glimpse into her mind ~18 years later, but this is where the meat of her story lives.3. LauraA vapid student of Sam's, who struggles with boys and school. 3.5. BishopWe only receive a smidge of his adult life in the military, but it is so poignant it deserves to be noted.4. PwnageA loner of a man who games with Sam in Elfscape (think WoW, without the copyright infringement), who is obsessed with the "New Me" who is sure to show up any day now.I run through these characters not because this is an opening of a play wherein you need these introductions, but because you need to understand just how different these characters are, and how masterfully Hill captures their unique voices. To go from a quiet, sensitive, regretful adult man to the self-absorbed neurotic rambling brain of a 21st century 18 year old girl to an obsessive, agoraphobic gamer to a 17 year old caught up in what, at the time, felt like revolution is astounding. This book is a case study in human nature, in what makes us feel, in what makes us whole. Books like this don't come around often, and I loved it all... except the very end.(view spoiler)[The ending, friends.Oh god the ending.The ending made me go "wait, what the fuck, really??" It reminded me of The Goldfinch in that, very negative, respect.Hill puts explosives up against the fourth wall in the last 30 pages. Sam goes up to Guy Periwinkle (his agent) and is all "I'm going to write a new book, about all of this, about my mother, about Bethany and Bishop, all of it." So he's basically going to write this very book.THEN he goes: "and I'll be sure to give you a ridiculous name."And Guy Periwinkle is a friggin' stupid name.So the end is this weird nod to the reader about how the book they're reading is the book Sam wrote and it gets meta in all the worst ways and pisses me off.So I look into Nathan Hill.Grew up in the Midwest.Wife is a professional musician.He's a writer (duh).His mother could have feasibly lived through 1968 and been of the age to experience all that Faye experiences and WHAT THE FUCK IS THIS BOOK NONFICTION?!And now that's all I can think about. And I'm fucking pissed about it. The book isn't ruined for me, but damn do I wish it had just ended on him and Bethany laughing, and everything else up in the air.Oh, oh, and PS. If Hill was going to put a neat little bow on all his characters at the end WHY DID HE TOTALLY FORGET ABOUT SAM'S POOR DAD?! Honestly, he's the real hero of the story, poor, repressed, confused, lonely Sam's dad :( :(  (hide spoiler)]...more

title: Lincoln in the Bardo
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was in grade school my best friend Hannah and I would write stories with ourselves cast as the main characters, and all of our friends strewn aWhen I was in grade school my best friend Hannah and I would write stories with ourselves cast as the main characters, and all of our friends strewn around in supporting roles. We would jump around into everyone's head so that the book read something like this:Beth - I looked up into the trees and saw a monkey staring down at me.Hannah - Why is Beth looking up at the trees? Maybe there's apples up there!Frank - Beth is so pretty... I wish she liked me...Donna - "YOU GUYS THAT MONKEY IS THROWING POOP!"We had never read a narration style like that before, and I don't really know how/why we ended up with that formula, but I have a stack of notebooks containing anecdotes not unlike the above.Well, I guess Saunders found us out, because Lincoln in the Bardo takes that same narration style: a jump-around train ride of an orgy of consciousness. It took me a while to figure out what he was doing, but given my background of inventing this style (and I will defend that until my dying day) it was relatively easy to get into the swing......not that I really wanted to be.Saunder's novel is a fantastical snapshot into the aftermath of the death of Abraham Lincoln's son Willie. We jump from the world of the living as it spectates on Lincoln's grief, into a Purgatory Plane, where Willie struggles with what's become of him. The Purgatory Plane contains dozens of characters, most notable a Timon/Pumba sort of coupling in Mr. Vollman and Mr. Bevins, who are trying to help Willie, arguably to his detriment. And I didn't get it.I didn't get why the specters in the Purgatory Plane revealed themselves as weird caricatures of their deepest desires. I didn't get why we needed to meet SO MANY of the specters. I didn't get why Saunders even involved a historical figure in this story, seeing as how both Abraham and Willie Lincoln have very little to do with the story at all, and the main point seemed to be those who were already residing in the Purgatory Plane. I didn't find the story or the characters compelling, and I didn't like the ending. I guess I can see how this is a more avant-garde type of story telling, and I'll relent that it is original. But I just. Don't. Care. Silver lining? This inspired me to re-read those nuggets of gold that are my middle school "books."...more

title: The Underground Railroad
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The grizzled reality of American slave life meets punchy fantasy to create a grotesquely fascinating historical mosaic.When asked to describe this booThe grizzled reality of American slave life meets punchy fantasy to create a grotesquely fascinating historical mosaic.When asked to describe this book in one sentence, I thought for a long time before spitting out the above. Author Colson Whitehead follows his character Cora from her childhood growing up a slave on a Southern cotton plantation, to her escape utilizing the cleverly literal underground railroad, and the (mis)adventures she finds herself in as a result. Written as a dark and hopeless tale with a twinge of fantastical madness, Colson has found a way to balance out the most horrendous bits of American history to be consumable for the masses.The characters in this book aren't fleshed out too much, but I would argue this is done intentionally. The Underground Railroad isn't a person profile novel. It's commentary on a movement, on hate, on perseverance, on rising up. It'll get your blood to boil and it'll make you want to cry. It'll make you say "that would never..." and then you have to catch yourself, because of course the atrocities in the book did happen, and worse.One can only hope that this becomes required reading in the classroom, not just as an innovative work of historically inspired fiction, but as a case study in how to feed the public even the saddest of stories, and get them to listen....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Yuval Noah Harari is the coolest. He's the guy smoking in the back of a murder mystery film, knowing the answers to all the questions folks are askingYuval Noah Harari is the coolest. He's the guy smoking in the back of a murder mystery film, knowing the answers to all the questions folks are asking, quietly providing them while the cast loudly ignores him.Sapiens is a sketch of humanity - how Homo Sapiens came to be, why they're the iteration of Homo which remains, and where we as a species are heading. He posits that, by 2050, there will likely be individuals who are a-mortal, that is, they will not die by disease or old age. And he provides real data to support this theory.Yowza. Unlike many similar books which ask big questions like "how did we get where we are" and "where are we going," Harari actually provides possible answers, with reasoning to back them up. He tackles why we moved from hunters/gatherings to agriculture; how we created constructs such as society, government, and currency; what it means to be a consumer; what purpose religion served... I can go on. But I won't. Because you need to read this book. Everyone needs to read this book.Give this man a goddamn cookie. ...more

title: And Then There Were None
author: Christie, Agatha
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Almost timeless.And Then There Were None is a fast-paced murder mystery about 10 strangers arriving on an uninhabited, mansion-holding island, to playAlmost timeless.And Then There Were None is a fast-paced murder mystery about 10 strangers arriving on an uninhabited, mansion-holding island, to play their part in a dark and twisted nursery rhyme.Agatha Christie has been a household name for a century, and is aptly known as the "Queen of Crime." But while we're on the subject of Christie the person, we've got to visit the racism.And Then There Were None is the artist formally known as Ten Little Indians which was the artist formally known as Ten Little N**gers. I mean... she wrote the book in 1939 - she knew that word wasn't okay. America, to its credit, never published the book under the original title (though it did subscribe to the less-but-still-pretty offensive title Ten Little Indians). The reader should go through the book and take every reference to "soldier" and replace it with the aforementioned racial epithet - because that's how Christie wrote the book. The characters are on N- Island, people. I cannot morally reconcile this. While I enjoyed the story - finding it original and brimming with wit, Christie's preoccupation with "otherness" is jarring. The original title/name of the island isn't the only squeamish bit. She also makes snide comments about the Jewish community, the Asian community, and women. I am tired of making excuses for people because they were a product of their time. Christie was too contemporary to have that excuse applied, especially considering she lived in several countries and traveled around the world. That word wasn't okay in the SEVENTEENTH century - never mind the year my grandfather turned 15. Whew, I'm glad I got that off my chest. Disgust aside the book is, perhaps unfortunately in light of the above, fantastic. Creative, intriguing, psychological... it's a compulsive read. What's more: I couldn't parcel out the ending. Quite frankly, I don't know the last time a book stumped me. To have the ending dramatically revealed where I went: "wait... what?!" was truly lovely. So... I guess... read it? But read it knowing that Christie the person was kind of a twat. ...more

title: Do Not Say We Have Nothing
author: Thien, Madeleine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What was a zero anyway? A zero signified nothing, all it did was tell you nothing about nothing. Still, wasn't zero also something meaningful, a numbeWhat was a zero anyway? A zero signified nothing, all it did was tell you nothing about nothing. Still, wasn't zero also something meaningful, a number in and of itself? In jianpu notation, zero indicated a caesura, a pause or rest of indeterminate length. Did time that went uncounted, unrecorded, still qualify as time? If zero was both everything and nothing, did an empty life have exactly the same weight as a full life? Was zero like a desert, both finite and infinite? How did a person know, he wondered, what was love and what was a facsimile of it? Did it matter? Ws the thing that mattered most the action that one took - or failed to take - in the name of that feeling? I'm not sure my words can add anything... or if they even matter. But I am sure that this book matters very much. Disappointment and revolution and massacre and lives left unlived... get ready to have your heart torn out and stomped on. It was totally worth it....more

title: Here I Am
author: Foer, Jonathan Safran *
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is Safran Foer going through a bad divorce? A bout of depression? Did he contemplate the human condition, find it wanting, and decide to write the mosIs Safran Foer going through a bad divorce? A bout of depression? Did he contemplate the human condition, find it wanting, and decide to write the most god-awfully-depressing series of words I have ever seen?...This isn't rhetorical.Safran Foer wrote my all-time favorite novel Everything is Illuminated. His second story about 9/11 was not as good, but still moving and well written. Eating Animals was a nonfiction attempt to understand the human relationship with animal products and, as a vegetarian, I really enjoyed his research. So why does Here I am suck so bad?The novel circles around a family: husband, wife, and their three sons. Recurring characters include the paternal grandparents, and the neglected family dog Argus. The family doesn't just have "normal growing pains" or "difficult times" - each character whose brain the reader peers into hates themselves and everyone around them. They are cruel, they are selfish, they are impossible to like. They aren't even fleshed out enough to truly understand them - the reader bases their impressions on the characters hate. And I just couldn't do it. I couldn't submit myself to ~500 pages of self-loathing and rage. After 200 pages, I skimmed through to see if they ever move past the "I hate you and you and everything" theme of the beginning of the novel. They don't. And thank god I didn't hold on until the end, because holy shit is that a terrible close to a story. (view spoiler)[I mean, seriously, putting the dog down?! Holy fuck, Safran Foer! Get a therapist! (hide spoiler)]. I guess this is the end for me and Safran Foer. We had a good run, bud, but fuck have you fallen far. ...more

review: Neil Gaiman is incredibly overrated and kind of a giant douche.Whew, I'm glad I got that off my chest. I disliked American Gods, finding it a great coNeil Gaiman is incredibly overrated and kind of a giant douche.Whew, I'm glad I got that off my chest. I disliked American Gods, finding it a great concept executed in the worst possible way. I also find Gaiman as a human very grating. I remember all the media buzz about the 12th Doctor being cast for Doctor Who, and Gaiman standing up all "I know better than you peasants" and spreading his shit all over the news about how he had inside knowledge that Capaldi was a consolation prize rather than who Moffat actually wanted and it all just felt so mean and bullying and unnecessary and YOU CAN'T SIT WITH US, GAIMAN!Wow, shit, okay. Reeling it in now.Imagine my surprise when a friend whose tastes I trust told me to read this book."Noooo," I whined. "Do I havveeee to?"My friend didn't reply, because I was being foolish, but his face basically said Suit yourself, you don't know what you're missing. I can't miss things.So I read it, expecting to hate it and Gaiman and my friend and who knows what else! Maybe this would make me hate The Doctor's Wife!Imagine my surprise when, finishing The Ocean at the End of the Lane, I turned to my husband and said "you know, you should really read this."A not-quite-short-story about a young boy and his brush with adventure and the queer neighbors who live at the end of the lane. The story has fantasy, horror, and drama elements, all wrapped up in the mind of a seven year old. I could quibble about the plot holes riddled in the adult version of the young boy, or about the flat, gray characterization of the boy's family, but surprisingly it isn't worth it. The Ocean at the End of the Lane is a solid fantasy story, even for those who may not think they like fantasy. ...more

title: Wool        (Wool, #1)
author: Howey, Hugh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So... what's the point of this book? I've heard that writers must ask themselves "why" when writing a story... did Hugh Howey forget to ask this questSo... what's the point of this book? I've heard that writers must ask themselves "why" when writing a story... did Hugh Howey forget to ask this question?Wool is a story about humans who live underground in a "silo." They can only make babies if they win a lottery allowing them to do so, and sometimes people are sent above the surface for "cleaning" - where people literally clean the lenses of the cameras pointed toward the desolate, post-apocalyptic sky. Oh, and then they promptly die 'cause it be poison out there.Yea, cause that makes sense. Why do they need a lens to the outside? Why don't they just have windshield wipers? How stupid are these silo people? C'MON!In theory? Interesting story I guess. In practice? A boring, dragging, clunky story where relationships between characters are superficial at best and any interesting bits are weighed down by irrelevant details and background. Authors aren't supposed to go on tangents unless they're Victor Hugo, so why is Howey getting a pass?I made it 150 pages into this book (and it took me 2 weeks to get that far) before I finally had to put this book down. I just don't care. Also, despite how long winded Howey can be, I still have no idea how these silos function. How do they have that many flights of stairs?! How do they actually GET on the different floors? They have electricity... so why no elevators? And if there is an uprising every X amount of years, how are there no people who survived through it still kicking around? How is the mayor so damn disconnected from friggin' everything? These holes alone pissed me off. The mustache twirling caricature of evil coupled with the fragmented attempt at story telling were just icing. ...more

Campbell Jr. was a double agent in WWII. He broadcasted Nazi propaganda, but with a secret code to help the Allies end the war.Does anyone believe him ? Does he believe himself?You are what you pretend to be. I really enjoyed the rambling, self-doubting torment of this narrative. I also enjoyed the balance of humor and desperation. Two examples :"You no longer believe that love is the only thing to live for?" She said."No," I said."Then tell me what to live for - anything at all," she said beseechingly. "It doesn't have to be love. Anything at all!" She gestured at objects around the shabby room, dramatizing exquisitely my own sense of the world's being a junk shop. "I'll live for that chair, that picture, that furnace pipe, that couch, that crack in the wall! Tell me to live for it and I will!"..I have never seen a more sublime demonstration of the totalitarian mind, a mind which might be likened unto a system of gears whose teeth have been filed off at random. Such a snaggle-toothed thought machine, driven by a standard or even by a substandard libido, whirls with the jerky, noisy, gaudy pointlessness of a cuckoo clock in Hell . Brava....more

title: A Little Life
author: Yanagihara, Hanya*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the most depressing book I have ever read, no contest. But... seriously, was there a contest? The way Yanagihara wrote this book, I'm beginninThis is the most depressing book I have ever read, no contest. But... seriously, was there a contest? The way Yanagihara wrote this book, I'm beginning to wonder if she was sitting around with her friends and they said "bet you can't write the saddest book ever created." And she took the challenge and fucking ran over the edge of the world with it.A Little Life follows four friends from early adulthood until middle age. First there is Willem, the sensitive pretty-type who wishes to be an actor. Estranged from his complicated family he seeks a family of his own making in his friends. Next, Malcolm. The privileged of the group who struggles with both his identity and sexuality while striving to meet his rich father's expectations without drowning under the weight of stuffing his square peg into the round hole of familial obligation. Third is JB, the dramatic, flamboyant, sometimes cruel and always passionate artist of the group. He's arguably the main foil in this novel. And, lastly, there is Jude. Jude is a thunderclap of sadness. He is the main character. He is the... protagonist? I guess? But after ~700 pages of Jude's self loathing I do not read him as a protagonist. In fact, the only character I consistently liked in the book is Malcolm. He's the only one who seems to grow up, while the rest of them flounder in Jude's past. To explain how and why every other character is utterly steeped in Jude (and I'm ignoring secondary characters like Harold and Andy and Richard and several others who are also swept away in the waves of Jude) would take dozens of pages worth of text. And maybe that was Yanagihara's main objective in crafting a novel as devastating as A Little Life. But I'm not buying it. I'm in the "she made a bet she could write the saddest story" camp. Because if you sat down and wrote out every single sad thing that could ever happen to a child, you still probably haven't thought up everything that happens to the character Jude. As we started to unfold Jude he became this delicate, beautiful, complicated character in literature. But as the book plodded on it Jude went from beautiful to infuriating and border-line ridiculous. The five dozen terrible things which happen to him start to become a caricature of trauma, and that is a truly terrible thing. By googling "terrible things that can happen to someone" and layering them on and on and on the character of Jude, Yanagihara has squandered an opportunity to detail how trauma can manifest itself in adulthood, and how it can radiate out to others. Instead, we're left with a mash of sadness which borders on ludicrous and that is a damn shame. (view spoiler)[PS. Willem and Jude getting into a relationship was friggin' infuriating. After all that time of being Jude's friend and watching him struggle, getting into a relationship with him was probably the stupidest and most unrealistic decision any of the characters make. And THEN she kills Willem off?? Seriously!? I just... no. At that point I had to place the book on the floor just to stomp up and down on it a few times before continuing.  (hide spoiler)]...more

review: Oof.Loung Ung was living the typical life of a 5yr old: her parents adored her, her siblings protected her, her upper-middle-class existence ensured sOof.Loung Ung was living the typical life of a 5yr old: her parents adored her, her siblings protected her, her upper-middle-class existence ensured she always had food and shelter......but then the Khmer Rouge army took over.Ms. Ung's story is heart wrenching. She details for the reader her first encounter with a dead body, how her young mind grappled with starvation and murder, and how anger helped give her the strength to survive. It's incredibly impressive how honest Ung is about what it was to be a child when her country and countrymen were being torn apart. She asked a lot of questions, she threw temper tantrums because she wanted to go home... basically she's a little shit, like most children are. As an adult, she feels as though she still needs to make reparations for her selfish behavior. It breaks your heart, because she was a child, of course she reacted as she did at the time, and to carry those weights all of those years? I hope someone has told her it's okay to drop them now. ...more

title: Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood
author: Noah, Trevor
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I would argue that you, like me, do not know a lot about Trevor Noah the person. He's a face in comedy, a celebrity, wealthy, attractive. You, like meI would argue that you, like me, do not know a lot about Trevor Noah the person. He's a face in comedy, a celebrity, wealthy, attractive. You, like me, may feel sort of "fuck that guy" - the way I feel when the models waiting for the crosswalk next to me complain about how they can't eat a whole banana because it's just too filling.Sorry - yesterday was a weird day.Listening to memoirs read by the author is something I find incredibly enjoyable. They know where to put the emphasis - they know the tone of their parents, their friends, their lovers. Noah does a really excellent job giving heart to his childhood as chronicled in Born a Crime. The story jumps around a bit, detailing different events in his life that shaped him while simultaneously educating the reader about growing up under apartheid. I expected his story to be unique. I did not expect to become upset... or cry... listening to a man, who by all outward appearances has a better life than I, tell his story. Noah did not have the easiest time as a colored child being raised by a single black mother in the mid 1980s. Fear was a standard, and that fear merely evolved once apartheid ended. Domestic abuse, South African police and jails, growing up poor, growing up awkward... Noah isn't shying away from the dirtier aspects of life, and he does it in an earnest and open way. His story is important - it isn't Tina Fey joking about being friends with lesbians, or Anthony Bourdain chronicling his debauched youth. Noah's memoir is a unique, hopeful, humbling story of poverty and perseverance. He is, at the risk of laying it on nauseatingly thick, an inspiration. ...more

title: The Food Lab: Better Home Cooking Through Science
author: López-Alt, J. Kenji
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read a lot of cookbooks. Like, a lot. Like, I'm getting raised eyebrows from my husband as our floor-to-ceiling bookshelf, which is overcrowded as iI read a lot of cookbooks. Like, a lot. Like, I'm getting raised eyebrows from my husband as our floor-to-ceiling bookshelf, which is overcrowded as it is, spills out with dozens of cookbooks. "You have the internet!" he cries. "You don't need these!"Oh, but I do.I never give myself "credit" for reading a cookbook because it's cheating. A bulk of the pages are taken up by pictures, ingredients lists, and procedures. It's a textbook of deliciousness, not a novel.That concept gets thrown out the window with The Food Lab, a 900 page, concussion inducing book which tackles the science of food and offers best practices for table favorites. Alt's book tells a story rather than throws a ton of recipes at you, and like On Food and Cooking reflects on how food has evolved and how it brings people together, rather than giving us our 85th recipe for the best chocolate chips cookies (spoiler: there are none better than these). My only critique is not a fair one: there are basically 3 whole chapters about meat - ground meat, roasts, and "fast-cooking foods" (that last chapter is misleading, it's really all about steaks and chicken and the ilk). And... uhhhh... I don't eat meat. So 3 whole chapters of this book are totally useless to me. Please hold your commentary. I am well aware that my non-meat-eating was the personal choice of 13-year-old me and most people eat meat and cookbooks are going to have meat and I just have to deal. That being said, I wish we had gone more in depth with things I love... like bread... and kicked the meat to the curb (there is NOTHING about bread baking in here. Nothing! What is more science-y than bread baking??? Harumph). ...more

title: Helter Skelter: The True Story of the Manson Murders
author: Bugliosi, Vincent
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Horrifying and fascinating all at once, Helter Skelter is exactly what you expect it to be. Written by case prosecutor Vincent Bugliosi, the book begiHorrifying and fascinating all at once, Helter Skelter is exactly what you expect it to be. Written by case prosecutor Vincent Bugliosi, the book begins the morning of the murders, working chronologically until the trial. Once there, the book becomes a tilt-a-whirl of past, present, and future, mixing Bugliosi's personal experiences with historical facts, creating a wholly immersive and subversive story.Growing up in the home of a corrections officer, I am no stranger to the cruel and unusual. The name Charles Manson was known to me at a (perhaps too early) age, and I read The Executioner's Song along with The Babysitter's Club. That being said, the blunt way in which Bugliosi writes shocks the narrative into a haunting tale of a sick-yet-articulate man, driven by madness and hate to twist young and broken minds to murder. It is unique and effective, allowing the actions and words of Manson himself to tell the story, rather than polluting the story with narrative flair or constructs. Sure, Bugliosi has ideas that are not based in stark fact, but the time he spent on this case, obsessing over such a mind as Manson's, gives him the right to some conclusion jumping.For anyone who is interested in law, order, madness, or murder, Helter Skelter is without doubt the book to read next. I tore through the book, audibly gasping more times than I care to recount.Bugliosi last updated this book over a decade ago, so those who want a complete story should do some Googling at the end. Good luck, and lock your windows, folks. ...more

review: Emma Cline is a 20-something who, I guess, became fascinated with the Manson murders and the women he was able to manipulate. Driven by curiosity or aEmma Cline is a 20-something who, I guess, became fascinated with the Manson murders and the women he was able to manipulate. Driven by curiosity or a deep understanding of how a girl can be so completely controlled by a man, Cline writes The Girls: a clunky, boring narrative following the stumblings of a teenager as she dances on the fringes of the Manson clan.There is a difference between lyrical writing and smashing random adjectives and nouns together. Cline doesn't write poetry, she just writes weird.There is a difference between dynamic characters and characters who are one dimensional. You forgot a couple of dimensions, Cline.There is a difference between suspense and the 4th grade tellings of "this happened, then this happened, then the orange tangerine couch of the sun split open with dew on my face." Seriously, her metaphors are that bad/meandering and her story telling that plodding.I grew up with a law enforcement father who taught me about serial killers and self defense at a young age. I have read nonfiction and fiction about the most famous and grisly cases in America. If you are hoping The Girls will split open any murky underbelly you will be immensely disappointed. review: Not the satire we deserve, but what we need right now.Paul Beatty is hilarious, poignant, and angry. In The Sellout he paints the fictitious town of DNot the satire we deserve, but what we need right now.Paul Beatty is hilarious, poignant, and angry. In The Sellout he paints the fictitious town of Dickens in a light so glaringly ridiculous, that we pass the point of absurd and begin to wonder if perhaps Beatty isn't too far off from reality. His mockery of a post-race America comes at a time when tensions and fears are high, providing a simultaneous belly laugh and slap in the face. Family, society, and law are all picked apart and analyzed under a psychedelic microscope leaving us to take pause and wonder how we have allowed things to be the way that they are. The Sellout should be required reading. ...more

title: Kiss Me Like a Stranger: My Search for Love and Art
author: Wilder, Gene
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I grew up watching Gene Wilder. Young Frankenstein is a movie I remember watching in my father's lap and I know the words to Springtime for Hitler by I grew up watching Gene Wilder. Young Frankenstein is a movie I remember watching in my father's lap and I know the words to Springtime for Hitler by heart. When Gene Wilder passed away I felt a tug to know more about the man at the forefront of so many films which made me smile over the years.Mr. Wilder grew up, it seems, in a loving family. He had a rocky beginning at a military school, which may have severely marred his ability to make lasting, loving relationships. He struggled with his sexuality and worth. It's refreshing that he didn't hold back with his struggles: he is open about infidelity and longing, about illness, be it physical or mental. A lot of memoirs tidy up around the closets; Mr. Wilder flings them open, scars and all. I applaud him.While letting his freak flag fly, however, he also shows us how aristocratic he was. Mr. Wilder spends too much of the novel talking about the famous people who appreciated him, the expensive wine he drank, etc. It felt weird and uncomfortable for him to keep slipping in little nods to how rich and renowned he was. We know, dude, it is really best left unsaid.The bottom line of Kiss Me Like a Stranger is that it is an honest account from the horse's mouth... it just may not hold what you wanted to know. ...more

title: All the Light We Cannot See
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Alright, friends, stop frothing at the mouth about All the Light We Cannot See. Or, at the very least, explain to me what in the hell makes this book Alright, friends, stop frothing at the mouth about All the Light We Cannot See. Or, at the very least, explain to me what in the hell makes this book so special to all y'all.Like 9,000,000 other books floating around in the literary universe, Doerr tackles WWII. His spin is to have a 3 pronged story told in a nonlinear fashion. We follow Marie-Laure, a young, Parisian blind girl living with her single father; Werner, an orphaned German who is drafted into the Hitler Youth Academy; and the comically evil Major Von Rumpel, who searches for a famed jewel. The book is... fine? A blind girl is an interesting narrator, I suppose, but Doerr relies so heavily on the story 2,000 Leagues Under the Sea that her story begins to fray at the seams under the weight of laboriously long quotes from 2,000 Leagues. Werner is... okay? I mean, we've got way, way better stories out there detailing the horrors of Hitler Youth Academy (I can even tap my own family tree to get some of these stories). Bottling it up in an orphan background makes it more... original? I guess? But Werner doesn't really mature/change/do anything despite the reader following him from a small child up until he was 18-19. As for Von Rumpel, well, he's sort of ridiculous with how cloak-and-dagger evil Doerr writes him. And his ending is kind of pathetic.I guess I just don't get it. The writing is fine. The story is fine. But everyone seems to have worked themselves up into a lather about a book that seems to fall completely flat. (view spoiler)[My last complaint is Doerr ripping away all magic/supernatural aspects of the book with the death of Werner. He could have at least survived until he lost/passed on the stone. But for him to just get BLOWN UP while holding it is Doerr saying "oh, yea, and by the way the stone means nothing KTHANXBYEEEE." Oy. Vey.  (hide spoiler)]...more

review: I read this on the beach. THE BEACH! This is not a beach read.So, thanks for that, Kathy. Paul Kalanithi has cancer. The bad kind. He's in his 30s andI read this on the beach. THE BEACH! This is not a beach read.So, thanks for that, Kathy. Paul Kalanithi has cancer. The bad kind. He's in his 30s and has some pretty long-term plans for his life. Suddenly, the life he worked so meticulously to piece together bursts into flames around him. That's a top fear for most of us in this stage of life: you're just getting your shit together and things are starting to get comfy... what if something comes along and flips the table on it all? We worked so damned hard, you know? Thinking about your mortality when it feels like life is really starting to bloom was unfathomable... until I read this book. Kalanithi's memoir is interesting because it's a neuosurgeon talking about his own cancer as he wastes away. It's sad and real and bitter and hopeful all at once, with a grim understanding of the odds.That being said, I walked away from the book feeling pretty "meh" about the whole thing. I think a lot of it had to do with the religious rant he goes on closer to the end of the book. I read this to read about his coming to terms with how life ends for all of us; not listen to him revel in his god. No thanks.(view spoiler)[He also writes a letter to his daughter. That may seem sweet, but he and his wife were basically going to get divorced before he got diagnosed. Then, when they know he's going to die pretty damn soon, they decide to have a baby even though he won't be there to watch it grow up. I had a hard time reconciling all of that, though I guess we can appreciate the honesty? (hide spoiler)]...more

title: The Warmth of Other Suns: The Epic Story of America's Great Migration
author: Wilkerson, Isabel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Isabel Wilkerson is a perfectionist. If she is going to tell you about the "Great Migration," she will leave no stone unturned and no story un-fact-chIsabel Wilkerson is a perfectionist. If she is going to tell you about the "Great Migration," she will leave no stone unturned and no story un-fact-checked. Contemporary journalists take note: this is how you write a story.Wilkerson's undertaking is mammoth: she is discussing an almost century-long mass movement of people escaping life in the South for a "Promised Land" in the North. She tackles sociology, psychology, economics... I mean, you're basically tapping into all the core classes you took in college. She quotes from newspapers and pamphlets and provides direct quotes wherever she can. The literal blood, sweat, and tears that created this book are obvious and written masterfully.Wilkerson tackles The Warmth of Other Suns by detailing the lives of three migrants: Ida Mae, the cotton picker who moves to Chicago; George Starling, the fruit picker who moves to NY; and Robert Foster, the doctor who moves to Los Angeles. She begins with their youths, and follows them until their deaths. The amount of time and care she puts into telling these life stories is obvious; toward the close she details going along on doctor visits and stopping by just for company's sake. Of course you bond with people you've interviewed for weeks/months/years, but Wilkerson is special: you can tell these people have become family. Gaps are filled with multi-year synopses, detailing the temperature of the country and peppering in stories from others she interviewed over the years.I was born in the 80s into the squeaky white suburbs of NY; I am woefully uneducated about integration and inner-city struggles. I cannot pretend to understand the injustices millions of Americans suffered but, thanks to Wilkerson, I can hope to begin. ...more

review: Sexism, racism, and a contrived plot line? I've read books written in 1891 which were more progressive than Grisham's The Firm.What do/did the masses Sexism, racism, and a contrived plot line? I've read books written in 1891 which were more progressive than Grisham's The Firm.What do/did the masses enjoy about this book? The flat characters with vague backgrounds and motivations? The tired cliches of scrappy youth, flummoxed FBI dude, and the bad guy who looks so evil he's basically got a Voldemort face? You don't need to read this book, I've written it for you:Boy marries girl while he's in law school. Law school is expensive so they're poor. But boy is, like, so smart, so he gets courted by all these firms and picks the one which pays the most because his girl wants a house and babies, like, yesterday. The firm he chooses has a hidden dark side. Boy must choose between $$ and doing The Right Thing.Ugh. And I'm just going to circle back to the vague motivations I mentioned before, because it just irks me so much. Grisham bends ZERO braincells trying to explain to his readers why the characters do what they do. Why is Ray in jail and should we care? What was Mitch's childhood and how has it shaped him (because why bring in a brother in jail and a deadbeat mother if you're just going to leave them there???)? What's the deal with Abby's family? Why does nobody care about the family dog? How did the other people get roped into the firm and what makes them stay? Grisham forgoes plot to deliver NONSTOP ACTION... except the action is pretty stale and the ending is a gaping hole of open-endedness and this is making me angry so I'm just going to stop right now.When I have the stomach to open the book back up to the dog-eared pages, I'll have to type up all the blatant racism and sexism... but I just can't right now. ...more

title: And the Band Played On: Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic
author: Shilts, Randy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Look around you. Do you notice the anger? The hopelessness? The inaction?The US government has been showing its hand this year. The public is watchingLook around you. Do you notice the anger? The hopelessness? The inaction?The US government has been showing its hand this year. The public is watching in horror as residents of Flint, Michigan are poisoned, as our puppet democracy shows its strings during the 2016 presidential race, as the transgender population has their rights stripped away, as women lose control of what happens to their bodies......it's been tough to feel proud of where I live recently.I wanted to read And The Band Played On... to learn more about the AIDS epidemic. Everything I know I've learned from Rent or Angels in America or just uncovered in passing when looking into something else. As a member of this society and this world, it seemed about time I learned about a disease which devastated tens of thousands of people during the 1980s.I expected it to be sad. I did not expect to walk away with so much anger in my heart. If we take Shilts word as gospel (which, spoiler alert, I do), there is a lot to be ashamed of. So many factions of the US government stuck their heads in the proverbial sand because no one wanted to come out as working on the "gay disease." American scientists stole and hid discoveries, the American media couldn't be bothered until AIDS struck the "normal" community (ie. heteros and celebrities), and the American people went about their daily lives as though there was no deadly disease ravaging their country. It may sound extreme, but Shilts is flexing his journalistic muscles on this one and backs everything up. I even asked my mother, who was in her 20s when this book takes place and basically lived on top of Manhattan (aka the epicenter for the disease), what she remembered of the AIDS epidemic."Nothing," she said. "It didn't affect me at all."I can't read a single news article without seeing Zika on the side bar, and AIDS is far more deadly. It is both shocking and disgusting to me that it took until ~10 years after the first known death for the President of the United States to even acknowledge the disease existed. I cannot imagine the disillusionment and abandonment that must have vibrated through these communities. They were utterly let down by their country which should have protected them.This book can get a little dry in the more science-y portions, and it is incredibly dense (seriously, it took me a month and a half to finish because there was just so much information to take in, and all of it was depressing). That being said, I implore you to read it. More people should know the truth. Maybe if they did, they would be quicker to stand up to the contemporary infractions on human rights. ...more

title: The Human Comedy
author: Saroyan, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Saroyan's book takes place in the fictional town of Ithaca, CA, in the middle of WWII. It's a contemporary book: Saroyan published it in 1942, while WSaroyan's book takes place in the fictional town of Ithaca, CA, in the middle of WWII. It's a contemporary book: Saroyan published it in 1942, while WWII was raging. But Saroyan isn't talking about Nazis or getting us down in the trenches with the soldiers like most WWII books. He doesn't have a political or social agenda in mind. His goals are simple: to paint what living was like for those who were expected to keep up business as usual. The Human Comedy centers around the Macauley family. Father passed away, mother keeps the home, big sister goes to school, big brother is fighting the war, middle brother picks up a job at the telegraph office to help keep food on the table, youngest brother (who is only 4 years old) watches the world and "tries to understand." It's an interesting read for the simplicity of it. The descriptions of the town and the people provide an interesting snapshot into what life was like for those living in small towns and having the deaths of neighbors and sons trickle in. But that's all this book is: a snapshot. Characters are not fleshed out (save, perhaps, Homer Macauley), and nothing much actually happens in the book. They just get by. But maybe that's enough. ...more

title: Alexander Hamilton
author: Chernow, Ron
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Chernow wasn't messing around when he wrote Alexander Hamilton; I'm pretty sure he read everything the man ever wrote, and everything ever written aboChernow wasn't messing around when he wrote Alexander Hamilton; I'm pretty sure he read everything the man ever wrote, and everything ever written about him. We all know the bare bones: There was a Revolution, a new country was born, then a bunch of men squabbled over how best to run it.What I didn't know was what delicate little flowers all of our founding fathers were. I mean, they flocked to newspapers to write scathing, semi-anonymous essays about one another, and stomped and pouted when they didn't get their way. Looking around, I guess that hasn't changed, but the important thing to note is that the faces of American politics haven't really degenerated either. Politics, it seems, attracts men with easily bruised egos. Alexander Hamilton begins at Hamilton's birth, and spans past his death, to see the end of both Aaron Burr's and Eliza Hamilton's lives. It tracks political tensions, international calamities, and the butt hurt barbs our founding fathers got all bent out of shape about. I kind of want a book consisting solely of the insults they threw at one another. I could spend all day quoting denouncements from this book, but I'll leave you with a personal favorite of Aaron Burr commenting on James Monroe:The man himself is one of the most improper and incompetent that could have been selected — naturally dull and stupid — extremely illiterate — indecisive to a degree that would be incredible to one who did not know him — pusillanimous and of course hypocritical — has no opinion on any subject and will be always under the government of the worst men — pretends, as I am told, to some knowledge of military matters, but never commanded a platoon nor was ever fit to command one — “He served in the revolutionary War” — that is, he acted a short time as aide de camp to Lord Stirling who was regularly drunk from morning to morning — Monroe’s whole duty was to fill his lordship’s tankard and hear with indications of admiration his lordship’s long stories about himself — Such is Monroe’s military experience . . . As a lawyer, Monroe was far below mediocrity — He never rose to the honor of trying a cause of the value of an hundred pounds....more

title: Freedom
author: Franzen, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Franzen's women are rough to read. In The Corrections you had the juxtaposition of Enid and Denise. One was a typical maternal housewife who kept hersFranzen's women are rough to read. In The Corrections you had the juxtaposition of Enid and Denise. One was a typical maternal housewife who kept herself a secret from her family so as not to upset them with the reality that she is actually a person. The other did the same, though less successfully and more promiscuously. At the time, I appreciated his honesty about the roles we attempt to force women into, and how they writhe, rebel, and destroy underneath those constructs.Now that I've read Freedom, I am less convinced. I think Franzen has some lady issues, and is working them out through fiction.Let's break down the characters, shall we?{IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT I HATE PRETTY MUCH EVERY CHARACTER IN THIS BOOK - READ WITH CAUTION}Patty is the worst. She reminds me of the Nirvana lyrics "come, as you are, as you were, as I want you to be." As in, every person in her life she claims to love as they are, then she claims that they have changed and were better before, then she accepts that she has idealized them, but still expects them to fit into the nice little molds she has created. She is manipulative and callous and I had absolutely 0 sympathy for her character.Connie defines herself by her relationship with Joey. She is depressive and utterly dependent on the man in her life. She says that multiple times, like the nanny in The Omen: "IT'S ALL FOR YOU!!". Ugh.Lalitha is purely a sexual object, and Carol and Jenna just aren't worth it to delve into. That leads me to Jessica, who actually seemed to have some layers to her. Unfortunately, despite devoting 461 pages to Patty, Walter, and Joey, Jessica does not get a single page for her own internal drama. I kept waiting for Franzen to give us a Jessica section. It never happened. Why introduce a family of four if one of them will be utterly left out of the script? It still makes no sense to me.What does it say when the only rounded out character gets absolutely no screen time? I can't tell you, but it makes me feel icky. Meanwhile, our leading men...Richard is a walking cliche: burned out artist with a string of women behind him who cannot create any real or lasting bonds in his life. The only relationship he can have is with Walter, and it's a tempestuous one at best.Walter is just sad. He's the beaten down guy you see in a relationship and you think to yourself "I bet he could blossom if he just shook off the dead weight of his significant other and gave himself time to grow in his own skin." I was equal parts frustrated, depressed, and flummoxed with his character. He is defined by Patty, even in the long passages where she is nowhere to be found. I'm hesitant to tackle Joey, because I just don't get him. What is he so angry about? What is he rebelling against? If we had his sister Jessica's side of things, it might make his childhood more sympathetic. However, we don't get any real glimpses into what it was like to grow up in the Berglund household, so we're just left to sigh and shrug. (view spoiler)[Also, the neat bow of his life in the end just felt rushed, and Franzen did not provide enough evidence to make his happy ending believable. (hide spoiler)]Franzen is highly observant when it comes to the Schadenfreude of the American upper-middle-class. It worked exceptionally well in The Corrections, but fell utterly flat for me in this novel. Who are these people? Why are they the way that they are? How do they reconcile or break under the realities of their malcontent by the close of the novel? These are questions I'm still asking, and it looks like I'll never get answers. ...more

title: The Nightingale
author: Hannah, Kristin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Every other novel out there is written about World War II. We keep dipping back into that same well, convinced it will never run dry. This is because Every other novel out there is written about World War II. We keep dipping back into that same well, convinced it will never run dry. This is because the events which happened all over the world at that time - the cruelty and struggle for survival and loss and pain - were unique for every person who lived through (or perished from) it. It is easy to be skeptical of WWII Lit. at this point (yes, WWII Lit. is a real thing and a college course you can take at universities with impressive Arts departments), and I'll admit I often am. At this point, new literature coming out on the subject is often so far removed from that subject that it loses heart. Night and The Diary of Anne Frank are all we truly need, for they are real, honest accounts. But we cannot rely on Frank and Wiesel for the whole picture; the war they suffered was theirs alone.Enter a veritable flood of historical fiction.Some of it is excellent and some of it is just terrible. Luckily for us, Kristin Hannah's The Nightingale is original and earnest enough to make it a truly gripping story.Hannah follows the story of fictional sisters Vianne and Isabelle and their struggle to survive the years in German occupied France (It should be noted that Isabelle is inspired by Belgium woman Andrée de Jongh, who risked her life to save felled airmen in France. She's pretty amazing. You should check her out). Isabelle plays the part of active resistance, while Vianne tries to keep her head down and survive. Both women are inspirational and infuriating, as only complete people can be. They struggle with their morality and what is responsible vs. what is right.Hannah does not shy away from the brute realities of what it was to live through WWII, and I thank her for that. Too much historical fiction glosses over the horrors to focus instead on love in spite of it all. Don't get me wrong, Hannah flexes her pen at this as well, but it plays second fiddle to the BIG PLOT POINTS: survival and loss.Is this book groundbreaking? Not in the least. But her characters are so heartbreakingly real and flawed and scared that it really doesn't matter. ...more

title: Batman: The Dark Knight Returns
author: Miller, Frank
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Full disclosure: I'm not the biggest Batman fan.Sure, I enjoyed Christopher Nolan's take on the super hero very much. However, Bruce Wayne has always Full disclosure: I'm not the biggest Batman fan.Sure, I enjoyed Christopher Nolan's take on the super hero very much. However, Bruce Wayne has always just felt like the whiny rich kid with a bunch of gadgets and some rage he needs to work out. He didn't appeal to me the way, say, Peter Parker did, because he really didn't have much to overcome, save a single tragedy, which is not unique - everybody eventually loses somebody. Even still, I felt the need to try The Dark Knight Returns because the vast majority of people I know, even those who are not comic book readers, seemed to really love it. Here's what I liked:Bruce Wayne embraces his whiny rich kid in this one. He's fighting a battle he's ageing out of, and it's pissing him off. I appreciated all that frustration so nakedly presented. The focus on the news stations as they reported on the different crimes and goings-ons in Gotham. It felt very real. If superheroes were running around beating up folks in reality, we would absolutely have talk shows going back and forth between pro- and anti-Batman representatives. They would be talking less about the issues, and more about their personal/gut reactions to Batman the person. Miller knows how toxic the media is, and doesn't shy away from shoving it back in their faces.But that's really all I liked. The characters, the villains, the driving plot... it all fell flat for me. It felt tired. Perhaps Miller actually aimed for it to feel tired; again Batman is older in this story, so perhaps the fatigue we feel reading it is the fatigue Batman feels fighting his battles? But that is a gigantic stretch, so let's hazard a guess that this was not Miller's intent. I am definitely the minority here, so I would think anyone who enjoys Batman and/or graphic novels would probably like this one. As for me, I'll stick with Locke and Key....more

review: Simply drawn but complicatedly written, Berlin, Vol 1 is a groundwork graphic novel. Jason Lutes tackles 1920s Berlin and the unrest there which arguaSimply drawn but complicatedly written, Berlin, Vol 1 is a groundwork graphic novel. Jason Lutes tackles 1920s Berlin and the unrest there which arguably allowed Adolf Hitler to come into power and do everything he did. Lutes gives us both sides, so the reader can begin to try to understand how every day people got swept up in such evil hate and malice. There are times where the narrative gets very very dense - but I suppose what better medium than a graphic novel to give a history lesson in 1920s German politics.My only gripe (and this may not be fair) is that the drawings are so simple, and the timeframes not explicitly noted, that I sometimes got confused about which character I was following at which time, and what exactly they were standing for, and how I should feel about what is happening to them. I had to flip back on more than one occasion to reorient myself to a different character or space. Oh, and bravo to Lutes for bringing a queer lens to this story. We damn well need more of those. ...more
