review: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty film edition is one of my all-time favorite movies. I'm not the biggest fan of Mr. Ben Stiller, but if he acted in draThe Secret Life of Walter Mitty film edition is one of my all-time favorite movies. I'm not the biggest fan of Mr. Ben Stiller, but if he acted in dramas more I might just change my mind because I'll be damned if I don't watch that movie once a month......but I digress.I figured it was due time I read the short story which inspired the movie which inspires me. The Secret Life of Walter Mitty story edition bears very little resemblance to the movie, but that's okay - great, even, because it provides a different take on a person trapped in the mundane, and how they use their imagination to free themselves.The Walter Mitty of Thurber's creation is a spacey, married man. We watch him run errands on a typical dreary day, wishing he was anywhere but here. The story itself is incredibly brief, but I think that's important to the power of the story: this is Mitty's day-to-day; you only need a snapshot. At once bittersweet and moving, the juxtaposition of Mitty's imagination and reality echoes within any person with wanderlust. The important take-away, at least for me, is to make sure to balance your reality with fantasy. The story-version Mitty is deliciously vague, while the film version unapologetically breaks the cycle to seek adventure. There is merit, and beauty, in both. ...more

author: Mnookin, Seth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Seth Mnookin is pissed off, and he's ready to tell you why.The Panic Virus is a book which begins at the dawn of modern medicine and vaccines, but speSeth Mnookin is pissed off, and he's ready to tell you why.The Panic Virus is a book which begins at the dawn of modern medicine and vaccines, but spends the bulk of its pages discussing autism and the groups of people who state that vaccines cause autism. It's a rough and angry read, but I implore pretty much everyone to read it.Reader be warned: this is not a "present both sides of the story" type of book. Mnookin details scientific evidence which support that that vaccines do not cause autism, then says "and here are the crazies who say vaccines DO cause autism, with no proof other than Mommy Instinct or Knowing with the Heart." He paints the doctors who support the anti-vaccine movement in their worst lights, and bashes both herd mentality and the media for jumping on the bandwagon (to be fair, by the sounds of it they all deserve a good bashing. I've wanted to slap Oprah Winfrey for her role in the creation of Dr. Oz for years - but reading how she elevated Jenny McCarthy has upgraded that slap to a sucker punch).Though this is a science book first, Mnookin writes with journalistic flair. This is seen most clearly in his Epilogue, which implores current and future readers to accept scientific evidence for what it is, rather than relying on gut instincts, fads, and crazes. And we could all do a little more of that, couldn't we?...more

review: UPDATE - re-read October 2020Reading my 2015 , I know exactly why I was so pissed off. Because Joe Hill made this shit so final. I didn't want tUPDATE - re-read October 2020Reading my 2015 , I know exactly why I was so pissed off. Because Joe Hill made this shit so final. I didn't want to let go, I didn't want the story to be over.Also, I apparently wasn't in the mood for morality 5 years ago, because what I called "preachy" in 2015 had me in tears in 2020. Call it a side-effect of where we are in the world right now, call it maturation, or just call it the reality of reading (that is: the same story will strike you quite differently depending on your mood, etc.). Jacked this up to 5 stars from 4. Locke & Key is the best graphic novel series, hands down. We can fight, it's okay.********************************************************************I just...**sigh**I really enjoyed the majority of Locke & Key. It was a totally original story telling a scary, intricate, sometimes horrifying, completely compulsive read. And the characters! Rufus was my main man (seriously, what a great character!), Kinsey was beautifully complicated, Bode was quintessential curious youth, and Dodge? Dodge was one of the most evil characters I've ever read... and I've read some messed up stuff.This last installment focuses around a few choice days, as Dodge makes his last-ditch effort to open the Black Door.My main issue with Locke & Key: Alpha and Omega is how dang preachy it got at the end. Everyone is making these sweeping speeches about mortality and spirituality. It was clunky and out of place with the rest of the narrative. I would have much preferred an abrupt ending, without all the hindsight-y monologues. (view spoiler)[Also, why did they have to kill 40+ students? It just felt heavy-handed and unnecessary. And insane. That's a freakin' massacre, and Hill hardly focuses on it because he's focusing on the "death" of Bode.And, hey, did they really have to burn down the dang house?? Were they worried about spin-offs or something?? It's always better when the creepiness prevails. To lose all those doors and magic was really tragic. I was more sad about the death of the house than any of the human deaths. I guess the whole thing with the animal door at the end was maybe a wink to the reader that the magic is still there... but I'm not holding my breath - that shit looks like it's gonna crumble. It was hugely disappointing to watch the house we've grown to love smolder. (hide spoiler)]Ah well, time to listen to the audio drama to keep the thrills coming!...more

title: The Brontës: Wild Genius on the Moors: The Story of Three Sisters
author: Barker, Juliet
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Whew!Juliet Barker's The Brontes is exhaustive and, as such, could be exhausting for those not thoroughly interested in the history of the Bronte famiWhew!Juliet Barker's The Brontes is exhaustive and, as such, could be exhausting for those not thoroughly interested in the history of the Bronte family. I mean, she starts out when patriarch Patrick is a child for cripessakes - clearly this will not be a short-winded affair. I picked this book up due to my interest in the youngest Bronte, Anne. I find her to be so damn intriguing with her feminism and critical eye on religion and marriage - what sort of woman would stand up in the face of society and spit on it so resolutely?? According to Barker, an exceedingly lonely one.Barker is not romanticizing the Brontes in her book. She berates Elizabeth Gaskell for her slanted "biography" of Charlotte, and provides the most honest, no matter how brutal, account of each Bronte. Charlotte is angry and bull-headed and selfish and arguably a bully to her younger siblings. Branwell is a love-sick puppy who destroys himself. Emily is the day dreaming, isolating genius. Anne is the tight-lipped loner with a critical eye. They're not sounding too great, are they?The Brontes lived a rural life, with each other as their only company. Charlotte and Branwell made friends outside the family; Emily and Anne depended on one another. It's a tragic tale of four incredibly intelligent people dying before their time and fighting the peril of low-middle-class in the 1800s. Barker does an expert job of allowing the Brontes to speak in their own words, using hundreds of pages of their letters and diary entries. She finishes by fleshing out the world around them, allowing for fully-immersive story telling. If you're interested in mid-nineteenth century England and/or the Brontes, you really shouldn't go anywhere else but to Barker. Though this book made me think Charlotte was kind of a terrible person, I found myself thoroughly engrossed in her story, even after her other siblings had all died. It wasn't until Charlotte's own death that I began to skim the book a little (the last 100 pages or so). The Brontes isn't for everyone, or really for most people. It is a hefty book, and the attention to detail is so obsessive, you have to wonder if Barker has a spot of OCD. That being said, for someone like me, who got her Masters in English, and has always found the Brontes fascinating? I wouldn't have minded if it had been even longer. ...more

title: Buffy the Vampire Slayer: Last Gleaming
author: Whedon, Joss
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I just......I don't get it.Maybe it was easier to suspend my disbelief in a TV show? Or maybe the tone/pace of Buffy doesn't translate well into comicI just......I don't get it.Maybe it was easier to suspend my disbelief in a TV show? Or maybe the tone/pace of Buffy doesn't translate well into comics? But I found the whole 8th season to just be... well......weird. And not necessarily in a good way.It's been mentioned before, but a lot of times the dialogue feels like it's pulling from the show. The 8th season is sort of an homage to the previous 7. Due to this, the overarching plot was uneven and got bogged down by the writers constantly trying to tie in the past. It's like they were jumping up and down yelling "Hey! Hey guys! This is the BTVS you know and love! We promise! Look - they say 'five-by-five' and talk in all sorts of other Buffy-isms! Hey! Look over here!"Seriously. The reader gets beaten over the head with this crap, and it makes the actual story they're trying to tell clunky. As a whole, the season was entertaining, but I'll be brutally honest: even if it had been horrendous, I couldn't bring myself to hate it. BTVS saw me through some stuff when I was younger, and I haven't watched the whole series through 3+ times for no reason. But even I can only take so much abuse!Most of the terrible stuff would spoil the plot of the season (see hidden section for more), but one thing that won't is the relationship between Willow and Buffy. The two of them are best friends. I'll-love-you-even-when-you're-evil sort of friends. We're-more-like-sisters sort of friends. So the fact that the writers keep throwing in these weird homoerotic vibes between Buffy and Willow is offensive and biggoted. What, so now that Willow has been a lesbian for a couple of years Buffy is going to think about doing her? Just because Buffy is basically a super hero and Willow is around her all the time she wouldn't say no to rolling around in bed with Buffy? THEY'RE BEST FRIENDS. The writers clearly do not understand women, or just want to treat the comics like one giant Fan Fiction fantasy of "what if everyone did each other all the time." Yes, that's how season 8 came off to me, and it made me mad.(view spoiler)[Also, how the hell does this whole Twilight thing make sense? Whistler convinced Angel to become Twilight by simply saying "uhhh, save the former cheerleader or save the world. heheh. I made a pop culture reference," and suddenly Angel is putting on a mask and threatening to kill people? And then he and Buffy sex a new universe into existence? How does that make sense? And the seed gives power/sucks out power to certain people for what reason I cannot comprehend (we won't even go into that heavy-handed metaphor because yuck). And then the sexed new universe appears to Angel as a lion and convinces him to fight Buffy? What???? IT MAKES ABSOLUTELY NO SENSE GAAHH.And then, the biggest kick in the balls is Giles. Not only do they KILL Giles - but Angel snaps his neck JUST LIKE HE DID TO JENNY?!?!?!?! I'm sorry, that's f#*&ing bull$#!%. How could Giles get his neck snapped by Angel after everything he's endured with that very Big Bad? I get it, it's the homage thing that the season kept shoving down our throats, but it's a cheap thrill which is inconsistent with the overarching story line. (hide spoiler)]I reserved judgement of the whole season until this installment, hoping that the finale would iron out all the awkwardness of the previous issues; but Last Gleaming was a big, stinking disappointment. Maybe season 9 will be better, but I've already read some homoerotic Buffy/Willow s&%! in that one, and I'm on page, like, 10. ...more

title: Modern Romance
author: Ansari, Aziz
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Frustrated with your dating search? Interested to hear how dating has evolved over the past ~75 years? Do you just want to listen to the slightly nasaFrustrated with your dating search? Interested to hear how dating has evolved over the past ~75 years? Do you just want to listen to the slightly nasal voice of Aziz Ansari during your morning commutes? Meet Modern Romance; the audiobook edition. I've watched his Netflix show and listened to pretty much all of his stand-up. There are quite a lot of parallels, and some blatant re-tellings between these three mediums. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but if you're already binging Ansari, give yourself a few weeks to refresh before diving into Modern Romance.Ansari breaks up the book into different categories: dating then, dating now, dating in other parts of the world, pros/cons of the dating evolution, his own dating experience, and a tidy conclusion which brings all of the points together, reminiscent of a high school essay (in an endearing way, I swear!). It's interesting and simple - popcorn for the brain where you actually learn something at the end!I really enjoyed when he spoke to how dating in places like Tokyo and Qatar differs so vastly from American standards/traditions. The sociological aspects of the book are well researched and will be great to use as party anecdotes. The rest of the book is just fun and funny... and, though not nearly as thought provoking, is an interesting glimpse into the internet dating world which I never experienced during my single life....more

title: Finders Keepers        (Bill Hodges Trilogy, #2)
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This trilogy should NOT be read back-to-back. Finders Keepers has a lot of echoes from Mr. Mercedes, and it can get a little tedious. The Plot: An autThis trilogy should NOT be read back-to-back. Finders Keepers has a lot of echoes from Mr. Mercedes, and it can get a little tedious. The Plot: An author murdered, items stolen from his house, buried and forgotten. Years later, a young kid named Peter bumps into the items, and decides to use them in a way that at first saves, then tries to destroy him.Peter and his family aren't very believable characters. Peter is wildly mature and calculating, though there does not seem to be a good reason for this. In contrast, his parents are absolute morons. How did they get such a smart kid? Is he adopted? Is he the milkman's son? I seriously thought these things as I read.The character of Jerome makes a return, and King's attempt at ebonics, annoying in the first book, is positively infuriating in this installation. Jerome goes to a &$(#% Ivy League University, for Christsakes. Why would he think it'd be funny to have this incredibly racist alter ego?? Also, Jerome's relationship with Hodges is still weird, and his relationship with Holly borders on inappropriate to me. King may have given up on developing characters, favoring fast-action-plot instead. Because, yes, characters aside, Finders Keepers is a very easy and very tense read. It's very strange, though, to call this part of a trilogy. Yes, Hodges and his team are in this book, but really only toward the end. The book is more geared toward Peter and his story (as it should be); but Peter's story has only the thinnest of connections to Mr. Mercedes. The story was interesting, but followed the same exact formula as its predecessor, which was disappointing. Also, if King is still looking to hearken back to noir, he stumbled on this one. Finders Keepers is pure thriller. Basically, I wasn't planning on reading the third and final Hodges book......until the last page. I'm not going to spoil it, but if you want a continuation of the first book, just go into the bookstore, read the last page of Finders Keepers, put it back on the shelf, and walk away. ...more

review: Pratchett is silly and funny and takes on literature in a totally unique and weird way. He deserves a lot of credit for creating an entire universe fuPratchett is silly and funny and takes on literature in a totally unique and weird way. He deserves a lot of credit for creating an entire universe full of dynamic characters......but I just don't very much care.Pratchett's style is all his own, and is unlike anything else, but that does not mean what he writes is everyone's cup of tea. For me, personally, Mort sounded like a very interesting idea for a story, but just dragged and my brain dragged trying to read it. It's like going on a walk with your dog and letting your dog lead. When you're in the mood, your dog will take you to all sorts of interesting places you appreciate and would never have even thought to visit. But sometimes you just want to finish the damn walk and not pointlessly meander.I swear I do not think Mr. Pratchett is a dog, really, truly....more

title: Mr. Mercedes        (Bill Hodges Trilogy, #1)
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Stephen King + noir? Probably doesn't sound terribly promising to the average ears. But, hey, I took more than one noir class in college, and have beeStephen King + noir? Probably doesn't sound terribly promising to the average ears. But, hey, I took more than one noir class in college, and have been reading Stephen King for almost two decades, so maybe if they run at each other hard enough they'll make something halfway okay?As you may be able to deduce, I didn't have terribly high hopes for this book. Noir, for me, belongs to Chandler and Hammett, and King has built a comfy little horror box he should stay inside.Well, color me embarrassed, because King can write noir wonderfully. He isn't breaking down the walls of the genre, which I suppose may ruffle some feathers. "it's so contrived" they may moan, or "it's been done before". Yeah... so? Any noir lover knows that the beautiful woman isn't what she seems, that the bad guy is really bad, and the good guy, regardless of his drinking and dark thoughts, is always going to be brilliant. I think King's decision to stick to the formula was perfect.So, as you may have already deduced, this story involves a detective and a bad guy. Hodges, recently retired detective, is whiling away watching Judge Judy and stretching the waistbands of his pants. On a day like any other, he goes to the mailbox, and has received a letter from one of the more notorious killers who got away on his watch.Cue 400 pages of action. I'm going to be straight with you: there are holes in this book. Jerome, the 17yr old across the street? Has no business being buddies with Hodges. Also, King has no business using the word "shorty." Seriously, King, knock it off. The killer, true to trope, is a walking cliche in a million ways I'm not going to get into because yawn and also because you can probably guess 250,000 of them. But man, I don't really care, because the pace of the book is great and Hodges is a perfect rendition of the hard-boiled detective and the character of Holly is just so damn intriguing. I'm not sure if the other books in this trilogy will stand up to Mr. Mercedes, but I sure as hell am going to hang around to find out. ...more

title: Fun Home: A Family Tragicomic
author: Bechdel, Alison
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Dear Alison Bechdel,What you did with Fun Home was brave. 2007 was still a rocky time for coming out as a lesbian ("The L Word" may have been in full Dear Alison Bechdel,What you did with Fun Home was brave. 2007 was still a rocky time for coming out as a lesbian ("The L Word" may have been in full swing, but that didn't mean people were into it) - so I commend you for standing up and writing this story. It's heartfelt, and you did some great tie-ins with the AIDS epidemic, and the gay culture both when you were a child and when you were realizing yourself in college.Fun Home is important because it came out when queer culture was just being introduced into the mainstream (don't talk to me about "Will & Grace). I am happy it exists, and I am happy you wrote it.But, as you know, just because something provided a stepping stone, or came out at a good moment, does not make it amazing.The broader gesture of your graphic novel aside, this is how Fun Home reads:I am a lesbian. Apparently, my father had affairs with men. Here is a snapshot of an instance in my life where I could have maybe picked up on my father' secret. Now, here is where I was at that time in discovering the truth about myself. My dad probably killed himself.Seriously. Each "chapter" or "section" has this exact formula. And you don't even tell us about the emotional turmoil you must have felt in making that ultimate discovery about yourself! Where is the meat??Your dad died in 1980, and you're still not over it. That's fair. I still have both of my parents, and cannot imagine what it must have been like to lose him so young, when you had just found this new footing with him.That being said, market this graphic novel for what it is: therapy. It's your way of coming to terms with the secret father you never knew, and relating his struggles with you own. The tie-in to queer culture seemed more, well, convenient than important, and I felt a little misled by the way it was marketed.Sincerely,B...more

title: Room
author: Donoghue, Emma*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Eww! Yuck! No, c'mon, sttoopp."That's what my brain did throughout this whole book.You go into the book knowing it's going to ick you out a little. A"Eww! Yuck! No, c'mon, sttoopp."That's what my brain did throughout this whole book.You go into the book knowing it's going to ick you out a little. A woman was abducted and left in a small room to be used/abused. She can never leave. She had a son in this room, and as far as he is concerned, Room is the only existing thing in the universe, and everything he sees on TV (birds, dogs, other people) is pretend. The book, told entirely from this little kid's perspective, opens on his fifth birthday. You're immediately immersed in the odd way his brain is wired, and the weird co-dependent, lets-take-baths-together, relationship he has with his mom. Yeah, yeah, she's been alone in a room for almost a decade so of course her relationship with her kid is going to a little more - ah - intimate than may be comfortable. But that doesn't mean it isn't unpleasant to read. Oh, and the fact that the kid is still breast feeding?! I was waiting for the moment when the mom reveals she breast feeds to lower her fertility so she's less inclined to become pregnant again. But that reveal never comes. So yeah, gross city.And also that kid is going to become a serial killer. Room an interesting look into how a mind can be molded and subsequently shattered, and Donoghue does a great job at capturing how a five year old most likely thinks. However, these things don't make up for the fact that Room is a gigantic creep fest that doesn't really have a point other than to shock and disgust you.(view spoiler)[Also, the ending pissed really pissed me off. I mean, really? she's out of the room for, what, 3 weeks? A month? And they allow her to go into a halfway house to live on her own? She JUST tried to kill herself, people! She was JUST asked if her kid reminds her of her abductor! Any real-life psychiatrist/psychologist would NOT allow a woman who has been in a constant state of trauma for almost a decade to just skip out of the psych ward to live alone. Nope. Nuh uh. Not happening. She's going to kill herself and/or the kid. The ending is just this infuriating false happy ending, which begs the question: did Donoghue mean for it to be falsely happy? Is that her way of saying "they'll never have a good life and always be struggling until they destroy themselves?" Because if that's her message, she did a pretty terrible job. The way the book reads is as follows: you can go through these jaw-droppingly disgusting things, and in a mere month you'll be just fine and ready to start life again. Hooray!" It's not happening, Donoghue, sorry. (hide spoiler)]...more

title: The Martian
author: Weir, Andy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Don't read this book if you're not interested in (partly made up and partly researched) mathematics, physics, and general MacGyver-ing.Don't read thisDon't read this book if you're not interested in (partly made up and partly researched) mathematics, physics, and general MacGyver-ing.Don't read this book if you don't like your reading to make you anxious.But hey, apparently you can still read this book if you're looking for horror. For some reason, I thought The Martian was going to be scary in a supernatural-y way (movies like "Sunshine" and "Alien" have probably ruined me for the space genre). But even when it became disappointingly apparent that Mark Watney would not, in fact, be battling aliens or some evil entity, I still really really liked this novel. Mark Watney is the 17th astronaut to ever go boots-on-the-ground on Mars. He's pretty happy about it, until a freak storm leaves him stranded and alone on the big, red planet.The Martian details Watney's efforts, failures, and witty journaling banter as he races against the clock of dwindling food supplies and ageing tech - ever determined to survive. All-in-all, The Martian is really a first person drama about realizing your full potential and never giving up. Except there is a ton of chemistry, physics, and other high school subjects thrown into the mix, on top of a bunch of baffling space jargon (don't feel guilty if you pop onto your computer and Google "Mars," because I totally did it).I'm just realizing that, on paper, this book sounds pretty damn boring. But Weir wrote Watney to just be so damn funny and likable, that The Martian is nothing but a compelling and gratifying read. ...more

title: The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society
author: Shaffer, Mary Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What is it about writers writing about writers? Why is it so boring? I get "write what you know" but... like... seriously? The Guernsey Literary... isWhat is it about writers writing about writers? Why is it so boring? I get "write what you know" but... like... seriously? The Guernsey Literary... is a book centered around Juliet - a youngish London woman, coming off of the success of her wartime book and still piecing life back together after WWII. She's fine, I guess. A little flat, a little too... okay, so she's like Carrie from Sex and the City: there is nothing wrong with her, but she doesn't have much personality/heart on her own. She's an observer/reflector of her interesting friends. I don't care at all about Juliet. Yea her parents died and she was kind of a precocious child but she isn't developed enough, which is insane because the whole book is written as a series of letters with her as the focal point.Did I mention I don't like letters-as-a-novel stories?Anyway, randomly gets a letter from a gentleman in Guernsey, looking for a book, and because she is sweet and friendly and boring she reaches out in such a gracious way that they begin corresponding together. Then she begins to correspond with other Guernseians and I - ah - guess intrigue happens?How is a (as described in the book) beautiful, intelligent, kind woman still single at 32 in 1946. That may sound like a ridiculous complaint, but people usually got married around 20yrs old back then. So what gives?That's just one of many historical eyebrow raises I have, and I'm already too bored to map out the rest.If you're writing a WWII book you better be coming at it with a crazy new angle. Some whatever writer woman from London finding stories of love and loss in Guernsey is a snooze fest of mediocrity. Pack it for your beach read, then promptly forget about it. ...more

title: A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail
author: Bryson, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If I were ruler of the universe, I would have slightly changed the title of this book before going to print:"A Walk in the Woods: Two Old Fat Guys WalIf I were ruler of the universe, I would have slightly changed the title of this book before going to print:"A Walk in the Woods: Two Old Fat Guys Walk Some of the Appalachian Trail"Because the way the title and book jacket spin it, Bill Bryson and his friend Stephen Katz walked ALL of the Appalachian Trail, and that is woefully, staggeringly, untrue. One day Bryson walks in the woods, looks around, and goes "huh, this is nice. Maybe I should do this woods thing more."Then he discovers the Appalachian Trail (AT).Then he gets this crazy idea. I don't want to steer you wrong with those lackluster 3 stars. Bryson is a good writer, and his writing focuses on the trail. I pretty much wanted to burn Wild after reading it, because I walked away from that book possibly knowing less about the PCT than I knew before. Bryson, however, delicately and masterfully splices in juicy historical tidbits about the AT: it's history, it's hikers, and it's nature, while keeping us abreast of where he is at on the trail and how he is feeling. Katz can get wearisome (he is bewilderingly unprepared and his ability to act without thinking gets exhausting), but their time in the woods is beautifully written and made me want to try at least portions of the AT.So, yes, this book is great... except that I feel utterly betrayed by Bryson and his editors.I went into this book expecting him to hike hike all 2,000+ miles, and fairly early on he lets us know that, no, he will disappoint us, he is not going to hike the whole thing, but only pieces of it, because he's a yellow-bellied pansy who can't commit to what he started.That may be harsh, especially coming from someone who hasn't hiked more than 4 days straight, but it's like someone promised me a WHOLE CAKE, and then I just get a sliver of a piece. Sure, that bit I got was delicious, but it's hard to appreciate when I had my sights set on a WHOLE CAKE. You get it? The hiking is the cake? No? You don't get it? That's okay... I'll let myself out......more

author: King, Stephen*

review: I'm usually liking what Stephen King is putting down in his books. Unfortunately, Revival is a weird, half-baked plot which was never fully realized. I'm usually liking what Stephen King is putting down in his books. Unfortunately, Revival is a weird, half-baked plot which was never fully realized. I've read somewhere (forgive me that I'm forgetting where) that the point of writing a book is to identify a story which needs to be written. But we could all do without Revival in the world. A story about a pastor who, in the face of tragedy, denounces religion and goes on this weird, sci-fi journey to figure out what happens after we die. And all of this seen through a waste-of-space former junkie who bops around the country with no real ties to anyone or anything. Were you bored reading that? I was bored writing it.Ah well, if you've written 100+ books some of them are doomed to suck. At least it wasn't as bad as Dreamcatcher....more

But then he gets out. It's awesome. But then his wife dies. Also sucky. Then this random, creepy old dude propositions Shadow: "Hey, want to help me wage a war against new gods like Media and Internet? There's money in it. The war is pretty pointless and this is going to drag on for 600+ pages without anything really happening. But your wife just died and you just got out of prison, so what else are you going to do?"Unable to argue with that logic, Shadow agrees.Mediocrity ensues. Gods waging war should be freakin' amazing. There should be explosions and intrigue and all of that good stuff. American Gods, however, is just a few conversations held in dimly lit places. It never gains momentum, and just trudges along to a stupid ending.Neil Gaiman should have written this whole book about the town of Lakeside. Those were the only readable portions.And now I've officially tried enough Gaiman, and officially dislike him.Beth out....more

title: A Room of One's Own
author: Woolf, Virginia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading A Room of One's Own I kept thinking of that one, very famous, very poignant phrase:"We hold these truths to be self evident..."A Room of One'sReading A Room of One's Own I kept thinking of that one, very famous, very poignant phrase:"We hold these truths to be self evident..."A Room of One's Own seems, to me at least, to be the self evident truths of being a woman. Men interpret women in their art, while women are scorned for attempting to provide their own perspectives on themselves. This, Woolf cries, is unforgivable. All voices should be embraced, and the voice of Woman has been quieted for too long. The solution? Let women have some time to themselves and have some agency! These days Woolf's ideas are not revolutionary, but in 1929 it was borderline madness. For those of you unfamiliar with her work, Virginia Woolf writes some of the most beautiful, flowing prose published to date. You may think: "how could an essay about women and writing work when Woolf's sentences meander about before landing on anything remotely resembling a concrete point?"Well, friend, see for yourself:"...And I thought of all the women’s novels that lie scattered, like small pock-marked apples in an orchard, about the second-hand book shops of London. It was the flaw in the centre that had rotted them. She had altered her values in deference to the opinion of others.""...Masterpieces are not single and solitary births; they are the outcome of many years of thinking in common, of thinking by the body of the people, so that the experience of the mass is behind the single voice.""...we must accept the fact that all those good novels, Villette, Emma, Wuthering Heights, Middlemarch, were written by women without more experience of life than could enter the house of a respectable clergyman; written too in the common sitting-room of that respectable house and by women so poor that they could not afford to, buy more than a few quires of paper at a time upon which to write Wuthering Heights or Jane Eyre.""And again I am reminded by dipping into newspapers and novels and biographies that when a woman speaks to women she should have something very unpleasant up her sleeve. Women are hard on women. Women dislike women."And this hysterical analogy on how men silence women:"...as if some giant cucumber had spread itself over all the roses and carnations in the garden and choked them to death."Lastly, Woolf's wish for all women:"I hope that you will possess yourselves of money enough to travel and to idle, to contemplate the future or the past of the world, to dream over books and loiter at street corners and let the line of thought dip deep into the stream."It's okay, you can swoon now. ...more

title: Station Eleven
author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Writing an apocalypse book pretty much guarantees you airtime these days. Like books about zombies and vampires, apocalypse books can be based around Writing an apocalypse book pretty much guarantees you airtime these days. Like books about zombies and vampires, apocalypse books can be based around the dullest, most idiotic concept; but they still get pushed through on a wave of crap into our hands. Yes, sorry Ms. St. John Mandel, "Station Eleven" is an unequivocal wave of crap.Take the premise: the book opens up with a man whacking his hand (his HAND people. Not his head. Not his back. His stupid, insignificant hand, and he dies from it).Immediately after this confusing scene where you think "wait, is that a misprint? did they mean head?," the surviving characters (aka the world) suffers an outbreak of the "Georgia Flu," and everyone pretty much dies. Instantly. The book jumps around from 20 years before the apocalypse to 20 years afterward. It focuses on characters who died before the apocalypse even hit, to characters who have no recollection of what life was like beforehand. The author tenuously links all of her characters together. However, these links are wisps of nothing which disintegrate upon touching. That is: the characters aren't really linked at all, save for maybe passing each other on the street or talking to each other a little. It's totally stupid.St. John Mandel either cannot write characters, or is too lazy to put in the effort. None of the folks we meet along the way are fleshed out in any way. Their relationships are cliches, and they walk glaze-eyed through life without doing/seeing/being anything.Kirsten, the character we spend the most time following, keeps telling the reader that she remembers nothing from the first year of the apocalypse. "Awesome," the reader thinks. "She's going to have a break at one point and remember something terrible our awe-inspiring or at least somewhat interesting."Then nothing happens.St. John Mandel introduces a creepy religious cult. "Oh whoa," the reader thinks. "Is there going to be an epic battle scene between them and the other characters??"Nope. Nothing happens.In fact, pretty much nothing at all happens in all 300+ pages. You'd think in a post-apocalyptic world where the reader has been warned that people shoot first, ask questions second, that there would be some conflict. But not so, I'm afraid. This book is about a ton of people who survived the apocalypse, and some people who didn't, but you never really delve into their character, and you never witness real conflict/emotion. So, basically, it's a waste of time and space. ...more

review: Written in a narrative style like no other, The Color of Magic is a lightning paced adventure story of an almost wizard and a tourist as they stumble Written in a narrative style like no other, The Color of Magic is a lightning paced adventure story of an almost wizard and a tourist as they stumble through battles and narrowly escape Death again and again.Pratchett has a weird, disjointed way of writing. He jumps from perspective to perspective, sometimes within the same paragraph, so at times the reader does not even know whose head they are in until it's too late. Strangely enough, this jarring narration only adds to the experience, rather than detract. Truly one of a kind, Pratchett happily leaves scenes vague, characters less-than-fleshed, and pace whiplash inducingly quick. Discworld is a wild ride. Surely, it is not for everyone, but objectively like no other. ...more

title: The Forgotten Garden
author: Morton, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So Kate Morton wrote one book about different generations of women in a family having secrets. Then she decided that every book ever was going to circSo Kate Morton wrote one book about different generations of women in a family having secrets. Then she decided that every book ever was going to circle around this and isn't that just a marvelous idea?!.No, Kate, no. It is not a marvelous idea. I was pumped about The Forgotten Garden because I really, really enjoyed The Secret Keeper. I wish someone had stopped me and warned that it'd be the same twists just with different people in a different time period. It would have saved me some time. Basically Cassandra's grandmother, Nell, dies (Cassandra's mother is out of the picture and is a negligent bitch, but this is never explained/explored), and has left her a house in England. A house in England?! But we live in Australia!!...Cassandra has absolutely nothing going on in her life, so she is able to spend a ton of time and $$ to check out the house (Something sad happened to Cassandra that totally shattered her and blahblah predictable issues of a broken woman and holy wow can we just not with the stereotypes?! god!). Where Cassandra is getting all this $$ is never explored, but we shouldn't worry about that because ooohhhh!! Mystery!!!The book is split between 3 time periods: Nell's family waaayyy back in the early 1900s, Nell herself exploring England in 1976, and Cassandra in "present day" (2005). The early 1900s chapters were entertaining, but I really disliked the other two. This book would have been much better if it had been solely about what happened at Blackhurst Manor in the early 1900s. Unfortunately, Morton is so damn hung up on secrets that she needs to package her "mystery" 3 times over before she's satisfied with it.It may be because I had already read The Secret Keeper, but everything was obvious from the get-go. Her method of unpacking the elements of her mystery were so damn similar, it's almost like she had a chart on her wall helping her map out the formula. Also, did she JUST learn how to write?? The prose are clunky at best and NO ONE IN REAL LIFE TALKS LIKE THESE CHARACTERS TALK. Everything felt so incredibly stiff - I'm shocked the same person wrote The Secret Keeper; a book I dearly loved. Contrived, blase, and disappointing, The Forgotten Garden is best left unopened. Kate Morton and Gillian Flynn should start a club. A "I wrote one really good book but all of my other books really smell up the joint and that good book was just a fluke! Sorry! Kthanxbye!" club - but I guess all that wouldn't fit above the door now would it?...more

title: Watership Down        (Watership Down, #1)
author: Adams, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Bunnies aren't just cute like everybody supposes,They got them hoppy legs and twitchy little noses,And whats with all the carrots?What do they need s"Bunnies aren't just cute like everybody supposes,They got them hoppy legs and twitchy little noses,And whats with all the carrots?What do they need such good eyesight for anyway?Bunnies, Bunnies, it must be bunnies!"Buffy the Vampire SlayerI'm generally with Anya when it comes to bunnies - they freak me out. Working at an animal hospital I quickly learned that bunnies are so dumb they can give themselves heart attacks by simply getting anxious over being put in a box. Or touched. Or looked at.Ugh.I never would have read "Watership Down" if it weren't for the place it holds in the canon of literature. When I told people "Watership Down" was next on my list the response was pretty unanimous:"A book about bunnies? Are you twelve? You're going to hate it."Lesson learned. Don't judge a book by the amount of bunnies it has. The novel begins when Fiver has a terrible premonition. Spurred by panic, he convinces his brother Hazel they need to get the 'eff out of dodge and begin again somewhere new. The two rabbits attempt to convince everyone in their "town" (called a warren in the story) to leave their homes and plunge into the Unknown. Obviously (because they're bunnies) most refuse, and a small, motley crew sets off into the wild.Would you ever be on the edge of your seat reading about bunnies hiding from foxes, darting out of heavy rains, and fighting for what they want from life? No? Think again. Though I was met with guffaws when I excitedly recounted what I dubbed the "bunny boss battle," I have no regrets. The whole lot of them: Hazel, Fiver, Bigwig (and let's face it, anyone who says Bigwig isn't their favorite is lying. He is the most badass bunny there ever was) suffered an incredible adventure that even Frodo Baggins could respect. ...more

title: Agnes Grey
author: Brontë, Anne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Satire. Was it a thing in the mid-nineteenth century? How would the critics react to such a scathing look into society?Apparently pretty well.When AgnSatire. Was it a thing in the mid-nineteenth century? How would the critics react to such a scathing look into society?Apparently pretty well.When Agnes Grey first came out, it was to relative silence. Anne's (yes, we're on a first name basis) pseudonym was a nobody, and her book, though appreciated by those who read it, took a few years to be recognized for the excellence it was.Agnes Grey follows young Agnes as she tries to do the right thing, despite how it may wound her. She fights for the right to become a governess (her family feels she should not trouble herself), unaware that the occupation will degrade, challenge, and humiliate her. The first family she is charged with is cold and haughty. She is physically abused by the children and is not permitted to act as an authoritative figure. She watches in confusion and horror as this rich and privileged family spoils under the weight of servants and gold and opportunity.She does not last long.She is not dismissed by her second job, but is scandalized by the 18yr old daughter living in the house. Miss Murray is a manipulative little b*^$% who takes some pretty sadistic pleasure in hurting Agnes and bringing all the boys to the yard with her milkshake. Agnes suffers through, because that is what she's "supposed to do," until tragedy strikes and she leaves her job of her own volition. What Anne is trying to accomplish in this story is staggering. She takes on religion, the role of women in society, how the upper class treats the lower classes... and does it all with a literary sarcastic eye roll. Seriously. That's how the book reads. Want some examples? Well, my friend, you're in luck.1. Miss Murray's journey takes a harsh look on how beautiful rich women stomp on those plainer, poorer, and/or of the opposite sex - but Anne isn't done there. She takes it one step further and unpacks the struggles of losing yourself in your husband and in having a child. The grief of losing your youth and the act of passing of the fun baton to the next generation - people get antsy when you bring that heavy crap up NOW - but Anne was ready for that conversation in the 1800s. 2. Anne's depiction of Hatsfield is a pretty brutal commentary on the corruption of the church. His cruelty to animals, his lecherous behavior, his disregard for the poor - all she needed to do was write in a scene where he's running around with a pitchfork poking his church goers to really bring the imagery home.Now, I've looked into some scholarship on Anne to try and beef up my final point, but have come up a little short. Few would agree, it seems, that Agnes herself is satire of the pious and proud. Popular opinion seems to lean on the notion that Agnes is a characterization of Anne herself - but I have to disagree. Yes, Anne was religious (but really who wasn't back then) and yes, she was a governess herself, and yeah, okay, I get it, she is popularly depicted as the sister who stuck to her place and yaddayadda - but I just don't buy it having read  Tenant of Wildfell Hall prior to Agnes Grey.Agnes in the first half of the novel reads almost like a caricature. Whenever anything happens, she prays rather than taking action. She is silent against her abusers, and everything just generally sucks for her. Even in the end, which is arguably happy, Agnes betrays no emotion to the reader, and ends with the line (I'm paraphrasing) "and now I think I've said sufficient."I actually laughed out loud at that last sentence. It's like Agnes is saying to us "well, I've bored you enough with my story and I'm sorry for it." Agnes actually cuts in multiple times to apologize to the reader for being emotional or rambling on about something that she actually cares about. I do not think Anne is doing this lightly. I believe it is her telling the reader that the overly pious, proud, and reserved, are doing themselves a disservice. What I take away from Agnes Grey is the notion of balancing your life. You shouldn't be a Miss Murray, but you shouldn't be an Agnes Grey either. A woman should possess the ability to reflect inward, rather than constantly worrying about the public view of the self. Miss Murray works too hard to flaunt and flounce, while Agnes attempts to fade into the background and be forgotten. Both think they are doing what is expected of them, and both are wrong. It reads to me as though Anne is challenging the women of her time to think before acting, and to grow a damned backbone.And now I think I've said sufficient. ...more

He is proud of the friends he has made and the life he has led, but still bitter about those who did not listen to him and the harder bumps in life's road. The Apprentice apprentice is enjoyable for what it is: a memoir written by a cook about his love and food, and how food brings family and friends together. Articulate, giddy, and udeniably mad, these journals chronicle Plath through her beginnings I read this in grad school when writing a paper on Plath. Articulate, giddy, and udeniably mad, these journals chronicle Plath through her beginnings as a writer through the tribulations of depression. What is most fascinating, is how Plath spirals from direct "I did this, then did that" journal entries to meandering, stream-of-consciousness to the utterly confusing and intelligible ramblings of a woman deeply sick. I laughed, I sighed, I cried. This book may not be for those who do not find Plath fascinating and an integral part of literature. But if you're like me and found it hard to breathe after reading "Daddy," well, you came to the right place. ...more

title: The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry        (Harold Fry, #1)
author: Joyce, Rachel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Harold Fry sits at home, eating his toast and enjoying his morning, when he receives a letter from an old acquaintance. Queenie is sickly, and in the Harold Fry sits at home, eating his toast and enjoying his morning, when he receives a letter from an old acquaintance. Queenie is sickly, and in the failing light of life has been thinking on the time they spent together.The letter rudely awakens Harold from the dream-state of old age. Unable to sit still and process this information, he pops outside for a quick walk......which lasts for months. The tale is two-fold:1. Harold Fry and his wife Maureen separately reflecting on their lives; the mistakes, joys, sorrows, deceptions, miscommunications, jokes, and regrets. 2. The bite-sized lives of those Harold meets along his journey.It's touching in that sad, lonely-old-man-on-the-bench-at-the-park way. At times the main pitfalls in Harold's life felt a little too formulated and cliched, at others author Rachel Joyce hit the proverbial nail directly on the head.There are, however, a few bits which are still irking me ~12 hours after having returned the book to the library.Firstly, do Maureen and Harold actually discuss everything they've been thinking on these past few months? Joyce states that they talk... but does Harold know of Maureen's betrayal? Does Maureen know that Harold still needs her? It's never stated outright, which leads the reader to worry that both may slump back into the drudgery of life prior to Queenie's letter.Secondly, it would have been nice to hear more from Queenie. Oh, and for Queenie to know what Maureen did. For the book to close without Queenie knowing the truth actually made me mad. Thirdly, where the eff did the dog go?? Seriously, he just got on a bus??All complaining aside, this is a nice little book with quirky narration about a man and his feet. It's nakedly honest about how fragile our bodies and minds are, and how one should never put off making amends, or reaching out to old friends. ...more

title: The Girl on the Train
author: Hawkins, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This may have been the worst book I have ever read.Ever.Like... including "Twilight."How? How could I dislike (hate? I might even hate) this book so mThis may have been the worst book I have ever read.Ever.Like... including "Twilight."How? How could I dislike (hate? I might even hate) this book so much? It's about a woman disappearing, and another woman getting to the bottom of it. That sounds like a pretty sweet deal, and something totally up my alley.Allow me to elaborate. 1. This is neither a thriller nor a mystery. When you only have a cast of ~6 characters, it is stupidly easy to figure out who the bad guy is. The second the disappearance of Megan became a plot element, I knew who the murderer was. I had hope as I skimmed (yes, skimmed, I could not handle her terrible writing style to fully devote my time to it) toward the end that perhaps I was wrong; perhaps there would be a twist. But no. Like the train Hawkins leans on for imagery again and again, this book is a straight-shoot to the obvious. It never wavers and never changes course.2. Does Hawkins hate women? This is a serious question. The novel is written in first-person-narrative, varying from the points of view of three woman: a) A non-functioning alcoholic named Rachel. Her husband left her, she lost her job, and the author pens her as a pathetic slob who can't even be bothered to clean up her own vomit (literally). She ONLY fell apart because she couldn't have a baby and then her husband cheated on her. So, let me get this straight, dear author: Rachel's only value is being a wife and a mother? Take those away and there is nothing but a pathetic shell? Nice, real nice. Anyway, Rachel inserts herself into a missing person's case which, as far as she can see, has literally nothing to do with her. She lies, snoops around, and is generally a total creeper throughout the novel. She has zero redeeming qualities. She does not grow or change throughout the course of the book. b) A mother and wife named Anne. You want more to her character? Too bad. There is nothing else. Hawkins wrote her as mother and wife, full stop. Her sections revolve solely around her interactions with her husband and child. That's it. That's all. Like Rachel, she does not grow or change as the novel progresses. c) The missing person herself: Megan. She is in an emotionally abusive relationship and copes with this by cheating on her husband. She has baby issues and commitment issues. Like Anne and Rachel she has no job and no other personality elements other than her role as wife, lover, and potential mother. The only other women we have multiple interactions with are Rachel's roommate Cathy and a female detective who we know by her last name: Riley. Cathy is periphery: she hangs out with her boyfriend (and will readily ditch Rachel if her boyfriend is free and wants to see her) and she disapproves of Rachel's drinking. That's all we ever see of Cathy. As for Riley: she is a weird stereotype of a detective. She is a stony-faced woman-of-few-words who is weirdly suspicious of everyone she comes into contact with. None of her suspicions amount to anything, and she fades from view as the missing persons case goes from the capable hands of the authorities to the incompetent, clumsy, and infuriating hands of a non-functioning alcoholic (I bring the alcoholic thing up again because that is pretty much what defines Rachel. Hawkins is too lazy or too terrible a writer to give Rachel any real personality traits, so she just keeps hearkening back to the booze. Every single page in Rachel's narration makes reference to her wanting a drink, or drinking. Don't believe me? Go to the bookstore and flip through this trash for a second). I would classify the novel as follows:A book about how women need babies/husbands in order to define themselves. If they do not have these things, they spiral the drain of alcoholism and are generally unable to take care of themselves. Women without babies/husbands will insert themselves into married lives, and systematically try to tear apart what they so desperately want. I find Hawkins a deplorable person - to write her female characters in such a cardboard and vapid way when she is a woman herself? Are you serious? Who allowed this to be published? Hawkins trying to dress up her book with a half-assed, completely obvious "mystery" adds more insult to injury, because people (like me) expect intrigue. If you have read at least one other mystery/thriller novel in your life, you know who the bad guy is immediately, and spend the rest of the book reading about how much Hawkins hates women.The moral:Hawkins should not be writing, especially about women. If she hates herself so much she should go to therapy, and not cry on a soapbox to a confused, bewildered, disappointed, and even (in my case) outraged audience. ...more

title: The Devil in the White City
author: Larson, Erik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "The juxtaposition of pride and unfathomed evil struck me as offering powerful insights into the nature of men and their ambitions."This is how Larson"The juxtaposition of pride and unfathomed evil struck me as offering powerful insights into the nature of men and their ambitions."This is how Larson explains his coupling of the World's Fair story and the story of H.H. Holmes.Whenever I thought to myself "why did he smoosh these two, pretty much independent stories together?" I remembered this sentiment.Because really, that's what the story of the World's Fair and the story of H.H. Holmes are. Though they happened in tandem, one really has nothing to do with the other. It'd be like me telling the life stories of butcherman Joe and big-time-lawyer-guy Matt. Joe and Matt live a few blocks away from one another in Chicago, but they never interact, except that one time Matt came into Joe's shop and ordered some lamb chops. Reading something so disjointed simply because of coincidence is odd and, at times, tiring. Larson tries very hard to overlap the stories when he can, so gold star for that. He is also excellent at research. The diary entries! The block quotes! The attention to detail from menus at parties to ailments some players suffered from! ...but that gets sort of tiring as well. All of the businessmen who had a hand in the Fair? I could not have cared less which parts of them ached, or when/why they fell ill, or how they ultimately died. It was far too much information. I cared about two things: the Fair itself, and how creepy H.H. Homes was. And, I mean, Larson did deliver, albeit in a tidal wave of other information. I now know everything about the World's Fair. I know how many people entered the park on certain days, the most popular sites and buildings, what sort of food there was, how people ended up dying(!) at the Fair... it was exhaustive, really. And while I was thoroughly entertained at times, I myself also become thoroughly exhausted reading about the Fair in such meticulous detail.As for H.H. Holmes (cue dramatic music, a lightening crash, and the neighing of a horse), holy crap was he a scary man. Really, if someone cut out all of the World's Fair portions and came out with just the H.H. Holmes sections, this book would get an A+(+++), because I really really enjoyed Larson's retelling. Holmes is basically the devil: he has no remorse, he is an expert manipulator, and he is positively fascinating (and the ending! Oh, I will not spoil it, but what happens AFTER Holmes' execution gave me literal chills). I wonder if Larson felt the same way I do, because his Holmes chapters are so much more lively than his chapters on the World's Fair. I'm spitballing here, but perhaps Larson initially presented his editor with a short, H.H. Homes novella. Maybe his editor read over and was all "Larson, baby doll, you gotta add some meat. You mention the World's Fair. Why not talk about that for a while?" But Larson can't half-ass anything, so he provides us with everything and anything we could have ever possibly wanted to know about the Fair (I mean, seriously. Everything). For history and/or architecture buffs, this book is definitely a slam dunk. Larson is razor-precise, and his hard work shines through. But, if you're like me and you're just looking for an entertaining, historical read? The book oscillates between wildly titillating, and blandly daunting. ...more

title: Tender at the Bone: Growing Up at the Table
author: Reichl, Ruth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ruth Reichl is not a household name. Ruth Reichl isn't even a name I'd ever heard before, and I grew up in the 90's (her heyday at the NY Times) and hRuth Reichl is not a household name. Ruth Reichl isn't even a name I'd ever heard before, and I grew up in the 90's (her heyday at the NY Times) and have been watching FoodNetwork obsessively since I was allowed to use the remote control (which, actually, was surprisingly late in life. My parents raised me right).Because Reichl is a stranger to me, I walked into this novel with zero expectations. I have not read a single one of her s, nor did I know anything about her, save that I heard quite of few times that this book is one of the best food-centric memoirs to grace the stands.The masses did not disappoint. I've decided the only memoirs worth reading are these kind. Reichl paints us a (blissfully chronological) portrait of what it was like to grow up in the 60s and 70s, while simultaneously taking us on her personal journey to a long-term relationship with food. The novel starts with Reichl as a child suffering through her mother's deplorable cooking (the woman managed to poison 100+ people at one party - eegads!), and ends as she begins to solidify her career in food writing. Though it relies heavily on the culinary portions of Reichl's life, the book manages to barrel through topical issues such as the mistreatment of the mentally ill and racial tensions through the eyes of Michigan during one of the most volatile times in history. It's peppered with the recipes of family and favorites, and reminds the reader of the magic of food; how it can take you to strange, nostalgic, and wonderful places with each bite. The only qualm I have is the last chapter. I can concede that this book is a victim of its time, but someone needs to cut the final pages. Seaturtles and shark fins? Really not okay anymore, Reichl. I can't speak to when this was originally published (because I did not even have all of my permanent teeth at the time), but I cringed and groaned with every sentence. Cut it? And we've got written gold. ...more

title: Garlic and Sapphires: The Secret Life of a Critic in Disguise
author: Reichl, Ruth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Who can self-deprecate AND self-aggrandize in the same breath? Meet Ruth Reichl, a woman who love/hates her job/self, as she eats her way through New Who can self-deprecate AND self-aggrandize in the same breath? Meet Ruth Reichl, a woman who love/hates her job/self, as she eats her way through New York City in the 1990s. Reichl, for those who may not be familiar with the name, was the NY Times food critic from '93 - '99. She has written several books detailing her relationship with food (personally, I recommend Tender at the Bone first). This particular novel focuses completely on her years working at the NY Times. Specifically, what she ate, how she liked it, and how her life was changed by the position.Reichl has to assume disguises, both internally and externally, to make it through her job. She has to "suffer" through being doted on when she is herself, and ignored when she is wearing her most convincing of costumes. Hilarious, heart-warming, and infuriating, this book runs the gamut of emotions for those of us who cannot afford to eat at crazy expensive/fancy restaurants.Personally, I have quite the relationship with NYC. Growing up so close to the city, I enjoyed my youth traipsing through the Village, Hell's Kitchen... pretty much anywhere which was off-beat and wouldn't drain my babysitting/college job $$. The types of restaurants Reichl talks about I'll probably never set foot in; not just because I could never afford them, but because a lot of them are no longer around. NYC is ever-changing, and the lifespan of a restaurant, especially a swanky one, is notoriously low. The affluent masses frequent a restaurant when it's new and exciting, then leave it to decay when the next big thing comes out. All that being said: don't read Reichl's book if you're looking for recommendations. You'll get them, but they won't necessarily by relevant.Instead, read Reichl's book to get a glimpse of what NYC was like in the 90s. Watch as Times Square morphs from a seedy area best avoided to the epicenter of tourism. Read it to immerse yourself in a love affair with food. Reichl, despite her griping about her job, loves food and the passion good food reveals. The recipes she tucks at the end of her chapters, and the fervor with which she recounts some of the best meals of her life are intoxicating.Though the passion and writing are good, Reichl clearly dates and prices herself and her food choices in this novel. Truffles? Bitch please. Foie gras? As if. Though she does paint herself as "one of the masses," it is clear that Reichl exists within the upper-echelon of people; eating the most pretentious food imaginable in excessive quantities. It's also tiresome to listen to Reichl bemoan the difficulties that come with your job requiring you to eat out at the most expensive restaurants in the world for free. We feel you, Reichl......Seriously, though, Reichl's book is a great snapshot in time of the food scene in NYC in the 1990s. If you love food as much as I do (which my well worn kitchen would tell you is A LOT), then you'll love this book, despite all the gold that glitters out of reach. ...more

title: The Lowland
author: Lahiri, Jhumpa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is no denying that Jhumpa Lahiri effortlessly weaves prose which elegantly delight and surprise. Her short story collections are the prime exampThere is no denying that Jhumpa Lahiri effortlessly weaves prose which elegantly delight and surprise. Her short story collections are the prime example of this, though her first full length novel, "The Namesake," did not disappoint or lead the reader to believe that Lahiri was solely a short story writer.Unfortunately, "The Lowland" had me wishing it was 300 pages shorter.The story is so Lahiri-esque: two brothers, born close together but of quite opposite dispositions, grow up. We see them first as children in the 1960s and close the novel in the winter of life, in the unnamed future (presumably either present day or even further into the future after the book was published). We twist through major events in Indian history, and watch how each character reacts. There is love and loss and disappointment and compromise. As the book goes on and the narrative progresses, the story becomes less linear. It is reflective of a true aging mind. Things become less concrete, time flows more freely between past, present, and future. In short, it's fantastic.That being said, the story itself plodded along, never exciting me or touching me. The characters are just so dang sad and have made such terrible decisions in life. What's more, even though they are cognizant of these decisions, they do nothing to change their situations or make things right. It's infuriating, and if I didn't have such a love of Lahiri's other work, I probably would not have finished the book out of sheer frustration. The prose themselves, as I have already said, are beautiful. But that is not enough. I need characters I care about and am definitively rooting for or against. Instead, the reader is introduced to what I would call "gray characters;" characters which settle into their ruts, no matter how uncomfortable, and never move or change. In a way, this was like the Indian take on "American Pastoral." I did not much appreciate that story either. ...more

title: Live from New York: An Uncensored History of Saturday Night Live
author: Shales, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Saturday Night Live has never been something I stay up for, or really care about at all. The only times I remember sitting down at 11:30pm and watchinSaturday Night Live has never been something I stay up for, or really care about at all. The only times I remember sitting down at 11:30pm and watching SNL were on the weekends my brothers and I stayed at my Dad's. It was this special bonding time between a Dad and the kids he doesn't see often. We'd stay up late, cracked out on buttery popcorn and chocolate goodies bought from Costco, and laugh even at the unfunniest of sketches, happy to be up past bedtime and happy to be with each other.In adulthood, I only pop onto Hulu to stream last Saturday's episode if:1. an actor or band I really like was involved2. the internet is exploding from how funny/whacky the episode wasWhy, then, would I even bother with this book? And how did I end up liking it so much?Miller and Shales aren't simply interested in the funniest sketches and the most destructive people which/who have danced across the stage. Rather, they treat this book as a march through eras of comedy and culture, beginning with the drug-infused 70s, and ending on the granola-and-kale early 2000s. They capture the most touching, the most hilarious, and the most cringe-worthy moments, and they allow every person who has walked into 30 Rock to tell their story.The structure is pretty fascinating (and I can't even begin to fathom the amount of editing that went on, whew!). Miller and Shales interviewed everyone they could get their hands on, and had these actors/writers/produces/passerbys tell, in detail, the life of SNL while they were there. Once each story has been collected, they are systematically hacked up and sprinkled throughout the book into bite-sized paragraphs, so that the readers get a chronological story; and get several views on the same event all at once.Really, really ingenious stuff going on here.The authors were able to nab pretty much all of the heavy hitters (save those who had already passed, and Eddie Murphy. Really, Eddie Murphy? You're too good for this shit? Nevermind the show, you know, made you who you are today but whatever, fine, be that way), [{[{HELLO! IT'S ME FROM THE FUTURE! 2020 to be exact. A good friend told me she was reading this, so I got nostalgic and decided to re-read my . All I have to say is... wow. Girl. Do some Googling. Eddie Murphy had to deal with SO MUCH RACISM during his tenure on SNL. It isn't surprising he passed on being a part of this book. Be better. Anyway, back to the 2015 }]}] and, surprisingly enough, were able to get some pretty honest takes on how SNL has evolved, who has been the best (and the worst) to work with, as well as some pretty great behind-the-scenes looks. I laughed out loud, I gasped a bit, and my feelings on some actors will never be the same (I never thought I'd dislike the guy who brought me "Zoolander" and a very good reboot of "Walter Mitty" ... but I sort of want to punch Ben Stiller in the throat after finishing this). The only negative I really have to say is: the final section on Lorne Michaels? Super unnecessary. Super boring. I found myself a little annoyed with the writers that they slapped it in here, and really only skimmed the end, looking for final anecdotes from the voices I liked the most.For anyone who appreciates SNL, or comedy at all for that matter, this book is quite simply a must-read. I was interested in this book solely to hear the voices of Akroyd, Curtain, Murray, Fey, Fallon, and Poehler (comedic icons, in my book), but I walked away having respect for so many more past cast members/writers, and respect for the sketch show that has survived so much, and just keeps truckin'....more

title: Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly
author: Bourdain, Anthony
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Anthony Bourdain is a dick.I have said this dozens of times. Watching his Travel Channel exploits, listening to his complaints/judgments/"I'm right, yAnthony Bourdain is a dick.I have said this dozens of times. Watching his Travel Channel exploits, listening to his complaints/judgments/"I'm right, you're wrong" opinions... Bourdain, though respected as a good chef (unlike those he shares the screen with: Ray, the "Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives" guy... **shudder**), is bossy, overly opinionated, and just grates on me.I clued my Father into my thoughts on Bourdain. "Have you read his book?" he asked. "Well, no..." "Get back to me when you have."All I have to say now is: damn.Bourdain isn't a dick - he's just annoyed. And, in my amended opinion, rightfully so. Bourdain grew up a privileged jackass who, upon graduating from the CIA, felt he was too good for anything but a chef job. He subsequently bopped around from sinking ship to sinking ship, dealing with thieves, savants, and idiot savants......and lived to tell the tale.He has waded through the more sewer-y corners of the restaurant world. He has worked with incredible people, big-headed people, criminals, rubes (reds? blues?). He has been seduced by drugs, resisted the seduction of the more greasy-palmed aspects of the business, and has unabashedly laid all of this out for his readers.The man has balls.I relished this book. I ripped through the pages like Bourdain ripped through his food. His "here was my experience, love it or hate it" approach deserves a standing ovation. I generally loathe memoirs for their squeaky clean, the-badness-swept-under-the-carpet take on life. Especially when we're dealing with someone in the public eye (I'm looking at you, Gilbert. I would burn every copy of "Eat, Pray, Love" if I wouldn't feel badly about burning a book). Bourdain knows his honesty is equivalent to playing with fire, and mentions it over and over again in his book (mentioning the book may get him canned, mentioning that he won't provide real names lest he get his head smashed in). He is honest and unapologetic. What's more: I was astonished at how humble this book comes off. The chapter "The Life of Bryan" brought this book from great to I'm-going-to-be-recommending-this-to-everyone-always. To approach your book as "this is what the industry is like. Here are all the disgusting, illegal, sexist, and racist things that go on," and then turn it on it's head to say "Stephen Bryan is a better chef than me, has had a totally different experience that is arguably disgust/sexism/racism free and totally legal and I'm an idiot" (he actually says that. He breaks the fourth wall and chastises himself with: "Wrong again, idiot!" I loved it). How can you not walk away from this book admiring Bourdain and his honest love for the food and the craft?I will read this book again - when I need a good laugh or a reality check. Bourdain is not a writer and he knows it. But his passion for what he does allowed for this book to essentially write itself, and masterfully so. Step away from the computer, trot on down to the nearest library, and hunker down with Bourdain for a few hundred pages. You won't be disappointed....more
