title: The Return of the King        (The Lord of the Rings, #3)
author: Tolkien, J.R.R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Last night I finally finished Tolkien's epic. I read "The Hobbit" for the first time in Spring 2014. 2014! It took me 1.5 years to get through these fLast night I finally finished Tolkien's epic. I read "The Hobbit" for the first time in Spring 2014. 2014! It took me 1.5 years to get through these four, pretty slight books!"So," Rob said, eyeing me carefully as I closed the cover for the last time. "What did you think?"I know this is a very important moment in our relationship. He feels about Tolkien how I feel about Pullman. That is, he is a wonderful magic weaver who can do no wrong. I've tortured him enough, taking so long to read these books, haven't I? Even if I hated it I'd lie, wouldn't I? I'd take him in my arms and say "Oh, Rob! It read like a dream! What a fool I was to wait so long! I love it and I love you!"Alas, it was not to be.I took a breath, faltered, but eventually (regretfully) said what I was thinking:"Why does this book even exist?!"No! No you fool! It's coming out all wrong!I did not heed innerBeth."I mean," I backtracked. "This book can't stand alone. It's just a bunch of neat little bows made from strings trailing out of the other books."His face is falling. I'm totally screwing this up."I mean, why didn't they just smoosh it with "Two Towers?""""The Return of the King" is my favorite," he said.Damnit.I did enjoy "Return of the King." Really I did! It rounded out the books. But that's just it: all "Return of the King" does is round. It has no agency on it's own, it's simply picking up where "The Two Towers" left off, and ending everything. "Return of the King reads as follows:Battle scene, battle scene, internal conflict, battle scene, quippy dialogue, weird songs I'm going to skip over anyway, battle scene, epic Mordor stuff, walking, walking, pansy battle scene, Frodo is too nice and seriously wants to bone Samwise, closure of everything that hasn't been closed, roll credits. It just wasn't enough for me. "The Return of the King" should really just be cut down to the Mordor stuff and an epilogue, then tacked onto the end of "The Two Towers." Are certain parts necessary to the plot? Yes. But to the plot of the previous novel, and that annoys me.Now if you'll excuse me, I need to check and make sure Rob isn't stealth-moving out as I type. ...more

title: Infinite Jest
author: Wallace, David Foster
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Love it, hate it, or throw it out the window, "Infinite Jest" is a book which cannot be ignored; so much so that the novel made it onto Time's Top 100Love it, hate it, or throw it out the window, "Infinite Jest" is a book which cannot be ignored; so much so that the novel made it onto Time's Top 100 list. It's a textbook-length satire about the human condition, as told by the the many pretentious voices of Wallace's characters. It is not so much a case-study of Human as it is a case-study of Wallace as told by Wallace. He personifies each part of himself; the I'm-too-clever-for-this-world Wallace, the get-me-out-of-here-just-make-it-end Wallace, the I-guess-I'll-just-get-high-cause-fuck-the-world Wallace, the fuck-shit-paranoid-what's-going-on Wallace, the tree-octopus-minimuffin-beanbag Wallace... seriously, dude, we get it. They're all you.The book does not need to be as long as it is and is told in the stream-of-consciousness/nonsense format which was brilliant for Faulkner, but is infuriating from Wallace. What's more, that one personification? The I'm-too-clever-for-this-world one? Really should be punched in the face. As one reads "Infinite Jest" in adulthood, it becomes irritatingly obvious why this book has received such undeserved praise. OF COURSE college-aged kids eat this shit up. They're taking Philosophy 101 and have convinced themselves that they are on a higher plane than the consumer-obsessed mongrels who plague the world. Wallace, it seems, never grew out of Freshman pretension. Partially from mental illness and partially from isolating himself, Wallace remained convinced of his superiority, and funneled all of his "brilliant" frustration into 1000+ pages of dross.I can say that Wallace's book is good for something, though I'll rally against those who insist his work is a "defining" one, or, worse still, that those who cannot grasp the beauty of "Infinite Jest" simply aren't enlightened/deep/clever enough (try high enough) to understand it. Honestly, the book would be brilliant if it had some cohesion to it. And hey, if Wallace truly wanted to pen a novel which just rambled and pithered about, he should have at least achieved beautiful prose. Yes, at times Wallace does hit on some poignant passages. But these passages ring more like that "monkeys with typewriters" scenario than of actual talent/genius.Wallace's book deserves to exist because it makes for a great case-study in mental illness. The broken, fragmented narratives of each of his characters speak not of the people he's made up, but of the person who resides within Wallace himself. "Infinite Jest" is a testament to Wallace's mental illness, and to how America treats mental disease. It illustrates how we naively attempt to combat it, as well as how our lack of education can affect both individuals and the globe. Is it a masterful work? Bitch please. But it'd be worth teaching excerpts in psychology classes. ...more

title: The Corrections
author: Franzen, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't say for certain if you have to be a particular age to truly appreciate this book; if you have to have lost someone to their mind, or worked thI can't say for certain if you have to be a particular age to truly appreciate this book; if you have to have lost someone to their mind, or worked through disappointing your parents, or misstepped a few dozen times in your life for Franzen's story arc to strike a chord. Luckily, the dysfunction I grew up in allowed me to feel part of the family Lambert, rather than looking in and thinking "damn, guys, your lives really suck."Allow me to explain.This 500+ page book circles around The Lambert's, a family of 5 in the autumn of their lives. Enid and Alfred, the elderly, midwestern parents; Gary, the ill-tempered oldest with a propensity to be petty and jealous as he wades through his unhappy marriage; Chip, the floundering middle child who manages to ruin every venture he undertakes, and never seems to settle down; and Denise, the youngest who simultaneously attempts to keep the family together while also trying to salvage some semblance of herself.Whew.The book structure alone is something to be appreciated. The book focuses on one slim time period: October - December of a single year, and is then broken up into 6 sections: one section for each character (with Enid and Alfred sharing their section), a section where they all attempt to get together for Christmas, and the epilogue. I found this an excellent way to tell the story of the Lambert's: you are introduced to each character in depth, focusing on a mere couple of months, with a hefty amount of flashbacks to flesh out how the character got where they are now. All the while you know you are hurtling toward the Enid proclaimed "One Last Christmas," where the family may or may not finally get together, where the fate of the sick Alfred will be hopefully be decided, and where the reader will discern whether each character was able to achieve the corrections they so desperately wanted in their lives.Franzen is unforgiving in how toxic a seemingly conventional family can be. The sibling anger, the pouty disapproval of a traditional midwestern mother, the cold and silent father who suddenly finds himself needing his family... these are characters that exist so readily in life, it would seem that this story would not need to be told. However, Franzen artfully crafts their internal monologues, fleshing out the fears and insecurities of even the most outwardly stable of people. I laughed out loud and teared up. I finished the book, shocked at how well it ended, while wishing that there was more. To close, and at the risk of fan girling: Franzen's "The Corrections" is a flawless case study of an American family at the dawn of the new Millennium, and really should be read by you....more

title: Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail
author: Strayed, Cheryl*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A book I probably never would have read had I not received it as a Christmas present. Cheryl Strayed was the same age I am now when she tackled this aA book I probably never would have read had I not received it as a Christmas present. Cheryl Strayed was the same age I am now when she tackled this adventure. Though I am outdoorsy myself, I really felt nothing either way about delving into her story. Holding this book in my hands before beginning I thought to myself: "Please, oh please don't be as bad as 'Eat, Pray Love.'"Well, it wasn't. But shit was it close.Cheryl Strayed has a shitty life. Her mom dies from cancer, and in response Strayed slams on the proverbial Self Destruct button of life. Cheating on and ultimately divorcing her husband, dropping out of college (though she does not describe it this way, there is no other way in which to quantify a person who simply did not complete the requirements of their university), doing heroin, working dead-end jobs... she has no forward no momentum and nothing going for her. So she makes the (arguably flippant) decision to hike the California portion of the Pacific Crest Trail (PCT).Though she states she prepared for the adventure for roughly six months before setting off, she is woefully unprepared. She doesn't understand how shoes work, she packs way too much stupid stuff (carrying more than one novel, a foldable saw, a roll of condoms), and doesn't pack things one might actually need for such a trek (suitable water containers, suitable clothes... oh and money). Reading this book I became alternately flummoxed and sympathetic. Yeah, it takes some serious balls to do this in the first place, but did she have to be so damn stupid about it? Sure, she was young, but she was the same age I am now and, having done multi-day hikes (though nothing close of this length) I know for a fact I would never have made some of the ridiculous decisions she does in the story. The way she wastes money on frivolities and relies on the kindness of strangers is maddening. I know perfectly well that a trek such as the PCT attracts a certain type of person (friendly, selfless, etc.), but even still, Strayed never would have made it through the hike without several of the characters in the book pushing her on.Oh, and hey, Strayed can't write well. She keeps mentioning in the book how she wants to be a writer and will be one day (we'll ignore that it took her the better part of 20 years to actually get this book done and out, but whatever). But for all her self-congratulatory bullshit, the reader is met with lines like (when discussing her mom begging her male nurse for morphine) "sometimes he told her no in a voice as soft as his penis in his pants" and "It was Friday morning and I could feel the Friday morningness emanating from the houses I passed." My personal favorite is: "I got an abortion and learned how to make dehydrated tuna flakes and turkey jerky..."For someone who talks about the death of her mother for more than half the novel, it is shockingly uncharacteristic that the abortion she has right before the start of her trip boils down to four matter-of-fact words. It makes me feel like, despite telling us about all of the random sex she had and all about her naked body, she refuses to divulge about something really significant in her life. Really?Strayed chooses to repeat things. A lot. Phrases, ideas, sometimes almost whole paragraphs. This works in novels with astounding prose, or in books of incredible length. It does not work here. It feels lazy, like she approves of how she described something once so she repeats it again. And again. And again...The book is less about someone hiking the PCT, and more about someone running away from their life and reflecting back on it as they build themselves anew. The retrospective narrative Strayed uses is clunky at best, and I found myself annoyed with her as she mentioned her mother for the 70th time, her step-father for the 58th, her poor ex-husband for the 49th.There was one part of the novel that particularly pissed me off. Strayed is reflecting (for the zillionth time) on her mother; thinking about how her mother didn't push her to apply to colleges. Insinuating, basically, that had her mother pushed her harder, she would have gone to Harvard:"But it was too late now, I knew, and there was only my dead, insular, overlyoptimistic, non-college-preparing, occasionally-child-abandoning, pot-smoking, wooden-spoon-wielding, feel-free-to-call-me-by-my-name mom to blame."Dude... seriously? It's you dead mom's fault you didn't go to an Ivy? Plenty of parents (my own included) do not help their children pick out universities. It's your future, take the reins yourself. It is not your dead mom's fault that you were a lazy teenager who did not do the research, did not discuss your options with a teacher/guidance counselor, and ultimately coasted through a meh college that you didn't even graduate from. Shit happens in life. Some people make the best of it. Some people dick around. So... way to dick around. I could have done with more descriptions of the places and trails and people; less of her ruminating on her bad decisions and bad life. All-in-all, Strayed is infuriating, and the book is best enjoyed skimming for the (seldom few) parts that have to do with hiking the PCT....more

title: Yes Please
author: Poehler, Amy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There is this sneaking suspicion in my head that Amy Poehler's editor didn't come into work on the day the booked was finished. Maybe her editor was oThere is this sneaking suspicion in my head that Amy Poehler's editor didn't come into work on the day the booked was finished. Maybe her editor was on a vacation for weeks and came back to a manuscript that was due to go to print a mere few days later. Poehler does tell us over and over again that she dreaded writing this book and dragged it out as much as she could, so it honestly wouldn't surprise me that she delivered the final product late, so that it was ed late, and thus the whole process was rushed.The reason I think this is quite simply because most competent editors would not have allowed this book to be printed. It rambles and repeats, and when I say repeats, I mean I read some long anecdotes 2-3 times over only a couple of chapters apart. It is glaringly obvious that Poehler wrote this in chunks whenever inspiration struck and did not read it through once she had enough to fill a book. There is no cohesion to the sections. Instead the chapters have been Frankenstein-ed together as they jump around space and time. The reader is hurtled from present day to childhood to Poehler's early 20s to Poehler's SNL hey-days and back. She writes like she would talk to you: beginning one story, then meandering off into a second, launching into a third, referencing the first again, beginning and completing a fourth story, completing the second story, and never quite letting you know what the point of the third was. It was a little maddening at times, and I found myself thinking over and over "oh, hun, no one told you to re-read your work, did they?"All the technical criticisms aside, this book was an entertaining memoir about a woman finding herself and attempting to tackle happiness. Part self-help book and part "this one time at band camp," Poehler's book is unapologetically honest about the mistakes and weird turns life takes, while simultaneously attempting to bolster any woman who may find herself in unsavory, unhappy, or just plain unhealthy positions. Poehler nestles nuggets of truth and inspiration in her otherwise erratic ramblings, and there were some parts that made me want to punch the air in solidarity - for Poehler knows the struggle of being a woman criticized for her personality, her looks, her priorities. Even the majority of us who are not and never will be famous can appreciate passages such as:"We didn’t take a lot of pills in my day, which was lucky. Those suckers are heart-stoppers. It’s scary today to see all those downers find their way into young people’s hands. Teenage bodies should be filled with Vonnegut and meatball subs, not opiates that create glassy-eyed party monsters."And my personal favorite "self-help" excerpt from her book (as she discusses struggling with loving yourself for who you are and what you look like):"Hopefully as you get older, you start to learn how to live with your demon. It’s hard at first. Some people give their demon so much room that there is no space in their head or bed for love. They feed their demon and it gets really strong and then it makes them stay in abusive relationships or starve their beautiful bodies. But sometimes, you get a little older and get a little bored of the demon. Through good therapy and friends and self-love you can practice treating the demon like a hacky, annoying cousin. Maybe a day even comes when you are getting dressed for a fancy event and it whispers, “You aren’t pretty,” and you go, “I know, I know, now let me find my earrings.” Sometimes you say, “Demon, I promise you I will let you remind me of my ugliness, but right now I am having hot sex so I will check in later.”"This book is best read before you go to sleep. Consider each chapter their own short story, and read them far apart from one another. The repetition and randomness of the whole "book" will feel less jarring and more cute and quirky, just as Amy Poehler and her fictional counterpart Leslie Knope so naturally are. ...more

title: Sharp Objects
author: Flynn, Gillian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Yeah. No.Flynn's first stab at writing a novel falls woefully short. She is so preoccupied with crafting a character who is too broken and too full ofYeah. No.Flynn's first stab at writing a novel falls woefully short. She is so preoccupied with crafting a character who is too broken and too full of weird ticks and quirks that everything else which may have been decent in the story dies along with her belabored efforts. Camille is not believable. She is a hard/strong/independent reporter who also has deeply seeded mommy issues, was a mean girl in high school, is self-mutilating, and an alcoholic. She also has a weird obsession with taking baths. And Flynn's "literary" device of having Camille feel words on her skin is so wholly out of place that it jars the reader out of a story that was almost impossible to get into in the first place.For a murder mystery you spend precious few pages actually focusing in on the driving force of the novel: the mystery. Instead you have to read through Camille meeting up with old high school friends, wading through small-town bullshit, dealing and re-dealing with her family, and drinking room temperature liquor for the thirty-eighth time.The tropes are so tired they're practically letting out exasperated sighs along with me. A person trying to run away from their past is thrown back in. Little girls are murdered. Little girls are mean. Big girls who have to deal with who they were when they were little break down.Dude, seriously? How Flynn ended up writing something as fresh as "Gone Girl" is beyond me. Had I read "Sharp Objects" first, I never would have bothered....more

title: On Immunity: An Inoculation
author: Biss, Eula
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "You have got to be kidding me."That's what I kept yelling, out loud, as I read this book.With the luxury of hindsight, I'm unsure what exactly I was "You have got to be kidding me."That's what I kept yelling, out loud, as I read this book.With the luxury of hindsight, I'm unsure what exactly I was hoping for in picking up On Immunity. I suppose I wanted the history of vaccines and the evolution of modern medicine and disease prevention. What I got was an overprivileged rich white woman who freaked out when she had a baby and realized her kid could get sick. Because her daddy is a doctor, she was able to harass other doctors and read daddy's medical textbooks to learn about smallbox (really the only disease she talks about at length), and decide whether she wants to subject her kid to medicine (because she's an idiot). On Immunity reads like a high school oral presentation. "The Oxford English Dictionary defines GERM as..." is how most of the book read. The remaining bulk was Ms. Biss talking about how HARD is was to be a rich, stay at home mommy worrying about her kid. I'm hazarding a guess she was only published because of said wealth/who her daddy is, because this book is a total waste of time, space, and effort. ...more

title: Out of Africa
author: Dinesen, Isak
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Karen Blixen (pen name Isak Dinesen) thought she was doing Europe a gigantic favor by writing this book. It basically reads as follows:Oh, life is chaKaren Blixen (pen name Isak Dinesen) thought she was doing Europe a gigantic favor by writing this book. It basically reads as follows:Oh, life is challenging to teach The Natives how to love Jesus and use a fork and understand how books work. Good thing I have always aspired to be an author and can explain exactly the trials and tribulations on both sides; the veritable war it takes to culture these Savages. At times I miss being among real people, but I know I am doing Good Work making fun of children who don't understand cuckoo clocks and live in a different society than I grew up in.I know, I know, Blixen was a victim of the time period in which she lived. Most people were pretty racist back then, so we really can't begrudge her her horribly uneducated and sweeping generalizations of African people, their customs, and their "shortcomings."But just because she was a victim of her time, does not mean that I have to appreciate the over-privileged White Woman attempting to educate me about an entire continent, based solely on her very sheltered, very skewed, and very narrow experiences. There are too many good books in this world to waste time on out-of-date and bigoted works. I got just shy of halfway through before I decided this. I hope I can do you a good service by warning you to not even pick it up (if you are a early twentieth century history buff who is very interested in reading about how one White Woman viewed Africa through her rose-tinted glasses, far be it for me to warn you off. But I'm pretty sure you are one of maybe twelve people who can appreciate this book without being offended). I'll leave you with a quote, which I feel demonstrates quite well Blixen's attitude. This is in regard to one of her favorite "Native Boys," who had taken up the role of cook, and had mastered making European dishes quite quickly:"Here even his intelligence sometimes failed him, and he came and offered me a Kikuyu delicacy, - a roasted sweet potato or a lump of sheep's fat, - as even a civilized dog, that has lived for a long time with people, will place a bone on the floor before you, as a present."...more

title: Neil Patrick Harris: Choose Your Own Autobiography
author: Harris, Neil Patrick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Listen: I'll be the first to admit that NPH is adorable. From his Doogie Houser days to his weird cameo in Harold&Kumar to HIMYM (even when that show Listen: I'll be the first to admit that NPH is adorable. From his Doogie Houser days to his weird cameo in Harold&Kumar to HIMYM (even when that show began to spiral the drain, the character of Barney never disappointed me. He was dynamic, layered like the best of cakes, and I really felt NPH's performance... which is weird when you consider I was watching a pretty silly sitcom).I'm laying the groundwork for this: I think NPH is a really standup guy, and I have always admired how professional and poised he is.Professional and poised? Does not make for a good book.This autobiography is rated "G" for "gigantic bore" and "gee whiz, when will we get to the good stuff?" NPH (or the person who wrote this for NPH) does not discuss anything negative or controversial, save a little drug dappling and one fight with a homophobic prick (and he even managed to put a cavity-inducing good spin on THAT). What I'm trying to say is: this book is snor-able and skip-able. There was little in this book I couldn't have picked up from his Wikipedia page. There were no revelations, no soul searching. Nothing. He gave us a couple of recipes, a couple of magic tricks, and a whole lot of YAWN.The few "pit falls" a person can stumble into in the "choose your own adventure" format are cute and silly... but if I wanted cute and silly, I'd watch a video of a puppy for a couple of minutes and not read a 200+ page book....more

title: Ender’s Game        (Ender's Saga, #1)
author: Card, Orson Scott
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When you marry space and war you pretty much have me at hello. Such was the case with Ender’s Game. I thoroughly enjoyed Card’s dystopian society, ravWhen you marry space and war you pretty much have me at hello. Such was the case with Ender’s Game. I thoroughly enjoyed Card’s dystopian society, ravaged by war and overpopulation; his dramatic irony, as the adults drove the children further into rabbit holes; and the nod to a future that, in many ways, mirrors current reality.Ender, though not the most believable of fictional children, was an excellent narrator; his fears, hesitations, and insecurities made for a compulsive read, and the ending gelled nicely with the ideologies which the author thrust on someone so young. Card gives us a bleakly real view into humanity’s savageness, that “eye on the prize” mentality that runs over the weak and sheeplike. Yet, impossibly, Card simultaneously reveals how completely beautiful some of humanity can be. He uses “us vs. them” to perfection, and I commend him for the larger issues of race and power that he tackles .My only complaint is that I could have used more chapters fleshing out Peter and Valentine. I was very invested in that subplot, and it felt like an abandoned half-baked cake. It’s as though Card realized their story could encompass an entirely separate novel and thus dropped it in favor of focusing on Ender. I get it, I really do, but I could have handled an extra 200 pages to better appreciate where they both end up at the close of the book. I would argue that this book should be taught in schools. I appreciate the tropes now, but would have devoured them at age 13. What’s more, it taught me more about life and love than Romeo and Juliet ever could. ...more

title: Mockingjay        (The Hunger Games, #3)
author: Collins, Suzanne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Take PTSD, war, torture, power struggle, and revolution, but funnel it through the eyes of a 17yr old. That's what Suzanne Collins does with her finalTake PTSD, war, torture, power struggle, and revolution, but funnel it through the eyes of a 17yr old. That's what Suzanne Collins does with her final installment of The Hunger Games trilogy. Over the course of just ~13 months, Katniss Everdeen went from a poor, pithy survivor getting by in her mining district, to a national symbol and a key player in a revolution. She wants none of this, and understands very little. She just wants to keep on living, along with the few people she loves. This is, first and foremost, a book about war. We get description of weapons and battles and strategy. This usually isn't my cup of tea. I don't like war, and I don't like books that belabor it. Luckily, Collins consistently focuses on the human part of war: the injured, the innocent, the bewildered... she wants her readers to think concretely about the cost of war. To package this in a YA book was a bear of an ambition, but she does it with skill and grace.Now, look, Mockingjay isn't perfect. Collins does Finnick and Johanna dirty. But I can't give Peeta anything less than 5 stars.I love these books....more

author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Stephen King and I are buddies. I have been reading at least one King novel a year since I was, oh, I don't know... 8? Some of it has been wonderful aStephen King and I are buddies. I have been reading at least one King novel a year since I was, oh, I don't know... 8? Some of it has been wonderful and some of it... well...Have you read Dreamcatcher?But I digress.I was wary to try 11/22/63. Not because the premise didn't intrigue me; it is an impressive idea. But that's exactly why it took me a few years to pick this book up: what if he failed miserably? What if he tackled too much? JFK, time-travel, crazy tie-ins with Derry? It could be only one of two novels:Rave worthy, or throw-it-across-the-room worthy.Well, folks, it ended up the former for me.In true King fashion, there are some maddening aspects of the book (go faster! Why did you do that?? Why aren't you privy to the dramatic irony, definition be damned! Stupid characters...), but I would gladly read this again, or shove it under the nose of anyone who asks me for a book recommendation.Jake Epping hurtles through a random time "bubble" into 1958, and spends the next 5 years marching toward the Kennedy assassination and the plan to change history. Side adventures abound as terrifying, heartbreaking, and white-knuckled events shatter his course again and again. I'm happy to report that the ending is quite satisfying. One of the unfortunate things I find with King's novels is while the journey is exciting, his endings often fall short (oh, Insomnia, how I had such high hopes for you). Not so with 11/22/63. It's touching. It's funny. It's King at his finest. ...more

review: Flann O'Brien (aka Brian O'Nolan) reminds of of F. Scott Fitzgerald. Reading At Swim-Two Birds gave me flashbacks of This Side of Paradise - just lackFlann O'Brien (aka Brian O'Nolan) reminds of of F. Scott Fitzgerald. Reading At Swim-Two Birds gave me flashbacks of This Side of Paradise - just lacking the upper class bullshit that Fitzgerald subjected us to.A Bildungsroman about a college-age guy who discovers beer, shooting the shit with your friends, and entertaining yourself with your own mind, At Swim-Two Birds is a glimpse into the drunken, confused, meandering youths of early twentieth century Ireland you never thought you'd care to read about. Inserted into these memoir-esque portions of the book are some story ideas O'Brien/O'Nolan was having at the time. A play about faeries, a story about a man who can think others into being... at times these side-stories were interesting, but mostly I found them either dull or bewilderingly off-the-walls-insane. I much preferred reading about the fictionalized O'Brien/O'Nolan working through school and the burden of being clever in an increasingly frustrating world, and wish the book had explored that aspect exclusively. ...more

title: Beloved
author: Morrison, Toni
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Despite a Master's in English, the only Toni Morrison that was ever assigned to me came in grad school, and it was A Mercy. But, don't worry, America'Despite a Master's in English, the only Toni Morrison that was ever assigned to me came in grad school, and it was A Mercy. But, don't worry, America's English curriculum isn't broken. We're fine. #Englishclasssowhite.This book isn't not good, it's just that magical realism isn't exactly my cup of tea. So when the ghost in house 124, which I assumed to be a metaphor for grief, turned out early on to be an actual ghost, I was like oh, shit, that's where this book is going.For the 3 other people who haven't read this book: Beloved follows Sethe, a woman who escaped slavery and has been living in Ohio ever since, in the house of her late mother-in-law, with her one remaining child. Early on, the reader knows that Sethe and her family have suffered significant tragedy, but the book reveals the extent of their pain in bits, peeling back the scar tissue thin layer by thin layer. Morrison is a master when it comes to the nuance of trauma, and those parts of the book had me gasping, tearing up, grateful that such a writer exists to pen so beautifully some of the horrors that were inflicted on people in the name of "discipline."That said, a cool 50% of the book isn't about that, but about the ghost in the house. And I just... really didn't like that. I didn't find it engaging; it felt like a distraction from the narrative of Sethe and Paul D in their earlier years. And, while lyrical stream-of-consciousness is usually my jam, the instances of this in Beloved fell flat for me. (view spoiler)[And, listen, I get that Beloved, both in baby ghost form and in adult humanoid form, is a physical representation of maternal love and fear and passion, and how that can metastisize and destroy. Also, I'm aware that Beloved is the catalyst for the unpacking of some Sethe's trauma. Please don't @ me that I "didn't get it." I did. But, again, the Beloved aspect of the book just wasn't my cup of tea. (hide spoiler)]All this to say, I would recommend Beloved, but with the warning that there is a supernatural element to the story, and that it can, at times, feel a bit clunky....more

title: Mrs. Dalloway
author: Woolf, Virginia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: They say a narrator who chooses to peer into every character's head is cumbersome at best, and reads like nonsense at worse. Whoever "they" are have cThey say a narrator who chooses to peer into every character's head is cumbersome at best, and reads like nonsense at worse. Whoever "they" are have clearly not read Woolf. She can jump from subconscious-to-subconscious in the same breath and have the whole thing flow masterfully. She can take a single frame: a car parked in the middle of the road, a mad woman scorning her lover in the street, and pore over that image with the perspectives of four different people; yet it never gets dull; it never wavers from the complete poetry which is Virginia Woolf.Mrs. Dalloway tells the story of Clarissa Dalloway on the day she is throwing a party. She is a Type A person with a propensity to daydream (try to reconcile that! I dare you!). She, like most characters in the novel, romanticizes the past and worries about how her life has turned out: has she wasted it? What was the point of it all?Woolf tackles mental illness in the characters of Septimus and Lucrezia, lesbianism in the characters of Sally and Clarissa, imperialism and infidelity in the character of Peter... these are popular tropes now but in 1925? Not so much. Scandalous, even.Mrs. Dalloway is a classic which bears no introduction and needs no analysis - dissertations have been written on the subject, so who am I to bore you with my thoughts? Let me leave you instead with Woolf's own words:One cannot bring children into a world like this. One cannot perpetuate suffering, or increase the breed of these lustful animals, who have no lasting emotions, but only whims and vanities, eddying them now this way, now that.For she was a child, throwing bread to the ducks, between her parents, and at the same time a grown woman coming to her parents who stood by the lake, holding her life in her arms which, as she neared them, grew larger and larger in her arms, until it became a whole life, a complete life, which she put down by them and said, “This is what I have made of it! This!”Sally stopped; picked a flower; kissed her on the lips. The whole world might have turned upside down! The others disappeared; there she was alone with Sally. And she felt that she had been given a present, wrapped up, and told just to keep it, not to look at it — a diamond, something infinitely precious, wrapped up, which, as they walked (up and down, up and down), she uncovered, or the radiance burnt through, the revelation, the religious feeling! — when old Joseph and Peter faced them:“Star-gazing?” said Peter.It was like running one’s face against a granite wall in the darkness! It was shocking; it was horrible!But she feared time itself [...], as if it had been a dial cut in impassive stone, the dwindling of life; how year by year her share was sliced; how little the margin that remained was capable any longer of stretching, of absorbing, as in the youthful years, the colours, salts, tones of existence, so that she filled the room she entered, and felt often as she stood hesitating one moment on the threshold of her drawing-room, an exquisite suspense, such as might stay a diver before plunging while the sea darkens and brightens beneath him, and the waves which threaten to break, but only gently split their surface, roll and conceal and encrust as they just turn over the weeds with pearl.And the most poignant of all, considering the end of Woolf's life:Death was defiance. Death was an attempt to communicate; people feeling the impossibility of reaching the centre which, mystically, evaded them; closeness drew apart; rapture faded, one was alone. There was an embrace in death....more

title: Eleanor Roosevelt, Volume 2: The Defining Years, 1933-38
author: Cook, Blanche Wiesen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This  will not be fair. You have been warned.I wanted to read a book about Eleanor Roosevelt because I wanted to learn more about the policies sThis  will not be fair. You have been warned.I wanted to read a book about Eleanor Roosevelt because I wanted to learn more about the policies she pushed forward, and the stances she took. I chose this particular book because "the defining years" sounded like an excellent place to start, I was interested in the beginning of her career, and Cook has received nothing but praise for her writings.Well color me disappointed.This book covered way too much of Eleanor's personal life. Hundreds of pages were dedicated to her alleged romance with journalist Ms. Hick. I had to read far too much about the woes of her children and her dinner parties and I felt robbed. Like I said - this isn't fair. This book gave a COMPLETE history of the times. What Eleanor ate, wrote, thought, loved, experienced, etc., and that was simply not what I wanted. So yes, I concede that just because I wanted a shorter book that focused primarily on the political times rather than the types of dresses Eleanor went shopping for doesn't mean this book was bad. And it wasn't bad. Cook was very thorough in her research and the bits that actually focused on policy and America were excellent. But that's all they were: bits. I skimmed whole chapters searching for the relevant bits and leaving out the "no, you hang up first" letter equivalents which Eleanor kept with Ms. Hick.So really all I have to say is this: I apparently do not care about Eleanor the person, I care about Eleanor the social legend....more

review: It seems weird to call this "chick lit" when it tackles issues like domestic violence, rape, murder, bullying, and infidelity; but there you go. MoriaIt seems weird to call this "chick lit" when it tackles issues like domestic violence, rape, murder, bullying, and infidelity; but there you go. Moriarty has penned the darkest beach read I have ever encountered. She barrels through the upper-class life of a group of Kindergarten moms and addresses everything from fashion faux pas to murderous rage. I think she provides an accurate and clear voice for all of her characters: children, teenagers, tired old moms, terrified young moms, bored moms, rich moms (red moms? blue moms?) but you get my drift. She was able to rile my emotions during the more harrowing scenes and she reminded me of when my own little brothers were bullied in school (and, yes, I did believe myself capable of murder back then).All of this being said, the whole thing felt a little, well, cliched. Each character's baggage was expected and worn; like the beat up duffel bag abandoned at the airport. I found myself audibly sighing at times, and becoming angry with the characters (and, subsequently, Moriarty) for not realizing how exasperatingly expected they were being. title: Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking
author: Gladwell, Malcolm
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Blink" is a really excellent idea for a book. The questions posed at the start are ones I would never think of asking myself: how do I make the littl"Blink" is a really excellent idea for a book. The questions posed at the start are ones I would never think of asking myself: how do I make the little, snap decisions in my every day life? What do they say about me? Can I control them? What happens if they control me?Genius.Sure Gladwell gets a little bogged down in his own subject matter from time-to-time and, no, I don't think I really understood his discussion of Kenna. But that aside, I found the stories he focused in on to be very clever insights into the working of the human mind.Gladwell takes us down various paths as he explores the questions posed at the beginning. From sexism to racism to relying too little on our "gut instincts" to depending on them to the point of fatal error - it's all in this book. Does Gladwell come to any real consensus about the human mind? Nope. And you know what? I find that one of the more endearing things about this book. You see: you can't thin-splice everything and everyone. Sometimes these snap judgments save, sometimes they cloud. That flip-flop, in my opinion, makes this book an excellent and honest discussion of the brain. Each brain adapts uniquely to their environment and therefore reacts to the same stimuli in vastly different ways. One of my favorite segments in this book revolved around monitoring an autistic subject as he watched a dramatic film. To compare his brain functioning compared to that of a more ordinary brain was a fascinating case study. It speaks a lot to how the brain can shape our world. How it can be our best friend and yet, in certain environments, cripple us in performing the most simple tasks.I'll say it again:Genius....more

review: A disclosure: I audio-booked this one. A second disclosure: the voice of said audiobook was Tom Hiddleston. What I'm trying to say is: I may have beenA disclosure: I audio-booked this one. A second disclosure: the voice of said audiobook was Tom Hiddleston. What I'm trying to say is: I may have been under the influence of his British accent and/or Loki fantasies as I listened to this commuting to and from work.Gardner tackles an interesting concept: France is about to erupt in revolution. In the middle of the unrest we peek in on the lives Yann and Tetu (gypsies who belong to a magic act and who have special abilities pertaining to "the threads of light"), Sido (the neglected daughter of an aristocrat), and Count Kallivoski (an at times cliche bad guy who has his hands deep in the lives of our characters). Gardner plays with the supernatural, love, adventure, and the historical significance of the times she chose. Here and there the story falls a little flat (Kallivoski can become tiresome with his constant threats, Sido can be a bit too damsel-in-distressy, and Yann's bravado can, at times, leave a sour taste). Even still, I do think "The Red Necklace" is a brave attempt to add some fantasy to an important time in history. I wouldn't recommend reading this one plain. Grab the audiobook and bask in all of the voices Hiddleston puts on for his listeners. ...more

title: The Pillars of the Earth        (Kingsbridge, #1)
author: Follett, Ken*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A book that spans over 50 years must lose the wind from it's sails, no? How could a book follow the progression of child to adult to aging elder withoA book that spans over 50 years must lose the wind from it's sails, no? How could a book follow the progression of child to adult to aging elder without contradicting the voice of the character or losing the interest of the reader?A book which covers the 12th century can't be too interesting, can it? People were basically living in hovels and hadn't grasped civilized society yet. And this book is 900 pages long? Count me out.That's what I thought when my Oma attempted to entice me into Follett's world several years ago. "Nah, Imma sunbathe outside on your dock, Oma. Thanks anyway!"Oh, what a dolt I was.Luckily, Oma is still around to point and laugh with a "told you so!" grin on her face because man, did I love this book.I mean, seriously. You've got monks and priors and kings and witches and peasants and nobles all crashing into one another in a mad scramble for power and peace during an incredibly tumultuous time in history. Every time a character gets comfortable? BOOM. Follett throws something else at 'em. It's fresh and interesting and on a topic few people write about. Architecture meets gods meets bloodlust meets a game of thrones?! What?! Why isn't THIS an HBO regular instead of a never talked about 2010 miniseries on Starz??Oh... right... dragons. BUT STILL! These characters have such humanity. The "heroes" all have their foils and the "evil" characters are twisted and complicated in sometimes uncomfortable ways. Power is a wobbly tower which no one can balance on for too long. This means that Follett gets to play out seemingly endless "what if..." scenarios each time someone topples. I mean, c'mon, the guy has 50 years of material here! He can knock the literary board over, pick up the pieces, and re-scatter them pellmell over and over. It feels natural, and it is done masterfully. Also, can we talk for a minute about dramatic irony? Nothing is more annoying than when Character A is all "oh I love so-and-so but they'll never notice me," and so-and-so is on the other end of the stage saying "Character A is such a dream boat... but I'll never tell!"Dramatic irony can be useful but in the above situation? It is infuriating.Kollett must feel the same way, because when he writes a love scene it reads as follows:"I feel this way and you should know that because it's the truth.""Well I feel this way, but I'm scared and I don't know and maybe we shouldn't touch.""Shut up and kiss me because life is too short."[INSERT MAKE OUT SESSION HERE]{Also insert Beth in the corner crying and yelling "BRAVA! ENCORE!" Because, seriously, we're all over the dramatic irony, especially in a 900+ page book. I ain't waiting for a payoff that long.}Yeah, sometimes the talk about buttresses got old, and for a book of such length the ending felt rather abrupt. And, yes, sometimes the filler before the big reveal was too much so I had to skim down to read the result, then double-back for the lead up. It may be cheating, but I've never been a patient person and, luckily, Kollett will never make you wait long. ...more

title: MaddAddam        (MaddAddam, #3)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm sad. I REALLY liked the first 2 books in this trilogy. "Oryx and Crake" gave us an insiders look into a very possible apocalypse. "The Year of theI'm sad. I REALLY liked the first 2 books in this trilogy. "Oryx and Crake" gave us an insiders look into a very possible apocalypse. "The Year of the Flood" gave us the perspectives of those out on the street when the (as the characters put it) chaos started. But the third book?The third book picks up where both the others left off. From there, the characters begin to make steps toward building up their lives and navigating the new landscape of the world. Well, they suck at it. All of the decisions the characters make almost made me face palm as I read. Also Jimmy, who was such a strong narrator in the first novel, was already broken from the close of the first and never recovered. That was vastly disappointing. The end of the novel felt rushed and, although it was supposed to be sad, I just felt sort of annoyed.As for the splicing in of the past? Atwood uses Toby as her primary narrator in this story (I won't tell you who ends up sharing those duties later on because, again, annoying). Toby works as a narrator; I enjoyed her backstory in the second installment. However, a large portion of the book involved Zeb telling her his back story. This felt forced and did not read nearly as well as if we had had flashbacks as was provided with literally every other character in the novel. The story kept getting interrupted by Toby's thoughts (and why? why did we need this?). Additionally, while parts of Zeb's story were necessary for the trilogy as a whole, some of these pops-into-the-past parts kind of droned on and I felt myself itching to get back to the present with the Painballers and Pigoons. I guess the first 2 books were full of adrenaline. As you read, you know that the end of the world is imminent, and you enjoy finding out who these people were before, and how it helps them out after. In the third book? There is nothing they're hurtling toward (with the exception of past Zeb who, as I previously explained, was longwinded and didn't hold my attention). While Atwood attempts to provide some tension and some final battle drama (the MaddAddamites do, after all, have predators lurking in the wilderness), nothing comes of those threats. I put the book down feeling underwhelmed and wishing the end of the second book had been an end of the series. There would have been unanswered questions, but I would have appreciated my own fill-in-the-blanks over this "conclusion."...more

title: An Everlasting Meal: Cooking with Economy and Grace
author: Adler, Tamar
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Every now and again you read a book that just feels... necessary. "An Everlasting Meal" is one of those books. Adler teaches us to love our lives, andEvery now and again you read a book that just feels... necessary. "An Everlasting Meal" is one of those books. Adler teaches us to love our lives, and find that love through food. She reminds us that it doesn't take anything fancy to make a delicious and nourishing meal. She provides tricks to make the most out of the food in your home, and provides anticipatory comfort for when things don't go the way you plan. Reading Adler was like having my grandmother next to me, providing advice on how to cook and how best to hide the cracks in my cake. I dog-eared the heck out of my copy and know I will be returning to these pages again and again for why I should save my pasta water and how even burned rice can be turned into a loved meal.If I have only 1 criticism it would be the flavors she suggests in this book. Almost every recipe calls for olive oil and parmesan. I wrote several notes in the margins reminding myself that there are other flavors out there besides traditional Italian, and that my palate deserves more than olive oil with a side of olive oil. Though perhaps that's just the point: that all you need is olive oil to make your meals and to make them well....more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Tartt has weaved an intoxicating plot for her readers: young boy stumbling through his "coming-of-age" years is struck with tragedy, bounced from homeTartt has weaved an intoxicating plot for her readers: young boy stumbling through his "coming-of-age" years is struck with tragedy, bounced from home to home, and tries to hold onto his romanticized past, quite literally, through the acquisition of the famous painting "The Goldfinch." Her love of adjectives, similes, and allegory do not feel clunky as one reads. Rather, she artfully dances through language as though she feels it with her whole body. Her stream-of-consciousness prose, her verbal paintings of NYC, the desert, and the heartbreak of childhood are all palatable. I ripped through the first 200 pages with a vigor and passion reserved only for the best.But then.Oh, but then.This novel gets caught up in how good it could have been. Tartt is aware of her talent; but her awareness begins to bleed through, causing a confusion in narrative and story.You know when you are looking at the Oscar line ups? You see an actor who underwent a severe physical transformation for their role, or a screenplay which deals with the hot controversial issues (homosexuality, race, incest), and you think to yourself "these people went with these transformations/themes not because they really felt the work, but because they knew it would get them the nod?"That's how this book ends up feeling.Tartt takes a beautiful, interesting, shattered boy and makes him a sad cliche. The drugs, the listlessness, the confusion... it all felt calculated. It was following a recipe for success, rather than allowing the character to grow naturally out of what was otherwise gut-wrenching prose. It's "Great Expectations" meets "White Oleander" and it is just tired. What's more, I'm not sure her evolving narration gels with the last 30 pages of the novel. The narration style makes sense until the ending: it begins a meandering and beautiful narration (with Theo as a child), then begins to unravel into stream of consciousness with Theo's drug abuse and general confusion as he hurtles through adulthood. But those last 30 pages switch to a philosophical history lesson that sounds out-of-body for the Theo narrator the reader has been with these past 700 pages. What is one to take away from this change? To establish the novel as a whole as a retrospective which Theo has just now written shatters an otherwise natural progression. Despite the attempt to reason this away with "oh yeah I've been keeping journals and that's how I know all of this," there is no way that his voice would change so dramatically from section to section. Are we expected to assume that Theo has grown up so much and has become so wise due to his experiences, that he is able to transcend his own voice to write this story for us? Doubtful, Donna Tartt. Had it not been for the ending, the stunning prose alone would have rendered this book a solid choice to recommend to others, and perhaps even re-read. But I cannot get over how jarred and cheated I felt at the end. Theo was a cracked and imperfect character from the outset. To write him as someone so wizened he deems it appropriate to teach us something; someone so removed from his experiences that he is not shackled by his own voice as he writes his memoir is, for lack of tact, bullshit. ...more

title: Oryx and Crake        (MaddAddam, #1)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh, Atwood, how do I quantify this novel? Atwood puts to paper so many things I've thought only in the darkest corners of my mind. She tackles the humOh, Atwood, how do I quantify this novel? Atwood puts to paper so many things I've thought only in the darkest corners of my mind. She tackles the human nonchalance regarding overpopulation, the widening chasm between the 99% v the 1%, and the corruption of big business - all in a span of ~400 pages and all through the eyes of one incredibly ordinary man.I've read "1984" and "Fahrenheit 451," but neither of these dystopias felt as imminent as Atwood's. Her critical view of the world and the people that control it plowed right through my gut and kept on going. But oh, Atwood, the ending. Once the disjointed timelines begin to catch up with one another the reader realizes there are really only 2 ways for the novel to conclude. One would require another 100 pages to explore, and the other would be sorely disappointing considering all we've been through with narrator Snowman.Can you guess which route Atwood took?The ending, of course, did not fully take away from the overall experience of this novel. I adored almost all of it, and recommend that anyone and everyone read it. That being said, couldn't we have had some sort of definitive close to Snowman's story? I understand that this book is a trilogy, so perhaps Atwood wanted "Oryx and Crake" to achieve epic cliff hanger status. Even still, it made me sad to come so far just to be left with a bunch of question marks in lieu of an actual ending. I may feel differently after reading the other 2 installments, but for now I sit, quizzical and slightly disappointed, with the finish of an otherwise beautiful novel....more

title: Catching Fire        (The Hunger Games, #2)
author: Collins, Suzanne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Middle installments of trilogies often suffer from filler. That is, they're the bridge between book 1, which set up the world, and book 3, which contaMiddle installments of trilogies often suffer from filler. That is, they're the bridge between book 1, which set up the world, and book 3, which contains the Ultimate Climax(tm) of the story. Catching Fire is my favorite book of the entire Hunger Games trilogy. We pick up a few months after the close of The Hunger Games. Katniss Everdeen has moved into the Victors Village with her mother and sister. Her relationships with SadFaceGale and Peeta Mellark are strained as she attempts to navigate what her life will be after competing in a fight-to-the-death reality television show. You know, after she forced The Capitol to crown not one but two victors for the first time in history. Our protagonist is a teenage girl, and Collins makes sure we don't forget that. She's confused and selfish and a little bit naive. As Katniss struggles to figure out who she is and what she wants, she has to contend with the expectations of an adoring public and the simmering possibility of a national uprising. You know, just normal girl things.Katniss is desperately trying to be the girl The Capitol wants her to be, and fails time and time again. Good for her, then, that she has Peeta. Calm, eloquent Peeta, who knows just what to say both in front of the cameras and to Katniss whether she's screaming herself awake from a nightmare or contemplating running off into the woods. This book is first-and-foremost about exploitation, oppression, violence, and how even the purported good guys manipulate pliable people for results. To package that with a love story is spoon-feed-y genius. It's that sprinkling of sugar on the medicine. I'm trying to avoid spoilers here, but here's what I can say: with such a strong first book, it was unclear how Collins could up the ante with her second installment. Well, she did. What's more - now that her world, Panem, is fully built in our minds, we can focus instead on making our main characters more deep and rich. Though Catching Fire has a lot of action, we are also graced with scenes focused on interpersonal relationships and Katniss' confusion as she becomes more open with the people around her.I also just want to gush about the character of Peeta. These books are all through the eyes of Katniss, and that's what makes the characterization of Peeta even more powerful. He's a boy completely in touch with his emotions and OK with it. He is comfortable being vulnerable and honest. He cares, he's free with his heart, he's hopeful, he's kind. These qualities don't make him weak. Peeta is clearly a strong and brave person.We don't get male characters like this. Suzanne Collins deserves a standing ovation for her dynamic male main character who subverts what popular books tell us men "should" be. Because, let's be real, all men should be more like Peeta Mellark.PS. If you are an audiobook person, I really can't overhype Tatiana Maslany reading these books. She's perfection....more

title: The Hunger Games        (The Hunger Games, #1)
author: Collins, Suzanne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's easy to write off The Hunger Games because it's categorized as YA, and because of the similar stories that came before it, most notably The Long It's easy to write off The Hunger Games because it's categorized as YA, and because of the similar stories that came before it, most notably The Long Walk and Battle Royale. Writing it off would be a huge mistake. The Hunger Games is incredibly clever. Our protagonist, Katniss Everdeen, is just 16yrs old as she walks us through her world her first-person narration. Katniss lives in some iteration of The United States, but after the ocean claimed swaths of land thanks to global warming... and after a failed revolution that resulted in a totalitarian government. The first person narration is brilliant; we're forced to puzzle things out alongside Katniss. She misinterprets things constantly. She's confused about the motivations of those around her, and about what she should do once she finds herself a competitor in The Hunger Games, a to-the-death reality television show. Katniss can be frustrating at times, but that's the point. She's a teenage girl thrust into an incredibly traumatizing situation that keeps gut-punching her. Her (re)actions to everything in The Games underscores the reality: she's a poor girl from a coal mining district, who has no idea how to be in a television show. She's clueless on how to present herself as anything but herself. And Katniss isn't exactly endearing. After the death of her father and her mother's subsequent catatonic depression, Katniss had to parent both herself and her little sister. This hardened her, made her suspicious of most people. She's not one to be open or vulnerable. It's protection, yes, but it also means everyone is arms length from her.That's what makes Katniss' counterpart, Peeta Mellark, such an effective character. Where Katniss flounders, Peeta breezes through. Where Katniss is offputting, Peeta is endearing. He's also shrew and calculating, acutely aware he's in a television show. He effectively plays the audience and the people around him to maximize survival. Survival for him? Or for Katniss? Katniss isn't sure, and since we only see Peeta through her eyes (remember, first person narration), we aren't immediately sure either. His silver-tongue, his charm... is it genuine? Or is it his biggest weapon against her? There can only be one victor of The Games, after all. As a stand-alone, The Hunger Games is a powerful commentary on poverty, exploitation, and how society can become numb to horror and violence. But The Hunger Games doesn't stand alone. It's a trilogy. And Suzanne Collins has only just begun. I've read the books and watched the movies a couple of times, but recently found out Tatiana Maslany narrated the audibooks. Since Tatiana Maslany is perfection, I decided I'd add another dimension to my Hunger Games experience. First text, then film, now audio. I'm not a big audiobook person. I generally find them boring, and the audiobooks I do listen to are usually memoirs because I find they're the most animated. Well, Maslany has made me a convert. She brings the characters to life.. I might just be relistening to these forever....more

title: Rabid: A Cultural History of the World's Most Diabolical Virus
author: Wasik, Bill*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had extremely high hopes for "Rabid." I find diseases fascinating... to the point where I sometimes wish I had studied biology. But that's just the I had extremely high hopes for "Rabid." I find diseases fascinating... to the point where I sometimes wish I had studied biology. But that's just the thing - I had hoped that "Rabid" would take me into the 'mind' of the virus - that I would be transported to the more molecular level where I would learn about why/how/when the virus does what it does and how. Instead, I was met with a whole chapter about werewolves and vampires (gag me) and probably ~20 pages detailing all the archaic ways people use to treat rabies (the first 3 examples were interesting, the next 79 bored the shit out of me). At the conclusion of this book I finally got a taste of what I had wanted: the authors delve into how the virus makes its way to the brain and what this means for the future of virus treatment as we know it. However, these 2 pages did not make up for the majority of the book which jumped around on a seemingly random basis to cover only marginally related themes.That being said, the book did what I think it wanted to: it discussed rabies in culture, from lore to recent breakouts in Bali and NYC. It discussed the human fear of the virus, the fictional isms of the virus, and the steps society has taken to prevent rabies from becoming again the monster it once was. For someone who wants to learn more about this the book will deliver in spades. I just wanted roughly 9345% more science. ...more

title: The Help
author: Stockett, Kathryn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Once upon a time there was a girl who was different. She had different thoughts and different dreams than those around her. After a while, the girl isOnce upon a time there was a girl who was different. She had different thoughts and different dreams than those around her. After a while, the girl is ostracized by her peers. However, she perseveres and sticks to her ideology, majority be damned. This isn't news to anybody. In fact, this plot is so-effing-boring.So what has Stockett written that diverges enough from a tired old formula to make it an engaging read? For one, the 3 different narratives. Minny, Abilieen, and Skeeter each provide their own unique perspectives and stories to the mix. Minny: the outraged and indignant; Abilieen: the quiet and kind; and Skeeter: the ugly duckling not-quiet-swan who toes the line between pursuing her own happiness and keeping those she cares about complacent. Stockett's excellent sense of humor and masterful character fleshing does a lot as well. By the end of the novel I cared deeply for all three of these fictional women.The bottom line is this: Stockett's topic is nothing new. We've seen civil rights books and female coming-of-age books roughly a bazillion times. However, Stockett's writing is fresh. She doesn't care for romantic subplots and instead aims straight for the heart of it... succeeding at every turn. ...more

title: The God Delusion
author: Dawkins, Richard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading Dawkins is like sitting down to a cozy group of like-minded intellectuals. Unlike other out-and-proud atheists, Dawkins does not stoop to condReading Dawkins is like sitting down to a cozy group of like-minded intellectuals. Unlike other out-and-proud atheists, Dawkins does not stoop to condescension and name calling (I'm looking at you Bill Maher, ya bully). Rather, Dawkins approaches his reader saying, "Now, don't be alarmed. I just wanted to tell you some facts. Don't you like facts?"His chapter-by-chapter breakdown takes the reader through religion: why it exists in the first place, what people use it for, and how it, more often than not, hurts the people who still buy into it.Dawkins is not perfect. His temper flares in his chapter on children and one can sense the lingering scars of a person who grew up steeped in the oppression that many religious childhoods inflicted. That being said, Dawkins is definitely worth the read. For anyone. title: The Night Eternal        (The Strain Trilogy, #3)
author: Toro, Guillermo del
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While the series as a whole ranked more of a 3-star word meal rather than a 4 or 5 star, I would still recommend the trilogy as a whole to anyone who While the series as a whole ranked more of a 3-star word meal rather than a 4 or 5 star, I would still recommend the trilogy as a whole to anyone who appreciates the horror genre.Here is why.Hogan and Del Toro are on to something really excellent in this series. Good v. Evil, biology v. the soul, weakness of the spirit v. the strength of a rebellion. All of the elements are there. The "join the dark side" Darth Vader theme that resonates throughout this third installment was riveting; as were the broken characters within it.Night Eternal opens 2 years after The Master has taken hold of the civilized world as we know it. Those few humans who remain, at the core, free, are cut off from each other, hopelessly wondering if they are the last out there... if the rest of the world has submitted to the Concentration Camp-esque reality that this particular apocalypse has taken. And that's what this really is: an apocalypse. How else would you explain the stripping away of existence as you know it and replacing it with something totally alien.At the heart we have the characters who had been fighting with us since the beginning: Eph, Nora, Fet, and Gus. Everyone is a little worse for the wear, and wondering when it will be time to throw in the towel. The hopeless desperation the reader feels as they dip into each of the main character's minds is excellently written and thoroughly engaging.Then why, you ask did I give it 3 stars? That answer is spoilers abound, and I fear giving too much away. That being said, I will give you a hint. There is nothing I want to read less than religious propaganda when getting my thrills on. Reading up on angels and the magnificence of them just, well, spoils my appetite for Hogan and Del Toro alike. They would have done much better to make the end a defeat/victory (I will not tell you which) for Man rather than higher beings. Because, seriously, who had been working for justice throughout the trilogy? Where was the God Hogan and Del Toro seem to revere in the past 1000 pages? Oh... nowhere?Exactly.The religious overtones in the final book just felt out of place in an otherwise excellent series.A note for the TV show that is pending? Shy away from your gods, and stick with the real stuff, would you?...more

title: The Secret Keeper
author: Morton, Kate*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Loving mystery novels is a curse. Sure, the first few times you're titillated and surprised, but soon it devolves into the following catch-22:1. BecauLoving mystery novels is a curse. Sure, the first few times you're titillated and surprised, but soon it devolves into the following catch-22:1. Because you've read so many mystery novels, you can't help but develop a theory early on. You decide almost immediately who the murder is/what the twist will be/who stole the painting/whatever. But it doesn't stop there. You become so attached to your theory that the actual, deviating ending is a disappointment. Even if it's a decent ending it's met with tirades of "they should have..." and "it would have been better if..." Friends and family alike will cover their ears and run screaming from this. Nobody cares and oftentimes your constructed alternate ending isn't even very good.2. The theory you've created is correct. But now you're peeved that the Big Reveal was so obvious that you were able to discern it from the first few chapters. You then subject friends and family to your smug monologues about how it was clear from page 12 that so-and-so did it. Ugh. Shut up.I was terrified this novel was going to fall into the latter. I weaved my theory early on and clung tight (jabbering incessantly to friends who rolled their eyes and tried to tune me out). Miraculously, about two thirds of the way through the novel my theory was blown apart. Though my hastily revised idea turned out to be the REAL twist, I was neither disappointed nor smug. This book is wonderful, superb, delightful... and any other synonym you've got.I want to gush, but I also don't want to give anything away. So here's the teaser I can muster:It's 1961 at the start of the novel. Laurel is 16 and sees something which forever fractures her views on her family and, particularly, her mother Dorothy. Fifty years later, Dorothy is suffering from dementia and dying. Stirred by her final chance to unearth the truth about what she saw, coupled with the discovery of a curious old photograph, Laurel embarks on a one-woman mission to make sense of the past.Masterfully split between present day Laurel and Blitz-era Dorothy, Morton explores all of the beautiful, complicated, devastating, and compromising iterations of family and of love. She can be funny even in the face of 1941 death and starvation. She can be tender, even when her characters are being despicable. Morton dives headfirst into the squirmier aspects of love, and emerges with prose to twist even the blackest of hearts.I loved it, and I wish it weren't over so I could go on reading forever. ...more

title: Then They Came for Me: A Family's Story of Love, Captivity, and Survival
author: Bahari, Maziar
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I give Bahari a lot of credit for his bravery. Writing this book meant potentially putting loved ones in danger. Reliving the time in prison must haveI give Bahari a lot of credit for his bravery. Writing this book meant potentially putting loved ones in danger. Reliving the time in prison must have been difficult, and one can feel the pain in his narration as he ruminates over how this has changed his feelings toward his country and his place in the world.That being said: I wanted more.Is that cold and callous of me? Have the years of vying for headshots in Xbox games ruined me? No, I don't think that's what is it.As I said before, one can feel Bahari's pain still fresh from being released. As such, I think it was extremely difficult for him to get into the fine details of his life in prison. Whenever he flirts with the true reality of his situation, the narrator reverts to speaking with the ghosts of his father and sister. Whenever he begins a session with Rosewater, he focuses not on the thoughts of his own mind, but rather pities the man who is torturing him. I get it, really I do. But I read this book in the hopes of having the survivor narrative revealed to me. Instead, this book represented a watered down and removed chronicle of prisons in Iran. It felt formal, it felt clouded, it felt removed.One can understand this as a defense mechanism, and of course I am not demanding that Bahari rip back open the wounds that have only just begun to scab. However, if he decided to take on the endeavor of such a difficult book, shouldn't he do all he can to illustrate, in painful detail, what is happening in Iran? So that we can do something to help? So that we know the absolute truth.At least, that's what I had hoped for. I suppose we'll just have to see what Mr. Stewart does with it. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: CS Lewis gives us the tale of Psyche and Cupid through the eyes of her older sister Orual. At least, that's what the back tells me. This story is moreCS Lewis gives us the tale of Psyche and Cupid through the eyes of her older sister Orual. At least, that's what the back tells me. This story is more about Orual with a touch of Psyche on the side. This is not to say that I didn't enjoy the novel. Lewis paints a painfully accurate and beautiful picture about those who use love to cause pain and control. However, he perhaps should have marketed his book differently. Orual makes for a volatile narrator. You are left to resolve her uncertainties as she brims with bias, anger, regret, and fear. Lewis harnesses the desperations and shortcomings of being a woman in power and I hung on every word.That being said, the reader could do with a lot more Psyche. And Cupid? If you weren't already familiar with the tale of Psyche you would not know that he enters the story at all. It's as though Lewis set out to write about the Greek myth, but became so distracted by the story potential in Orual that is original plan never took off. The bottoms line: If you Lewis' writing style and want something different than Narnia this is your bag. Lewis' story-telling chops are at their best in this novel despite the deceptive packaging. ...more

title: This Side of Paradise
author: Fitzgerald, F. Scott
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An author's first book always fascinates me. The desperation and fervor of the prose; the determination to mean something... I truly enjoy discoveringAn author's first book always fascinates me. The desperation and fervor of the prose; the determination to mean something... I truly enjoy discovering these as I read.Fitzgerald's novel has a bumpy past. The first draft was rejected so he returned to it, spliced it up, and added some more "unifying" portions. He also interjected part of a play he wrote during his Princeton days, and often breaks out into original poetry.Can you tell where I'm going with this?Fitzgerald is a new and inexperienced writer when this comes out. For me it reads very "look at me, look at me." That is, he wants to be a master at all things: poetry, play, prose, etc. etc. His partly-autobiographical character of Amory expresses this even more plainly than his disjointed plot. Amory toils in the gift/misery of a talented artist and wanders about the cities of America pontificating. Oh, woe is the educated man.Sarcasm aside, there is value in this novel. For one, if you treat "This Side of Paradise" as a collection of snapshots rather than one cohesive novel, the resulting effect is quite nice. Secondly, Fitzgerald speaks of a problem that all directionless college-grad's face: the "where do we go from here" madness of The Rest Of Your Life. Take, for instance, part of his closing sentiments:"Here was a new generation, shouting the old cries, learning the old creeds, through a reverie of long days and nights; destined to finally go out into that dirty grey turmoil to follow love and pride; a new generation dedicated more than the last to the fear of poverty and the worship of success; grown up to find all Gods dead, all wars fought, all faiths in man shaken..."That, my friends, is a universal truth....more
