review: Picturing Leonardo DiCaprio in the steamy portions of this book was a pretty welcome brain picture.That being said, this book falls into the "yeah... Picturing Leonardo DiCaprio in the steamy portions of this book was a pretty welcome brain picture.That being said, this book falls into the "yeah... so?" category of literature for me.The story is as follows: it is the mid-1950s. Everyone is still talking about Nazis and Communists. Teddy, a US Marshal, finds himself on Shutter Island investigating a missing patient from the psychiatric facility located on said Island. Through a series of codes, puzzles, and dream "revelations," Teddy finds himself falling further down the rabbit hole of delusion vs. reality.It's an interesting read, even if you've seen the movie (which pretty much everyone I know has).That being said: the writing is pretty mediocre. Sometimes with these sorts of books (pulpy, fast-paced, action-based more than prose-based), the lack of creative narration doesn’t matter. However, this books relies heavily upon dream sequences and flashbacks, thus making the actual literary portion of the novel tantamount to the novel’s success. I did not connect with Teddy on any level, and at times became confused due to the fractured and rambling and, really, subpar narration. Though the final 30 pages or so were great, they did not make up for the book as a whole. I wanted the suspense and fogginess of truth that comes with a detective novel, sure, but I wanted to actually be able to understand what I was reading while I was at it. ...more

title: A People’s History of the United States
author: Zinn, Howard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Zinn says it himself: this book is bias.I have a theory. I believe that Zinn took this book to his editors with a title along the line of "The 'Other'Zinn says it himself: this book is bias.I have a theory. I believe that Zinn took this book to his editors with a title along the line of "The 'Other's' History of America;" but his editors balked and made him change it to something more relatable... something LESS other. That being said, I really enjoyed this book. If we know anything about history it's that the past is written for the future by the victors. Zinn does not provide a well-rounded history. He does not provide a complete history. Zinn is offering his readers something they never received from school or from "conventional" history books: the perspective the 99%. Picking up this book means learning more about the Native Americans, slave culture, women, and the working class. It means punching capitalism in the gut and exposing the seedy truths that have otherwise been glossed over. Zinn is handing us this book as a supplement to the vast majority of literature on the past. He's saying "yes, America is great. But all great things rest on the shoulders of the oppressed. I give you the voices of those shoulders."They should teach this book to teach children that nothing is one-sided, that no nation is all powerful, that there are a sea of voices in the making of the USA. It's time to turn down the cacophony of rich white dudes and turn up the truths whispered by everyone else.If you couldn't tell... I want you to read this....more

title: Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail '72
author: Thompson, Hunter S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So first off: this book is important. Thompson captures a volatile time in history, both politically and socially. He covers McGovern v. Nixon well buSo first off: this book is important. Thompson captures a volatile time in history, both politically and socially. He covers McGovern v. Nixon well but, more importantly, he speaks to the layman's outlook on politics: the corruption, the greed, the confusion, the madness. In his drug and alcohol stupors, Thompson manages to be more honest about the American political process than anyone else. It begs the question: if it takes being that strung out to accurately describe our system, isn't it time we changed a thing or two?That being said, Thompson's descriptions often unravel into rants, and he jumps around a lot as new ideas strike him. It is obvious he was on drugs and reading it sober was daunting at times.For anyone into history, specifically political history, this book is a must-read. I consider this book part of the American canon not for the grace of the writing (it's more like driving on Route 66 these days: daunting and full of pot holes), but as a snapshot in what it was like to live and matter in 1972....more

title: Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies
author: Diamond, Jared
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When it comes to non-fiction I often finish the book and say to myself, "well, I'm glad that this exists, but that doesn't mean what I just read was gWhen it comes to non-fiction I often finish the book and say to myself, "well, I'm glad that this exists, but that doesn't mean what I just read was good."Diamond's book elicited that exact brain think.It's not that the material isn't interesting, because it is. Also Diamond is extremely intelligent and more than qualified to comment on the subject matter.That being said, everything laid out before us just felt like: "yeah... and?" I felt spoon-fed the most simple of concepts. Groups who were not inherently nomadic domesticated animals. Yeah duh. Those isolated from other cultures were not exposed to germs or technology the way others were. Again: duh.With such a compelling heading Diamond had the opportunity to dig deep. How did germs evolve? What do anthropologists believe about the cultural significance of guns and other, more advanced fire power? How does the past cast a shadow on our future and the technological advances we have taken it recent times? These were the types of questions I hoped Diamond would broach. Even if they weren't the most scientifically sound hypotheses... at least it would have been interesting. Instead I got the same 4 general concepts regurgitated roughly 25 different ways. Is it reductive to call this book a yawn-fest? Maybe, but I'm already dozing so there it is. yawn...more

Bonk focuses primarily on how sex research has evolved over the centuries. There is a little too much on pig and monkey detail for my taste, and some of the things I learned were downright gross. The main current underneath the cringing, however, is one of self-discovery and self-empowerment, especially for women (because caring about our pleasure is a pretty new thing, history-wise). If you're curious about how we got to Masters and Johnson (two people she focuses a lot on), or how everything "down there" works together - you're probably going to enjoy this book... even if you gag a little bit too (you see what I did there? Martin gets so bogged down with all of his characters that I forget what is going on with which character and who is dead and who is angry and... just... argghhh! Martin, get your shit together. Seriously. The first book was so dang good and I had hopes for the series as a whole but as the plot trudges along I begin to get that feeling that stirs when you're in a relationship for too long. You know what I'm talking about. You've been in it for so long that you can't imagine getting out but every time you're with that book/person you want to tear your hair out and/or set things on fire. I had to quit before it was over. Maybe, after a good, long break, I'll come back with renewed vigor. But for now Martin's exhaustingly extensive universe goes back on my shelf.ADDENDUMI wish I hadn't stopped reading when I did. Literally 50 pages after I gave up on this book it got super awesome. At least, this is what writers Terry Pratchett and Neil Gaiman advertise in the cult claThe apocalypse is upon us and you’ve been given a front seat. At least, this is what writers Terry Pratchett and Neil Gaiman advertise in the cult classic Good Omens. Devilishly funny and quick-witted, Good Omens chronicles eleven year old Adam Young, Anti-Christ, as he grows up, gets a pet dog, and slouches toward the end of the world.The novel opens with the birth and accidental misplacement of Adam. Originally intended to be raised in a Satanic household, Adam ultimately ends up living an ordinary life with an ordinary family; much to the ignorance of the powers that be. An angel/demon friendship seen in the characters of Aziraphale and Crowley rounds out the plot as the two contemplate thwarting the apocalypse after several centuries of comfortable earth living. They pay close attention to a boy they mistakenly believe to be the son of hell, and join dozens of characters in the mad dash to save humanity during its final days. Pratchett and Gaiman’s take on good vs. evil is truly a tantalizing read and eleven year old Adam Young’s descent into wickedness is both clever and chuckle-inducing. Each character, however fleeting, provides a fresh and entertaining take on all events leading up to the apocalypse. At times it is tempting to grab a notebook in order to keep the characters straight; but the important ones are fleshed out again and again to resolve any confusion. Pratchett and Gaiman’s tag-team lends itself to an engaging, though sometimes chaotic, plotline. While the novel is abounding with wit, the two writers are often forced to play catch up with the staggering number of characters they introduce; leaving parts of the novel a bit slow. Despite changes in pace, Good Omens is a laugh out loud journey that barrels toward the end of the world… and what lies beyond. If the apocalypse is this funny, one might not mind the thought of it....more

Does this make her a realist writer? Perhaps, but this does not mean that she's dull in the least. Her ability to weave devastating short stories astounds me. The ending of "Heaven-Hell" hit me like a brick.Every now and again Lahiri's prose gets clunky. I'm not sure why the ill-placed similes weren't eradicated by her editor, but these minor issues do not take away from the overall feel of the collection. The trilogy in the second part of Unaccustomed Earth? Wonderful.The simplicity of grief is the most profound thing to read. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Eugenides has a reputation to keep up. "Middlesex" is one of the best books I've ever read while "Virgin Suicides" is heartbreakingly wonderful. "The Eugenides has a reputation to keep up. "Middlesex" is one of the best books I've ever read while "Virgin Suicides" is heartbreakingly wonderful. "The Marriage Plot," for me at least, promised to be something spectacular. The story follows Madeline as she hurtles toward the big "now what" question of post graduation in the 80s. Here I am, straight out of graduate school while America is in a recession... it was as though the man were writing for me specifically.Maybe I had too much riding on Eugenides. Perhaps I shouldn't exult him as something more than he is. So Eugenides: I'm sorry.This book did nothing for me. Eugenides is attempting to make a commentary on Victorian literature, while making a commentary on religion, while making a commentary on depression/social diseases, while making commentary on women and the institution of marriage, all in the span of 400 pages with only 3 characters to work with. What I'm trying to say is: he tried too hard with too much and thus the entire book fell short.If he had taken one or two of his good ideas and really fleshed them out he would have had a winner on his hands. This is not the case. While Eugenides prose remain enticing, this book can easily be passed over for something more... well... complete....more

title: Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell
author: Clarke, Susanna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, here's the deal:Clarke can write. She knows how to squash words together into compelling sentences. If she were inept even at this I probably woulSo, here's the deal:Clarke can write. She knows how to squash words together into compelling sentences. If she were inept even at this I probably would not have finished reading the novel.You see, nothing ever happens in this book.The novel spans several years and follows 1. a demon/fairy, 2. Mr. Strange, 3. Mr. Norrell, and 4. a butler named Stephen with whom the demon/fairy is obsessed with. That is a lot of ground to cover in my opinion. As such, it should not have been difficult for Clarke to find interesting things to write about. A deal is made with a demon, fundamentals of magic are contradicted and argued over, and there is a supposed prophecy which is on the cusp of being fulfilled. You interested yet? So was I.Unfortunately, Clarke does not follow through with any of her plots. Not. One. Oh sure, she dances around them - she'll bring up these conflicts in order to keep her readers interested - but nothing comes of these otherwise fascinating outsets. Really, dude? Writing a book requires at least a conflict, a climax, and a resolution. Her conflict? Practically nonexistent. What she attempted to pawn off as a climax was a yawner, and the "resolution" actually kinda sorta contradicted the structures established from the beginning of the story. What I'm trying to say to you is this: don't bother. Don't do to yourself what I did. Go rewatch The Prestige and call it a day, folks....more

author: Erdrich, Louise
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are a couple of spoilers in this ... nothing that ruins the plot but even still, you have been warned.I'm on the fence between 3 and 4 staThere are a couple of spoilers in this ... nothing that ruins the plot but even still, you have been warned.I'm on the fence between 3 and 4 stars with this book. The only reason that I settled on the kinder of the two is because I am enamored with the character Pauline.What do we do with such a woman? She hides behind ideologies of piety and martyrdom but Pauline is, in fact, the most wicked character in the entire novel. I can't wrap my head around Erdrich's creation. Though Pauline has conformed to the ideals of the white man, she is a moral stain in the book. Even still... she views herself as something holy and worthy of the praise of god. Fascinating.The story is engaging, to be sure. Fleur is a wild woman of a character and Nanapush, despite the many penis jokes, is endearing and the sort of character you cannot help but look up to. If nothing else Erdrich has certainly created a cast we care about.That being said I can't help but wonder about the point of the novel. From time to time Erdrich brings in the harsh realities of being a Native American in the early 1900s. There is famine and death and that pesky western money... yet at the close of the novel we have Nanapush talking to Lulu and lingering on the ideas of marriage. Perhaps there is something I am missing at this close? For such a touchy subject I would expect the end to have more of a bang and less of the fizzle I encountered here. I was thoroughly engaged throughout the text, yes, but I wonder about Erdrich when she ends such a potentially powerful novel on the shoulders of a shallow little girl....more

title: A Mercy
author: Morrison, Toni
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've been learning for quite some time that the things I learned in history books aren't necessarily the truth of things. Morrison just pushed me overI've been learning for quite some time that the things I learned in history books aren't necessarily the truth of things. Morrison just pushed me over the edge with "A Mercy." Did you know that we used to enslave whites as well as black and native americans? Yeah. They were called indentured servants and they were treated just as poorly as the rest until a slave rebellion made the land owners think twice about grouping all these people together. Blows my mind.Morrison's book is about all the different types of slaves and how they interact with one another over the main character Florens. Whether you came from Africa or were sent for to wed or a white man who is different and therefore less than - you are represented in this book. Morrison not only gives us a history lesson, she begs us to see the humanity back in 1690 - how people were treated and how some things really haven't changed. The slavery isn't all just white men ruling over the Other - there are those who choose to be slaves (does that not make sense? Read this book and get back to me).Read this, read this, read this. It's a slight novel and it's jammed packed with literary goodness. I bow before Morrison and her heart-wrenching honesty. There aren't enough writers like her out there these day....more

title: The Gunslinger        (The Dark Tower, #1)
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm honestly shocked that The Gunslinger is retaining the 4-star rating I gave it back in 2011. When I re-read The Stand in 2020 it dropped in my regaI'm honestly shocked that The Gunslinger is retaining the 4-star rating I gave it back in 2011. When I re-read The Stand in 2020 it dropped in my regard by A LOT. Mostly because it suffers from King's lazy, accidental racism and sexism.And I think that's why The Gunslinger is still great: there are basically no women and/or POCs in the book. It's really just Roland, Mr. Gunslinger himself.Why do I love this book? Because it's a 200+ page description. King is not himself in these pages. He isn't relying heavily on plot and conversation. It's introspective. Roland is walking the desert, thinking back on the past, on regrets, on the fruitlessness of fighting destiny. We see flickers of his past, and how we arrived at the desert, and the long pursuit of The Man in Black. Essentially, The Gunslinger is the story of a man who follows a path that was set before him long ago. He walks it despite doubt, despite fear, despite anger. He follows it knowing he must. He follows it because, after you lose everything, what else is there to do?I don't know how I'll feel at the end of our journey to The Dark Tower, but The Gunslinger remains a fantastic book. ...more

I was hoping for more of an exploration on the anthropological aspect of eating meat but Foer focuses mostly on contemporary factory farming. He also seems a little biased to me (I, for one, think PETA is a radical book that shouldn't be commended for all that they do. Foer disagrees).That being said I enjoyed reading this book and Foer has me thinking about going full-blown vegan. Of course, I don't need much convincing being an on-again off-again vegetarian for almost a decade, but Foer says something that will stick with me a long time, that is: "if you can't stomach killing an animal then don't eat meat." It's a fair argument and a fairer book. I recommended it for meat and non-meat eaters alike. Just don't take everything he says literally. title: This Lullaby
author: Dessen, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I probably last read this book in ~2007. That said, re-reading this book now, so many years later, I could feel the echoes. I saw phrases I use regulaI probably last read this book in ~2007. That said, re-reading this book now, so many years later, I could feel the echoes. I saw phrases I use regularly in conversation now. What I'm saying is: I think I read this book many many times as a teenager. 10? More? I don't know. But, like some of my favorite Buffy episodes, I can repeat whole passages from memory.Remy and I were very similar people as teenagers: Closed off, skeptical of love, wearing our callouses on our sleeves. It's no wonder I basically memorized the book: I was craving a Dexter in my own life; someone who would prove to me that being vulnerable is worth it, that a life lived inwardly isn't fully lived. I am so grateful I grew out of that mentality, and hope Remy did the same. That said, this book smacks of early aughts in good ways... and also in VERY bad ways. Dexter, the love interest, comes on SO STRONG. She said no, dude. Leave her alone. When Remy talks to one of Dexter's friends about his pursuit of her:“Doesn’t matter,” he said, shrugging. “You’re officially a challenge. He’ll never give up now.” Ew. He smiled at this, stopping the window with his hand. “I’ll behave,” he said. “I promise.” And then, he started around the front of the car, as if I had said yes, grabbing the picture off my windshield and tucking it into his back pocket. The next thing I knew he was sliding in beside me, settling into the seat, the door swinging shut behind him.She. said. no. Get out of her car, like, what the fuck. The worst part about this book is the way Sarah Dessen has her protagonist describe losing her virginity. It sounds an awful lot like rape, and Dessen doesn't touch that with a 10ft pole, which felt wildly inappropriate. If you are going to introduce something like that, you've got to unpack it, otherwise you're just being irresponsible. But, like, that's so 2002, right? Did Dessen even think this scene constituted rape back then? Who the hell knows. Anyway, here's the whole scene, for those of you who are curious:(view spoiler)[That was the first night I ever got really drunk. It was a bad start with the cherry brandy, and an hour later I found myself making my way across Albert’s living room, clutching an easy chair for support. Everything was spinning, and I could see Lissa and Chloe and Jess sitting on a couch in the living room, where some girl was teaching them how to play quarters. The music was really loud, and someone had broken a vase in the foyer. It was blue, and the pieces were still scattered everywhere, strewn across the lime carpet. I remember thinking, in my blurry state, that it looked like sea glass.It was one of Albert’s friends, a really popular senior guy, who I bumped into on the stairs. He’d been flirting with me all night, pulling me into his lap while we played Asshole, and I’d liked it, felt vindicated, like it proved I wasn’t just some stupid sophomore. When he said we should hang out and talk, alone, I knew where we were going and why. Even then, I wasn’t new to this.We went into Albert’s bedroom and started kissing, there in the dark, as he fumbled for a light switch. Once he found it I could make out a Pink Floyd poster, stacks of CDs, Elle McPher son on the wall with December beneath her. He was easing me back, toward the bed, and then we were lying down, all so quick.I’d always prided myself on having the upper hand. I had my patented moves, the push offs and casual squirm, easily utilized to slow things down. But this time, they weren’t working. Every time I moved one of his hands another seemed to be on me, and it seemed like all my strength had seeped down to my toes. It didn’t help that I was so drunk that my balance was off, my equilibrium shot. And it had felt so good, for a while.God. The rest comes in bursts when I do reach that far back, always these crazy sharp details: how fast it was all happening, the way I kept coming in and out of it, one second vivid, the next lost. He was on me and everything was spinning and all I could feel was this weight, heavy, pushing me backward until I feel like Alice, being sucked into the rabbit hole. It was not how I wanted my first time to be.When it was over, I told him I felt sick and ran for the bathroom, locking the door with my hands shaking, unable at first to perform even that easiest of operations. Then I gripped the sink, gasping hard into it, my own breath coming back at me, amplified, rattling my ears. When I lifted my head up and looked in the mirror, it was her face I saw then. Drunk. Pale. Easy. And scared, unsteady, still gasping as she looked back at me, wondering what she had done. (hide spoiler)]Are we blaming the victim here? Like, Christ. This is so bad. So, so bad. Especially for a young woman to read, which is who this book is marketed toward. THE VERY NEXT SCENE after this flashback Remy gets drunk at a bar and this guy is chatting her up and asks her to leave with him (very much condensed for readability): “I’ll make sure you get home. Come on.” And then he put his hand on my arm, curling his fingers around my elbow.“Let go”“Don’t be like that”“I’m serious,” I told him, jerking my elbow. He held on. “Let go.”Then he started to tug me off my stool, which normally I would have made more difficult, but again, my balance wasn’t exactly right on just then. Before I knew it I was on my feet, then getting yanked through the crowd.“I said let go, you fucking asshole!” I pulled my arm loose, hard, and it flew up, smacking him in the face and sending him stumbling... One nasty remark from Chris and I’m bar trash, fighting in public with some guy named Sherman? I could feel the shame rising up in me, flushing my face. Everyone was looking at me.“Okay, okay, what’s going on here?” That was Adrian, the bouncer“Crazy bitch. She hit me.”I was standing there, rubbing my arm, hating myself. I knew if I turned around I’d see that girl again, so weak and screwed up. She’d go to the parking lot, no problem. After that night at the party, she’d gotten a reputation for it. I hated her for that. So much I could feel a lump rising in my throat, which I pressed down because I was better than that, much better. I wasn’t Lissa: I didn’t trot my pain out to show around. I kept it better hidden than anyone. I did.“God, this is swelling,” Sherman whined“You want me to call the police?” Adrian asked.“Either I call the cops or I don’t,” Adrian said. “But I got to get back to the door.”“Forget it,” Sherman told him. “I’m out of here.”“You.” Adrian pointed at me. “Go home. Now.”Again, to introduce this scene and not unpack it at all is so insanely irresponsible, and it's scary that I read all this at such an impressionable age. All of the characters, and arguably Dessen herself, seem to be blaming Remy in this scene. It feels so very she asked for it and, like I say, Dessen doesn't unpack these scenes, so how else are we supposed to feel?I had some experiences in college. A man following me out of the bar and trying to pull me in his direction. A man entering a closed off bedroom where he knew I was passed out, because he wanted to be in there with me passed out. Dessen: I did nothing wrong. I was allowed to talk to that man in the bar without sleeping with him. I was allowed to get drunk and choose to sleep in my friends room without fear. I didn't "deserve" these experiences, and neither did Remey, even in 2002, when women were, apparently, always at fault. Why the 3 stars, then? This feels like a stinker. Well, despite it all, I still see so much of me in Remy that I can't help but love her and, thus, like this book. Here are some quotes I actually like from this book, very much informed by my own adolescent experience:She takes on husbands the way other people change their hair color: out of boredom, listlessness, or just feeling that this next one will fix everything, once and for all.I’d powered through the last two years with my eyes on one thing, which was getting out. Getting gone... Just me and the future, finally together. Now there was a happy ending I could believe in.The conquest-getting me alone-was all that mattered, and once he saw me up close I wasn’t so special after all. But I, of course, knew that already.I didn’t show weakness: I didn’t depend on anyone. And if he’d been like the others, and just let me go, I would have been fine. It would have been easy to go on conveniently forgetting as I kept my heart clenched tight, away from where anyone could get to it.The past was so sticky, full of land mines: I made it a point, usually, not to be so detailed in the map of myself I handed over to a guy. And the song, that song, was one of the biggest keys to me. Like a soft spot, a bruise that never quite healed right. The first place I was sure they would strike back, when the time came for them to do so. BE BETTER DESSEN....more

title: The Tenant of Wildfell Hall
author: Brontë, Anne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Anne is officially my favorite Brontë.This book is pretty daring for the time. Anne laughs in the face of her male-controlled existence and proceeds tAnne is officially my favorite Brontë.This book is pretty daring for the time. Anne laughs in the face of her male-controlled existence and proceeds to write a book that mocks both male and female "values" that she undoubtedly had to suffer through. The characters gossip and lie and it becomes quite obvious Anne is lobbying for change, at least within upper class societal conventions. Every single person in her novel has an unsavory quality that comes from the ideologies and enforcements of gender roles.Anne strikes at Victorian England with her main character Helen - a woman with actual agency despite the obstacles in her way.Though Anne undoubtedly exaggerates and provides us with the very worst extremes at times, it cannot be denied that her book reads easily and that these extremes are necessary in order to get her point across. Hyperbole yields shock factor yields a (hopeful) shift in the treatment of women/marital relationships.This book is pretty much a must-read for anyone who cares about history. I can't believe this book eluded me for so long and I had to make due with her sisters' lesser novels until this point.Three cheers for Anne and her vision of a New Woman....more

His name was Abe Fortas. His argument was essentially that disobedience was acceptable only if it didn't go directly against the laws of the country.Another guy named Howard Zinn read it, got really pissed off, and wrote the book I am now ing.It's pretty much 124 pages of Abe Fortas getting bitch slapped.Zinn, though especially radical at times, does make some very compelling arguments such as: "how many lives does it take until a law becomes unjust," and "disobedience ensures the health of democracy." title: Sybil
author: Disraeli, Benjamin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Disraeli definitely had an agenda with this book. Yes, he was very political in his life so why wouldn’t we expect his novels to reflect that? The difDisraeli definitely had an agenda with this book. Yes, he was very political in his life so why wouldn’t we expect his novels to reflect that? The difficulty with him is the following:a)	He is trying to explain an entire movement in the Victorian period: the struggle for the rights of the working class. To encapsulate this in around 400 pages is extremely difficult to do. Thus, Disraeli introduces A LOT of characters that randomly show up one in every 20 chapters. Confusing? Fuck yes.b)	He has to deal with the structure of traditional story telling v. his hopes for the characters he has created. He thus has to compromise either his beliefs or the believability of his inventions.c)	He was kind of a dick in real life.That being said I did enjoy this book. Though I think Sybil is a hypocrite and Egremont should have quit being such a weenie, I appreciate what Disraeli attempted to do in writing this novel.Plus: Lord Marney is so deliciously evil I just want to cackle along with him :)...more

We start in a cemetery of forgotten books and journey forward into the line of fire as the reader is coaxed to figure out who is disappearing where and when and does the devil really exist? The main character's desperation to set things right, his persistent curiosity, and his boyish passions lend for a deep and rich character paired well with every other person Zafon created in his universe. I sighed outwardly at Zafon's manipulation of the written word and held tight for each twist and turn. review: It's winter break. Usually that means reading all the things I couldn't during the semester. Getting an MA in Literature, however, means that my vacatIt's winter break. Usually that means reading all the things I couldn't during the semester. Getting an MA in Literature, however, means that my vacations are full of TV and trashy magazines.My mother handed me this. Said she enjoyed it back in the day. I loved Judy Blume as a kid and figured what the hell, a little fluff for the end of winter break? Nothing wrong with that. Especially because I have to read "Heart of Darkness" yet again this spring.Anyway, the book was... okay. I know that is such a vague way to put it... but I don't know what else to say. The book has good moments: any girl who was mousy and shy in her youth had the popular, perfect friend they wanted to live up to. In that way I appreciated the book for its honesty about the unhealthy friendships women get themselves into. That being said, the book was a little too much of a downer when all was said and done. Other than the Bru/Catilin/Vix story lines I sort of skimmed through the rest because, as I've mentioned before, I hate having my heartstrings pulled too taut.I think I'll be sticking with the Blume classics such as "A Tale of the Fourth Grade Nothing," but at least this book teared me away from Buffy the Vampire Slayer for a couple of days....more

review: Is it just me or are you getting sick of books that talk about WWII. I know it's full of fictional potential but it's beginning to feel as though one Is it just me or are you getting sick of books that talk about WWII. I know it's full of fictional potential but it's beginning to feel as though one out of every three novels is dealing with the topic these days. Can't we choose a different war? Or no war at all? I'm beginning to get exasperated.That being said, Kogawa has written a very interesting book about the topic. From the eyes of the Japanese discriminated against in Canada, this book, for once, moves away from Nazis and Europe to give us a vastly different picture of what the war did to the world. Though some of her metaphors are clunky, Kogawa achieves a realistic portrait of what it was to be a Japanese-Canadian in the 1940's; proving to be not only a decent read but a bit of a history lesson for those unaware of the injustices done in an unexpected country....more

author: Beaumont, Francis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, after some critical reading and a debate or two I've come to a different conclusion about this play. Although to just simply sit down and read iOkay, after some critical reading and a debate or two I've come to a different conclusion about this play. Although to just simply sit down and read it can be daunting, to act it out is something completely different. Beaumont was a very intelligent man in that he played with the concepts of satire and parody that his audience wasn't ready for (explaining why this play wasn't well received in the beginning). The citizen and his wife, though frustrating at times, add certain elements to the play that are wonderfully original. The character Rafe is, by far, the best character in the play for all that he represents. And Humphrey! My God, Humphrey. The man only speaks in rhyme, which illutrates to the ridiculousness of the romantic genre and how it is "played out." All in all Beaumont was a critic of the very thing he worked in. It's a tough play to sell, but once you really crack down and read it the gems can be found. ...more

title: A Woman Killed with Kindness and Other Domestic Plays
author: Heywood, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let's talk a minute about how much the portrayal of women gets under my skin in dated literature. "A Woman Killed with Kindness" was first performed iLet's talk a minute about how much the portrayal of women gets under my skin in dated literature. "A Woman Killed with Kindness" was first performed in 1603, so I'm sure there are people out there who insist that I shouldn't be so peeved. "Women were subservient to men," the historically privy people roar, "deal with it! This play is simply reflecting the time it was written in." Well, I doubt African Americans enjoy reading Lit that debases their people; similarly I disregard Lit that debases mine.And oh, am I going to spoil the shit out of this play.Anne and Susan need to get the hell out of their lives, pronto. Anne rips herself apart for infidelity while the guy she cheated with (who had a creepily close relationship with her husband pre-coitus) runs off to see the world and one day return redeemed. Cause that's fair. MEANWHILE in a plot far far away Susan's brother convinces her to give up her virginity to square away a psychological debt he has to some guy named Francis. Francis, meanwhile, doesn't want her to be a whore because he's not an asshole (at least, not to Susan. He IS an asshole to his sister, Anne, saying he would murder her if he were in her husband's shoes).Structurally speaking, this play is confusing. Comedies stereotypically end in weddings, tragedies in death. This play has both. Tell me, how am I supposed to take that?Dear Heywood,I wish someone would bring you back to life just so I could punch you in the gut. Societal norms be damned, this play is stupid and rather cruel, even with full knowledge of its context....more

review: Atwood is honest; sometimes uncomfortably so. She is honest about women, their relationships with both other women and men. She is honest about the crAtwood is honest; sometimes uncomfortably so. She is honest about women, their relationships with both other women and men. She is honest about the cruelty of children, insanity, and the desperation of being in one's own head. This book is rumored to be partially autobiographical, and I believe it. Few people can write with such frankness about the uncomfortabilities of life, unless they're speaking from personal experience. Due to the closeness of the subject matter to living peoples, however, I find it awkward to critique. Suffice to say that I thank Atwood for writing this book, for making me feel better in my own skin. We all have a little voice inside our head, we all question the validity of our existence, and yet, we all deserve acceptance....more

review: Dude. That's the first word that comes to mind after having completed Marlowe's "Dr. Faustus." First of all, Marlowe is a sick character. Renouncing tDude. That's the first word that comes to mind after having completed Marlowe's "Dr. Faustus." First of all, Marlowe is a sick character. Renouncing the god his society accepted, writing a play about selling your soul to the devil; and the way he portrays Faustus! I mean, you're almost rooting for him to get his wishes and spoils regardless of his nefarious personality.The only thing that I can't help getting annoyed about is: who wrote it? I read both the A and B texts and (liking the A better), I find myself frustrated. Even in the A text there are things mentioned beyond Marlowe's time that he could not possibly have written originally. And the extended pope scene? Don't even get me started on that political pile of poop.All in all, this play is a wonderful mystery of a text, I only wish Marlowe hadn't been murdered so young....more

review: There are three different types of love stories out there:1. The quirky/awkward/funny type2. The gasping romantic type that can almost qualify as softThere are three different types of love stories out there:1. The quirky/awkward/funny type2. The gasping romantic type that can almost qualify as soft porn3. The tragic typeI am not a fan of love stories and thus only the first one appeals to me. My mother, on the other hand, is a sucker for "I'm going to try to make you cry for these sad, sad lovers" types, and thus thrust this book into my hands sniffling:"read it, it's like poetry."Now I'll admit, the book was under no means poorly written... it was just TOO much... you know? Everyone is sad and unhappy and they all have to get on the plane at the end of Casablanca (which has always annoyed the shit out of me!), and Waller is, in my humble opinion, trying way too hard.Also: the note the mother leaves for her children is nasty. Who, as their last message to their offspring, writes: "yeah, I had an affair. We had sex all over the house... probably where you're sitting right now."Blech.All in all I can see how those who enjoy the third category of love stories would devour this story; I am not one of them....more

title: Feed        (Newsflesh, #1)
author: Grant, Mira
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is old news, I know, but I love horror. Specifically, I love zombies. Problem is, I hate reading about zombies. It seems like everyone has their This is old news, I know, but I love horror. Specifically, I love zombies. Problem is, I hate reading about zombies. It seems like everyone has their own zombie definition and they all feel the need to thrust it upon me... and it takes 400 pages... and it's always mediocre at best.Not so with "Feed."Grant has a bold new take: why not write about zombies AFTER the initial infliction?? Not only that, but why not actually involve science. I loathe when horror authors go "because I said so, who cares, it's all sci-fi anyway" when it comes to the origins of viruses such as those addressed in the zombie sub-genre. It does get a little dry, at times, at the first 100 pages had me guessing: "now, do I like this book? Or don't I?" I decided yes, and thankfully kept on truckin' through the sometimes monotonous "main" plot of a presidential campaign. That being said, Grant blows me away with her originality PLUS (and spoilerspoilerspoilerSPOILER DON'T LOOK!) she changes first person narratives 3/4 in the book?! Genius! New! Different! Finally!I'll admit, I was more than wary going in. I'm a stickler for shitty horror books and it is obvious from the get-go that this book doesn't exactly blow your mind away in terms of diction. But man, the book was worth it. Perhaps not the best, but definitely entertaining and fresh for those as into bumps in the night as I am. Slight woman crush? Yes. Ashamed? Hell no....more

I mean, whatever, I went to a state school so a sorority seemed rather silly (if it's not furthering my career why bother and why pay for friends and- but wait, I'm getting carried away and far from this book now aren't I? Better close that parentheses.), but this book seemed to open the cellar door and let all the creepy, gross things that come along with being a "sister;" things I never want to experience.I believe Robbin is being honest and is trying to give an accurate representation but I just got kind of scared once I had finished the book.I give it 3 stars for the sole reason that 1. I read it quite some time ago and haven't picked it up since (which rings out to me as a warning sign that it wasn't amazing. C'mon! I haven't even touched touched the thing in 3 years) 2. title: Nightlight: A Parody
author: Harvard Lampoon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is undoubtedly funny.I have to admit that I probably didn't get enough out of it since I couldn't stomach finishing the actual "Twilight," bThis book is undoubtedly funny.I have to admit that I probably didn't get enough out of it since I couldn't stomach finishing the actual "Twilight," but the over-done descriptions, Bella Swan's clumsiness, and the all together awful writing of Stephenie Meyer are definitely present in spades. Belle Goose and Edwart Mullen are laughable caricatures of what Meyer fantasizes about every night (if you tell me Bella is not Meyer writing about herself you are wrong, sir. That entire series is one big pre-teen dream when you weren't asked out to the school dance), and Lampoon definitely hones in on the more ridiculous aspects of "Twilight," I could give you an example but I would suggest trying it on for size - 2 hours with the book and you'll have it finished.A note of caution, however: though I found myself laughing out loud on several occasions (a feat since I am wary of laughing in public when nothing amusing is happening around me. That whole looking crazy thing, you know?), the book IS a representation of "Twilight" and can get exhausting at times. Also, the ending sucks.Even so, the writers do a lot to assure everyone who face-palmed once they had read a chapter of "Twilight" that they are not alone, and that vampire obsessed, self-proclaimed "special" girls ('cause, like, I totally read books without pictures and don't get leggings as pants and so totally don't fit in which makes me such a babe) are babbling morons....more

review: It is an awkward task; critiquing something that is not a work of fiction. Luckily, Ali made it quite easy with her informative, horrific, and yes, evIt is an awkward task; critiquing something that is not a work of fiction. Luckily, Ali made it quite easy with her informative, horrific, and yes, even (sometimes) funny story. A must for anyone looking into the life of Muslim women, and a harrowing look into the climate of her time, Ali is not shy with the life she has led. I truly enjoyed every bit of this book but be warned: this book is not for those in love with superfluous adjectives or pretty language. Ali is frugal with her words, which adds to the gritty nature of her subject, but this style is not for everyone (though someone did stop me at the airport to let me know he loved the book).Recommendation: give it a try. If not out of genuine interest then out of a false one trying to play it off like you care about the rest of the world. You may surprise yourself with how engrossing a tale "Infidel" is....more

title: Twilight        (The Twilight Saga, #1)
author: Meyer, Stephenie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Here is the story of my interaction with "Twilight:"I had heard good things about Stephanie Meyer's Twilight series so, when I was helping a friend moHere is the story of my interaction with "Twilight:"I had heard good things about Stephanie Meyer's Twilight series so, when I was helping a friend move into her dorm summer 2007 and saw the books on her shelf, I asked what she thought of them. Now, I consider this girl my intellectual equal, just thought I would throw that out there because upon my asking she goes:"I don't want to talk about it.""Why?" I ask."Because," getting exasperated, "I have such a, like, deep connection with the characters and it's really bugging me that everyone else likes these books. These characters are mine, you know?"Uhhh... sure crazy.Anyway, a couple of months later I was in Barnes&Noble and picked up the first book. I skimmed a couple of pages, got bored, and put it away.Now this past winter (like, December 2009), I see the Twilight books on ANOTHER friend's shelf and say:"Dude, seriously, are those books any good at all?!"She laughs, tells me to see for myself, and tosses over the first one.Now I tried. I really tried. I sat down, read, got frustrated, paced the room, sat down again, slammed the book down, pulled at my hair, bit my nails, tried AGAIN, and finally gave up.Stephen King was right: Stephanie Meyer cannot write worth a darn.Her characters are flat, as is her scenery. Her writing style is elementary and littered with grammatical errors (someone should slap her editor, seriously), PLUS the plot itself was horrible. How is Bella likable to anyone at all? She is whiny and pathetic to the point that I could not put my brain through any more trauma and had to give up Twilight forever.Shame on all of you. Hang your heads in literary defeat if you like this book (and now, Beth, prepare to be beaten by team Edward & team Jacob teeny-boppers a like)... this book has no substance and no worth except to keep you warm if you've run out of wood for the fire place.I cannot believe popular culture sank this low....more

title: White Oleander
author: Fitch, Janet*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel has gotten buttloads of attention over the years. And I, an innocent twenty-something that knows nothing of good literature, must beg the qThis novel has gotten buttloads of attention over the years. And I, an innocent twenty-something that knows nothing of good literature, must beg the question: why? Why, you sheep people, have you followed the critical masses into adoring this book for its mediocrity and flashy language. Did you really dissect it? Look into the guts? Because, dear critic, I would assume if you did you would find something old and rotting underneath."But Beth!" you cry out, shocked and appalled, "you gave the book two stars! How could you write so cruelly about something that you obviously found a wee bit tasteful?"I'm so happy you asked!You see... this book reads like a relationship; in the beginning it's all beauty and glamour but, soon, you stop caring about your appearance and you've gained twenty pounds and you hate the person your with.That's how I feel about Janet Fitch.First off: can we gloss over how much this woman is in love with herself? I'm sorry, it shows through interviews, what I read of her, and even in "White Oleander." It's as though she's good, knows she's good, and loses her integrity for just that reason.If I could give the first half of the book a , I would cuddle up to it, hand it to my friends on a silver platter, and swear it could cure the common cold. The second half, however, is like herpes; it's annoying and it never ends. Thus it brings the quality of the book as a whole to a screeching halt, falling to two stars. Not enough to quit over (and, yes, I suppose I see how some people could really like the book) but enough to annoy me.I would really like to know if she wrote the book chronologically. You see, the beginning of the book read like a dream, I applauded her prose as well as her take on an otherwise used up subject (oh poor teenage girl has a hard life, foster homes, mommy doesn't love me blahblah gag). As the book went on, however, it drastically lost its flair and I found myself wading through the last hundred pages, wishing it would just be over already. It's as though she made her point to the public that she had talent and then got shockingly lazy after page 300. How can a woman so revered for her language get away with the simile:"It was a fear that could open its mouth and swallow me whole, like a hammerhead shark in five feet of water." (406)Excuse me, I have to throw up now....more

title: A New Religious America: How a "Christian Country" Has Become the World's Most Religiously Diverse Nation
author: Eck, Diana L.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think I have a huge woman-crush on Diana Eck. Sure she's 65, but the woman still looks good PLUS she is smart to boot. Enter this book.For my final I think I have a huge woman-crush on Diana Eck. Sure she's 65, but the woman still looks good PLUS she is smart to boot. Enter this book.For my final undergraduate semester I figured I'd take a religion class (religion fascinates me like car wrecks fascinate most of you), but I have to admit: most literature on the subject is boorriinngg.I mean, c'mon guys. Religion is the driving force for so much war, death, love, and charity, how did you manage to make it so dull? I found myself buried in texts for this class, crying out: "can't anyone write worth a damn about this subject?!"Eck, however, does a pretty good job of keeping the narrative going. Sure, she can fall into the type of diction only a professor lecturing has, but all in all I found myself enthralled with her explanation of the Other in America, and would recommend this book to anyone slightly interested in the subject....more

title: Under the Dome
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I can't decide what I think about this book. It didn't help when, upon handing me the book, my Oma announced: "I didn't like the end**spoiler alert** I can't decide what I think about this book. It didn't help when, upon handing me the book, my Oma announced: "I didn't like the ending." Immediately my mind started dissecting the book... looking for possible endings, trying to figure out where King was going with it all.Did I like it as a whole? Sure. Though a couple of his characters feel cliche by now (but the man has written at least 40 books so how could a few not be), I found myself huddled in the back of the lecture hall, reading this beast instead of paying attention. Plus Piper Libby, the agnostic pastor with the dangerous temper as well as Ollie, the farm boy whose entire family have killed themselves and left him alone in the world were wonderful, wonderful characters that I will not be forgetting soon.The ending, (and spoilers are indeed coming)however, troubles me.King has this deeper message that he's trying to convey, something that I never really expect from him. I don't know if he's getting sentimental as he ages but... aliens? Really? This is probably why I didn't like Dreamcatcher but aliens just don't do it for me. The whole book felt cheapened once it became extraterrestrial.I do like the idea of us being ants under a microscope, being tortured by children... but that last page and a half is still churning in my head. "They're wearing that gift that had been given to them... life." Ugh, cheese me out, man! I am unimpressed by the way he attempted to get his message across.Simply put: King had good intentions, but the ending? Eehh. I get it, King: do unto others and all that. The ones with the power stomp the meek and its time to turn the microscope back in on ourselves.But didn't you have to get so......contrived?...more

title: GI Jews: How World War II Changed a Generation
author: Moore, Deborah Dash
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I did not realize I was so ignorant about antisemitism until I had finished this book.Yes I know plenty about World War II, but the external and interI did not realize I was so ignorant about antisemitism until I had finished this book.Yes I know plenty about World War II, but the external and internal conflicts of the Jewish solider had never been conveyed to me as a terribly important part of the story.Though the book relies heavily on oral retellings and Moore goes as far as to interview her own father (showing a huge bias and thus making her seem less scholarly to me), the book does achieve a frank realism that had been missing from my knowledge of the war before.All in all the book was okay. I was distracted by the thought that the mind does exaggerate and change things as time passes (and the book was published in 2004), so all of these first hand stories could be a little, or severely, skewed,but the woman does try. And for that I thank her....more

title: Generation Kill: Devil Dogs, Iceman, Captain America, and the New Face of American War
author: Wright, Evan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One thing I want to make clear: I think this book is imporatant for Americans to pick up. You don't have to read the whole thing, but Wright is writinOne thing I want to make clear: I think this book is imporatant for Americans to pick up. You don't have to read the whole thing, but Wright is writing the facts as they were in 2003. He does not add literary flare, his does not shove his own political opnions down your throat, and he stays true to simple war facts.There are some difficulties with the novel: Wright wants to be so accurate he introduces us to a new character every 5 pages, which makes it rather confusing as to who is who. He also doesn't want to leave out any one instance, and doesn't want to condense for authenticities sake, thus you are stuck reading very similar situations over, and over, and over.Despite this I did enjoy the novel. It was a slow read, but every time I picked it up I enjoyed Wright's voice, and his ability to distance himself from the content. He isn't afraid to be honest, a rarity in Journalism and his epilogue is like a kick in the gut....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't decide what I think of Larsson. There are parts of this second installment when I'm completely into the story line, ignoring academia to find I can't decide what I think of Larsson. There are parts of this second installment when I'm completely into the story line, ignoring academia to find out what is going to happen with Mikael and Lisbeth next. Then there are times that Larsson gets drab for me. You see, Larsson is a lover of detail. The: "then she had two cups of coffee as she lounged in her new baby blue couch from IKEA" type of detail. Aka, waayyy too much for me. It gets in the way every now and again, you know? I don't care what the characters are having for breakfast, I care about who committed those fucking murders! It feels like filler and I want the go-go-go of the crime mystery genre.With that being said, I would give this book a rating of 3.5. Larsson knows how to engage his readers, and he loves to tease us (the whole time I was reading it I wanted to scream: JUST TELL ME WHAT "ALL THE EVIL" IS ALREADY BBAAHH), but every now and again he gets caught up in the mundane which, to me at least, is a pit-fall of an otherwise well written and fast paced novel....more

title: The Strain        (The Strain Trilogy, #1)
author: Toro, Guillermo del
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have never stayed up all night reading a book... I love sleep far too much. And though this book is no exception, it came pretty damn close.Del ToroI have never stayed up all night reading a book... I love sleep far too much. And though this book is no exception, it came pretty damn close.Del Toro and Hogan embrace the pace of Hollywood and somehow seamlessly weave it into novel form with "The Strain". Though a sucker for horror, I consider myself critical of the genre (having read so much of it, you see), and these two men deserve a standing ovation for what they put out. They provide explanations for the phenomenon driving "The Strain" (trust me it's a lot to ask when most writers are saying "dude, whatever, it's horror/sc-fi! Nothing needs to be defined.'), a compelling (and gleefully well-written) narrative, and talent with the pen that had me sleeping with the light on last night. With all the crap out there, it's nice to see some people still know what a captivating story is.I will admit they ripped off the third "Blade" movie ever-so-slightly but other than that the novel is surprisingly original. The 'main' character works for the CDC which was brilliant, if you're asking me, so the reader gets a deep look into the transformation from man to monster (but who is to say we weren't that far off to begin with?). PLUS the authors stalk around the 5 Boroughs, peeking through all sorts of windows, so you're getting a bird's eye view of the metamorphosis, with a broad spectrum of human reactions. ('But Beth!' you whine, 'all those POVs are confusing! I hate when authors do that!' Well suck it up. Seriously. It's not as confusing as it may seem, just take note of names and places, write it on a goddamn notepad if you have to... this book is worth flipping back through pages going: 'now who the hell is this again...?')I plan on sharing this novel with everyone around me, and that includes you, dear browsers of cyber-space: go read "The Strain." If you're a native New Yorker such as myself, though, you may be afraid to venture outside upon completion, so be prepared....more

title: The Call of the Wild
author: London, Jack
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ack, ick, gag, blech.That's what my brain was doing through the entirety of this slim novel.Dog is ripped from his home, forced into harsh conditions,Ack, ick, gag, blech.That's what my brain was doing through the entirety of this slim novel.Dog is ripped from his home, forced into harsh conditions, and struggles not only to survive, but thrive in his new life.All I wanted to do was cuddle the damn dog. When critiquing structure rather than prose, I am quick to jump on the bandwagon and pronounce this novel a crucial part of the literature canon. London is a master at internal dialogue, descriptions, conflict - his technique is flawless. I understand and support this novel remaining a required reading for students, for it teaches how to lay out a novel, how to not ramble, how to stay on point with the development of your characters and conflicts.....But that's it. That's all the milk I could squeeze out of this stone of a book.Because personally? If we're talking purely storyline?Ack, ick, gag, blech.It's too bloody, too savage, and just too dang sad for my personal preferences. I really disliked the story simply because I like dogs so much. I'm that asshole who gasps when the pet is inevitably murdered in the horror movie. I hate it - it's not for me. So London and I will never be best friends. Reading London was like watching an ice skater perform a beautiful routine, only to have him open his mouth and be incredibly racist and chauvinistic and pigheaded and disgusting. So: great technique - but did not give me butterflies and actually actively repulsed me at times. It's too bad, really, for Buck is a compelling "narrator" when throats aren't getting torn out. ...more

title: The House of Mirth
author: Wharton, Edith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is 2020 not depressing enough? Well, then, have I got a book for you!The Age of Innocence is one of my all-time favorite novels. But, surprisingly enoIs 2020 not depressing enough? Well, then, have I got a book for you!The Age of Innocence is one of my all-time favorite novels. But, surprisingly enough, I haven't read anything else by Edith Wharton. Looking to remedy that, I packed up The House of Mirth for my lakeside vacation (vacation?! In 2020?!). Yes, and I even have the negative COVID test to prove it.ANYWAY.In case you were wondering, The House of Mirth is decidedly NOT an appropriate vacation read.Lily Bart, the story's protagonist, is 29, and beginning to feel her age. Though she is as lovely as ever, she sees the door for a "good" marriage beginning to creak shut. Her father was financially ruined just after Lily "came out" in society, and Lily has lived under a domineering, stodgy-yet-wealthy aunt ever since, toggling between looking for a rich husband (what she "should" want) and trying to actually be happy in this life (what she, despite better reason, wants). Wharton cuts like a goddamn razor when it comes to the upper echelons of New York high society. The people floating around up there are fake, vapid, cruel, manipulative. While Lily doesn't fit in when it comes to the contents of her coffers, she is beautiful, and she comes from "good stock," so those claiming to be her friends take her along to parties and on grand vacations, simultaneously judging and talking about her, still unmarried, and conspicuously having friendships with married men (something that, were she to be married too, would not be an issue). Lily knows she should marry one of the several wealthy men circling her. However, all of them repulse her as much as their money allures her. To complicate matters further, it seems as though Lily might actually be falling in love... with the objectively NOT wealthy Lawrence Selden. Selden sees who she really is, and he still cares for her. Though he sees her beauty, it's not just her beauty that entices him. This excites her, and also terrifies her. To marry Selden is to give up on the finer things in life that she, despite herself, feels she needs.And that's where we get to the really depressing part of the book. You feel for Lily, you really do. She is trapped in a lesser position in society, simply because she was born Woman. Any attempts to try and secure wealth independently is met with either scorn or suspicion. The idea of marrying for love is laughable; Lily, like most women, is looking for the most financially secure suitor. That said, Wharton does a frustratingly fantastic job at painting the contradictions within Lily. She wishes she could move around in the financial world like the husbands of her friends. But, in the next breath, she verbally abuses the working women around her: cleaning women, laundresses, etc. While she is aware of her misfortunes, she is blissfully blind to the women around her who have it so much worse. Lily's forays into being a secretary, hat trimmer, etc., don't even endear her to the working women around her. Despite railing against the condition of being Woman at this time, any women "below" her are simply Other, and Lily is incapable of acknowledging the larger societal issues at play when it comes to the role of Woman. This crystallizes toward the end of the novel, when Lily is taken in by Nettie Struther, a poor woman that Lily once helped when she was volunteering with the only good character in the book, Evie. Lily is at her absolute lowest: living alone in a boarding house, sitting in the rain, realizing the futility of her situation. She is incapable of playing the cruel game her "friends" play, and so she has officially lost that game. Nettie takes Lily to her home, where she is warm and cozy and dry with her baby and her husband. Nettie has taken her "less-than" life, and has made something comfortable, albeit it plain. Lily is even repulsed by this. She cannot see Nettie's happiness; she only sees how small her home is, how much she lacks. Thus, reading this book, I absolutely hated Lily. I felt sorry for her still, yes, but I couldn't stand how, because of her social standing, Lily was incapable of broadening her frame. And that is Wharton's genius. She is able to use Lily as a magnifying glass into all that rot within high society. Yet, even though Lily is Other from that group, her desire to be among them makes her suck, too. It's a ladder of suck, and Lily is perched on a pretty high rung.In the struggle between who we actually are and what society wants us to be, it is possible to slip between the cracks of the two, and destroy yourself more completely than if you had just chosen. I need a drink just thinking about it, but commend Wharton for how she unfolded that for us in Lily.Brava. ...more

review: Catholicism, atheism, marriage, divorce, homosexuality, women's rights. These are hot button topics now, nevermind in 1945, looking back at the 1920s.Catholicism, atheism, marriage, divorce, homosexuality, women's rights. These are hot button topics now, nevermind in 1945, looking back at the 1920s. The story follows Charles Ryder as he begins university. A sheltered and impressionable boy, he cannot help but notice the magnetic if not somewhat eccentric Sebastian. Sebastian takes a shining to Charles, and the two become close friends and lovers for a spell, after which Charles remains somewhat tethered to Sebastian's family, and all the tragedy they represent.It's difficult to pick apart the book without spilling the beans on the entirety of the story. Suffice it to say that Waugh takes a beautiful look at how humans sacrifice happiness for what they are supposed to do, and how we grip onto the past even as it turns to dust in our fingers.My gripe with the story is that, while undoubtedly a breaker of ground in its time, it reads a little stale in the present day. I wasn't compelled to read, I did not have much sympathy or attachment to the characters, and I certainly wasn't sad when it was over. While there are one or two beautiful passages in this book, they are far eclipsed by boring recounts of what was eaten and drunk, and how the rich idled away their time. ...more

title: A Passage to India
author: Forster, E.M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Forster was incredibly brave for penning the book he did. "A Passage to India" is a novel which does not shy away from questions which are still tosseForster was incredibly brave for penning the book he did. "A Passage to India" is a novel which does not shy away from questions which are still tossed around almost one hundred years later: does god exist? What is racism? How is the justice system flawed and how can we fix it? Again, I commend him.There is a "circle of screaming" sort of mentality when it comes to racism in this novel. The British fear the Indian aristocrats, who fear the lower class, who fear the untouchables, who are so far removed as to be perceived as beautiful by the British and so on around-and-around. It's a "I am jealous of/fear this other person so let me lash out at whatever is directly below me." This general observation of society is startlingly acute even today.On the flip side of this story we have the troubling Woman and her fragile sexuality. The White Woman cries assault, and she is immediately taken at her word, despite her obvious uncertainty in herself. Forster paints Adela as an unreliable narrator from the start. In fact, everyone is unreliable in their own way within this novel. This may be frustrating for some, but I feel it is an accurate portrayal of human nature and as such it makes for a truly compelling story. If you could not tell from by my liberal use of adjectives: I adored this book. Even the heavy-handed extended metaphor which dragged on for the last ~40 pages of the novel. Screw it. Forster is one of the most daring authors I've encountered and he deserves a permanent place in the literary canon. ...more

title: A Room with a View
author: Forster, E.M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I try to read a "classic" novel a year. E.M. Forster has popped up a lot recently, so I thought cool, okay, let's try A Room with a View. The 3 stars I try to read a "classic" novel a year. E.M. Forster has popped up a lot recently, so I thought cool, okay, let's try A Room with a View. The 3 stars are mostly for George & his father. The rest of the book feels solidly 2 for me.The basic plot is: Lucy and her "cousin" (I'm putting that in quotations because her cousin is basically an old lady so... like... they ain't actually cousins?) travel Italy together so that Lucy, sheltered and naive and simple, can become a little more worldly. They meet some strange folks. They go home. Lucy becomes engaged to a twat. Some funny and some boring things happen. The pond scene was hilarious. The book concludes.I am perfectly aware that Forster is making commentary on the lives and the concerns and the frivolities of the upper ends of society. But I felt about this book like I feel about Jane Austen: I still had to read about all of those people living out their boring and stupid lives and having their boring and stupid conversations and I just didn't care about the pithy "moral" that they all need to get over themselves. I see that! I get that! Why do we have to read 10 paragraphs about the drapes?! God! Lucy, our protagonist, was not someone for whom I was rooting. Forster's narrative appears to be suggesting that women are "more" than men, but this book doesn't pass the Bechdel test, so that didn't exactly hit. George was fun to read, and Freddy was just stupid enough to be entertaining, and George's father was a cool lil dude. Everyone else in this book can go scratch. ...more

title: To the Lighthouse
author: Woolf, Virginia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A weaving, meandering narrative about the Ramsay family and friends, as seen on two separate days, many years apart from one another. It's a book wherA weaving, meandering narrative about the Ramsay family and friends, as seen on two separate days, many years apart from one another. It's a book where nothing really happens and, shockingly, I'm okay with this.Don't read Woolf for the plot, climax, conclusion formula of literature. Read her for the beautiful way she manipulates word; for the mastering of the English language. "To the Lighthouse" is split into three parts:Part IThe Ramsay's and co. are young. Some characters fret about marriage and the future, while others romp by the shore and others more worry about the choices they have made, and how it will reflect upon them when they are dead and gone. A jumping, stream-of-consciousness narration, where actual dialogue is few and far between. Instead, Woolf focuses on the innermost thoughts, desires, and fears of her characters. One could be peering into the mind of Mrs. Ramsay, only to have Minta walk by and, almost jarringly, we peer into Minta's head until she bumps into Mr. Banks and immediately hear his thoughts. It's as though you are a mosquito on the grounds, buzzing from one person to the other, getting close to their ear, and listening to the echoes of their minds.In short, it's incredible. Part IITakes place during the night. As everyone snuffs out their lights and prepares themselves for sleep, the reader is tucked into a time machine and prepares to jolt into the future. Though Mrs. Ramsay is checking on her youngest children before bed, the reader is clued into her fate. Children who will grow up and die in the war are painted as young boy and KIA solider in the same breath. The maid tidies up from the day, ruminating on the day's activities, and the events which will occur far off into the future. It's a psychedelic literary experience (don't think that's a thing? think again) to exist both in the present and the distant future of the characters, but Woolf is a natural and pulls it off with ease.Part IIIWe are officially in the future, following the surviving characters as some make their way to the lighthouse, and others stay on the grounds, thinking over their lives and losses.If the plot isn't enough to suck you in, I'd like you to hear from Woolf herself. Her insights into the human condition are poignant and heartbreaking and can you tell I'm in love?"...how life, from being made up of little separate incidents which one lived one by one, became curled and whole like a wave which bore one up and threw one down with it, there, with a dash on the beach.""The words seemed to be dropped into a well, where, if the waters were clear, they were also so extraordinarily distorting that, even as they descended, one saw them twisting about to make Heaven knows what pattern on the floor of the child’s mind.""For now she need not think about anybody. She could be herself, by herself. And that was what now she often felt the need of — to think; well, not even to think. To be silent; to be alone. All the being and the doing, expansive, glittering, vocal, evaporated; and one shrunk, with a sense of solemnity, to being oneself, a wedge-shaped core of darkness, something invisible to others.""If she had said half what he said, she would have blown her brains out by now.""What does one live for? Why, one asked oneself, does one take all these pains for the human race to go on? Is it so very desirable? Are we attractive as a species? Not so very, he thought...""...thinking again of Mrs. Ramsay on the beach; the cask bobbing up and down; and the pages flying. Why, after all these years had that survived, ringed round, lit up, visible to the last detail, with all before it blank and all after it blank, for miles and miles?"Excuse me, I have to go swoon now...more

title: The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao
author: Díaz, Junot
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Despite the flippant use of racial slurs and crude language, despite that infuriating use of footnotes in a work of fiction (who was the first person Despite the flippant use of racial slurs and crude language, despite that infuriating use of footnotes in a work of fiction (who was the first person who did that, making others think it's okay? I want to slap them), despite a weird and faceless narrator who did not feel necessary and who still, even at the end, did not seem qualified to know all he claims to know, I loved this book.It's weird.When I began reading The Brief Wondrous Life..., I had pretty low expectations. Diaz has a gruff way of writing; a forced street tongue which felt clunky coupled with a distracting amount of LOTR references. Okay, I thought. This isn't going to go very well.And I would have been right, if I didn't become so completely emotionally invested in Oscar.Now, full disclosure, my feelings about Oscar are swayed by my life experiences. Without blowing up anyone's spot, I know an Oscar (or, rather, I channeled someone I care about into Oscar), so everything he went through, all of the slights and disappointments and depression, hit me right in the ribs.Oscar isn't a character we as readers come across very often. He's not just socially awkward - he is nonsocial (note: NOT anti-social. Oscar would love to have friends and people who love him, he just can't find someone to share his life with, save his sister Lola). He tries and fails infinitely to make connections with the outside world and, with every failure, retreats further into a world of scribbled notebooks, sci-fi film, and fantasy novels.Even we as readers do not get a full picture of Oscar, as he is presented to us through the eyes of Yunior, a "friend" of Oscar's. (view spoiler)[But, dude, how the hell does he have the right to tell us about Oscar? A dick of a room mate who kept trying to make it with Oscar's sister? Then, when he finally did get Lola, he continued to cheat on her until she left him? Talk about an unreliable (and far removed!!) narrator. Ugh. (hide spoiler)] Yunior is an odd choice (and I'm being diplomatic there). However, yielding control of the story to him shrouds Oscar further in mystery, so we see him as an outsider would. He is the person you see in the hallway, but don't really acknowledge. He's the guy sitting a few seats down on the subway you don't make eye contact with. You are both intrigued and put-off by his lack of self-care, of the earnest in his eyes. I want to take Oscar out of the book and give him a hug.Outside of the character Oscar, The Brief Wondrous Life... provides its audience with a history and culture lesson which we as Americans never get in school. I know nothing about the DR - who was going to teach me? World Lit. focused on ancient Rome & Egypt... maybe there were some Huns sprinkled in there. Oh and don't forget all the Martin Luther babble because our country is still steeped in religion an-*ahem* - I'm sorry, I'm getting off topic.What I'm trying to say is, even if you don't feel for Oscar like I feel for Oscar, Diaz's ability to weave a compelling narrative around a stodgy history lesson is impressive. As an adult, I am only going to learn these things if they are hidden and wrapped prettily, like sneaking vegetables into a child's dessert. So thank you, Diaz, for feeding me my vegetables. And I encourage you, dear reader, to eat yours too. ...more
