review: How do you quantify a book that meant so very much to you in your childhood? Lyra, in my mind, is the heroine every little girl should encounter as soHow do you quantify a book that meant so very much to you in your childhood? Lyra, in my mind, is the heroine every little girl should encounter as soon as she is able to handle chapter books. Pullman challenges his youthful readers to question authority and convention as he rallies against religion and upholds science. And he packages all of this, beautifully, in a few fantasy novesl. Lyra's adventure comes to a head in this third and final installment of the "His Dark Materials" trilogy. All of the moving pieces (the clans of witches, the angels, Lord Asriel, Ms. Coulter, Mary Malone, The Church, The Dead... god I could go on) slam into each other in a final battle against destiny and the movement of the world. I had a distinct memory of finishing this book as a child and crying from the emotional weight of it all, but all the same I was surprised to find myself tearing up again, 15 years after my initial reading. Lyra's choices and losses were written so passionately it makes me suspicious that Pullman may have written a memoir here, and actually had fallen into a world of daemons and war and objects with incredible, magical properties (so, seriously Mr. Pullman, come clean. Are you Will? Cause, ya know, your secret is safe with me).Pullman urges his audience to remain curious and wild and ardent, to always question and never settle, to accept that grownups do not necessarily know more than their younger counterparts, and to never, ever, forget what it's like to believe in magic. A standing ovation, from both my 12 and 26 year old selves. Bravo, Mr. Pullman, these are my favorite books of all time. ...more

title: The Subtle Knife        (His Dark Materials, #2)
author: Pullman, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Slower than "Golden Compass" but no less wonderful, "The Subtle Knife" delves deeper into destiny, prophecies, and how deeply entwined the lives of WiSlower than "Golden Compass" but no less wonderful, "The Subtle Knife" delves deeper into destiny, prophecies, and how deeply entwined the lives of William and Lyra truly are. A very dark second installment, "The Subtle Knife" tackles mortality, deception, and growing up masterfully. Though at times it feels a little too grown up (seriously, Pullman? With the Daemon stroking already??), the author challenges his audience to think about science, religion, and the tenuous strands of reality and life itself. Am I gushing? I don't mean to - truly I don't! I am first to admit that this novel isn't nearly as compulsive as the first (all of the thinking and dull conversations in the air balloon, while necessary for plot clarity, most definitely drag). That being said, I truly and madly feel that all other YA series ain't got nothing on these. ...more

author: Levitt, Steven D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I debated about whether or not to give this book 4 stars and here is why I did what I did:1. Since their first book, Levitt and Dubner have become a lI debated about whether or not to give this book 4 stars and here is why I did what I did:1. Since their first book, Levitt and Dubner have become a lot more cock-sure in themselves. In the first book it was obvious they were writing it for information's sake whereas in this one, though for the most part enjoyable, they got almost... well... preachy. Although they remained true to keeping personal opinions out of the content, I found myself almost annoyed once or twice.2. Some parts of it did get a bit dull. They reiterate once or twice too many one some things while they simply glean over others (prostitutes v. monetary experiments on monkeys. Guess which one got more airtime).3. It wasn't readable with external interference. This might be a dick reason to give a book less than its due but if the television got switched on or there was a conversation between two people on the train I got distracted from the text at hand which proves to me it wasn't engaging enough.Even so, Levitt and Dubner bring up some fascinating points about doctors, global warming, and our primal instincts. I just wish they'd go back to their roots and become a little more humble....more

review: I am terribly upset.When I was 16 my boyfriend told me to read "Hitchhikers Guide." Having recently failed with "The Hobbit" I figured that, aside froI am terribly upset.When I was 16 my boyfriend told me to read "Hitchhikers Guide." Having recently failed with "The Hobbit" I figured that, aside from Star Wars, sci-fi was just not for me. On a whim over the summer I bought this thinking: "what the hell, what's the worst that could happen?"The first two books were outstanding. I read them in less than 24 hours and curled up in a corner during a party just to find out what would happen next.It was all down-hill from there.I read something about Adams that he was not a big fan of writing or literature in general and it definitely shows after the first two. It's as if he's trying to stick it to his editors and goes off on stupid tangents with ridiculous holes in both time and plot.The last book tried to redeem itself but (spoiler alert) introducing a kid?! Really? And her name is Random? Oh Adam, you have almost fallen to Stephanie Meyer status on that one with blatant stupidity.Basically I would highly recommend the first 2 books to any and all... even those who just "don't get" sci-fi. With the rest? Don't waste your time....more

title: The Blind Assassin
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You're going to need a good, strong hug after this novel because, dude, talk about sad.Here we go.The Blind Assassin is a novel told in four separate You're going to need a good, strong hug after this novel because, dude, talk about sad.Here we go.The Blind Assassin is a novel told in four separate parts:1. Little old lady Iris writing a memoir about her life and living in the present day (1999)2. The memoir itself, primarily focusing on the 1930s3. Newspaper "articles" filling in certain gaps4. The book The Blind Assassin, by Laura Chase (Iris' sister)Disjointed novels like this are totally up my alley. Using perspectives like newspaper articles and Laura's book were excellent devices to look at Iris' story at wholly different angles... especially when there are so many "mysteries" in the novel (we'll get to those quotation marks, and my lackluster three star rating, later). So here's what we know in the beginning: pretty much everyone Iris had any connection to is either dead, or torn away from her. It's sad. She's a lonely old woman in the winter of her life, reflecting on her past mistakes.Ouch.Driven by duty and what is expected of her, Iris systematically stomped on every chance at happiness when she was younger. Atwood, surprisingly, does not do a great job of fleshing out Iris' hopes and dreams. Instead, the core of Iris' character circles around being and doing what she assumes she is supposed to do, and cowering in a corner.My venom spitting aside, Atwood once again wows us with her lyrical prose, and I couldn't help but grab a pencil to underline particularly beautiful passages. However, at the end of the day The Blind Assassin is just so dang sad and tired that I closed the book and thought to myself "well, shit, I just feel bad now."If you want to know why, you'll have to be spoiled below!(view spoiler)[ First off, the twists in the novel can be seen from approximately 10,000 miles away. OF COURSE Laura didn't actually write The Blind Assassin. She was such an innocent idiot, she could never write something fueled with passion (though, to be fair Iris doesn't have enough flesh on her bones to seem capable either, but I digress). Secondly, OF COURSE Laura was actually pregnant, and OF COURSE it was Richard's baby. I never understood Atwood making Iris think "oh, it must have been Alex." I guess it's just to keep the reader guessing as to who the woman is in The Blind Assassin? But, c'mon, it's obvious Alex is in love with Iris, why the hell would he sleep with her sister??Lastly, The Blind Assassin has such a thinly veiled double meaning, I was just like "well, everyone should have just killed Iris and they all would have been happy." Because OF COURSE The Blind Assassin is actually Iris herself. Without Iris in the mix pretty much no one would have died. Her father would not have been driven into madness by Richard (because there would not have been a Richard), Laura would not have had such a strong emotional meltdown, and Alex would have run away long ago and would not have been caught in the war. SHE inadvertently killed everyone she loved. SHE is the blind assassin, and it's annoying.  (hide spoiler)]I guess The Blind Assassin is good for high school students to understand allegory and shit... but I just... it's just... no. ...more

I had picked up some from Jhumpa Lahiri (a wonderful writer, by the way), but that whole Touchable/Untouchable thing was lost on me. I beg this a lot but: read it slowly, savor the diction Roy has to offer, there is so much to find in the simple fragment: "Awake. Alert. title: The Zombie Survival Guide: Complete Protection from the Living Dead
author: Brooks, Max*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Entertaining? Yes. Worth it? Well...Let's chat a little bit about zombies. I was a kid when I watched Evil Dead and I have had a deep affection for thEntertaining? Yes. Worth it? Well...Let's chat a little bit about zombies. I was a kid when I watched Evil Dead and I have had a deep affection for that sub-genre of horror ever since. That being said I am very, very picky about my zombie literature. Max Brooks pisses me off because a lot of his claims are not classical zombie, but rather is own take, and it bothers me. I don't want someone to teach me about zombies as though I don't know what they are. I understand that it probably made sense to both him and his editor that he give background for his audience, but I felt a little offended at times. My copy is annotated complete with cross-outs, disagreements, and amendments. I would not say that Brooks did not do well in his attempt, it's obvious he's a zombie junkie not unlike me. But, because of this junkie status, I figured the book would be a conversation between two people battling out a zombie apocalypse instead of a novel chock full of fake history and lectures....more

title: The Omnivore's Dilemma: A Natural History of Four Meals
author: Pollan, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ugh. I so missed the train on this one.Had I read Omnivore's Dilemma when it first appeared on my book shelf (2008? 2009?), it would probably still beUgh. I so missed the train on this one.Had I read Omnivore's Dilemma when it first appeared on my book shelf (2008? 2009?), it would probably still be relevant. As it stands, however, Pollan is speaking to a 2006 audience, which is vastly different from 2015. These days CSAs abound, we are moving away from corn syrup, and Farmers Markets are booming. Was this in direct relation to Pollan's book? Probably not. But he did bring up a lot of important issues that definitely provide a frame of how far we've come in the past 10 years.Pollan's book is important because it is a snapshot of our culture and of our relationship with food. As a vegetarian myself, some portions of the book were a little rough to read (I know all about those chicken farms, which is why I haven't eaten chicken in 10+ years); but I powered through to get to the message underneath that gore. Pollan gets a little preachy at times - and definitely views himself as on a higher moral plane than his readers. But maybe he deserves to feel a little superior. In 2006, the majority of consumers weren't thinking about where their food was coming from, or how the life the food came from was treated. And, it does stand to question, why we would put so little thought into something so vital to our lives. Read The Omnviore's Dilemma as a cultural history book, and read it if you don't often think of your food. You might be surprised... and you may even be changed. ...more

title: On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My thing right now is to read books I read way back in the day. I didn't remember much about this one - my Oma purchased it for me when in came out inMy thing right now is to read books I read way back in the day. I didn't remember much about this one - my Oma purchased it for me when in came out in paperback form so I was all of... 13? years old when it came out? It sounds like King's publishers wanted him to provide an introspective "how-to" for his audience. Even 20 years ago he was already quite the prolific author... sounds like an easy cash grab, eh?King acknowledges fully that there is no guide map to being a writer. What works for him didn't work for Hemingway or Woolf or DeMille or any other popular novelists. But, you're reading this book, so here's what works for him. The funniest thing about this book is his statement that he very rarely knows where his books are going plot wise. Instead, a character or a scene or a question pops into his head, and he sits down and tries to see where that snippet will take him. If you, like me, have read a lot of Stephen King, this makes SO MUCH SENSE. So many King books start off strong and then go off the rails by the end. Even beloved books like IT go haywire, while books like Under the Dome and The Outsider unravel about 2/3 of the way through. If I remember correctly, I think his youngest Owen King actually suggested the ending for Under the Dome. Which makes sense, because it suuuccckkksss.While this book is primarily about how he writes/how to write, the first section of this book is all memoir, and King had quite the childhood. A bit of neglect, a bit of abuse, and a whole lot of imagination. It's not surprising that King became a writer, but it's impressive that he kept with it even while he and partner Tabitha were struggling in the late 60s/early 70s. If you have any interest in King the man, then this book is 100% for you.The real kicker of this book is that King was halfway through writing it when he was hit by that car in 1999. King recounts the whole ordeal in this book and holy hell is he lucky he didn't die. I am very familiar with that area of Maine: my Oma lives there. When she had a heart attack a water helicopter had to land on the lake and rush her to the hospital. When my Opa died there it took over an hour for someone to come and take his body away. It's a beautiful area... but it's remote as hell. Three cheers for the medical staff who attended to King and saved his life.The extra extra kicker is this little bitty footnote at the end of one page. King is talking about how Bryan Smith, the man who struck Stephen King with his car, was given a relatively light sentence for almost killing a man. After detailing how Smith could be on the road as early as 2001, he asterixes down to a footnote that says Bryan Smith was found dead at his trailer home shortly before this book went to print, 1 year after the accident... on Stephen King's birthday.There was no sign of trauma or indication that he had died in pain. The empty bottles of painkillers found nearby were the only indication of probable cause.  The Guardian, Oct 1, 2000This article and others like it go on to say that a toxology report would take months to come back. Some basic Googling fails to show any follow-up on the matter, except a quick line in 2010 NPR interview with King himself: "A toxicology test indicated he died of an accidental overdose, a combination of medication and alcohol."...So we're left with a question: who killed Bryan Smith? Himself? Or...?Post Script:Excerpt from a Cracked.com "article" (remember that place on the internet?)Smith -- a drug user with 11 prior driving offenses -- was rushing to get some "Marzes bars" from the store... Smith thought he'd hit a deer at first, but then he noticed a pair of bloodied glasses on his passenger seat... King's first act of revenge was to buy the minivan that almost killed him for 1,500 dollars so he could beat the shit out of it with a sledgehammer, because that's the sort of therapy you can have when you're rich. Then things got creepier... Smashing his tormentor's van with a sledgehammer and seeing Smith's physical and mental departure from this plane of existence wasn't enough for King, who had to make sure Smith lived on in infamy. His Dark Tower series is like 11 Bibles long and difficult to explain, but in it you'll find a character who has a Rottweiler named Bullet, drives a blue minivan, and is generally an all-around mouth-breather. He's an irresponsible, mentally deficient drug addict, and his name is -- cue gasp of surprise -- Bryan Smith. Smith is looking to score some drugs when he hops in his van, and almost strikes a fictionalized King, who's saved by the sacrifice of hero Jake Chambers... King's passive-aggressive jab was written years after Smith's death and served as the ultimate cherry on top of his rage sundae. Thanks to King's ceaseless anger, Bryan Smith is immortalized as a drug-addled asshat who damn near kills a beloved character, because in horror, even death can't spare you from revenge. By the by, Stephen King didn't buy and/or smash the car - it was cubed (I learned this from that same 2010 NPR interview. And, honestly, I don't blame him for his anger. Dude almost died... like... c'mon. ...more

title: Carrie

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I remember reading this book so distinctly, even though it was so long ago. It was the summer between middle school and high school and I would go outI remember reading this book so distinctly, even though it was so long ago. It was the summer between middle school and high school and I would go out on our driveway to sunbathe, this book under my arm. I remember stopping mid-sentence to flag down the ice cream man (for a screwball and candy cigarettes, of course) and realizing, even at 14, how morbidly contrasting my confectionery tastes and this horrifying book were.Carrie is Stephen King's stunning break out onto the literary scene, and the second King book I ever read. Watching a shy, confused, and tormented young girl go from quiet to enraged mass-murderer was astoundingly original and totally awesome.I'm still scared of Carrie, and it's been years since I've either read or watched her.This is one of those books that leaves a lasting impression. title: The Stand
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh how the mighty have fallen.I thought re-reading books I had given 5 stars to and hadn't read since I was a teenager was a good idea.Big mistake. HuOh how the mighty have fallen.I thought re-reading books I had given 5 stars to and hadn't read since I was a teenager was a good idea.Big mistake. Huge.I remember thinking The Stand was one of the best books I'd ever read.Best?! Really?! If this is what I thought best was in ~2005 I shudder to think about what books I was reading back then. In The Stand, a super flu wipes out most of the human race. Survivors in the United States begin to band together behind two forces: a kindly, holy, old woman, and arguably the devil himself. It's a good v. evil epic, and was especially interesting to read as we passed over the 1yr mark of our own super flu pandemic. I've got a couple hundred pages left of this 1141 page 1990 reboot, but, let me tell you: the racist and sexist language in here is crazy bananas. Do I think King is a racist and/or sexist? No, I do not. But reading this book was flat out painful at times for its lack of self-awareness. One could argue it is a victim of its time, having originally been published in 1978. But, no. I've read books a hundred years older than this one that didn't hit me upside the head will all this fucked-up-ppery. Was King intentionally make me uncomfortable with the racism and sexism? Taking it head-on instead of dancing around it or utterly ignoring the race/sex problem like those very aged books I just vaguely mentioned? I mean, maybe? But he did a clumsy ass job of it. Also, it's not just the characters that dabble in racist/sexist language... the narrative itself is guilty of those crimes. And what good is that, I wonder? Here are only 2 of passages I marked:There were plenty of Occidental executives, but enough of them were Japanese to make him feel, at six-feet-two, like a very tall horse's ass. The small men and women with the upslanted eyes look at his caked forehead and bloody jacket sleeve with unsettling Oriental blandness....Whoa Her fever had given her a rose, girlish glow that went jarringly with her bereavement. Perhaps the minister had been afraid she was going to make a pass at him.Bitch is actively dying. Are you kidding me with this?This doesn't even scratch the surface. I'm not going to bog us down by including all of the horrible language surrounding the mentally handicapped or African Americans. Nor will we dive into the scene where, right after a bunch of women who have been serially raped are saved, more than one of the main (male) characters thinks about sleeping with the more attractive women of the group. Fucking yikes. Here is a really fantastic article: https://level.medium.com/stephen-king...We'll see how the last couple hundred pages alter my new star rating, if they do at all.UPDATE: The last couple hundred pages did not jettison this book into the 4-star category, however, there were some lines I really liked:You didn't have to give cops guns until the cops couldn't remember the names... the faces...andDear children, the toys are death - they're flashburns and radiation sickness and black, choking plague. These toys are dangerous; the devil in men's brains guided the hands of God when they were made. Don't play with these toys, dear children, please, not ever. Not ever again. Please... please learn the lesson. Let this empty world be your copybook.Feels pretty effin' relevant, eh? ...more

title: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
author: Eggers, Dave
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The general public seems to have a hard on for Eggers. They herald him a genius, a beacon of light in a sea of crap. I'm going to let you in on a secrThe general public seems to have a hard on for Eggers. They herald him a genius, a beacon of light in a sea of crap. I'm going to let you in on a secret: I don't see it. At all. One of the themes seems to be that Eggers is "owed" something from the sad experiences in his life. I think we're owed to be able to hear about something different through the 400+ pages he vomited up.And the title. Oh dear god the title. The title is actually what took me so long to read it. But a (soon to be ex)friend said to me: "c'mon, Beth. If the title is that pretentious it has got to be good. What editor would allow it?"Klosterman and Eggers should have a duel. A who is more in love with themselves duel. I'm not sure who will win.Oh and the ENDING. Jesus Christ! The ending alone knocks this book down from two to one star. It's just a not-quite-stream-of-consciousness littered with profanities. It actually annoyed me as I was reading it. I know you folk often judge him for his minimalist tendencies, but I hold him up for that fact.I remember reading "Hills Like White Elephants" in high school and being blown away.I remember hearing about him and his friend making a bet about whether he could write a story in 10 words or less. He won with: "Baby shoes. For sale. Never been worn."If you read "The Sun Also Rises" or "For Whom the Bell Tolls" and found it lacking, why not try his shorter stuff on for size? Jessica Darling's high school experience very much mirrors my own. From the late night runs to the insomnia to the love life... reading it so many years after high school is nostalgia to the max. That said, I'm not sure it would be very good for someone reading it for the first time. You see: it's got some HUGE problems that relate directly to when it was written. Some of the language is almost unreadable, but it was utterly commonplace in 2000, when this book takes place. I don't believe this just because she had almost no romantic experience in her lifetime, or that she shared a bed with her sister. Instead, I base this on the "eehh" factor of every single book she writes.Please.What's so great about Elizabeth? She shows a shred of independence but we all see that it can easily be stomped out. title: The Golden Compass        (His Dark Materials, #1)
author: Pullman, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this book as a child and fell in love with Lyra, Iorek, and the world they lived in.The idea of re-reading this trilogy as an adult was emotionI read this book as a child and fell in love with Lyra, Iorek, and the world they lived in.The idea of re-reading this trilogy as an adult was emotional. What if the tropes and story did not stack up to the memories I have coddled and treasured over the past 10+ years? What if Pullman actually reads like Stephanie Meyer? Turns out I had nothing to worry about."The Golden Compass" holds up in adulthood as few YA books do. An epic on the same level as Harry Potter, Lord of the Rings, and The Lion, The Witch, and the Wardrobe; the His Dark Materials trilogy is an incredible undertaking of science vs. religion, child vs. adult, and age vs. wisdom. Lyra, a girl of only 11, is thrown into a complex destiny plot, unwittingly charged with an adventure which will decide the course of every world's future, and of destiny itself. From playing on rooftops to bargaining with bear kings, Lyra's story is a journey not only through worlds, but from child to adulthood. I still white-knuckled through Lyra's trek from Jordan College, to the Seas, to The Great, Wide, North, despite knowing (albeit dimly) where she would end up at the close of this first installment. Pullman writes Lyra as that tomboy youth that everyone either knew, or embodied when they were young. The innocence, arrogance, and curiosity of this cusp-of-puberty Bildungsroman is utter perfection. I only wish I had revisited Lyra sooner. ...more
